abstract: As truck drivers are forced to adapt to increasing difficulties on the road, the support system that serves them is at risk of disappearing.
lead_paragraph: The Petro Travel Center on Interstate 10 in Ontario, Calif., is one of scores across the country. At the front of the building are the things road trippers see when they stop for gas or snacks: a convenience store, restrooms and some dining options.

headline: A Memoir of Friendship and Death in a Vacation Idyll
abstract: Charles McGrath’s “The Summer Friend” recounts happy days and the gut punch of an untimely death.
lead_paragraph: THE SUMMER FRIENDA MemoirBy Charles McGrath

headline: An Engaged Woman Sees the Ghosts of Relationships Past
abstract: In her second novel, “Cult Classic,” Sloane Crosley brings an essayist’s eye for detail to the plight of seeking love.
lead_paragraph: Of the several common New York nightmares I’m afraid of — like tripping down the subway stairs, being touched on my bare skin by a rat or sweating so hard in the summer that my eyeliner ends up on my chest — running into an ex is high on my list. It is a unique kind of horror story, one that oddly promises a juicy little thrill, but a horror all the same. Just because something’s titillating and a little bit exciting and holds the promise of something illicit and fulfilling doesn’t mean it isn’t terrifying.

headline: Reporting Home Covid Test Results Can Be Confusing. Here’s How to Do It.
abstract: In many places, there is no system for sharing home test results with health officials, but the information may still be beneficial for public health.
lead_paragraph: So, you got a positive result on your home test for Covid-19. What do you do next? In addition to everything else on your plate — isolating and notifying close contacts, taking time off work and rescheduling appointments — it’s good practice to report your test results.

headline: In Small-Town Maine, Things Are More Sinister Than They Seem
abstract: Adam White’s debut novel, “The Midcoast,” takes readers to Damariscotta, where a native son becomes obsessed with a lobsterman’s fortune.
lead_paragraph: Place, like class, is often understood by Americans to be a temporary state of affairs on the way to something — or somewhere — better. This rootlessness, this faith in mobility, has found its way into many contemporary books, wherein the settings are more like painted backdrops, inert and somewhat arbitrary. But there’s an older, perennial instinct in American literature to claim a place as one’s own, to study it minutely and evoke its ultimate mystery. It’s this instinct that’s on full display in Adam White’s vividly rendered debut novel, “The Midcoast.”

headline: Can My Co-op Charge Me to Get Rid of the Bedbugs in My Apartment?
abstract: Landlords and co-op boards are legally obligated to exterminate bedbug infestations. But there are other costs involved that can fall on residents.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a small Manhattan co-op. Last summer, my apartment had a bedbug infestation, which I treated by calling an exterminator. The process entailed multiple visits and cost several thousand dollars. I never billed the co-op, partly out of embarrassment, even though I might have been able to. I later learned that my upstairs neighbor also had bedbugs and treated them on her own. Now a year later, the board is updating its proprietary lease so that the treatment of bedbugs is entirely the responsibility of tenants. Can it do that? Do any state laws govern a co-op’s response to bug infestations?

headline: Apple Starts Connecting the Dots for Its Next Big Thing
abstract: The company has enlisted Hollywood directors like Jon Favreau to help its effort to create products that blend the physical and virtual worlds.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 15 years after the iPhone set off the smartphone revolution, Apple is assembling the pieces for what it hopes will become its next business-altering device: a headset that blends the digital world with the real one.

headline: For Families in Uvalde, Laws Limit Paths to Accountability
abstract: Police officers rarely face criminal charges for inaction, and limits on civil lawsuits shield school districts and the police.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the mass shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, parents and community members have clamored for accountability, asking how officers allowed a gunman to remain inside a locked classroom with injured students for more than an hour.

headline: Jubilee Honors Britain’s Queen, but Also Highlights Her Increasing Absences
abstract: Throngs of admirers cheered Queen Elizabeth II at her Platinum Jubilee appearance on Thursday, but she was unable to attend a service on Friday. Prince Charles, in a familiar role, played the understudy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II’s Platinum Jubilee has become a party without its guest of honor. Her absence is a metaphor for the twilight of Britain’s second Elizabethan Age, an awkward limbo in which the 96-year-old queen still reigns but has, in many ways, been replaced by her eldest son and heir, Prince Charles.

headline: If New York City Gets Las Vegas-Style Casinos, What Else Will It Get?
abstract: Whether casinos deliver on their long-term economic promises has long been debated. Evidence from other cities suggests they rarely do.
lead_paragraph: Before too long, New Yorkers and the millions of tourists who visit the city every year may have a new way to test their luck — and part with their money — amid the bright lights and skyscrapers of Midtown Manhattan: hands of blackjack or spins of the roulette wheel inside a new casino with all the trappings of Las Vegas, down to the incessant ringing and fluorescent flashing of a sea of slot machines.

headline: Tanned, Buff and Ready to Pose, Gaza Bodybuilders Feel Weight of Blockade
abstract: Bodybuilding is popular among Palestinians living in Gaza, but travel restrictions and other obstacles as a result of the Israeli blockade make competing abroad a struggle.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Rain, shine or war, one bodybuilder’s day begins with a cup of instant espresso coffee — no sugar or milk — and a power walk, usually along the beachfront boardwalk of Gaza City.

headline: A Farmer Holds On, a Fraying Lifeline for a Besieged Corner of Ukraine
abstract: Most farmers have fled the Russian advance, but Oleksandr Chaplik has stayed, despite the lethal risks and a lack of workers, water and power.
lead_paragraph: SIVERSK DISTRICT, Ukraine — One of the few civilians still driving on a road leading toward the battle front, Oleksandr Chaplik skidded to a stop and leaned out the car window to swap information with a villager.

headline: Mariachis Ride Into Uvalde With Songs of Heartache and Hope
abstract: With trumpets, strings and serenades, their music traces the arc of life. It often accompanies moments of jubilation, but it can also speak to a community’s profound sorrow.
lead_paragraph: UVALDE, Texas — A bus rolled in off the dusty highway and into the heart of a town mired in sorrow.

headline: The Bachelorette Party Comes for Scottsdale
abstract: Local hot-air balloon and desert Jeep tour outfitters are crawling with groups of women belting out Katy Perry songs and only occasionally throwing up.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — On a recent Friday afternoon, at a $5 million mansion turned short-term rental property just outside Scottsdale city limits, God’s perfection revealed itself as elements of the natural and synthetic world collided at Marissa Sklar’s bachelorette party.

headline: A ‘Steel Cable’ That Connects the Mets and Dodgers
abstract: A tense series between the N.L.’s best teams paused to honor Gil Hodges, an icon for both franchises who had his No. 14 jersey retired by Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The connective tissues stretch all the way across the country and back again, binding Brooklyn, Los Angeles and Queens. Through the years, through all the true bounces and bad hops and yellowed pages, the contents of this baseball triangle remain snugly bound.

headline: Amid a Wave of Mass Shootings in the U.S., Canada Tightens Gun Laws
abstract: The handgun market in Canada has been frozen as Parliament reviews sweeping legal changes, including a mandatory buyback of some rifles.
lead_paragraph: It was an unusually hectic week of announcements and news from Canada: a freeze on handgun sales and transfers; the introduction of a gun reform bill that includes a buyback of “military-style assault rifles”; another damning report on sexual misconduct in the military with a road map for ending it; decriminalization of the possession of small amounts of opioids and other illegal drugs in British Columbia; and a vote in Ontario that returned its Progressive Conservative government to power.

headline: Summer Vacation Movies
abstract: They offer a double dose of escape.
lead_paragraph: June arrives freighted with possibility. It brings summer’s first act, and the trappings of the season loom in the imagination: barbecues and beach trips, some time out of town if you’re lucky. The promise of June is one of escape: from winter, from the school year, from everyday life into a more magical and sun-dappled one.

headline: London Police Evacuate Trafalgar Square, but Say ‘Incident Has Now Been Concluded’
abstract: The evacuation of the square in Central London rattled the capital on the third day of Queen Elizabeth’s Platinum Jubilee. The police later said it was not related to terrorism.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The police evacuated crowds and cordoned off Trafalgar Square in central London on Saturday morning after responding to a report of a suspicious vehicle, rattling the British capital on the third day of Queen Elizabeth’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations.

headline: Here’s how to watch or stream the final.
abstract: In the United States, the final will air on NBC and the NBC Sports website and app.
lead_paragraph: For fans waking up early to watch the French Open in the United States, matches throughout the tournament have been spread across a few television channels and streaming outlets.

headline: Mourning Tiananmen’s Victims, and the Hong Kong That Was
abstract: In Taiwan and elsewhere, people met on Saturday to remember those killed in China in 1989 — and the freedoms lost in Hong Kong, where such vigils are now unthinkable.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — For decades, a large candlelight vigil was held in Hong Kong each June 4, to commemorate those killed when Chinese soldiers crushed the Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing.

headline: DeLillo, Psychiatry and a Novella
abstract: Our critic recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Dear Readers,

headline: The Office Monsters Are Trying to Claw Their Way Back to 2019
abstract: Some corporate leaders are grasping at whatever they can to get back to the way things were. But they might find themselves fighting a culture shift beyond their control.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of May 30, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: As Geese Leave Mementos, a California City Weighs a Cull
abstract: The proposal has pit animal rights activists against officials in Foster City, Calif., where Canada geese have been fouling up public spaces with their feces. “It’s everywhere,” the mayor said.
lead_paragraph: They poop on the lawn. They poop in the park. That poop makes its way into the waterways. Officials in one California city have decided that enough is enough.

headline: Johnny and Amber: Trouble in Paradise
abstract: The starry, sorry spectacle and why we watched it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the years, when I felt twinges of envy, gazing at other people’s glamorous travelogues on Instagram or visiting friends who seemed to have the perfect lives, I summoned these comforting lines:

headline: Republicans Elevate Diverse Recruits in Bid to Win House Majority
abstract: The G.O.P.’s plan to win back the House rests on candidates of color who leaders hope can help broaden the party’s appeal.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON, Ariz. — When Juan Ciscomani first brought his family to his new congressional campaign office in the Catalina foothills, his father asked him: “Do you know where we are?”

headline: ‘Wherever I Am Is Hong Kong’: Migrants Build a New Life in the U.K.
abstract: More than a year after they first began arriving in Britain under a new visa program, people from Hong Kong are settling into their new home. But they still long for the one they left behind.
lead_paragraph: SUTTON, England — The days were short, and so much colder than the ones they had known, when Eric Wong and his family set foot in London in the winter of 2020 to start new lives.

headline: Don’t Referee Every Schoolyard Conflict. Help Kids Learn to Solve Them on Their Own.
abstract: When parents interfere too much, children miss out on building an essential life skill.
lead_paragraph: Most days when I pick my two daughters up from elementary school, they happily bound out the door — another day of high-spirited chatter about whom they played with and some facts about the Battle of Saratoga. But occasionally, there’s some kind of schoolyard spat. One of them will stomp out, furious about some perceived slight, which they reveal to me on our way home.

headline: Senior Iranian Officer Dies, Leaving Questions About His Death
abstract: Col. Ali Esmaelzadeh was the second high-ranking officer of the same unit to die in a week. The circumstances were unclear, and Iranian news media provided conflicting reports.
lead_paragraph: The death of a senior Iranian military officer at his home in a Tehran suburb a week ago has fueled conflicting reports that he fell from a balcony, committed suicide or was killed.

headline: Iga Swiatek Dominates in French Open Final for Championship
abstract: Swiatek, 21, beat Coco Gauff, the 18-year-old American prodigy, 6-1, 6-3, in just over an hour.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After winning her first French Open out of season in October as an unseeded teenager, Iga Swiatek proved that was anything but a fluke by winning the title again in the spring as an overwhelming favorite.

headline: A Little Hong Kong in London
abstract: More than a year after they first began arriving in Britain under a new visa program, migrants from Hong Kong are settling into their new home. Here's what some of them told me about their experience so far.
lead_paragraph: More than a year after they first began arriving in Britain under a new visa program, migrants from Hong Kong are settling into their new home. Here's what some of them told me about their experience so far.

headline: Tropical Weather Floods Miami Streets, Stranding Some Motorists
abstract: The storm system in South Florida also caused a sewage overflow in Miami-Dade County.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The first tropical threat of the hurricane season in Florida drenched the southern part of the state, leaving behind flooded streets, motorists calling for help from stranded cars and even a sewage overflow.

headline: Russia increases its use of air power to support its fight in the Donbas region, an intelligence report says.
abstract: Ukrainian forces poured men and armor toward the front line in Sievierodonetsk on Friday, and a military official said Ukrainian troops had managed to push Russian forces back by 20 percent.
lead_paragraph: Russia has increased its use of air power in support of artillery and ground troops who are fighting to expand their territory in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine, including in the city of Sievierodonetsk, a British intelligence report said on Saturday.

headline: When Every Conversation Becomes a Game, We All Lose
abstract: A disagreement is too often a wish to destroy.
lead_paragraph: I graduated from college in 2009. Since then, I’ve lived in two cities and had at least eight jobs, three of which I was pretty good at. And I think, or at least I hope, I’ve learned a lot. And perhaps the biggest lesson I’ve learned is about learning.

headline: Let’s Not Pretend Planting Trees Is a Permanent Climate Solution
abstract: Carbon emissions are forever, so carbon removal should be, too.
lead_paragraph: Trees are our original carbon removal technology: Through photosynthesis, they pull carbon dioxide out of the air and store it. They have lately been touted as a climate savior, a way to rapidly reduce the carbon dioxide that has accumulated in the atmosphere as we cut our emissions. A “trillion trees” initiative was launched with much fanfare at the World Economic Forum in Davos back in 2020, and it was one of the few climate solutions embraced by the Trump administration. Planting trees and protecting forests are a major part of many corporate efforts to offset emissions.

headline: Fandom Is Out of Control
abstract: What drives a grown person to travel to a courthouse in Virginia to hurl insults at someone she has never met, about behavior she didn’t witness and money she is not owed?
lead_paragraph: “Boo! Where’s the money?”

headline: The ‘Open Secret’ on Getting a Safe Abortion Before Roe v. Wade
abstract: Psychiatrists were once arbiters of abortion access. Will they resume that role post-Roe?
lead_paragraph: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, will psychiatrists resume their pre-Roe role as arbiters of abortion access? The law once compelled psychiatrists and pregnant women to perform dishonest rituals to get abortions. Will psychiatrists once again need to be complicit post-Roe?

headline: Ann Turner Cook Dies at 95; Her Face Sold Baby Food by the Billions
abstract: Her likeness as an infant has graced the labels on Gerber products for more than 90 years, though for decades her identity was not disclosed.
lead_paragraph: For years, the suspects were legion:

headline: The Debate Over the Best Way to Teach Reading
abstract: Readers discuss an article about a trend back to emphasizing phonics.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Mass Shootings Where Stricter Gun Laws Might Have Made a Difference
abstract: Four measures could have affected shootings that killed 446 people since the Columbine massacre in 1999.
lead_paragraph: Four measures could have affected shootings that killed 446 people since the Columbine massacre in 1999.

headline: Tropical Weather System Floods the Streets of Miami
abstract: Drivers in Miami faced slashing rains and flooded streets as a rapidly growing weather system moved into the South Florida region.
lead_paragraph: Drivers in Miami faced slashing rains and flooded streets as a rapidly growing weather system moved into the South Florida region.

headline: Barry Sussman, Washington Post Watergate Editor, Dies at 87
abstract: He worked closely with the reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein in covering the break-in and the subsequent scandal that doomed Richard Nixon.
lead_paragraph: Barry Sussman, the editor closest to The Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein as they covered the Watergate break-in and pursued the subsequent scandal that led to President Richard M. Nixon’s resignation, died on Wednesday at his home in Rockville, Md. He was 87.

headline: As Battles Rage, Ukraine Rejects Macron Plea Not to ‘Humiliate’ Russia
abstract: Amid reports of battlefield gains by Ukraine, an official angrily rejected Mr. Macron’s advice, saying it “can only humiliate France.”
lead_paragraph: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — As Ukrainian troops tried to claw back territory and stave off a blistering Russian assault along the country’s embattled eastern front, the government on Saturday sought also to repel a demand earlier in the day by President Emmanuel Macron of France that Moscow not be humiliated to improve chances of reaching a diplomatic solution.

headline: U.S. Warship Arrives in Stockholm for Military Exercises, and as a Warning
abstract: For Sweden and Finland, which want to join NATO, the U.S.S. Kearsarge is a promise of the protection that membership in the alliance would bring against President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: ABOARD U.S.S. KEARSARGE, in the port of Stockholm — If ever there was a potent symbol of how much Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has altered Europe, the sight of this enormous warship, bristling with 26 warplanes and 2,400 Marines and sailors, moored among the pleasure craft and tour boats that ply this port, would certainly be it.

headline: We Can’t Be Ukraine Hawks Forever
abstract: A hawkish policy has worked so far. A hawkish grand strategy is still unrealistic.
lead_paragraph: Sure, it works in practice, but does it work in theory? Over the years I’ve heard this parody of academic pomposity put in the lips of various targets, from French intellectuals to University of Chicago economists. Lately, though, I’ve begun thinking it myself — about the hawkish side in the debate over the Ukraine War, whose practical policies have so far achieved favorable results but whose deeper theories of the conflict still seem implausible, unworkable or dangerous.

headline: Dispatcher Fired Over Mishandling 911 Call During Buffalo Shooting
abstract: A Tops supermarket office manager said a dispatcher yelled at her for whispering, as she hid during the shooting, and hung up on her.
lead_paragraph: An emergency services dispatcher in Buffalo who was accused of hanging up on a 911 call from a supermarket employee during the racist shooting rampage last month was fired on Thursday, an official said.

headline: Biden Evacuated From Beach Home After Plane Enters Restricted Airspace
abstract: A White House official said the incursion appeared to be an accident and that there was no threat to the president or his family.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden was briefly evacuated Saturday from his beach home in Rehoboth Beach, Del., after a small private plane accidentally flew into restricted airspace, according to White House and Secret Service officials.

headline: Fetterman’s Heart Issues Add Wild Card to Key Pennsylvania Senate Race
abstract: Part of John Fetterman’s appeal as the Democratic Senate nominee has stemmed from his brash sense of vitality. It’s not clear if his recent stroke and absence from the trail will affect that.
lead_paragraph: Just three weeks ago, a varied cross-section of Pennsylvania Democrats put its hopes on the broad shoulders of John Fetterman, confident that the commonwealth’s burly lieutenant governor could vanquish anything or anyone that a fractured Republican Party could throw at him.

headline: Ex-Air Force Sergeant Sentenced to 41 Years for Murder of Federal Officer
abstract: Steven Carrillo pleaded guilty to a premeditated attack on law enforcement officers motivated by his support for an online anti-government movement.
lead_paragraph: A former Air Force sergeant who participated online in an extremist anti-government movement was sentenced on Friday to 41 years in prison for murdering a federal security officer and injuring another outside a courthouse in Oakland, Calif., according to court documents.

headline: Let’s Get Literature
abstract: Christina Iverson and Katie Hale shoot a puzzle through a canon.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Christina Iverson lives in Ames, Iowa, and is the assistant crossword editor for The Los Angeles Times; Katie Hale is a full-time parent in London. The idea for this grid started with Katie; she laid eyes on a copy of “The Great Gatsby,” and the phrase THROW A FITZGERALD popped into her head. Inspiration!

headline: Baby Formula Plant That Shut Down and Fueled Crisis Restarts Production
abstract: Abbott Nutrition said that its plant in Sturgis, Mich., resumed production of EleCare and other formulas on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Abbott Nutrition, the company that fueled a national shortage of baby formula when it shut down a leading production plant in February because of contamination concerns, said on Saturday that the site has restarted producing EleCare and other formulas.

headline: Ukraine aims to restart soccer leagues on its own soil in August.
abstract: In an interview with The Associated Press, the leader of Ukraine’s soccer federation said President Volodymyr Zelensky had approved the decision.
lead_paragraph: Even as the war in their country continues, Ukrainian soccer officials are planning to restart the soccer season in August, hoping that the renewal of games will be a morale boost, according to The Associated Press.

headline: In the N.H.L., Russian Goalies Grab the Spotlight
abstract: Igor Shesterkin of the Rangers and Andrei Vasilevskiy of the Lightning, arguably the best goalies in hockey, are leading a wave of talented netminders.
lead_paragraph: A new cheer was introduced during the Rangers’ emphatic Game 1 victory over the Tampa Bay Lightning on Wednesday, when fans at Madison Square Garden demonstrated their devotion to their own Russian goalie over the Lightning’s Russian goalie.

headline: There’s a New Gerber Baby and Some Parents Are Mad
abstract: Though not at the very adorable winner, fortunately.
lead_paragraph: Kelsey O’Hagan first heard about the Gerber Photo Search from a nurse at a doctor’s appointment for her now-12-month-old son, Everett.

headline: North Korea Launches a Volley of Short-Range Missiles
abstract: The North’s latest test, involving eight missiles, came a day after the United States and South Korea finished joint naval exercises in the East China Sea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — North Korea launched a ​barrage of ​short-range ballistic missile​s toward the waters off its east coast on Sunday, a day after the United States and South Korea completed a joint naval exercise involving an American aircraft carrier group, according to South Korean military officials.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Migrants to U.K. Build Life Outside Hong Kong
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 5, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “You grow up in a place, and you don’t recognize it. It becomes a stranger. When we think of it, we just want to cry.”

headline: Corrections: June 5, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 5, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 18 this weekend about a hub for Inuit artistry in arctic Canada misspells the name of the Indigenous First Nations people of Canada and the United States with whom Wanda Nanibush is identified. The people are Anishinaabe, not Anishabee.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Spending Time With a Family in Crisis
abstract: A 13-year-old’s aggressive behavior was a danger to her and her parents. A Times reporter followed their search for help.
lead_paragraph: In a recent article, Joseph Goldstein, who covers public health for the New York Times Metro desk, provides a close-up look at the Benedict family: 13-year-old Sabrina, who was given a diagnosis of autism and a rare genetic disorder, and her parents Jeremy and Crystol. Mr. Goldstein spent months following the family. In his article, he provides an intimate portrait of the fear and helplessness that Jeremy and Crystol feel when they can’t control their daughter’s aggressive behavior, which can lead to her harming herself and others, and their journey to try to help her. He described that reporting in an interview. That conversation appears edited below.

headline: Cruel Twist Puts Wales in World Cup and Keeps Ukraine Out
abstract: Ukraine had ridden national pride and emotion to the cusp of a berth in the World Cup in Qatar. But Gareth Bale and Wales had a story, too.
lead_paragraph: CARDIFF, Wales — When it was over, when the referee blew his whistle and the crowd roared and Ukraine’s dream of earning a place in this year’s World Cup was gone, most of its national soccer team dropped straight to the grass. A few players held their heads in their hands. The rest simply stared off into space.

headline: ‘Feeling Smug, I Sat Down and Began to Look Around’
abstract: A surprise on the No. 6, losing a great barber and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Mental Health Clinic in School? No, Thanks, Says the School Board
abstract: American teenagers are reporting severe levels of anxiety and depression. But when Connecticut moved to expand mental health services in schools, it ran into fierce opposition in one town.
lead_paragraph: KILLINGLY, Conn. — One evening in March, a high school senior named Sydney Zicolella stood before the school board in this rural, blue-collar Connecticut town and described her psychiatric history, beginning in the sixth grade, when she was “by definition, clinically depressed.”

headline: New Zealand’s Biodiversity Crisis Prompts Extreme Measures
abstract: A few years ago, the nation vowed to rid itself of most imported predators. But now some people are asking if that goal is feasible, or worth what it will cost.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — The volunteer clambered down the cliffs, progressing along a series of knots on a thin rope as he made his perilous way about 100 feet down a steep rock face to the small box that he needed to refill with poison.

headline: ‘From Russia With Love’: A Putin Ally Mines Gold and Plays Favorites in Sudan
abstract: Backed by the Kremlin, the shadowy network known as the Wagner Group is getting rich in Sudan while helping the military to crush a democracy movement.
lead_paragraph: AL-IBEDIYYA, Sudan — In a scorched, gold-rich area 200 miles north of the Sudanese capital, where fortunes spring from desert-hewn rock, a mysterious foreign operator dominates the business.

headline: How Asylum Seekers Cross the Border
abstract: The southern border is seeing a historic spike in migrant crossings. Many are coming in hope of asking for asylum, a right that has been unavailable because of pandemic-related restrictions on immigration. A New York Times photographer documented three ways that people cross the border into the United States.
lead_paragraph: HIDALGO, Texas — Since President Biden took office, migration at the southern border of the United States has increased to levels not seen in decades. Crossings in the past two months have eclipsed the high numbers of last summer, and officials expect the trend to continue, even though, with pandemic restrictions still in place, there is almost no access to asylum.

headline: Dozens Killed and Hundreds Burned in Bangladesh Depot Disaster
abstract: A fire set off a series of explosions, killing at least 49 people, including firefighters. Many others were in critical condition.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — At least 49 people were killed and hundreds more suffered burns when a fire at a container depot in Bangladesh set off a series of explosions, officials said on Sunday, the latest such disaster in a country where mass-casualty fires have become a recurring problem.

headline: Oxford Quartet: The Women Who Took On the Philosophical Establishment
abstract: “Metaphysical Animals” traces the careers and friendships of Iris Murdoch, Philippa Foot, Elizabeth Anscombe and Mary Midgley.
lead_paragraph: METAPHYSICAL ANIMALSHow Four Women Brought Philosophy Back to LifeBy Clare Mac Cumhaill and Rachael Wiseman

headline: In Older Americans, Rising Debt May Adversely Affect Health
abstract: Research shows that debt has risen among older people, and those who owe are more likely to have multiple diagnosed illnesses.
lead_paragraph: Denise Revel had a history of developing blood clots, so in 2011, when her leg grew painfully swollen and hot to the touch, she knew what to do. She headed for the emergency room.

headline: Homes That Sold for $550,000 or Less
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Andrew Holleran’s Work Has Traced the Arc of Life. Now, He Takes on Death.
abstract: Holleran, a pioneer in gay literature for a post-Stonewall age, touches on universal themes of loss and the transience of life in his latest novel, “The Kingdom of Sand.”
lead_paragraph: Death has always been on Andrew Holleran’s mind.

headline: CNN Enters the Post-Jeff Zucker Era. Bye-Bye ‘Breaking News’ Banners.
abstract: Chris Licht, the new CNN chairman, is encouraging a more nuanced approach to coverage. Some at the network are skeptical.
lead_paragraph: CNN’s ubiquitous “Breaking News” banner is gone, now reserved for instances of truly urgent events. Snarky on-screen captions — “Angry Trump Turns Briefing Into Propaganda Session,” for instance — are discouraged. Political shows are trying to book more conservative voices, and producers have been urged to ignore Twitter backlash from the far right and the far left.

headline: In San Francisco, Democrats Are at War With Themselves Over Crime
abstract: Fueled by concerns about burglaries and hate crimes, San Francisco’s liberal district attorney, Chesa Boudin, faces a divisive recall in a famously progressive city.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As the former chair of the San Francisco Democratic Party, Mary Jung has a long list of liberal bona fides, including her early days in politics volunteering in Ohio for the presidential campaign of George McGovern and her service on the board of the local Planned Parenthood branch. “In Cleveland, I was considered a communist,” she said in her San Francisco office.

headline: In Races to Run Elections, Candidates Are Backed by Key 2020 Deniers
abstract: The origin story behind a slate of Republican candidates for secretary of state features a QAnon figure and several promoters of 2020 conspiracies.
lead_paragraph: Key figures in the effort to subvert the 2020 presidential election have thrown their weight behind a slate of Republican candidates for secretary of state across the country, injecting specious theories about voting machines, foreign hacking and voter fraud into campaigns that will determine who controls elections in several battleground states.

headline: Mongols Motorcycle Club Says Its Leader Was an Informant
abstract: The biker group hopes to set aside a $500,000 racketeering conviction, alleging that its former president cooperated with the government during a trial.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, federal law enforcement authorities pursued the Mongols, a notorious motorcycle club whose members had a long history of murder, assault, drug dealing and robbery.

headline: Twilight of the NIMBY
abstract: Suburban homeowners like Susan Kirsch are often blamed for worsening the nation’s housing crisis. That doesn’t mean she’s giving up her two-decade fight against 20 condos.
lead_paragraph: Susan Kirsch is a 78-year-old retired teacher who lives in a small cottage home in Mill Valley, Calif., on a quiet suburban street that looks toward a grassy knoll. A Sierra Club member with a pesticide-free garden, she has an Amnesty International sticker on her front window and a photograph on her refrigerator of herself and hundreds of other people spelling “TAX THE 1%” on a beach.

headline: ‘She Was My Sweet Girl’: Remembering the Victims of the Uvalde Shooting
abstract: These are the 21 people — 19 students and two teachers — who were killed by a gunman at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas.
lead_paragraph: A boy who played Little League. A girl who dreamed of becoming a veterinarian. Young children who loved their siblings and classmates. Several who had just made the honor roll. In all, 21 people — 19 students and two teachers — were killed by a gunman at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, on May 24.

headline: Pride Is in the Air
abstract: All the looks that are fit to print from the Monster x Coach pride party, Guggenheim young collectors gala and the Moth Ball.
lead_paragraph: Pride month got off to a fashionable start on Wednesday, when Coach hosted a rainbow-hued party at the Monster, a venerable gay bar across the street from the Stonewall Inn. Saucy Santana performed before a youthful crowd that included Bowen Yang, Joel Kim Booster and Tommy Dorfman.

headline: Mass Shooting in Philadelphia Kills at Least 3 on Weekend of Gun Violence
abstract: Shootings in Tennessee, Virginia, Arizona and South Carolina left six more dead and dozens injured.
lead_paragraph: A brawl between at least two men turned a packed Philadelphia street into a scene of terror Saturday night after they pulled out guns and began firing wildly at each other. By the time the gunfire ended, three people were dead and 12 more were hurt.

headline: And Just Like That, I Could Smell Exactly Nothing
abstract: After eight days, I was feeling fully recovered from my rendezvous with Omicron. Then my nose called it quits.
lead_paragraph: Like any other vaxxed and boosted human, I didn’t look forward to getting Covid — not when it was life-threatening Alpha, not when it was Delta-variant dreadful, not when it was Omicron omnipresent. I had enough brain fog already, thank you very much, and wasn’t kindly disposed toward the uncertainties of long Covid. But I was confident that when I did succumb, as perhaps we all must, there was one thing I didn’t need to worry about: anosmia. Though I might wind up coughing, feverish and as clogged as a frat house toilet, I just knew I’d be spared my sense of smell. My nose was too darned sensitive and persnickety to capitulate.

headline: Your Kids Are Not Doomed
abstract: The green future has to be a welcoming one, even a thrilling one.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, I’ve been asked one question more than any other. It comes up at speeches, at dinners, in conversation. It’s the most popular query when I open my podcast to suggestions, time and again. It comes in two forms. The first: Should I have kids, given the climate crisis they will face? The second: Should I have kids, knowing they will contribute to the climate crisis the world faces?

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘I’ve Always Struggled With My Weight. Losing It Didn’t Mean Winning.’
abstract: A diet app helped writer Sam Anderson shed his extra Covid pounds — and reminded him that he was still his old self.
lead_paragraph: We cannot escape our bodies. So how do we reconcile them with who we really are?

headline: The Supreme Court Is Pursuing a Very Dangerous Strategy for the Environment
abstract: The court’s conservative majority seems intent on pursuing an agenda that would limit the federal government’s ability to shield the planet.
lead_paragraph: News Update: On Thursday, the Supreme Court voted 6 to 3 to significantly limit the authority of the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate greenhouse gas emissions in a narrow reading of the Clean Air Act.

headline: The Week in Business: Meta Changes
abstract: Jobs growth continued to be strong. OPEC Plus announced that it would increase oil production. And a report on inflation in May is coming.
lead_paragraph: Sheryl Sandberg announced Wednesday that she was stepping down as chief operating officer of Meta after 14 years with the company. In that time, Facebook, as it was formerly known, grew into a behemoth, acquiring dozens of companies and extending its influence across the internet. Ms. Sandberg built her personal brand alongside the company, publishing “Lean In,” her best-selling 2013 book about how to succeed as a woman in the workplace. But Ms. Sandberg’s reputation suffered as Facebook faced backlash for its role in the spread of misinformation during the 2016 election, the data breach involving Cambridge Analytica and other scandals. And many of the women who once subscribed to Ms. Sandberg’s philosophy grew disillusioned as they discovered that “leaning in” did not bring about the raises and promotions she spoke of. Ms. Sandberg will remain on Meta’s board.

headline: The Jack Welch Effect
abstract: His ruthlessness as General Electric’s C.E.O. was ultimately bad for the company, a new book argues.
lead_paragraph: If you look at historical data on the U.S. economy, you often notice that something changed in the late 1970s or early ’80s. Incomes started growing more slowly for most workers, and inequality surged.

headline: A Cancer Trial’s Unexpected Result: Remission in Every Patient
abstract: The study was small, and experts say it needs to be replicated. But for 18 people with rectal cancer, the outcome led to “happy tears.”
lead_paragraph: It was a small trial, just 18 rectal cancer patients, every one of whom took the same drug.

headline: Snake on a Train
abstract: Discovering why a subway seat is empty.
lead_paragraph: Discovering why a subway seat is empty.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Make cottage cheese pasta, a spin on an Eastern European classic, or an elegant one-pan roasted fish with cherry tomatoes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’ve got a taste for grilled baby back ribs with spicy peanut shake, with spicy coleslaw on the side and a classic birthday cake for dessert, with a cold glass of milk. It’s summertime! Fish are jumping.

headline: I Married the Wrong Person, and I’m So Glad I Did
abstract: I want to normalize significant periods of confusion, exhaustion, grief and unfulfillment in marriage.
lead_paragraph: I truly believe that everyone marries the wrong person. But even by that standard, my husband’s and my match was particularly fraught. We got married young with no idea what we were getting into or how to decide who — or if — to marry. We both brought plenty of baggage into our relationship. We argued a lot, and didn’t handle conflict well. We had a vague sense that marriage was good and a mistaken idea that it was a necessary passage into adulthood. But even as I walked down the aisle, I harbored doubts about whether we should marry.

headline: Is America Having a Breakdown?
abstract: Responses to Michelle Goldberg’s column that said America may be broken beyond repair. Also: The art of translation; the abortion ban in Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rafael Nadal, Looking Unbeatable, Wins 14th French Open Title
abstract: Nadal extended his men’s singles record of 22 Grand Slam tournament titles with a win in straight sets over the eighth-seeded Casper Ruud.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — He fooled us again, which is, in itself, quite a feat at this stage of the game.

headline: The Darts Queen Who Regularly Beats the Men
abstract: And Fallon Sherrock will tell you, “They don’t want to lose to a girl.”
lead_paragraph: When the world’s best darts players faced off at the Theater at Madison Square Garden in the U.S. Darts Masters on Friday and Saturday, there was only one woman among them.

headline: How a New York County Used the State’s ‘Red Flag’ Law to Seize 160 Guns
abstract: Suffolk County on Long Island aggressively uses the law to take guns from people in crisis in an effort to prevent shootings and suicides. Its experience could inform a national debate.
lead_paragraph: The boy made his threat aboard a school bus.

headline: Party Before the Hangover: Queen’s Jubilee Offers Britons Respite From Woes
abstract: The Platinum Jubilee celebrations ended Sunday. Monday political and economic unease returns.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain wrapped up a joyful four-day tribute to Queen Elizabeth II on Sunday with street fairs, picnics and a pageant, after a star-studded Saturday night concert at Buckingham Palace that offered a pop-culture mash-up of Rod Stewart performing Neil Diamond’s singalong “Sweet Caroline.”

headline: Dozens Killed in Explosions From Fire at Depot in Bangladesh
abstract: Hundreds of other people, including many now in critical condition, suffered burns, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of other people, including many now in critical condition, suffered burns, officials said.

headline: My Times: Career Advice From a Career in the Trenches
abstract: Thirty years ago, I arrived at The Times as an intern. This is what I’ve learned.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, I arrived at The New York Times as an intern. I never planned to be a “company man.” I had no real plan. This is just the way things worked out.

headline: Martha Myers, Who Taught Dancers How to Move and More, Dies at 97
abstract: She was an institution at the American Dance Festival, and also made early television dance and exercise programs.
lead_paragraph: Martha Myers, who influenced generations of dancers both as the founder of the noted dance department at Connecticut College and as the longtime dean of the school of the American Dance Festival, died on May 24 at her home in Manhattan. She was 97.

headline: Review: ‘Third Bird’ Doesn’t Quite Land
abstract: The fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi is a terrific host, but this production at the Guggenheim Museum is awfully shaggy for an avian story, our critic writes.
lead_paragraph: Prokofiev’s “Peter and the Wolf” is a children’s classic, an ideal introduction to the instruments of the orchestra. The production of the score that Works & Process has presented annually at the Guggenheim Museum since 2007, narrated by the fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi, has itself become a local classic.

headline: Biden Has ‘Only Bad Options’ for Bringing Down Oil Prices
abstract: The president’s trip to Saudi Arabia is unlikely to reduce oil and gasoline prices, and it is not clear that anything else he might do would work, either.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — When President Biden meets Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Saudi Arabia, he will be following in the footsteps of presidents like Jimmy Carter, who flew to Tehran in 1977 to exchange toasts with the shah of Iran on New Year’s Eve.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Russian Missiles Hit Kyiv
abstract: Plus Hindus try to flee Kashmir and Taipei commemorates Tiananmen Square.
lead_paragraph: At least five missiles hit Kyiv early on Sunday, the first Russian strike in Ukraine’s capital in over a month. At least one person was injured, officials said, as the city’s sense of relative security ruptured.

headline: Derrick White’s Celtics’ Run Has His Group Chat Going Crazy
abstract: There was lots of talk about “beautiful basketball,” said one friend of the Boston Celtics guard, who is competing — improbably — in the N.B.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After his junior season at the University of Colorado Colorado Springs, Derrick White knew he needed to have a difficult conversation with Alex Welsh, his best friend and teammate. And Welsh, for his part, knew the conversation was coming, not that that made it any easier.

headline: ‘Don’t Lose Hope’: Addressing the Breakdown of College Education
abstract: Jonathan Malesic responds to readers concerned about the breakdown in college students’ learning since Covid.
lead_paragraph: In my May 13 guest essay, “My College Students Are Not OK,” I described an apparent breakdown in college students’ learning after more than two years of disruption by Covid. “Universities need to help students rebuild their ability to learn,” I wrote. “And to do that, everyone involved — students, faculties, administrators and the public at large — must insist on in-person classes and high expectations for fall 2022 and beyond.”

headline: Dozens Feared Dead in Church Attack in Nigeria
abstract: Gunmen fired on Catholics celebrating Mass in a usually peaceful part of the country. There was no claim of responsibility and the motive was unclear.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Dozens were believed to be dead after assailants attacked a Catholic church in southwestern Nigeria on Sunday, firing on worshipers as they celebrated Mass, according to local officials.

headline: A (Very) Early Start, a Walk-Off Win and Pizza on the Town
abstract: Thanks to an 11:35 a.m. start against Detroit, Yankees players had the rarest of treats: a Sunday afternoon in June with nothing to do but relax.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Rizzo didn’t skip a beat when asked if he could spare a few minutes to talk by his locker Sunday morning.

headline: Write on Stone
abstract: Go on a journey with Michael Schlossberg’s Monday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Monday, solvers! Today, we have a puzzle from the constructor Michael Schlossberg, who is making his fifth appearance in the New York Times Crossword.

headline: Struggling in Ukraine’s East, Russian Forces Strike in Kyiv
abstract: Vladimir Putin threatened “to strike targets we haven’t hit before” if Western nations proceed with plans to send long-range missiles to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Russian forces pressed hard on Sunday to take the town of Sievierodonetsk, one of the last obstacles to seizing the region of Luhansk. But as so often in this grinding war of attrition, the Russian Army is finding the going difficult, with Ukrainian forces making counterattacks and seizing back some of the town.

headline: Russia Seeks Buyers for Plundered Ukraine Grain, U.S. Warns
abstract: American diplomats have alerted 14 countries, most in Africa, that Russian ships filled with stolen Ukrainian grain could be headed their way, posing a dilemma to countries facing dire food shortages.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Russia has bombed, blockaded and plundered the grain production capacity of Ukraine, which accounts for one-tenth of global wheat exports, resulting in dire forecasts of increased hunger and of spiking food prices around the world.

headline: For Tampa Bay, a Win Over the Rangers Comes at an Opportune Time
abstract: At risk of falling into a three-game deficit, the Lightning scored a late goal to beat the Rangers for the first time in six games this season and maintain their pursuit of a third straight title.
lead_paragraph: After being thoroughly outplayed by the Rangers and losing the first two games of their Eastern Conference finals series, the Tampa Bay Lightning looked like a team being swamped by a younger version of itself.

headline: Star-Studded Uruguay Provides Stiff Test for U.S.
abstract: The young American team came away with a scoreless draw against the 13th-ranked team in the world as it continues to tinker with its roster and tactics ahead of the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — For the United States men’s national soccer team, a string of four games this month against a diverse set of opponents presents any number of productive opportunities.

headline: Golden State Rebounds With Game 2 Win Over Celtics in N.B.A. Finals
abstract: After collapsing in the fourth quarter of Game 1, Golden State turned an early lead in Game 2 into a big-time victory to even the series.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It was exactly the kind of release the fans at the Chase Center had been seeking — some reason to jump up out of their seats in a delirious celebration of this team they couldn’t believe had lost Game 1.

headline: The (No Longer) Secret World of Surf Spots
abstract: Publicizing certain surf spots, especially ones off the beaten path, is similar to violating the first rule of Fight Club. Instagram and some new surfers have threatened that reverence.
lead_paragraph: As one of the world’s most productive wave hunters, Josh Mulcoy is used to keeping his discoveries to himself, whether it’s a remote beach or in his backyard of Vancouver Island, British Columbia. But nowadays, Mulcoy, a professional surfer and photographer, takes more care than ever about what information he shares — and what he doesn’t.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Britain’s Jubilee celebrations.
lead_paragraph: At least five missiles hit Kyiv early yesterday, the first Russian strike in Ukraine’s capital in over a month. Russia said the missiles destroyed tanks and armored vehicles supplied by Ukraine’s Eastern European allies. At least one person was injured, officials said.

headline: No Corrections: June 6, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 6, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Jubilee, Britons Find Respite From Woes
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 6, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I’m pretty sure the jubilee atmosphere is a four-day wonder, and that the national mood will turn fairly sour again fairly quickly. It feels like we’re all waiting for something to happen. For the storm or the dam to break.”

headline: What’s on TV This Week: The Tony Awards and ‘P-Valley’
abstract: The 75th Tony Awards air on CBS. And Katori Hall’s “P-Valley” is back on Starz.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 6 - 12. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Here are the latest developments from the war in Ukraine.
abstract: Russia’s bid to capture the key eastern city of Sievierodonetsk is faltering against a fierce Ukrainian counteroffensive that has reclaimed significant sections of the city, where Moscow has concentrated its troops with the goal of fully seizing the province of Luhansk.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s bid to capture the key eastern city of Sievierodonetsk is faltering against a fierce Ukrainian counteroffensive that has reclaimed significant sections of the city, where Moscow has concentrated its troops with the goal of fully seizing the province of Luhansk.

headline: Could One County’s Success With ‘Red Flag’ Orders Be a Model?
abstract: Suffolk County authorities have acted more often than their counterparts elsewhere in New York to seize weapons from the home of someone who has made a threat.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at the one county in New York State where judges have issued the most red flag gun orders. We’ll also get a review of a play about a City Council from a New York City Council member.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Administrative note: If you’re interested in receiving puzzles, brain teasers, solving tips and more in your inbox every week, sign up for the new Gameplay newsletter. The first edition will be sent on Thursday, June 9, 2022.

headline: Thefts, Fraud and Lawsuits at the World’s Biggest NFT Marketplace
abstract: OpenSea, one of the highest-profile crypto start-ups, is facing a backlash over stolen and plagiarized nonfungible tokens.
lead_paragraph: Chris Chapman used to own one of the most valuable commodities in the crypto world: a unique digital image of a spiky-haired ape dressed in a spacesuit.

headline: Assassinations Become Weapon of Choice for Guerrilla Groups in Myanmar
abstract: A movement to restore democracy has evolved into deadly warfare between a ruthless military and a resistance force with limited weaponry.
lead_paragraph: The gunman entered the small government office in central Myanmar, walked up to the man in charge and shot him four times in the head. “You are the ward administrator!” the gunman shouted, according to a brief video clip that captured part of the shooting.

headline: Britain’s prime minister, beset by a scandal over lockdown parties, faces a decisive vote.
abstract: Members of the British leader’s party reached a threshold to hold the vote, after he had come under fire about claims he misled Parliament about Downing Street parties during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Conservative lawmakers dealt Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain a potentially lethal blow to his leadership when they triggered a no-confidence vote on Monday that could force him from power a little more than two years after his landslide election victory.

headline: ‘Crying in H Mart’ Made Michelle Zauner a Literary Star. What's Next?
abstract: “My creative life has been so raw and personal that I would like to do something more analytical.”
lead_paragraph: “My creative life has been so raw and personal that I would like to do something more analytical.”

headline: How to Listen to ‘First Person’
abstract: To listen to this free New York Times Opinion podcast, follow these instructions.
lead_paragraph: Every opinion starts with a story. A narrative show hosted by Lulu Garcia-Navarro (@lourdesgnavarro). New episodes every Thursday. You can listen to the trailer here.

headline: There Has to Be a Tipping Point on Guns, Right?
abstract: Or maybe not.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I know we’ll talk about Joe Biden’s gun-control proposals, but I wanted to ask how Dan is feeling — about Covid and the Celtics.

headline: Supreme Court May Hear ‘800-Pound Gorilla’ of Election Law Cases
abstract: Next week the justices will consider whether to resolve a long-simmering dispute about the power of state legislatures in federal elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In October 2020, with the presidential election looming, four conservative justices issued opinions that seemed prepared to endorse a legal theory that would radically reshape how federal elections are conducted. The theory would give state legislatures independent power, not subject to review by state courts, to set election rules at odds with state constitutions, and to draw congressional maps warped by partisan gerrymandering.

headline: Democrats Can Win This Fall if They Make One Key Promise
abstract: To make the 2022 elections a referendum on Roe, Democrats have to put protecting Roe and abortion rights on the table.
lead_paragraph: Democrats hope to make November’s midterm elections a referendum on Roe v. Wade, the linchpin decision upholding abortion rights, which the Supreme Court is almost certain to strike down this summer. That strategy makes sense. Polls show that roughly two in three Americans oppose overturning Roe and almost 60 percent support passing a bill to set Roe’s protections in a federal law. What’s more, polls showed a rising number of voters listing abortion as their top midterm issue after news of Roe’s imminent demise leaked in the form of a draft court opinion published by Politico.

headline: A Broken Redistricting Process Winds Down, With No Repairs in Sight
abstract: A brutal battle over drawing district boundaries in the House of Representatives has left the two major political parties roughly at parity. But no one is celebrating.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The brutal once-a-decade process of drawing new boundaries for the nation’s 435 congressional districts is limping toward a close with the nation’s two major political parties roughly at parity. But the lessons drawn from how they got there offer little cheer for those worried about the direction of the weary American experiment.

headline: High California Gas Prices Rattle Democrats Ahead of Midterms
abstract: “I don’t hear anything about the other national issues we’re focusing on in Washington,” a congressman said. A driver put it succinctly: “I’m really unhappy.”
lead_paragraph: SANTA ANA, Calif. — Orange County, Calif., symbolized Republican struggles in America’s diverse and highly educated suburbs during Donald J. Trump’s presidency, as a backlash to Mr. Trump transformed center-right strongholds into increasingly Democratic territory.

headline: Behold the Lionfish, as Transfixing as It Is Destructive
abstract: Lionfish, while spectacularly beautiful, are wreaking havoc on Caribbean reef habitats.
lead_paragraph: The silence underwater is overwhelming. Time passes quickly. Having spotted my target, I focus on it intensely, knowing that if I miss, and the animal gets away, it may learn from the encounter and be harder to hunt in the future.

headline: Big City Mayors, Furious About Mass Shootings, Fear Sweeping Gun Limits Are Out of Reach
abstract: Mayors described being caught in an exasperating partisan impasse, charged with managing the country’s carnage but pushed to the margins when trying to fix it.
lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — As the mayors filed into the conference room, they received a pamphlet called the “Mass Shooting Protocol” that included practical tips on coordinating with the police, setting up family reunification centers and organizing vigils. Make sure to post updates on a single social media account, the brochure advised. Immediately set up a fund for donations. Keep the news media away from victims’ loved ones.

headline: ‘Ms. Marvel’ Introduces a New Hero (and a New Actress)
abstract: This Disney+ series, about a teenage Muslim superhero, represents the first screen role for its 19-year-old star, Iman Vellani.
lead_paragraph: When Iman Vellani watches herself as the title character in “Ms. Marvel,” she cannot help but feel a sense of disbelief. Before this Disney+ series came her way, she was a high school senior with a seemingly impossible dream to be in a Marvel project — now she’s playing one of its powerful costumed champions, just like some of the actors she has spent her life idolizing.

headline: The Many Faces of the 2022 Tony Nominees
abstract: As Broadway embarked on its road to recovery, these 45 theater artists helped pave the way.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway season that just ended, the first since the pandemic shutdown, will be remembered for many reasons — the persistence of Covid, the death of Stephen Sondheim, the dwindled tourism and the indispensable understudies. It was a season for renewed appreciation: of song and storytelling and shared experiences, of a beloved art form and a rebounding industry. And it was a season that featured an extraordinary volume of work by Black artists, catalyzed by the social unrest of 2020. The 2022 Tony Awards, which take place June 12, offer an opportunity to honor some of Broadway’s best work; in anticipation of that event, we photographed and interviewed many of the performers, and a few of the writers, directors and choreographers, nominated for awards. Below are portraits and edited excerpts from the interviews.

headline: It’s Been 50 Years. I Am Not ‘Napalm Girl’ Anymore.
abstract: The surviving people in war photographs, especially the children, must somehow go on. We are not symbols. We are human.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in the small village of Trang Bang in South Vietnam. My mother said I laughed a lot as a young girl. We led a simple life with an abundance of food, since my family had a farm and my mom ran the best restaurant in town. I remember loving school and playing with my cousins and the other children in our village, jumping rope, running and chasing one another joyfully.

headline: I’m a Republican Who Represented Uvalde in Congress. I Want More Than Thoughts and Prayers.
abstract: There are real solutions to this epidemic. We just need the courage to act.
lead_paragraph: Last month, a fourth-grade classroom in Uvalde, Texas, a small, quiet community that I represented in Congress, became a war zone. Nineteen beautiful, innocent children and two dedicated, brave teachers are gone forever because of a vicious massacre. It’s infuriating. It’s heartbreaking. It was preventable.

headline: We Need to Stay Heartbroken About This
abstract: After the massacre in Texas, the children’s author Kate DiCamillo captured the depth of our grief.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — I wish I could report that shock was my first reaction to the news from Uvalde, but it was not shock. My first reaction to the slaughter of 19 children and two teachers was grief — terrible, garment-rending grief — followed by something dangerously close to resignation. Here we go again. And again and again. When you know something unbearable will happen, and then it happens, grief and resignation sit together in the same pew.

headline: What Depp v. Heard Means for #MeToo
abstract: The winning legal strategy could change the dynamics of the era.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language and details of a sexual assault accusation.

headline: A Post-Roe America
abstract: We look at what abortion access would look like.
lead_paragraph: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, more than 20 states — home to roughly half the country’s population — are likely to outlaw nearly all abortions. For women living in Mississippi, the closest place to receive a legal abortion might then be Illinois.

headline: An Attempt at Inclusion Proves There Is More Work to Do
abstract: A day after the Dodgers finally embraced the memory of Glenn Burke — Major League Baseball’s first gay player — a group of Rays players undercut their team’s Pride Night.
lead_paragraph: Something was missing in the top of the eighth inning on Saturday at Tropicana Field in St. Petersburg, Fla. The Tampa Bay Rays used two relief pitchers that inning — the left-handers Brooks Raley and Jalen Beeks — who wore jerseys without a patch on their right sleeve.

headline: Tropical Storm Alex Drifts Into the Atlantic After Flooding Florida
abstract: The storm brought rain and strong winds to Bermuda before becoming a post-tropical cyclone.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Alex brought strong winds and rain to Bermuda before becoming a post-tropical cyclone on Monday, days after the weather system caused flooding across South Florida and killed at least three people in Cuba.

headline: Draymond Green Drags Golden State Back Into the Fight
abstract: A fiery star tests some limits in carrying Golden State over Boston in Game 2.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — There is a line. Draymond Green knows the line well at this stage of his career. Sometimes he uses his arms and elbows and vocal cords to push right up against the line. And there are other occasions when he enthusiastically tramples all over it.

headline: Beijing relaxes Covid measures as fears of another outbreak linger.
abstract: The Chinese capital relaxed pandemic rules at midnight on Monday, including a ban on dining in, after a partial lockdown that lasted more than a month.
lead_paragraph: Beijing residents eagerly indulged in a privilege that they had not enjoyed in weeks: dining inside a restaurant.

headline: How Boris Johnson Shattered His Own Invincibility
abstract: The prime minister survived a no-confidence vote, but has been politically wounded by the same baffling mix of strengths and foibles that propelled his rise: rare political intuition, and breathtaking personal recklessness.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Boris Johnson won a landslide election victory for his Conservative Party in 2019, he loomed as a colossus over British politics, the man who had redrawn the country’s political map with a vow to “get Brexit done.”

headline: British pound and stocks rise as vote on prime minister washes over markets.
abstract: Markets are moved more by global concerns, like the war in Ukraine, than by domestic political infighting.
lead_paragraph: Financial markets appeared unperturbed by the political shock waves following the announcement that Britain’s prime minister, Boris Johnson, would face a no-confidence vote in his leadership. When he won the vote, they continued as they had before.

headline: The Mets Keep the Doors Open, the TV On and Opponents on Edge
abstract: Splitting a series with the high-spending Dodgers was a good start to the Mets’ West Coast trip. Dodging a few potential injuries was even better.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The weekend didn’t quite go the way the Mets imagined it would to open their 11-day, 10-game tour of Southern California, but their rules of engagement became pretty clear: Leave the hotel doors open, the television on and make sure Pete Alonso keeps swinging.

headline: She Dreams of California While Stranded on a Cargo Ship in China
abstract: A crew has had to remain on its ship since February because of Covid-related delays in repairs and quarantine rules.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes Madeleine Wolczko dreams of her runs up the mountainsides of the Sierra Nevada, or the weekends diving for abalone off the Mendocino coast. Her only travels these days are in her mind.

headline: He Helped Cure the ‘London Patient’ of H.I.V. Then He Turned to Covid.
abstract: Ravindra Gupta, who led the efforts that resulted in the second case of a patient being cured of H.I.V., was drawn into pandemic research.
lead_paragraph: Visionaries is a limited series that looks at figures who are trying to transform the way we live.

headline: $3 Million Homes in California
abstract: An 1883 Victorian in Los Angeles, a three-bedroom house in Encinitas and a desert compound in Pioneertown.
lead_paragraph: An 1883 Victorian in Los Angeles, a three-bedroom house in Encinitas and a desert compound in Pioneertown.

headline: ‘You Don’t Become Lou Reed Overnight.’ A New Exhibition Proves It.
abstract: “Lou Reed: Caught Between the Twisted Stars” offers glimpses of a life in rock ’n’ roll — from doo-wop to “Metal Machine Music” — and tracks the evolution of one of music’s polarizing legends.
lead_paragraph: At a glance, it is a modest artifact: a five-inch reel of audio tape, housed in a plain cardboard box. Its wrapping bears a postmark of May 11, 1965, and the sender and addressee are the same: Lewis Reed.

headline: $3 Million Homes in California
abstract: An 1883 Victorian in Los Angeles, a three-bedroom house in Encinitas and a desert compound in Pioneertown.
lead_paragraph: This house was first built in downtown Los Angeles on Bunker Hill, a fashionable area at the time. It has since been moved twice — first in the early 1900s, to an area just west of the city center, and again in 1989. By the middle of the 20th century, most of Bunker Hill had been razed, which makes the survival of this home especially remarkable.

headline: Biden to Pause New Solar Tariffs as White House Aims to Encourage Adoption
abstract: Critics said the move would shortcut an investigation by the Commerce Department, which has been considering whether to impose the tariffs as part of a trade case against Chinese companies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Monday announced a two-year pause on imposing any new tariffs on the solar industry, a decision that follows an outcry from importers who have complained the levies are threatening broader adoption of solar energy in the United States.

headline: A political escape artist finds his career on the brink.
abstract: When Boris Johnson won a landslide election victory for his Conservative Party in 2019, he loomed as a colossus over British politics, the man who had redrawn the country’s political map with a vow to “get Brexit done.”
lead_paragraph: When Boris Johnson won a landslide election victory for his Conservative Party in 2019, he loomed as a colossus over British politics, the man who had redrawn the country’s political map with a vow to “get Brexit done.”

headline: For Nikki Walton, Writing About Hair Was Just Step 1
abstract: At the height of her success as a leader of the natural hair movement for Black women, the author known as CurlyNikki started asking the big questions.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, Nikki Walton had a thriving website, a best-selling book and a schedule packed with promotional events and appearances on TV talk shows. And yet she felt something was wrong.

headline: Biden v. Musk
abstract: The President’s comment on Friday dismissing the billionaire entrepreneur is the latest barb in Biden’s unfortunate feud.
lead_paragraph: Andrew here.

headline: Elon Musk Threatens to End Twitter Deal Without Information on Fake Accounts
abstract: Mr. Musk’s lawyers said Twitter was “actively resisting” his requests.
lead_paragraph: In a crisp, six-paragraph letter to Twitter on Monday, lawyers for Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, made his displeasure known.

headline: Battered by Russian Shells, a Monastery Remains Loyal to Moscow
abstract: The monks and nuns cloistered in a monastery complex in eastern Ukraine absorb daily bombardments from Russian artillery. And yet they remain loyal to the Russian Orthodox Church.
lead_paragraph: SVIATOHIRSK, Ukraine — Of the hundreds of battle sites all across Ukraine, the Sviatohirsk Monastery of the Caves surely ranks among the most incongruous.

headline: Mexico President Will Not Attend Americas Summit in Blow to Biden
abstract: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico said he made the decision because Cuba, Nicaragua and Venezuela were not invited.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In a rebuke to President Biden, the president of Mexico, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, said Monday that he would not attend the Summit of the Americas in Los Angeles after news emerged that the United States would not invite Cuban, Venezuelan and Nicaraguan leaders to the meeting.

headline: High-tech Western Weapons Pose Challenge for Untrained Ukrainian Soldiers
abstract: Ukrainian fighters are getting increasingly sophisticated weaponry from abroad. Some have been reduced to Googling instructions.
lead_paragraph: Staring through the sight attached to an anti-tank gun camouflaged in netting and green underbrush, Junior Sgt. Dmytro Pysanka is greeted with a kaleidoscope of numbers and lines that, if read correctly, should give him the calculations needed to fire at approaching Russian forces.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: A no-recipe meal of steak and fiery fruit salsa, Ali Slagle’s green curry glazed tofu, and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. A friend stopped by the other night with skirt steak, which struck me as a bit like a friend stopping by with a huge tin of caviar. The price of skirt steak keeps ballooning, and inflation isn’t doing us any favors. I hadn’t cooked with it in months. It felt like a rare and lavish treat.

headline: Students, We Want to Hear What You Have to Say About School Shootings
abstract: Opinion wants to know what you are thinking and feeling in the aftermath of school shootings.
lead_paragraph: How many words have adults spoken in the aftermath of mass shootings in America, and are we any safer? Countless words. Countless arguments about gun control and gun violence. Countless thoughts and prayers. Adults have been doing the talking since Buffalo, Uvalde and Tulsa; now it’s time for us to listen too.

headline: A Frozen-Treat Journey Around Los Angeles, in 10 Delicious Stops
abstract: Our critic’s favorite ice creams, paletas, sorbets, shave ices and other summer delights.
lead_paragraph: Every now and then, on a hot day in northeast Los Angeles, you might wish for something sweet and icy and refreshing, and at that exact moment, a raspado vendor will appear. The serendipity of it! Riding in a magnificent converted golf cart, honking the horn as if responding to a local emergency (which he is, in a sense), he carries ice, sorbets, bottles of chamoy sauce and syrups, fruit and a vast array of bagged, spicy snacks to customize your order.

headline: This Optical Illusion Has a Revelation About Your Brain and Eyes
abstract: Your pupils may be dilating when you see images like this one as your brain tries to anticipate the near future.
lead_paragraph: Do not be alarmed.

headline: Mercedes-Benz recalls nearly 1 million vehicles over brake issue.
abstract: The German carmaker said possible corrosion could cause the brakes in two of its S.U.V.s and in a luxury minivan model to malfunction.
lead_paragraph: Mercedes-Benz is recalling nearly one million cars that were sold around the globe between 2004 and 2015 over concerns that the brakes could fail, the company said on Monday.

headline: In Britain, a New Test of an Old Dream: The 4-Day Workweek
abstract: A six-month program involving thousands of workers across 70 companies in Britain will be the latest effort to assess the effects of a shorter workweek.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Thousands of employees across 70 companies in Britain started the first day of a four-day workweek on Monday, a pilot program that is the latest test in the decades-long quest to scale back workers’ hours while they earn the same amount of pay.

headline: A Couples’ Counselor Takes On ‘Normal Marital Hatred’
abstract: In his new book, ‘Us’, Terrence Real explores how ‘enlightened self interest’ could save your relationship.
lead_paragraph: As a family therapist for more than 25 years, Terrence Real sees how often couples fail to compromise or repair damage when things go awry. In his new book “Us: Getting Past You and Me to Build a More Loving Relationship,” he argues it is because we’ve created “a toxic culture of individualism.” We know relationships are hard work, says Mr. Real, who has counseled thousands of couples across the country, including Bruce Springsteen and his wife, Patti Scialfa. “But we don’t know how to deal with that. We don’t teach how to speak with love, how to negotiate, how to deal with grief.”

headline: Sheryl Sandberg’s Advice for Working Women
abstract: Readers discuss what the departing Meta executive’s “lean in” philosophy meant to them. Also: Abortion; sources of morality; the popularity of “Top Gun.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Guerrilla Attacks Signal Rising Resistance to Russian Occupation
abstract: Fueled by brutal Russian repression and worsening humanitarian conditions, Ukrainian partisans appear to be striking deep inside Russian-controlled territory.
lead_paragraph: The Kremlin-backed mayor of the Ukrainian town of Enerhodar  was standing on his mother’s porch when a powerful blast struck, leaving him critically wounded. A week later, about 75 miles away, a car packed with explosives rocked the office of another Russian-appointed official in the occupied southern city of Melitopol.

headline: Harry Styles Repeats at No. 1 With ‘Harry’s House’
abstract: The One Direction singer’s latest solo album is the first since Adele’s “30” to go back-to-back atop the Billboard chart after debuting there.
lead_paragraph: A big week of vinyl sales made “Harry’s House,” the latest solo album by the One Direction singer Harry Styles, the fastest-selling release of the year so far. A lack of new competition kept it at No. 1 for a second week running.

headline: ‘Irma Vep’ Returns, More Meta Than Ever
abstract: In this new HBO series by Olivier Assayas, a continuation of his self-referential cult film from 1996, past and present are inextricably intertwined.
lead_paragraph: Most shows fall within recognizable categories: original stories, spinoffs, docudramas or, increasingly, reboots and revivals.

headline: The Parental Burnout Test
abstract: At what point does the exhaustion working parents feel become something more significant? Take this quiz to find out.
lead_paragraph: At what point does the exhaustion working parents feel become something more significant? Take this quiz to find out.

headline: A Young Horn Player Could Become ‘a Real Legend’
abstract: At 21, Nathaniel Silberschlag landed a principal seat with the storied Cleveland Orchestra. Now tenured, he doesn’t ever want to leave.
