lead_paragraph: Dmitry Kovtun, a former Russian intelligence agent accused of fatally poisoning a fellow ex-spy with green tea laced with radioactive polonium in the bar of a luxury London hotel, died on Saturday in a hospital in Moscow. He was 56.

headline: Why It’s So Hard to Get Cars Off the Road
abstract: If turning a few blocks into a plaza in Berkeley isn’t easy, is there any hope?
lead_paragraph: Several blocks of Telegraph Avenue on the south side of the campus of the University of California, Berkeley, have been a contested space on and off for the past 60 years. In the 1960s, the street became the center of an anarchic West Coast counterculture of hippies, artists and dropouts once described as “the greatest freak show on earth.” In 1969, a group of radicals inspired by the nearby People’s Park fight created the Berkeley Liberation Program and sought to turn the stretch of Telegraph into a “strategic free territory for revolution.”

headline: Ariana DeBose on Hosting the Tonys: ‘Whatever We Do Is Going to Be Fun’
abstract: The Broadway ensemble member turned Oscar winner vows that the ceremony will celebrate the often unsung actors who have stepped in so often during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Ariana DeBose made her Broadway debut as an understudy in the musical adaptation of “Bring It On.”

headline: Ingram Marshall, Minimalist Composer of Mystical Sounds, Dies at 80
abstract: An influential figure in American experimental music, he was part of a group of composers who stripped music down to basic elements and used digital sounds.
lead_paragraph: Ingram Marshall, a minimalist composer known for the mystery and melancholy of his works, which featured sounds as disparate as San Francisco fog horns and Balinese bamboo flutes, died on May 31 in New Haven, Conn. He was 80.

headline: For Summertime Mocktails That Shine, Look to Tea
abstract: With its tannic qualities and endless applications, tea can add much-appreciated complexity to nonalcoholic drinks.
lead_paragraph: In early 2020, I developed long Covid and stopped being able to tolerate alcohol. In my experience, it was among the triggers of relapses so severe I would spend long stretches of time incapacitated with renewed symptoms of extreme fatigue, brain fog, tachycardia and more. As a food and drinks writer, this presented a particularly distressing work challenge: How could I create recipes that I couldn’t always have?

headline: The Precarious Art of Cecilia Vicuña
abstract: Chilean-born, New York-based, she emerges at the Guggenheim after years under the art-market radar with just the right scrappy feel.
lead_paragraph: After the spectacle of high-end hoarding that was this spring’s art fair and auction season, it’s refreshing to find a career survey at the Guggenheim Museum of an artist who has always regarded much of her work as disposable — she refers to one series of sculptures as “basuritas” (little garbages) — and has used it to promote the ideal of a socially and environmentally sustainable world.

headline: DealBook DC Summit
abstract: The DealBook D.C. policy forum brings together leaders to discuss how national policy should evolve.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook D.C. policy forum brings together leaders to discuss how national policy should evolve.

headline: Ingram Marshall Built and Obscured Monoliths of Sound
abstract: The composer and pianist Timo Andres remembers his former teacher, who “gave the impression that all of music was at our feet.”
lead_paragraph: I first came to know the composer Ingram Marshall, who died on May 31 at 80, as a campus personality. Benevolent and slightly spectral, he’d glide into Yale’s music library, where I had a work-study job as an undergraduate student, and I’d help him find scores and recordings. I already knew a few of his pieces, and was a bit awe-struck chatting with their creator. His musical and real-life personalities seemed directly related: unhurried, easygoing, more likely to follow a train of thought than pursue a rigorous argument, but unafraid to let the conversation become serious or philosophical.

headline: Aware of Injuries Inside, Uvalde Police Waited to Confront Gunman
abstract: More than a dozen students remained alive for over an hour before officers entered their classrooms. The commander feared a risk to officers’ lives, new documents show.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — Heavily armed officers delayed confronting a gunman in Uvalde, Texas, for more than an hour even though supervisors at the scene had been told that some trapped with him in two elementary school classrooms needed medical treatment, a new review of video footage and other investigative material shows. Instead, the documents show, they waited for protective equipment to lower the risk to law enforcement officers.

headline: 3 Foreign Fighters in Ukraine’s Army Sentenced to Death in Russian-Held Territory
abstract: Legal experts said the death sentences appeared calculated to discourage foreign volunteers from joining Ukraine’s military.
lead_paragraph: Two Britons and a Moroccan who had fought for the Ukrainian armed forces were sentenced to death Thursday by a court in Russia-occupied eastern Ukraine after being accused of being mercenaries, Russia’s Interfax news agency reported.

headline: Supreme Court Allows Undated Ballots in Pennsylvania Election
abstract: A state law required mailed ballots to be accompanied by a signed and dated declaration, but a federal appeals court ruled that undated declarations sufficed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Thursday that election officials in Pennsylvania may count mailed ballots accompanied by voters’ declarations that were signed but not dated. The court’s order came in a tight race for a seat on a state court, but it is likely to affect other contests in the state as well.

headline: The White House is eager to show that Biden is removed from the Jan. 6 committee’s decision-making.
abstract: When the House committee investigating the Capitol insurrection gavels open its prime-time hearing on Thursday, President Biden will be thousands of miles away, preparing to dine with world leaders in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: When the House committee investigating the Capitol insurrection gavels open its prime-time hearing on Thursday, President Biden will be thousands of miles away, preparing to dine with world leaders in Los Angeles.

headline: Biden and Bolsonaro of Brazil meet for the first time.
abstract: President Jair Bolsonaro addressed concerns about Brazil’s upcoming election, saying he came to power democratically and would leave office the same way.
lead_paragraph: President Biden met for the first time on Thursday with President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil, the leader of the second-largest country in the Western Hemisphere, in a face-to-face discussion that was one of the most anticipated of the ninth Summit of the Americas.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: “Peaky Blinders” is back. Or check out a new AMC thriller starring Zahn McClarnon.
lead_paragraph: ‘Dark Winds’When to watch: Sunday at 9 p.m., on AMC, or on AMC+.

headline: Ranan Lurie, Political Cartoonist With a Global Pen, Dies at 90
abstract: Starting in the Air Force in Israel and later moving to the United States, he set a record as the world’s most widely syndicated in his field.
lead_paragraph: Ranan Lurie, an Israeli war hero and world peacemaker who set records as the world’s most widely syndicated political cartoonist, died on Wednesday in Las Vegas. He was 90.

headline: Iran Begins to Dismantle Nuclear Program Cameras After Western Criticism
abstract: At a moment when experts say Iran is, again, on the verge of possessing enough fuel for a bomb, the dismantling of U.N. cameras was a sign of worsening prospects for the 2015 deal.
lead_paragraph: Iran began dismantling the U.N. monitoring system of its nuclear program this week, partly blinding nuclear inspectors in apparent retaliation for a resolution condemning its lack of cooperation with international inspectors, just at a moment when Tehran is again on the verge of possessing enough fuel for a bomb.

headline: Guantánamo Prisoner Who Completed War Crimes Sentence Sues for Release
abstract: Majid Khan filed a lawsuit against the Biden administration, demanding his transfer to anywhere but his native Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — A Pakistani man who was tortured by the C.I.A. and then pleaded guilty to serving as a courier for Al Qaeda has filed suit against the Biden administration for continuing to hold him prisoner after he completed his war crimes sentence.

headline: New 42 Worker Files Bias Lawsuit Over Diversity Training
abstract: A white teaching artist at the theater organization says it discriminated against white people. The nonprofit declined to comment.
lead_paragraph: A contract worker at a nonprofit New York theater organization has filed a lawsuit saying that the institution’s diversity trainings were themselves discriminatory.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Covid Vaccines, Cancer and Debt
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: ‘Dead Cities’ Become the Flashpoint for the Fierce War in the East
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky has framed the battle in Sievierodonetsk as pivotal to the broader fight for the Donbas. Amid relentless Russian attacks, Ukraine holds on and waits for Western weapons.
lead_paragraph: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — Just to move about town, Ukrainian soldiers accelerate to breakneck speeds in their S.U.V.s, screech around corners, zip into courtyards, then pile out and run for cover.

headline: Republicans Try to Undercut Jan. 6 Committee With Inaccurate Claims
abstract: Before public hearings begin, Republican lawmakers sought to portray the panel as illegitimate.
lead_paragraph: Hours before the House committee investigating the Capitol riot opens its public hearings, Republican lawmakers sought to portray the panel as illegitimate. In a news conference, they denounced the committee’s formation, its work and Speaker Nancy Pelosi with inaccurate claims. Here’s a fact check.

headline: Florida struggled with bad data in the pandemic’s first months, an audit finds.
abstract: Officials and the public “may not have had all the information necessary” to take appropriate actions, the state auditor general’s office found.
lead_paragraph: Florida’s government leaders and residents spent the first months of the pandemic trying to make decisions based on inaccurate or incomplete information, according to a new report by the state auditor general’s office.

headline: Paladino Draws Backlash for Calling Hitler ‘the Kind of Leader We Need’
abstract: Carl Paladino, a Republican House candidate from New York, has been endorsed by Representative Elise Stefanik, a member of party leadership.
lead_paragraph: Carl P. Paladino, a Republican running for a House seat in Western New York, praised Adolf Hitler last year for inspiring his followers, describing the fascist dictator as “the kind of leader we need today.”

headline: Your Friday Briefing: A Crucial Moment in the Ukraine War
abstract: Plus the U.S. begins Jan. 6 hearings and Chinese pilots provoke U.S. allies.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky described the battle for Sievierodonetsk as a crucial moment in what is increasingly a war of attrition in eastern Ukraine. “The fate of our Donbas is being decided there,” he said.

headline: A Saloon for the Downtown Fashion Set
abstract: With the River, a bar in Manhattan’s Chinatown, Emily Bode and Green River Project have expanded their wood-stained empire.
lead_paragraph: Evan Mock, the 25-year-old skateboarder, “Gossip Girl” actor and Calvin Klein model, was cast in amber light, leaning up against a pine wall at the River, a new bar on Bayard Street in Manhattan’s Chinatown.

headline: Sean Thackrey, Creator of Eccentric California Wines, Dies at 79
abstract: A polymath, he dismissed conventional wisdom about varietal wines, terroir and scientific management and won a global following.
lead_paragraph: Sean Thackrey, an autodidactic polymath who, in between collecting antiquarian books, running a San Francisco art gallery and learning five languages, developed a cult following as one of California’s most intriguingly eccentric winemakers, died on May 31 in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 79.

headline: Biden’s Choice to Run the A.T.F. Picks Up Support of 2 Key Democrats
abstract: The backing appears to pave the way for the nominee, Steven Dettelbach, to become the first permanent director of the agency responsible for enforcing gun laws in nearly a decade.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s nominee to run the embattled Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives appears to have secured the 50 votes needed to ensure his confirmation after two conservative Democrats came out in favor of his nomination on Thursday.

headline: A Queer-Film Historian Discusses Movies That Provoke
abstract: Elizabeth Purchell, who has programmed a series on the documentaries of Rosa von Praunheim, sees Pride Month as a chance to discover, and uncover, the past.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Purchell isn’t afraid of “Transexual Menace,” even though she is a transgender woman and the film sounds like the kind of hateful propaganda you’d find for sale at a convention of conspiracy nuts.

headline: How a Highway Divided a Community in Philadelphia
abstract: On a personal episode of “Still Processing,” Wesley Morris revisits a highway that he walked across as a kid. He never knew how deeply it had transformed the neighborhood it ran through.
lead_paragraph: If given the choice to drive or walk, Wesley Morris, Times critic and co-host of “Still Processing,” will always choose to walk. He grew up in Philadelphia, but he resisted getting his driver’s license until the age of 32.

headline: Mysteries Linger About Covid’s Origins, W.H.O. Report Says
abstract: “The lack of political cooperation from China continues to stifle any meaningful progress,” one expert said.
lead_paragraph: In its first report, a team of international scientists assembled by the World Health Organization to advise on the origins of the coronavirus said on Thursday that bats likely carried an ancestor of the coronavirus that may have then spilled over into a mammal sold at a wildlife market. But the team said that more Chinese data was needed to study how the virus spread to people, including the possibility that a lab leak played a role.

headline: NASA Plans to Join U.F.O. Research Efforts
abstract: The truth is out there, and now America’s space agency will add its resources to the study of unidentified aerial phenomena.
lead_paragraph: U.F.O.s almost certainly are not alien visitors buzzing Earth’s skies, but NASA is nonetheless financing a study that will look at unexplained sightings with an open mind.

headline: Reporter Felicia Sonmez Is Fired by The Washington Post
abstract: Ms. Sonmez, a national political reporter, has been at the center of a debate over The Post’s social media policies.
lead_paragraph: Felicia Sonmez, a reporter for The Washington Post who in recent days has been at the center of a debate over the organization’s social media policies and the culture of the newsroom, was fired on Thursday, according to three people with knowledge of the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss personnel matters.

headline: Liz Cheney Takes On Trump, and Her Own Party
abstract: “There will come a day when President Trump is gone,” the Wyoming Republican warned members of her party at the Jan. 6 hearing. “But your dishonor will remain.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Liz Cheney, Republican of Wyoming, had just matter-of-factly rattled off a string of damning revelations illustrating how former President Trump had stoked the mob who attacked the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, when she paused to address the members of her own party who she said were “defending the indefensible.”

headline: Stella Abrera to Run the ABT Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School for a Year
abstract: Abrera, a former principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has been named acting director of the school.
lead_paragraph: Stella Abrera, a former principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has been named acting artistic director of the ABT Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School, the company announced on Thursday. Abrera will oversee all artistic aspects of the school’s children’s division, pre-professional division and national training curriculum.

headline: A War Correspondent’s View
abstract: We talk to Carlotta Gall about the brutal fight in the east.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: The U.S. and Latin American countries will commit to receive more migrants.
abstract: A joint declaration is expected to be issued Friday meant to address surging migration rates that have affected nations throughout the region.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The United States and Latin American countries on Friday plan to issue a joint declaration at the Americas summit, committing nations across the region to receive migrants and provide avenues for them to secure humanitarian protection and earn a living, according to U.S. officials who publicly spoke of the plans Thursday.

headline: Leader of Mexican Church Is Sentenced to 16 Years for Sex Crimes
abstract: Naasón Joaquín García, head of the church La Luz del Mundo, pleaded guilty in Los Angeles to sexually abusing three minors.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The leader of La Luz del Mundo, a Mexico-based church that claims to have more than one million followers worldwide, was sentenced on Wednesday to more than 16 years in prison for sexually abusing three minors.

headline: Justice Dept. Is Investigating Louisiana Police Over Accusations of Abuse
abstract: Similar investigations are underway into the Minneapolis Police Department in connection with the killing of George Floyd and the Louisville Police Department’s actions leading up to the shooting of Breonna Taylor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Thursday opened an investigation into the Louisiana State Police over accusations that officers had engaged in abusive and discriminatory behavior, including the fatal beating of a Black motorist three years ago.

headline: How to Clear a Clogged Drain
abstract: Avoid the chemical cleaners.
lead_paragraph: Avoid the chemical cleaners.

headline: Janet Yellen says the U.S. is likely to avoid a recession.
abstract: While the Treasury secretary predicted rising gas prices, she said strong employment and household finances would avert an economic downturn.

headline: Jamie Raskin: A former impeachment manager plays a key role in the Jan. 6 inquiry.
abstract: Mr. Raskin was the lead impeachment manager in Mr. Trump’s second impeachment trial.
lead_paragraph: Few members of Congress have been as aggressive in trying to hold former President Donald J. Trump accountable for the Capitol riot as Representative Jamie Raskin, Democrat of Maryland.

headline: House Passes Red-Flag Bill as Senate Talks on Gun Violence Continue
abstract: The legislation stands little chance of enactment in its current form, but the idea of incentivizing states to allow guns to be taken from dangerous people is in play in bipartisan Senate talks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday voted nearly along party lines to pass legislation that would allow guns to be temporarily confiscated from people deemed by a federal court to be dangerous, acting a day after it passed a sweeping measure to bar the sale of semiautomatic weapons to people under the age of 21 and ban the sale of large-capacity magazines.

headline: Employee Fatally Shoots 3 at Maryland Manufacturing Plant, Officials Say
abstract: The suspect fled and was caught after exchanging gunfire with a Maryland State Police trooper, the authorities said. Both were injured.
lead_paragraph: An employee opened fire at manufacturing plant in Maryland on Thursday afternoon, killing three co-workers and critically injuring another before he was shot by a state trooper in an exchange of gunfire that left both wounded, the authorities said.

headline: House Again Delays Bill Bolstering Security for Supreme Court Justices
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said a bill to extend protections to the justices’ families and court officers would come to a vote early next week, but Republicans accused her of playing politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats put off consideration of Senate-passed legislation to bolster protections for Supreme Court justices a day after a man armed with a pistol, a knife and other weapons was arrested near the Maryland home of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh.

headline: Zoe Lofgren: An impeachment veteran brings her expertise to the inquiry.
abstract: A close ally of Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California, Ms. Lofgren, first elected to Congress in 1994, is one of four lawyers on the committee.
lead_paragraph: Representative Zoe Lofgren, Democrat of California, has described the attack on the Capitol and the events leading up to it as “more serious than the threat that was posed by Watergate to our country.”

headline: Starbucks’s C.E.O. Howard Schultz: ‘I don’t know if we can keep our bathrooms open.’
abstract: Speaking at The Times’s DealBook D.C. policy forum, Howard Schultz said safety concerns have prompted Starbucks to reconsider its 2018 policy on customer use of restrooms.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks’s chief executive, Howard Schultz, says the company is considering ending its open bathroom policy.

headline: Read an excerpt from the committee chairman’s opening statement.
abstract: “We can’t sweep what happened under the rug,” Representative Bennie Thompson of Mississippi is expected to say in his opening statement.
lead_paragraph: This evening, the opening statement of Representative Bennie Thompson of Mississippi, the chairman of the House committee investigating the Capitol riot, will include the following excerpt:

headline: These G.O.P. Lawmakers Went to D.C. on Jan. 6. Here’s Where They Are Now.
abstract: Twenty-one state legislators joined the crowds in Washington as they sought to overturn the 2020 election. For some, it was a ticket to grass-roots stardom on the right. For others, it was a political dead end.
lead_paragraph: Much of the news coverage of Donald Trump’s attempt to overturn the 2020 election has rightly focused on the machinations in and around the White House. If you haven’t yet, read The New York Times’s big package today pulling together the definitive timeline.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Stephanie Murphy: Her roots in Vietnam fuel a concern for democracy.
abstract: Her family’s escape from a war-torn Vietnam to the United States is part of what has shaped Ms. Murphy’s work on the select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: In spring 2002, Representative Stephanie Murphy, a Florida Democrat who was born in Vietnam, returned to the country for the first time as an adult with her father, as local elections were underway. She was shocked by the propaganda, as well as her relatives’ frank acknowledgment that their votes would not make a difference.

headline: Health officials again warn about possible effects on U.S. virus testing supply without more aid.
abstract: The officials described the consequences of repurposing Department of Health and Human Services funds meant for testing in order to pay for more vaccines and treatments.
lead_paragraph: Federal health officials on Thursday warned of potentially dire consequences to the U.S. coronavirus testing supply later this year if lawmakers do not replenish funding for the federal pandemic response, leaving the nation at risk of shortages and more dependent on foreign manufacturers.

headline: The Proud Boys, who were at the center of the Capitol riot, have a history of street fighting.
abstract: For nearly the entirety of Donald J. Trump’s four years in the White House, the Proud Boys protested — and often brawled — on the streets as part of a never-ending series of culture-war skirmishes. They opposed the removal of Confederate-era statues, the supposed spread of Shariah law and the mass demonstrations that emerged in response to the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: For nearly the entirety of Donald J. Trump’s four years in the White House, the Proud Boys protested — and often brawled — on the streets as part of a never-ending series of culture-war skirmishes. They opposed the removal of Confederate-era statues, the supposed spread of Shariah law and the mass demonstrations that emerged in response to the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis.

headline: Fetish Fashion, the Writhe and Fall
abstract: Megan Thee Stallion, Bella Hadid and Chloë Sevigny appear in a viral video for Mugler. But who’s buying it?
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Mugler released a video for its spring 2022 collection, the final installment in a trilogy of high-octane, super-sexy fashion films directed by Torso Solutions.

headline: Biden Meets With Bolsonaro for First Time Since Taking Office
abstract: At the Summit of the Americas, President Biden and President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil were expected to discuss climate change and the pandemic recovery.
lead_paragraph: At the Summit of the Americas, President Biden and President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil were expected to discuss climate change and the pandemic recovery.

headline: The committee hired a TV executive to produce the hearings for maximum impact.
abstract: It has brought on a veteran TV executive James Goldston to produce the hearings.
lead_paragraph: For almost a year, the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol has been painstakingly collecting interviews with 1,000 witnesses and producing over 140,000 documents.

headline: How to Avoid Nasty Pool Germs This Summer
abstract: Some watering holes are riskier than others.
lead_paragraph: Our local water park opened over Memorial Day weekend, and of course the kids begged us to take them. My husband and I easily relented — we enjoy zipping down water slides on hot days, too — but it was as crowded as we’d ever seen it. Eyeing the wave pool as it teemed with sweaty adults and snot-encrusted kids, I couldn’t help but wonder what kinds of gross germs lurked in it. And what about other crowded pools and lakes in the summertime — are they more like cesspools than swimming pools?

headline: Crime and Political Punishment
abstract: Voters are justifiably upset, but they’ll probably support the wrong people.
lead_paragraph: Results from Tuesday’s primaries in California suggest that crime may be a big issue in the midterm elections. In San Francisco, a progressive prosecutor was ousted in a recall vote. In Los Angeles, a businessman and former Republican who has run for mayor on the promise to be a big crime fighter made a strong showing.

headline: Biden, Looking for Unity, Faces Criticism From Latin American Leaders
abstract: The U.S. president called for concrete commitments on several major issues, but other leaders said the United States is doing too little to meet the moment.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — President Biden on Thursday promised aggressive new leadership to confront economic despair and mass migration in Latin America, but his pledge was met with skepticism from the leaders in the region, who said the United States is doing too little to meet the grim moment of a global crisis.

headline: Democrats Failed to Extend Assault Weapons Ban in 2004. They Regret It.
abstract: A push to renew the ban is so unlikely to succeed that one Democratic aide likened it to trying to jam the world’s biggest genie back into the world’s smallest bottle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In late 1993, Democrats were on the cusp of a legislative triumph that seems inconceivable in today’s polarized debate over gun control: They were about to outlaw an entire class of firearms — semiautomatic assault rifles — as part of a big bipartisan crime bill.

headline: In videotaped testimony, Barr dismissed Trump’s claims of fraud.
abstract: Trump’s last Senate-confirmed attorney general recalled how he had told the president he considered it “bullshit” and wanted no part of it.
lead_paragraph: Representative Bennie Thompson, Democrat of Mississippi, opened the hearing by calling the actions of former President Donald J. Trump an “attempted coup,” laying out starkly the threat that the country faced on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Bill Cosby’s Lawyers Present His Defense in Sex Assault Lawsuit
abstract: Judy Huth has accused Mr. Cosby of sexually assaulting her 47 years ago, when she was 16, but an expert witness for the defense testified that memories can become distorted over time.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby’s lawyers presented expert testimony about memory at a civil trial in California on Thursday as they tried to discredit a woman’s account of what she said was a sexual assault by Mr. Cosby some 47 years ago.

headline: Pete Aguilar: A top messaging official was drafted for the inquiry.
abstract: Drafted for the committee by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Mr. Aguilar has risen to become vice chairman of the House Democratic Caucus and the highest-ranking Latino in Congress.
lead_paragraph: When Representative Pete Aguilar, Democrat of California, hears Republican critics argue that the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol does not serve a legitimate purpose, he bristles.

headline: Jan. 6 Committee Plays Testimony From Ivanka Trump
abstract: In a videotaped testimony, Ivanka Trump, the former president’s daughter, said that she “accepted” former Attorney General William P. Barr’s assessment dismissing Donald J. Trump’s claims of election fraud.
lead_paragraph: In a videotaped testimony, Ivanka Trump, the former president’s daughter, said that she “accepted” former Attorney General William P. Barr’s assessment dismissing Donald J. Trump’s claims of election fraud.

headline: Kushner Says He Dismissed White House Counsel’s Threats to Resign
abstract: In videotaped testimony, Jared Kushner, former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law and a senior adviser, said he took the threats as “whining.”
lead_paragraph: In videotaped testimony, Jared Kushner, former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law and a senior adviser, said he took the threats as “whining.”

headline: Kushner said he thought White House counsel was ‘whining’ when he spoke of resigning.
abstract: Jared Kushner, former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, was featured prominently in videotaped testimony saying that he was engrossed in pushing through dozens of pardons at the end of the administration and dismissed threats of resigning by the White House counsel as “whining.”
lead_paragraph: Jared Kushner, former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, was featured prominently in videotaped testimony saying that he was engrossed in pushing through dozens of pardons at the end of the administration and dismissed threats of resigning by the White House counsel as “whining.”

headline: Man Pleads Guilty to Selling $2.7 Million Worth of Unregistered Covid Pesticide
abstract: Paul Andrecola, a 63-year-old New Jersey chemist, sold pesticides that had not been registered with the Environmental Protection Agency. Some of his customers were federal agencies.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey man admitted in federal court on Thursday to illegally selling $2.7 million worth of pesticides that he falsely claimed had been registered with the Environmental Protection Agency as effective safeguards against the coronavirus.

headline: Caroline Edwards: The first Capitol Police officer injured in the riot has said, ‘I’ve never experienced anything like it.’
abstract: She was struck during an assault at a barricade at the base of Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: After Capitol Police Officer Caroline Edwards suffered a concussion during the mob attack on Congress on Jan. 6, 2021, she didn’t stay down long.

headline: Nick Quested: A documentary filmmaker who had embedded with the Proud Boys is now in the spotlight.
abstract: Mr. Quested began spending time with the Proud Boys after the election as part of a project meant to explore the increasing polarization and extremism in American politics.
lead_paragraph: As a documentary filmmaker, Nick Quested has made a career of telling other people’s stories — many of them under harsh conditions. Over the years, he has made films about soldiers under fire in Afghanistan and the inner workings of a Mexican drug cartel.

headline: Fox News gives its viewers a revisionist history lesson of Jan. 6.
abstract: Tucker Carlson said the Capitol Riot was “forgettably minor.”
lead_paragraph: Despite not broadcasting the Jan. 6 hearing live, Fox News was conducting a Jan. 6 inquiry of sorts itself on Thursday night, one that the host Tucker Carlson said would reveal the truth about the event he said “was not an insurrection.”

headline: First-Pass Friday: The Only Way Out Is Through
abstract: It took me forever to break into Blake Slonecker’s puzzle, but it was worth it. The key is not giving up.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Welcome to another First-Pass Friday, the occasional column where I show you how I got my start in a New York Times crossword. More often than not, I actually show you how I didn’t get much of a start, because even someone who has solved crossword puzzles every day for the past decade can still completely miss the boat. If I do this correctly, you should feel reassured about your own solving. No, don’t thank me. I’m a giver.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Sam Ezersky scrambles up a twisty Sunday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Yeow, this puzzle is tough; at every turn, there’s a clue that looks incomprehensible and requires consideration to interpret, let alone to solve. I expect as much from Sam Ezersky, who has been on a streak of devilishly difficult weekend constructions for the daily and variety puzzles.

headline: Jared and Ivanka, Without the Power or the Masks
abstract: In stark videotaped interviews, Ivanka Trump accepted the notion that there had been no fraud in the 2020 election. Jared Kushner complained that a White House counsel had been “whining.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They were stripped of their White House backdrop, their power and their masks.

headline: Three Characters at the Heart of an Unsettling Jan. 6 Narrative
abstract: The House committee built the story it laid out around Donald Trump, the Proud Boys and a Capitol Police officer, drawing clear contrasts along the way.
lead_paragraph: At the heart of the Jan. 6 committee’s presentation Thursday night was a gripping story with a sprawling cast of characters, but only three main players.

headline: Song Hae, Who Survived War and Poverty to Become a Beloved TV Host, Dies at 95
abstract: Born in what is now North Korea, he was known for his cheeky grin and folksy wisecracks as the host of South Korea’s weekly “National Singing Contest” for more than three decades.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — Song Hae, who fled North Korea as a young man during the Korean War and became a beloved television personality in South Korea, recognized by Guinness World Records as the world’s “oldest TV music talent show host,” died on Wednesday at his home  here. He was 95.

headline: Trump Is Depicted as a Would-Be Autocrat Seeking to Hang Onto Power at All Costs
abstract: As the Jan. 6 committee outlined during its prime-time hearing, Donald J. Trump executed a seven-part conspiracy to overturn a free and fair democratic election.
lead_paragraph: In the entire 246-year history of the United States, there was surely never a more damning indictment presented against an American president than outlined on Thursday night in a cavernous congressional hearing room where the future of democracy felt on the line.

headline: Jan. 6 Committee Blames Trump for Attack on Capitol
abstract: Representatives Bennie Thompson, Democrat of Mississippi, and Liz Cheney, Republican of Wyoming, led the first hearing on the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, which included testimony from a Capitol police officer and a documentary filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: Representatives Bennie Thompson, Democrat of Mississippi, and Liz Cheney, Republican of Wyoming, led the first hearing on the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, which included testimony from a Capitol police officer and a documentary filmmaker.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Russia and Ukraine are struggling to control “dead cities.”
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky described the battle for Sievierodonetsk as a crucial moment in what is increasingly a war of attrition in eastern Ukraine. “The fate of our Donbas is being decided there,” he said.

headline: Brought Together by Dance, and Undeterred by Distance
abstract: About a year after Drs. Maya Kailas and Amit Kohli met as members of a college dance team, they started dating and became “inseparable.” Then he graduated.
lead_paragraph: In July 2019, after six years of long-distance dating, Drs. Maya Kailas and Amit Kohli were finally in the same city. Yet even though they shared an apartment in Manhattan, they still faced similar struggles when it came to finding time to see each other.

headline: A Hot Priest? Definitely a ‘Handsome’ One.
abstract: Annalise Deal and Kevin Neil met for coffee to discuss becoming Episcopal priests. The spirit also moved them to start dating.
lead_paragraph: Neither Kevin Gordon Neil nor Annalise Brittany Deal were looking for romance when they were introduced by a mutual friend in February 2020.

headline: On Their First Night Out, He Spilled His Guts
abstract: Bianca Chavez and Stefan Norgaard, both Stanford graduates, met at the start of college in 2011. Their first interaction outside of class was not exactly romantic.
lead_paragraph: If there was a registry for stupendously awful meet-cutes, the one between Bianca Larez Chavez and Stefan Peter Norgaard could certainly be included.

headline: Despite a ‘Microscope Incident,’ Two Med Students Match
abstract: After an awkward encounter in their first year at Harvard Medical School, Drs. Ginger Jiang and José Orozco got a second chance at a connection.
lead_paragraph: Drs. Ginger Yu Fei Jiang and José Miguel Orozco didn’t quite hit it off after they were accidentally assigned the same microscope in pathology class during their first year at Harvard Medical School in 2013.

headline: After a ‘Raucous’ Start, a ‘Miss Guided’ Proposal
abstract: When Paul Harris Jr. met Allison Strickman, he was a few beers deep and left her unimpressed. They reconnected months later, and their ensuing courtship culminated on a boat called “Miss Guided.”
lead_paragraph: Though Allison Leigh Strickman’s first impression of Paul Clinton Harris Jr. was memorable, it was for reasons that Mr. Harris might have preferred she forget.

headline: Singleness Is Not a Stigma
abstract: It’s time we stop privileging romantic connections over all others.
lead_paragraph: In Yoruba, my native language where I grew up in Nigeria, my first name means “love,” but I have yet to experience love, the romantic kind. I want to love, to be loved, to witness a shower of affection beyond declarations or a supposed responsibility, but I remain unmoored by the prospect of romance.

headline: Fitting Into His Schedule, Then Into Her Royal Family
abstract: Jamal Akil Robinson offered just 30 minutes for his first meeting with Edna Tafari Makonnen who, unknown to him, was an Ethiopian princess. When it ran to an hour, he saw it as a good sign.
lead_paragraph: Edna Tafari Makonnen and Jamal Akil Robinson initially struggled to find equal social footing when they got together for coffee in February 2015. That she is royalty was not the problem.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Low Pay Is Thinning Staff at Public Defender Offices, Straining Those Who Stay
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 10, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Budgets are values. If you’re worried about staffing N.Y.P.D. and staffing up corrections, but you’re not worried about staffing up the public defenders, you’ve got a value problem.”

headline: Corrections: June 10, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, June 10, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on April 29 about 16 states that sued the Postal Service for failing to properly vet clean alternatives to gas-powered mail trucks misstated the agency that brought to light the poor gas mileage of new Postal Service vehicles. It was the Postal Service itself, not the Environmental Protection Agency, that found that the trucks would achieve only 14.7 miles to the gallon, or 8.6 miles per gallon when using air conditioning.

headline: Chair Stalking Returns to Bryant Park as Midtown Begins to Perk Up
abstract: Despite the patchy way in which workers are going back to their offices, the heart of New York City is starting to resemble itself in some ways.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at the unevenness of R.T.O. — return to office — and what it means for New York.

headline: When Cockatoos Become Cocka-Too Much
abstract: The native Australian birds are charismatic and deeply destructive.
lead_paragraph: The Australia Letter is a weekly newsletter from our Australia bureau. Sign up here to receive it by email.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the First Jan. 6 Hearing
abstract: The committee’s leaders laid out what they described as an intentional scheme with Donald J. Trump at the center. Videotaped testimony showed that key figures surrounding the president didn’t believe the lie of a stolen election.
lead_paragraph: The opening House hearing into the events surrounding the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol was a compact and controlled two hours, designed as an overview of what was described as a methodical conspiracy, led and coordinated by President Donald J. Trump, to thwart the peaceful transfer of power and democracy itself.

headline: Stephen Colbert Recaps ‘Episode One’ of the Jan. 6 Hearings
abstract: He called the prime time congressional hearings “this summer’s most compelling drama.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A ‘Strange’ Wind Blowing: Tony Voters Like ‘Loop’ and ‘Lehman’
abstract: We surveyed voters ahead of this year’s ceremony on Sunday. They are strikingly split in the races for leading musical performers.
lead_paragraph: After a strange year on Broadway, it looks as if it could be a “Strange” night at the Tony Awards.

headline: Lessons From Henry Ford About Today’s Supply Chain Mess
abstract: The automobile pioneer believed short-term interests must not squeeze out investment in a business’ resilience, a lesson many companies have learned the hard way since 2020.
lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — Henry Ford, the godfather of mass production, was tormented by the possibility of running out of parts and raw materials. Suspicious of financiers — a spirit that animated his fervent antisemitism — he was especially distrustful of his suppliers. He was consumed with stockpiling enough materials to ensure that his assembly lines could continue operating without debilitating shortages.

headline: Inflation is expected to have remained elevated in May as gas, rent and other prices surged.
abstract: The government is expected to report on Friday that consumer prices climbed by 8.2 percent in the year through May, as inflation hovers near the fastest rate in four decades.
lead_paragraph: The government is expected to report on Friday that consumer prices climbed by 8.2 percent in the year through May, as inflation hovers near the fastest rate in four decades.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including a review of "Jurassic World Dominion."
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including a review of "Jurassic World Dominion."

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, June 10, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Sexual Justice’ and ‘Last Call’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: SEXUAL JUSTICE: Supporting Victims, Ensuring Due Process, and Resisting the Conservative Backlash, by Alexandra Brodsky. (Metropolitan, 336 pp., $18.99.) In the words of our reviewer, Michelle Goldberg, Brodsky’s treatise on handling sexual assault allegations is a “practical, lawyerly work” and a refreshing intervention into debates about standards of evidence and the protections that students should be afforded.

headline: Three Critical Lessons of the Watergate Hearings That the Jan. 6 Committee Should Learn
abstract: How do you take a complex, amorphous series of events, with a wide, confusing cast of characters, and translate it to the American people?
lead_paragraph: The Jan. 6 committee kicked off Thursday night with a powerful first hearing, complete with compelling witnesses, video clips of depositions and stunning footage of the violence that unfolded at the Capitol as Congress tried to certify the electoral vote. It came almost a half-century after the nation was captivated by a summer’s worth of Senate Watergate hearings — a cinematic 1973 drama packed with eye-opening revelations that ultimately helped unravel Richard Nixon’s presidency.

headline: It’s Hard to Believe That China Is Moving Forward When You’re Trapped in Your Apartment
abstract: Recovering from this breach of public trust won’t be easy.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — In late March, Shanghai’s government assured us that there would be no Covid lockdown. Our city, China’s largest and most vibrant, was far too important for that.

headline: Why It Matters That the Jan. 6 Hearings Put ‘a War Scene’ on Display
abstract: The spectacle is the message.
lead_paragraph: There is every reason to be skeptical, even cynical, about the effect and impact of the Jan. 6 hearings on the political landscape.

headline: Spring Awakening
abstract: Rachel Carson, the power of wonder, and me.
lead_paragraph: The ocean was not the native habitat of Rachel Carson. She was born amid the tumbled hills near Pittsburgh, in Springdale, one of many western Pennsylvania hamlets that took root by a river and experienced a fleeting industrial heyday. Soon after I moved to this region I visited her birthplace on a pilgrimage of sorts, one I recently undertook again. Carson helped shape my worldview and values. An expert on the sea, through her vision of the operatic grandeur of evolution she gave context to my landlubber rambles. Childless herself, she helped frame my notions about parenting.

headline: It’s Not Just the Story of Drag in Brooklyn, It’s the Story of America
abstract: Nicole Pasulka’s new history of drag in Brooklyn, “How You Get Famous,” closely follows a handful of queens to explore the cultural and business evolution of the drag industry.
lead_paragraph: HOW YOU GET FAMOUS: Ten Years of Drag Madness in Brooklyn, by Nicole Pasulka

headline: ‘The Wire’ in Five Scenes
abstract: Cast members look back at some of the HBO drama’s most pivotal moments 20 years after its premiere.
lead_paragraph: From its premiere in June 2002 to its final episode in March 2008, “The Wire” told a sweeping story of crime, punishment and institutional disintegration in Baltimore. It was the components of that saga — the people, the moments — that made it unforgettable, scenes depicting the human consequences of civic collapse as well as the occasional hard-won triumph.

headline: Hugh Dancy Is Ready to Skate Again
abstract: The “ridiculously handsome” British actor stars in the revived “Law & Order” and a “Downton Abbey” film.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Dancy flew around the rink, gliding from one foot to the next atop the black matting. The wind tousled his hair, the pattern on his houndstooth blazer blurring as he picked up speed.

headline: What Supporters of Gun Rights Mean When They Talk About ‘Evil’
abstract: Christian theology teaches that societies — not just individuals — bear responsibility for evil.
lead_paragraph: Greg Abbott, the governor of Texas, began his news conference on the day of the Uvalde massacre not with policy but theology. He said, “Evil swept across Uvalde today. Anyone who shoots his grandmother in the face must have evil in his heart, but it is far more evil for someone to gun down little kids.”

headline: Hawa’s Hip-Hop Journey from the Philharmonic to Fashion
abstract: The classically trained rapper has modeled for Telfar, Burberry and North Face.
lead_paragraph: Name: Hawa

headline: How to Avoid a City Pool for Only $150 a Day
abstract: Pools were once the great social unifier of New York. The current vogue for high-priced day passes at rooftop hotel pools changes the equation.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday afternoon in midsummer “when everyone sits around saying ‘I drank too much last night,’” Neddy Merrill, the doomed protagonist of John Cheever’s seminal 1964 short story, “The Swimmer,” sets out to make his way across his patch of well-heeled suburbia by water, traveling from pool to pool in what becomes an act of haunting self-realization.

headline: When a Night on the Town Means Drinking, Dancing and Death
abstract: In “Last Call at the Nightingale,” a fizzy detective novel set in Prohibition-era Manhattan, a champagne-soaked evening at a speakeasy ends in murder.
lead_paragraph: Vivian Kelly, the heroine of Katharine Schellman’s fizzy series debut, LAST CALL AT THE NIGHTINGALE (Minotaur, 312 pp., $27.99), longs for escape. It’s Manhattan, 1924, not long after women gained the right to vote and lost the right to drink alcohol. The Jazz Age giveth and taketh away, but Vivian, a seamstress with an adventurous streak, doesn’t know that yet.

headline: Blood Tests That Detect Cancers Create Risks for Those Who Use Them
abstract: The tests screen for cancers that often go undetected, but they are expensive and some experts worry they could lead to unnecessary treatments without saving patients’ lives.
lead_paragraph: Jim Ford considers himself a lucky man: An experimental blood test found his pancreatic cancer when it was at an early stage. It is among the deadliest of all common cancers and is too often found too late.

headline: Two Men of the Jungle Meet in Herzog’s First Novel
abstract: In “The Twilight World,” the filmmaker Werner Herzog vividly reconstructs the personal war of Hiroo Onoda, who stayed in the jungle for years after World War II ended.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years ago in Tokyo, where he had come to direct the world premiere of the opera “Chushingura,” the German filmmaker Werner Herzog received an enviable invitation. At a dinner of the cast and crew, the opera’s composer greeted Herzog with the thrilling news that the emperor of Japan would welcome a private audience with him. “My goodness, I have no idea what I would talk about with the emperor,” Herzog responded. The room froze. “I wish to this day that the earth had swallowed me up,” Herzog recalls dramatically in his first novel, “The Twilight World” — a book in which, his epigraph explains, “most details are factually correct; some are not.” When a guest broke the silence to ask if there was anyone in Japan he would, in fact, like to meet, Herzog answered: “Onoda.” He elaborated: “Hiroo Onoda.”

headline: Socialism Is Supposed to Be a Working-Class Movement. Why Isn’t It?
abstract: Bhaskar Sunkara explains the reasons for the progressive left’s setbacks in winning power — and elections — in America.
lead_paragraph: American socialists today find themselves in a tenuous position. Over the past decade, the left has become a powerful force in American politics. Bernie Sanders seriously contested two presidential primaries. Democratic socialists have won local, state and congressional races. Organizations like Democratic Socialists of America and socialist publications like Jacobin have become part of the political conversation.

headline: Hoax Shooting Threats Rattle New York Schools
abstract: A tactic using social media sites to direct threats at individual students has unsettled schools in New York City and around the country.
lead_paragraph: A 14-year-old freshman at Murrow High School in Brooklyn was sitting in history class one April morning when she got a string of chilling texts from a friend. A threat to shoot up the school had been posted on the chat site Omegle — and it included a list of about a dozen students who would be killed. One of them was the 14-year-old girl.

headline: The Johnny Appleseed of Sugar Kelp
abstract: The quest of a Long Island seaweed farmer to make kelp the next kale.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Doall was a teenager, he hated seaweed, and so did everybody else he knew on Long Island. It was an icky nuisance that brushed against your legs at the beach, fouled your fishing hook and got tangled around the propeller of your boat. Only later, as a marine scientist and oyster farmer, did he develop a love for sugar kelp, a disappearing native species that is one of the most useful seaweeds. Now he is on a mission to bring it back to the waters of New York.

headline: How a Playwright and Memoirist Spends His Sundays
abstract: Every weekend, Alvin Eng revisits his past by strolling through Chinatown and the East Village.
lead_paragraph: The playwright and storyteller Alvin Eng grew up with five siblings in a house near the family’s business, the Foo J. Chin Chinese Hand Laundry in Flushing, Queens. Sunday, the only day the laundry was closed, was a big deal, as he recounts in his new memoir, “Our Laundry, Our Town: My Chinese American Life From Flushing to the Downtown Stage and Beyond.”

headline: A Chinese Entrepreneur Who Says What Others Only Think
abstract: Already a maverick in business circles, Zhou Hang has dared to openly criticize the government’s zero Covid policy — and urges his peers to speak out, too.
lead_paragraph: China’s entrepreneur class is grappling with the worst economic slump in decades as the government’s zero Covid policy has shut down cities and kept would-be customers at home. Yet they can’t seem to agree on how loudly they should complain — or even whether they should at all.

headline: Not Just a Fence: The Story of a Stainless Steel Status Symbol
abstract: Like the white picket fence, the stainless steel fence — prevalent in New York neighborhoods densely populated by Asian homeowners — evokes a sense of making it, but it’s flashier.
lead_paragraph: On the residential streets of Flushing, Queens, and Sunset Park, Brooklyn, steel fences line almost every other house. They’re silver, sometimes embellished with gold, and they’re in striking contrast to the modest brick and vinyl-clad houses that they encircle, like a diamond necklace worn atop an old white T-shirt.

headline: Some Monarch Butterfly Populations Are Rising. Is It Enough to Save Them?
abstract: Not all scientists agree with the findings of a new study, which seem likely to fuel an ongoing debate about the threats the butterflies face.
lead_paragraph: Every autumn, swarms of migrating monarchs descend on the mountains of central Mexico. It is the final stop on a journey of thousands of miles, as the butterflies travel from their North American breeding grounds to their winter colonies, where they blanket fir trees. Visitors who time their trips correctly might find the air so thick with monarchs that they can hear the butterflies’ wings beating.

headline: Food Export Bans in Asia Prompt Fears of More Protectionism
abstract: Restricted so far in the name of domestic food security: Indian wheat, Malaysian chicken and Indonesian cooking oil. Experts warn of unwanted consequences.
lead_paragraph: As Russia’s invasion of Ukraine helped push global agricultural prices to soaring heights, some Asian governments restricted the export of products they viewed as essential to domestic food security.

headline: ‘We Are Still in Shock’: A Month Trapped in a Basement by Russian Forces
abstract: More than 300 Ukrainians, 77 of them children, were imprisoned in a dank and airless school basement for nearly a month. Ten of them died.
lead_paragraph: YAHIDNE, Ukraine — More than two months after the residents of Yahidne kicked down the bolted basement door where the Russian army had held them hostage, the village is being rebuilt but the memories remain fresh — and deeply painful.

headline: The Bumpy Road to a Group-Led Documenta
abstract: The 2022 edition of this exhibition in Germany is curated by a leaderless collective. Things didn’t always go to plan.
lead_paragraph: KASSEL, Germany — Every five years, the international art world descends on this orderly, prosperous city for Documenta, considered the world’s most important contemporary art exhibition.

headline: Klaus Mäkelä, 26, Takes Podium at Storied Concertgebouw Orchestra
abstract: The Finnish maestro, a rapidly rising star in classical music, has been named the new chief conductor of the 133-year-old Amsterdam ensemble.
lead_paragraph: Klaus Mäkelä, a 26-year-old Finnish maestro on a rapid rise, will be the next chief conductor of the storied Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra in Amsterdam, the ensemble announced on Friday, after a several-year search following the dismissal of Daniele Gatti over sexual assault allegations in 2018.

headline: The major tourist draws of San Juan, and Miami-Dade and Honolulu counties, have become virus hot spots.
abstract: “Covid-19 hasn’t disappeared as much as our patience for precautions has,” said one public health expert.
lead_paragraph: The three sizable urban centers in the United States where the coronavirus is spreading fastest right now have something in common: They are major warm-weather tourist destinations.

headline: How Inflation May Change Where You Put Your Cash
abstract: At last, interest rates for money market funds have started to rise. But inflation means that in real terms, you’re still losing money.
lead_paragraph: The stock market hasn’t provided much joy, bonds have been a source of considerable pain and inflation is troubling.

headline: The Real Meaning of Chesa Boudin’s Recall
abstract: Much of the reaction to the ousting of San Francisco’s progressive district attorney may be a misreading of the moment.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language.

headline: Rangers Cede Control of Conference Finals to the Lightning
abstract: New York has come back throughout the playoffs, and will have to again on Saturday in Tampa with the Lightning one win from a third consecutive trip to the Stanley Cup Finals.
lead_paragraph: Though they were facing the two-time defending champion Tampa Bay Lightning, and though they had needed seven games to advance from each of the first two rounds of the playoffs, the Rangers always had a trump card in their pocket: Fortress Madison Square Garden.

headline: How Liberal Are the Movies?: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: How inflation became a global problem.
abstract: Factors that were expected to fade have become stubbornly entrenched.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has caused inflation to become stubbornly entrenched in countries around the globe.

headline: Why the Hearings Matter
abstract: Even if the Jan. 6 attack will not become a unifying moment for the country.
lead_paragraph: The opportunity for the Jan. 6 attack to serve as a unifying moment for the country has already been lost.

headline: Expert Picks: Who Will Win the Belmont Stakes?
abstract: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert assess the contenders for the 154th Belmont Stakes on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Rich Strike, the 80-1 shot ridden by Sonny Leon and trained by Eric Reed, mounted a furious and improbable rally to capture the 148th Kentucky Derby on May 7. He was not even in the field until another horse was scratched the day before the race.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 1: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by June 17 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on June 28.
lead_paragraph: Update, June 28: Week One winners have been announced!

headline: Markets Recoil as Inflation Report Raises Stakes for Fed
abstract: The data suggested that policymakers would need to take aggressive steps to cool the economy, spooking investors.
lead_paragraph: Stubbornly high inflation has loomed over the stock market for months, but some investors had started to think that the worst was over. They cited scattered signs of moderation in price increases and a belief that policymakers could rein them in without sinking the economy.

headline: If You’re Looking for Thor, Check the Beach
abstract: His outrageous fastball may never come back, but Noah Syndergaard is enjoying his new life with the Los Angeles Angels, on and off the field.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Those who vividly remember Noah Syndergaard on top of the mountain, hair flying and fastball sizzling, may not recognize the 2022 version of the man they called Thor.

headline: We’ve Added More Songs to the California Soundtrack
abstract: Our never-ending pursuit for a playlist that perfectly captures the Golden State.
lead_paragraph: It’s Friday. We’ve added more of your picks to our Golden State playlist. Plus, triple-digit temperatures are expected in large swaths of California.

headline: Inflation Sped Up Again in May, Dashing Hopes for Relief
abstract: The Consumer Price Index picked up by 8.6 percent, as price increases climbed at the fastest pace in more than 40 years.
lead_paragraph: A surge in prices in May delivered a blow to President Biden and underscored the immense challenge facing the Federal Reserve as inflation, which many economists had expected to show signs of cooling, instead reaccelerated to climb at its fastest pace since late 1981.

headline: You’re Never Too Young for a Roth I.R.A.
abstract: But there are rules around opening one for a child. First: The child must have earned income.
lead_paragraph: Has your teenager landed a summer job? Good! Now, consider putting your child’s earnings to work long term by opening a Roth individual retirement account.

headline: Report Reveals Sharp Rise in Transgender Young People in the U.S.
abstract: New estimates based on C.D.C. health surveys point to a stark generational shift in the growth of the transgender population of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The number of young people who identify as transgender has nearly doubled in recent years, according to a new report that captures a stark generational shift and emerging societal embrace of a diversity of gender identities.

headline: What Is LIV Golf? It Depends Whom You Ask.
abstract: Bold new project or crass money grab? Even golf’s best players can’t agree on the new Saudi-financed golf tour. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The new Saudi-financed, controversy-trailed LIV Golf series, which is holding its first event this week at an exclusive club north of London, is the talk of golf. Not always, though, in the ways its organizers had hoped.

headline: No Relief in Sight for Prices
abstract: The outlook for the U.S. economy and more at DealBook’s D.C. summit
lead_paragraph: The latest Consumer Price Index showed a re-acceleration in inflation, dashing hopes that price increases were moderating. The government  reported that consumer prices climbed by 8.6 percent in the year through May,  writes The Times’s Jeanna Smialek. Fed officials are watching for signs that inflation is cooling on a monthly basis as they try to guide price increases back down to their goal, but today’s report offered more reason for worry than comfort. The headline inflation rate was the fastest since late 1981, as a broad array of products and services including rents, gas, used cars, and food became sharply more expensive.

headline: Pope Francis Postpones Trip to Africa, Citing Knee Problems
abstract: The postponement of the trip to the Democratic Republic of Congo and South Sudan comes as speculation swirls that the pontiff may be thinking of stepping down.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The Vatican said Friday that Pope Francis would postpone a trip to Africa because of problems with his knee, an announcement that came as speculation swirls that the pontiff may be planning to follow in the steps of his predecessor and step down.

headline: U.S. Warns China on Taiwan as Defense Officials Meet to Cool Tensions
abstract: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III accused Beijing of “provocative” activity near the disputed island after meeting with his Chinese counterpart.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III warned China on Saturday against what he called “provocative and destabilizing” activity near the disputed island of Taiwan, following talks with China’s defense minister, Gen. Wei Fenghe, that focused on preventing regional tensions from escalating into crises.

headline: A Conductor’s Tumultuous, Invaluable Tenure Ends in Minnesota
abstract: After 19 years, Osmo Vänskä is leaving a Minnesota Orchestra that once again stands proud after a nearly disastrous lockout.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Osmo Vänskä has said goodbye to the Minnesota Orchestra once before. But this time, it’s for real.

headline: In the Club and the Clubhouse, a Coach Adds Some Flavor
abstract: His passion is playing percussion at salsa clubs, but Charlie Montoyo also thrives at his day job: managing the Toronto Blue Jays.
lead_paragraph: The salsa band was 45 minutes into their first set at Lula Lounge on a recent Saturday when Charlie Montoyo showed up at the front door. An owner of the music club spotted Montoyo and led him and his group to a table reserved for them closest to the stage.

headline: John Waters, an Auteur of Trash, Would Like to Thank the Academy
abstract: Curators from the new Academy Museum of Motion Pictures rummaged through his Baltimore home to plan an exhibition on Waters and his cult films.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — John Waters was leading a delegation from the Academy Museum of Motion Pictures — in for the week from Los Angeles — on a tour of his home of 32 years, cluttered with film artifacts and kitschy curios and tucked behind trees on a quiet corner five miles from this city’s waterfront.

headline: Beauty and the Beasts
abstract: In Jo Rioux’s “The Golden Twine,” an orphan girl who lives among traveling merchants aspires to be a monster tamer.
lead_paragraph: During a book giveaway at my daughter’s school, shrieking children swarm tables of books: “Are you sure it’s free?” “I can just have it?” “This is the best day of my life!” (Actual quotes. I’m going to mark that last one down as hyperbole.)

headline: Aliens Among Us
abstract: Liam Francis Walsh’s graphic novel “Red Scare” revisits a chapter in American history when the fear of being labeled a communist led to rampant conformism.
lead_paragraph: Liam Francis Walsh’s masterly graphic novel debut, “Red Scare,” takes place in the fictional town of Clinker’s Corners at the height of the Cold War, when most Americans believed communists had infiltrated their institutions and neighborhoods. Ironically, anyone with a different set of values was considered an enemy, bringing the American way of life dangerously close to the Soviet way of life. The fear of being accused of communist affiliation resulted in a conformist attitude that spread across American society. Outward “normalcy” became the only acceptable form of social behavior.

headline: Rents climbed, a pain for tenants and policymakers alike.
abstract: Housing costs make up a big part of the overall inflation index, so they are keeping pressure on prices overall.
lead_paragraph: The cost of renting an apartment or home is climbing quickly, keeping inflation high and making life tougher for households on a tight budget.

headline: Test to Return to the U.S. by Air Will Be Dropped
abstract: In a move hailed by the travel industry, starting Sunday morning passengers will be able to board flights to the U.S. without a negative coronavirus test.
lead_paragraph: As coronavirus policies and masking rules around the world faded away in recent months, one major mandate remained in place: Travelers flying to the United States had to provide a negative test result before boarding their plane.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: A new way to choose your next book. Also in this edition: hiking to one of America’s most unique hotels, and a dating expert’s data-driven approach.
lead_paragraph: A new way to choose your next book. Also in this edition: hiking to one of America’s most unique hotels, and a dating expert’s data-driven approach.

headline: Steven Knight Isn’t Ready for ‘Peaky Blinders’ to End
abstract: The cult British show’s final season is now on Netflix, but its creator has plans for a spinoff movie and says he wants to follow the Shelby family into the 1940s and ’50s.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Steven Knight knew something special was happening around “Peaky Blinders,” his TV crime drama, a few years ago, when the rapper Snoop Dogg asked to talk with him.

headline: Chile Loses Bid to Replace Ecuador at World Cup
abstract: Chile’s soccer federation had argued Ecuador should be ejected from the tournament for using an ineligible player in qualifying. FIFA disagreed.
lead_paragraph: Chile’s bid to have its South American rival Ecuador thrown out of soccer’s World Cup failed on Friday when a disciplinary panel at soccer’s global governing body rejected a claim that Ecuador had fielded an ineligible player in several qualification matches.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: A superlative macaroni salad, chile-lime zucchini and chickpeas, and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I shop the deli counter sometimes. There’s joy to be had at a good one. I’ll pick up some egg or tuna salad for lunch, some mortadella for rollups (with mayonnaise and pickled jalapeños), a couple slices of fried eggplant. Once I bought a quarter pound of antipasti salad and stuffed it into a hero to eat on a boat. That was a messy delight.

headline: America’s Most Luxurious Butter Lives to Churn Another Day
abstract: Animal Farm Creamery, one of the most highly regarded small dairies in America, was nearly lost. Then, a young couple down the road stepped in.
lead_paragraph: SHOREHAM, Vt. — In a wooden barn perched on a grassy hill, some of the most celebrated cows in the dairy business — the bovine royal family of American fancy butter — sampled hay in their new abode.

headline: Feeding a Hotter Planet
abstract: Hunger is rising again even though we produce enough food. As the planet warms, it’s crucial to fix a broken system.
lead_paragraph: The world faces a frightening hunger crisis. Climate change makes it worse.

headline: What Are You Reading (or Watching or Listening to) That Has Given You an ‘Aha!’ Moment?
abstract: Tell us about the work and why it set off a light bulb.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, the Interpreter newsletter — featuring original analysis on the week’s biggest global stories from the columnist Amanda Taub — includes an item that particularly caught Taub’s attention or sparked an “aha!” moment.

headline: Biden Casts Inflation as a Global Problem During a Visit to the Port of Los Angeles
abstract: The visit to the nation’s busiest entry point for goods comes as President Biden struggles to show progress on resolving supply chain issues that are fueling inflation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — President Biden on Friday defended his administration’s efforts to deal with inflation, just hours after a new report showed a surprise spike in prices that puts new pressure on the White House to ease the burden on consumers.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: From pensive dramas about androids to upbeat anime about virtual pop stars, this month’s selection of films has creative range.
lead_paragraph: The director Kogonada’s vision of the future looks suspiciously like present-day Sedona, Ariz., the capital of woo-woo vibes: People wear loosefitting linen, always use their inside voices and appear preternaturally mellow. The mild mood even carries over to their jobs; Jake (Colin Farrell) runs a tea shop bathed in mood lighting.

headline: U.S. Scrutinizes Swiss Currency Practices
abstract: The Treasury Department declined to label any country a currency manipulator, but singled out Switzerland as an offender in its semiannual foreign exchange report.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department said on Friday that it was concerned that some of America’s trading partners were taking actions to weaken their currencies and gain unfair trade advantages against the United States — but declined to label any country a currency manipulator.

headline: After a Political Storm, Gay Days Return to Disney
abstract: An L.G.B.T.Q. tradition at Disney World took on new significance this year, when Disney was ensnared in a heated cultural debate.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Last Friday evening, about 6,000 people — almost all of them gay men — poured into a Walt Disney World water park near Orlando, Fla. Each had spent $100 or more on tickets for a private, adults-only Pride bacchanal called Riptide. “For one night, Disney’s Typhoon Lagoon Water Park becomes entirely yours for the party of the year,” online ads had promised. “Be part of the magic!”

headline: An ‘Ugly’ Inflation Report Upended Hopes That Price Gains Would Ease
abstract: Investors and economists had expected to see some moderation in inflation. Instead, prices accelerated again in May, delivering an unwanted surprise.
lead_paragraph: Friday’s inflation report delivered an unwanted surprise for the White House, Federal Reserve and investors.

headline: Swapping Books Brings Katy Tur Closer to Her Mother
abstract: “It’s like getting a postcard from inside the other’s head without even having to talk about it,” says the NBC News correspondent, whose new book is “Rough Draft,” a memoir. “Because who wants to talk about it?”
lead_paragraph: John le Carré’s “A Perfect Spy” and “Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy”; Zadie Smith’s “Grand Union”; Eve Babitz’s “Sex and Rage”; “A Short History of London,” by Simon Jenkins, “Discovering the News,” by Michael Schudson, and (for reasons I can’t quickly explain) “Stop Reading the News: A Manifesto for a Happier, Calmer and Wiser Life,” by Rolf Dobelli. I also have a copy of “Hotel Scarface,” a book by my friend Roben Farzad about an old drug dealer’s hangout in Miami that was, by coincidence, a hangout of my old retired drug dealer of a father-in-law.

headline: ‘Dark Winds’ Review: Murder Most Foul in the Navajo Nation
abstract: A six-episode adaptation of Tony Hillerman’s tribal-police mysteries finally puts the invaluable actor Zahn McClarnon at the top of the cast list.
lead_paragraph: The natural way to lead a review of “Dark Winds,” which premieres Sunday on AMC, would be to note that it is a series written, directed and performed largely by Native Americans; set in the Navajo Nation and filmed on location in New Mexico; and bringing to screen the tribal police officers Joe Leaphorn and Jim Chee from Tony Hillerman’s best-selling mystery novels.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Bhaskar Sunkara
abstract: A conversation with the political writer Bhaskar Sunkara.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Bhaskar Sunkara. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Reliving ‘That Infamous Day, Jan. 6’
abstract: Readers wonder if the hearings will change minds, praise Liz Cheney and compare them to Watergate. Also: A gun owner’s plea for gun control.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: SZA’s ‘Ctrl’ Bonus, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Saucy Santana, Demi Lovato, Joyce Manor and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Even a Powerful Queen First Must Survive Being a Teenager
abstract: “Becoming Elizabeth,” a new show on Starz, depicts Queen Elizabeth I’s early years, which are rarely seen onscreen, as a claustrophobic family drama.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At the start of “Becoming Elizabeth,” a new Starz series about the little-depicted teenage years of Queen Elizabeth I of England, a carriage clatters through a rain-drenched dawn, led by riders on horseback bearing flaming torches. It is January 1547, and the carriage is carrying the body of King Henry VIII; immediately after, we see his legitimate children, Edward, Mary and Elizabeth, roused from bed and ushered through dark corridors.

headline: Royal Shipwreck From 1682 Is Found Off the Coast of England
abstract: The Gloucester, which was carrying a future king of England when it ran aground, was found 15 years ago. Its discovery was revealed this week.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The wreckage of a Royal Navy ship, from which a future king of England narrowly escaped when it sank 340 years ago during a period of political strife, was discovered off the country’s east coast, researchers said on Friday.

headline: Et Tu, Ivanka?
abstract: Even some of the president’s closest allies knew his Big Lie was a lie. But it’s the Jan. 6 congressional committee bringing the truth to light.
lead_paragraph: It turns out that not even Donald Trump’s daughter Ivanka bought into the former president’s toxic fantasies about the 2020 election having been stolen from him. She came to understand pretty quickly after the election that there was no evidence of a plot by Democrats, accepting the assessment of Bill Barr, Mr. Trump’s attorney general at the time, that the game had not been rigged. Mr. Trump had lost, and all the wild claims to the contrary, as Mr. Barr says he told Mr. Trump, were “bullshit.”

headline: It’s Rosé Season, but Drink These 12 Bottles Year-Round
