abstract: There’s no reason to confine rosé to the summer, but for good reasons the season does have a special hold on the wines.
lead_paragraph: I don’t need to tell you that rosé season has begun. The bottles are crowding the seasonal displays in wine shops, the days are still growing longer and the get-it-done determination of the cooler months is giving way to a summer laxity.

headline: Paula Rego, Artist Known for Unsettling Images, Dies at 87
abstract: Her paintings, many of which focused on women’s experiences and perspectives, might depict fear or menace. But it was up to the viewer to fill in the blanks.
lead_paragraph: Paula Rego, who in extraordinary artworks across 70 years could be menacing, unsettling, playful or all of those at once, her paintings suggesting macabre stories but inviting viewers to fill in the details, died on June 8 at her home in North London. She was 87.

headline: The Jan. 6 Hearing Put a True-Crime Drama on Prime-Time TV
abstract: The first night of the Jan. 6 hearings was serious public service, but it told an engrossing story with the tools of a limited series drama.
lead_paragraph: The first night of the congressional Jan. 6 hearings was not an entertainment. It was deadly serious reality, offering a panorama and a terrifying close-up of a real nightmare: The attempt, through violence, to effectively end American democracy by overturning the will of the voters and keeping President Donald J. Trump installed in an office that he lost.

headline: Cool Cukes, Alluring Avocado
abstract: Hetty McKinnon’s easy, earthy recipe contrasts crunch with creaminess.
lead_paragraph: For much of my life, I thought I didn’t like cucumbers. I liked sour pickles and Sichuan-style smashed cucumbers, but in most other settings — especially bad renditions of Greek salad — cucumbers struck me as watery, slippery filler, the honeydew of the savory salad world. (I stand by my dislike of honeydew.) Why would you dunk a cucumber spear in dip when you could choose a carrot? Or a radish? Why?

headline: Behind Enemy Lines, Scouts Help Ukrainians Execute Deadly Strikes
abstract: A nascent insurgency made up of civilians or former soldiers provided information that aided Ukraine’s attack on two Russian bases, according to a senior Ukrainian military official.
lead_paragraph: While a lack of weapons, ammunition and equipment hampers the Ukrainian military, there are signs that a nascent partisan insurgency is growing in potency, allowing Ukrainian forces to deliver deadly strikes on Russian-controlled territory even in areas where it is dangerous and sometimes impossible to commit troops.

headline: Wonking Out: Why Monetary Policy Has Gotten So Hard
abstract: If you aren’t taking risks, you aren’t doing your job.
lead_paragraph: Today’s newsletter isn’t about what the Federal Reserve or its counterpart the European Central Bank should be doing. I have views, of course: For what it’s worth, I think the Fed is getting it roughly right and the E.C.B. is overreacting. But that’s a debate both huge and inconclusive; in fact, it may never be resolved, since people are so good at convincing themselves that they were right.

headline: Review: The Kids (in New Hands) Are Still All Right
abstract: The student dancers looked good in Kids Dance, the performance troupe of Ballet Tech, which has passed from Eliot Feld to Dionne Figgins.
lead_paragraph: Eliot Feld was riding the subway when the car filled with a bunch of rambunctious kids on a field trip. The year was 1977, and Feld, a prominent choreographer, had an epiphany: not about how to escape, but how he might discover undeveloped dancers among children like those. The next year, he joined with the New York City Department of Education to start a dance training program for public school students, which eventually became a school for grades four to eight: Ballet Tech.

headline: Steph Curry Is Boosting Black Designers at the N.B.A. Finals
abstract: The Golden State fashion plate has made a point of wearing looks from independent labels during his “tunnel walks.”
lead_paragraph: As the Golden State Warriors and the Boston Celtics face off in the N.B.A. finals, each team’s players have been bringing their top game to the court — and their best looks to the tunnel.

headline: Robert Lewandowski, Bayern Munich and the Bitter End
abstract: A star striker is eager to move to Barcelona, and his club doesn’t seem to realize it might be its own fault that he wants to go.
lead_paragraph: Robert Lewandowski does not, in his own words, like to make “too much show.” He is, and always has been, a touch more impassive than the average superstar. He does not greet his goals, the ones that have come for so long in such improbable quantities, with a roar, or a leap, or a scream. Instead, he grins. For the really good ones, he might go so far as a beam.

headline: How Superworms Make Styrofoam Into a Healthy Meal
abstract: By understanding the microbes that help large beetle larvae digest polystyrene, scientists hope to find a better disposal process for packing foam.
lead_paragraph: The plump, glossy larvae of the darkling beetle, nicknamed “superworms” perhaps because of their size, are usually content to munch on wheat bran. But a number of the two-inch-long critters recently found themselves dining on much stranger fare in the service of science: polystyrene, the long-lived plastic packing material known sometimes by the brand name Styrofoam.

headline: For South Africa’s Leader, Being a Burglary Victim Spells Trouble
abstract: After a fortune in cash was stolen from President Cyril Ramaphosa’s farmhouse, he kept it secret. Now that word is out, critics ask what he was hiding.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — The burglars cut through a wire fence around the sprawling property, crept up to a stone farmhouse, climbed through a window and rifled through the furniture until they found their bounty: a fortune in U.S. dollars, in cash, said to be in the millions.

headline: Valery Ryumin, Who Set Endurance Record in Space, Dies at 82
abstract: A Soviet cosmonaut, he spent 362 days in flight on three missions. He returned 18 years later on a U.S. shuttle to the Mir space station.
lead_paragraph: Valery Ryumin, a Soviet tank commander who became a cosmonaut and spent more than a year in space, setting endurance records — and then, after 18 years, took another flight, this time on a U.S. space shuttle — died on Monday. He was 82.

headline: ‘Quince’ Review: A Mexican American Tale That Explains Too Much
abstract: The new play, about a 15-year-old girl and her impending quinceañera, creates a fitting party vibe. If only the script didn’t clarify every cultural reference.
lead_paragraph: In the backyard of a modest house with a thriving garden, a woman in a brimmed hat festooned with streamers bends over the flowers, tending to them silently. Her face a mask, she pays no attention to the pair of teenage sweethearts in the midst of a private talk.

headline: In ‘The Baby,’ Killing With Cuteness
abstract: This British horror-comedy, which has its season finale on Sunday, literalizes the terrors of motherhood.
lead_paragraph: The British horror-comedy “The Baby” contains its fair share of blood, supernatural machinations and demonic possessions. Since its premiere in April on HBO, the limited series has delivered a steady stream of gore, grisly deaths and ghosts.

headline: Britney Spears: The Once and Future Versace Muse
abstract: The singer wore the Italian brand for her wedding to Sam Asghari, culminating a longstanding fashion relationship.
lead_paragraph: The dress was long. It was white. It was Versace. And it wasn’t just a wedding dress.

headline: C.D.C. Dismisses Airborne Transmission of Monkeypox. Some Experts Disagree.
abstract: The virus “is not known to linger in the air,” agency officials said. But the research is far from definitive.
lead_paragraph: Officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday pushed back against the idea that the monkeypox virus can spread through the air, saying the virus is usually transmitted through direct physical contact with sores or contaminated materials from a patient.

headline: Manhattan’s New Green Space Was J.P. Morgan’s Side Yard
abstract: The Morgan Library & Museum celebrates the restoration of a McKim building and unveils a garden with classical sculptures from the financier’s collection.
lead_paragraph: In 1908, an unnamed correspondent for The Times of London wrote the first public account of the two-year-old library of the financier J. Pierpont Morgan, next to his home just east of Madison Avenue on 36th Street.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: After a couple of weeks off, the late-night hosts returned to a landmark week on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: After a couple of weeks off, the late-night hosts returned to a landmark week on Capitol Hill.

headline: Biden and Latin American Leaders Announce Migration Deal
abstract: President Biden is trying to confront repeated surges of migrants at the U.S. border by casting the issue as a problem for the entire region, not just the United States.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — President Biden and leaders of Latin American countries signed a new agreement on Friday to confront the consequences of mass migration, making specific numerical pledges to allow more people fleeing political and economic strife to cross their borders.

headline: Trump Hits Back at Daughter’s Account That She Accepted His Election Loss
abstract: The former president, responding to videotaped testimony played at the Jan. 6 hearing, said Ivanka Trump had been “checked out” and was not involved in studying the election results.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the House committee hearing on the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.

headline: At Least 20 Million Watched Jan. 6 Hearing
abstract: The number is in the ballpark of big television events like a “Sunday Night Football” game.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the House committee hearing on the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.

headline: Lockdowns Protected Older People. But at What Cost to the Health of Young Adults?
abstract: Since the pandemic began, their rate of death from all causes has skyrocketed.
lead_paragraph: Covid-19 has killed mostly old people. But since the pandemic began, the rate of death from all causes for younger adults has risen by a bigger percentage than has the rate of death from all causes for old people.

headline: ‘Soft’ Review: Young Black Men, Gently Pointed Toward Liberation
abstract: In Donja R. Love’s new play, an English teacher struggles against the penal system — and with his own guilt — to help students see a future beyond prison.
lead_paragraph: Black manhood is envisioned as a delicate garden full of blossoms and wilts in Donja R. Love’s compelling new play “Soft,” receiving its world premiere at MCC Theater in Manhattan.

headline: Love Letter: Let’s Forget Romance
abstract: “How does one fall in love? Wouldn’t one fall out of it?”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Modern Love essay, “Singleness Is Not a Stigma,” Ife Olatona calls into question “the widespread assumption that everyone is better off in an exclusive, romantic relationship.”

headline: Tom Perrotta on the Return of Tracy Flick
abstract: Perrotta talks about “Tracy Flick Can’t Win,” and Ann Leary discusses “The Foundling.”
lead_paragraph: Few fictional characters in recent decades have been as intensely discussed as Tracy Flick. The ambitious teenage protagonist of Tom Perrotta’s novel “Election” (1998) and the ensuing film adaptation, starring Reese Witherspoon, has been reconsidered in recent years as misunderstood and unfairly maligned. On this week’s podcast, Perrotta talks about Tracy’s return in his new novel, “Tracy Flick Can’t Win.”

headline: Single Cigarettes in Canada Will Be Inscribed With Warning
abstract: Cigarette boxes and packaging in Canada are also expected to see an expanded list of health effects related to smoking.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Every individual cigarette sold in Canada will carry a warning message under the terms of a new federal regulation intended to curb smoking, especially among young people, the country’s minister of mental health and addictions announced on Friday.

headline: In Alaska, 48 House candidates and a first-of-its-kind special election
abstract: Voters are taking part in a mail-only special election with an open primary. Former Gov. Sarah Palin and Santa Claus are on the ballot.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Alaska are taking part in a new type of election this weekend: one conducted entirely by mail, the first of its kind in the state’s history. And it will be an open primary, allowing people to pick from candidates of both parties — also new in the state.

headline: A new study is the first to document likely cat-to-human virus transmission, but risks are low overall, experts say.
abstract: People are far more likely to give the virus to cats than cats are to pass it to humans, experts stress.
lead_paragraph: A veterinarian in Thailand likely contracted the coronavirus from an infected pet cat last year, researchers concluded in a new study. It is the first documented case of suspected cat-to-human transmission, although experts stress that the risk of cats infecting humans with the virus remains low overall.

headline: A Single Image of Gun Violence Could Help Change Minds
abstract: Though grisly, showing what rifles do to people is a chance to finally shift the gun debate.
lead_paragraph: At a judges’ dinner this week for the Livingston Awards, aimed to honor the work of journalists under 35 years old, the older ink-stained wretches like myself talked about a range of things that were impacting the media business. That included the usual topics, like online misinformation. (In fact, the national award went to an astonishing series about that toxic and growing phenomenon, including a family torn asunder by conspiracy theories, by Jose A. Del Real at The Washington Post.) Also on the docket, as always, the question of how to restore the American public’s trust in the reporters and the institutions they work for.

headline: U.K. Officials Won’t Investigate Political Donation Flagged for Russian Origins
abstract: A bank alert had said a $630,225 Conservative Party donation originated in a Russian account. The authorities say there’s no evidence that a crime was committed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British law enforcement and elections officials said they will not investigate a major political donation to the Conservative Party that had been flagged as a suspected illegal campaign donation in documents linking it to a Russian bank account.

headline: Stonewall Jackson’s Name Fell Fast, and a Fury Quickly Followed
abstract: Removing the names of Confederate generals from schools in Shenandoah County, Va., was a response to racial justice protests. The community has been fighting about it ever since.
lead_paragraph: WOODSTOCK, Va. — It was getting late, well past 10 p.m., when the Shenandoah County School Board finally got around to the question that had been hanging over the county for two long and exhausting years. Should Stonewall Jackson return?

headline: Oklahoma’s Abortion Law Raises Questions About N.C.A.A.’s Softball World Series
abstract: The N.C.A.A. has restricted previous events in response to state lawmakers. It faces that test again in Oklahoma, where softball championships are a mainstay and a restrictive abortion ban recently became law.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — Last Saturday, like many days here in early June, was a softball fiesta. The 13,100-seat stadium — burnished and bulked up by a $27.5 million renovation that added a second deck — was teeming with young pony-tailed fans from Alva to Ardmore, partisans in Oklahoma, Oklahoma State or Texas colors, and softball aficionados who make the yearly sojourn to the Women’s College World Series.

headline: Our Racial Reckoning Could Have Come Sooner. What Made 2020 Different?
abstract: The murder of George Floyd, a pandemic and social media released a storm.
lead_paragraph: Why was there an all-encompassing racial reckoning in this country starting in the spring of 2020? And why then? Examining that question reminds us that history is driven — by general trends classifiable as progress or decline — but also just happens. Specifically, chance factors, what historians sometimes call “contingency,” have greater effects than we are always inclined to notice.

headline: Shortage of Artillery Ammunition Saps Ukrainian Frontline Morale
abstract: Shells for Soviet-era weapons are running short, and powerful Western weapons are not arriving fast enough to make up the difference, giving Russia a big advantage in artillery.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK REGION, Ukraine — Nearly four months after Russia invaded, the Ukrainian military is running low on ammunition for its Soviet-era artillery and has not received enough supplies from its allies to keep the Russians at bay, Ukrainian officials and artillery officers in the field say.

headline: Julee Cruise, Vocalist of ‘Twin Peaks’ Fame, Dies at 65
abstract: In projects for the director David Lynch, she brought an eerie, otherworldly style to “Falling” and other songs.
lead_paragraph: Julee Cruise, a singer who brought a memorably ethereal voice to the projects of the director David Lynch — most famously “Falling,” whose instrumental version was the theme for Mr. Lynch’s cult-favorite television show, “Twin Peaks” — died on Thursday in Pittsfield, Mass. She was 65.

headline: Dining Out This Summer
abstract: Professional eaters give advice.
lead_paragraph: Summer is on the horizon and the urge to spend lazy evenings dining with friends on a sunny terrace is getting stronger. At the same time, virus cases are ticking up in many areas of the U.S., complicating the restaurant experience.

headline: Running Low on Ammo
abstract: Ukraine is in short supply of ammunition needed to hold the line against Russia.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: No New Money for Jail Officers and Police in $101 Billion N.Y.C. Budget
abstract: Helped by better-than-expected tax revenue, the spending plan reflects the tension between Mayor Eric Adams and the City Council over the issue of crime.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams and New York’s City Council speaker, Adrienne Adams, said on Friday they had reached agreement on a $101 billion municipal budget that, among other things, excludes Mr. Adams’s proposals to significantly increase staffing levels at the city’s jails and slightly increase the Police Department’s budget.

headline: Republicans Caught Every Break in New York. Then Paladino Arrived.
abstract: The incendiary congressional candidacy of Carl Paladino has divided New York Republicans and now threatens to shake up party leadership.
lead_paragraph: For New York’s beleaguered Republican Party, all signs had been pointing for months toward 2022 being an exceptional year.

headline: McDonald’s Is Back, Moscow Style, as Russian Economy Stumbles On
abstract: The reopening of the fast-food stores under Russian ownership (and with a new logo) illustrates the economy’s surprising resilience in the face of intense sanctions, though tough times lie ahead.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Shumilkin is going back to work on Sunday. To prepare, he pulled the familiar “M” off what had been his McDonald’s shirt and covered the “M” on his McDonald’s jacket with a Russian flag patch.

headline: New MoMA PS1 Director Resigns
abstract: Kate Fowle, who arrived in 2019, said she would step down in July from the Long Island City museum. She offered no reason for her abrupt departure.
lead_paragraph: Kate Fowle, who became director of MoMA PS1 in 2019 and barely had the chance to lead the museum as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic, abruptly announced on Friday that she was stepping down as of July 15 from the museum in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Ocasio-Cortez Turns a New York Brawl Into a National Democratic Proxy Battle
abstract: By endorsing her colleague’s primary challenger, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has escalated a skirmish rippling beyond New York.
lead_paragraph: Sean Patrick Maloney is a Democratic Party stalwart who declares himself a “practical, mainstream guy.”

headline: Nancy Clark Reynolds, a Player in Reagan’s Washington, Dies at 94
abstract: A renowned political insider, she parlayed her connections to become one of the city’s most sought-after lobbyists in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Clark Reynolds, whose life as a Washington insider stretched from the 1930s, when she arrived as the daughter of a New Deal congressman, to her role as a confidante to Ronald Reagan and, finally, to her prominence as one of the city’s most well-connected lobbyists in the 1980s, died on May 23 at her home in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 94.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How Journalists Wrestle With Covering Threats to Democracy
abstract: A new report challenges news outlets to provide richer, more urgent coverage of the rise of authoritarian movements in the United States and abroad.
lead_paragraph: The banner headline on Friday’s print edition of The New York Times was pretty direct:

headline: Iraqi at Guantánamo Bay to Plead Guilty in Afghan War Crimes Case
abstract: Abd al-Hadi al-Iraqi, who is accused of leading forces that killed U.S. and allied troops, is disabled. A resolution of his case would involve finding a country to take him into custody.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — A disabled Iraqi prisoner at Guantánamo Bay has reached an agreement with military prosecutors to plead guilty to war crimes charges related to his role as a commander of insurgent forces in Afghanistan in the early 2000s, lawyers disclosed in court Friday.

headline: Idaho City to Pay $11.7 Million to Man Wrongfully Convicted in 1996 Killing
abstract: Christopher Tapp spent 20 years in prison for a murder he did not commit. He was exonerated in 2019, and the person who really killed Angie Dodge, 18, of Idaho Falls, was sent to prison.
lead_paragraph: The city of Idaho Falls, Idaho, has agreed to pay $11.7 million to a man who spent 20 years in prison after he was wrongfully convicted of murdering an 18-year-old woman in 1996.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Puts Focus on Cabinet Discussions About Removing Trump
abstract: Other reports verify Representative Liz Cheney’s assertion that cabinet members considered using the 25th Amendment to oust Donald Trump after the assault on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: When Representative Liz Cheney asserted at the House Jan. 6 hearing on Thursday that Trump administration cabinet members weighed invoking the constitutional process to remove President Donald J. Trump from office after the attack on the Capitol by his supporters, she did not immediately provide details or evidence.

headline: What Is Ramsay Hunt Syndrome?
abstract: Justin Bieber announced that he had the rare facial condition. Here’s what you need to know about it.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Justin Bieber announced that he has Ramsay Hunt syndrome, a rare condition that has paralyzed half his face.

headline: Bill Cosby Team Says Accuser Gave Conflicting Account of ‘Sex Assault’
abstract: A 2018 essay based on an interview with the accuser, Judy Huth, depicts her encounter with Mr. Cosby in 1975 differently than in her testimony. But Ms. Huth has said the essay is wrong.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby’s defense team introduced a former reporter from The National Enquirer at his sexual assault trial in California on Friday, arguing that the reporter’s depiction of Judy Huth’s encounter with Mr. Cosby at the Playboy Mansion starkly contradicted Ms. Huth’s own account from the stand.

headline: Who Is the Former TV News Chief Helping the Jan. 6 Committee?
abstract: James Goldston was a longtime producer at ABC News and then its president for seven years.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the House committee hearing on the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.

headline: Days before his South Carolina primary, a G.O.P. congressman who voted to impeach Trump stands by his vote.
abstract: Representative Tom Rice is bracing for a tough runoff election against a Trump-backed challenger following Tuesday’s primary.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on primary elections and results in South Carolina.

headline: Biden Announces Migration Deal with Latin American Leaders
abstract: The agreement commits the United States to taking 20,000 refugees from Latin America over the next two years, a small fraction of the migrants who typically try to cross the southern border each year.
lead_paragraph: The agreement commits the United States to taking 20,000 refugees from Latin America over the next two years, a small fraction of the migrants who typically try to cross the southern border each year.

headline: 2 Teens Drown in New York Waterway Known for Strong Currents, Police Say
abstract: The boys, both 13, were on a sandbar in Jamaica Bay before entering the water in an area known for dangerous currents and sudden drop-offs.
lead_paragraph: Two 13-year-old boys drowned on Friday after slipping into Jamaica Bay off a sandbar, the police said. With summer approaching and more people being drawn to the water, the deaths were a reminder of the danger posed by the bay’s strong currents and steep drop-offs.

headline: ‘We All Have a Duty to Ensure That What Happened on Jan. 6 Never Happens Again’
abstract: The hearings on the Capitol riot challenge all Americans to recommit to democracy.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, a congressional committee began an unflinching conversation with the citizens of this country about, in the words of the committee chair, Donald Trump’s last stand, his attempt to spur the enemies of the Constitution to subvert American democracy.

headline: Former Bolivian President Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison
abstract: The trial of Jeanine Añez, who took power after Evo Morales was ousted, has led to concerns about politicians’ use of the justice system to target opponents.
lead_paragraph: Jeanine Añez, the former president of Bolivia, was sentenced to 10 years in prison on Friday following accusations that she illegally took over the presidency after the resignation of her predecessor, Evo Morales.

headline: ‘It’s Anyone’s Guess’
abstract: Sid Sivakumar’s puzzle presents a wide range of possibilities.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a connoisseur’s grid that will also please the rest of us, which is no surprise considering it comes from Sid Sivakumar. I did not pick up on the seriously low word count until I read the Constructor Notes — after all this time solving, I think I might have to try constructing a grid or two myself, to hone my eye — but I did note the cavalcade of artful crossings and tough clues.

headline: Reforms Are Imposed on U.N. Agency That Made Questionable Investments
abstract: After a New York Times report revealed unusual investments putting tens of millions of dollars at risk, the board of the U.N.’s Office for Project Services demanded major changes.
lead_paragraph: After a series of puzzling financial decisions that put tens of millions of dollars at risk, the executive board of a little-heralded United Nations agency took the rare step on Friday of voting to swiftly enforce a series of reforms.

headline: Stephen Curry’s Spectacular Night Fuels Key Win Over Celtics
abstract: Golden State desperately needed a win after losing two of the first three games in the N.B.A. finals. Curry’s 43 points on Friday got it done.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — For two days, Golden State forward Draymond Green saw it in his teammate Stephen Curry. The fire Curry plays with isn’t always apparent to outsiders, but Green sensed that it was simmering within.

headline: Quotation of the Day: With Lifeguards Scarce, Beach Season Needs Saving
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 11, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “It’s hard to watch. It’s 100 degrees in Texas. If they don’t come to their lifeguarded neighborhood pool, they will find a body of water somewhere.”

headline: Corrections: June 11, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 11, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about Naasón Joaquín García, the head of the church La Luz del Mundo, who was sentenced to more than 16 years in prison for sexually abusing minors referred incorrectly to Alondra Ocampo. She is a woman.

headline: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
abstract: Three and a half months into the war, it has become clear that some of the most intense barrages of sanctions ever meted out by the West — and the torrent of Western companies voluntarily leaving Russia — have failed to completely dismantle the Russian economy or spark a popular backlash against President Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: Three and a half months into the war, it has become clear that some of the most intense barrages of sanctions ever meted out by the West — and the torrent of Western companies voluntarily leaving Russia — have failed to completely dismantle the Russian economy or spark a popular backlash against President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Moderna’s Covid Vaccine Is Effective in Children Under 6, F.D.A. Says
abstract: Outside experts will meet next week to decide whether to recommend that the agency authorize the vaccine for kids 6 months and older.
lead_paragraph: Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine for children under 6 is effective in preventing symptomatic infection without causing worrisome side effects, the Food and Drug Administration said on Friday night.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Why We Still Haven’t Solved the Unpaid Internship Problem
abstract: Unpaid internships benefit schools and employers, but aren’t fair to college students footing their own tuition bills.
lead_paragraph: The president and vice president announced this month that they were going to pay their interns. The White House put out a news release. I think we were supposed to stand up and cheer.

headline: Biden Races to Expand Coalition Against Russia but Meets Resistance
abstract: Many Asian, African and Latin American nations are maintaining ties with Russia as the United States tries to isolate President Vladimir V. Putin and end the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even before the start of the war in Ukraine, an international alliance to rally the world against a Russian invasion came together so quickly that President Biden later marveled at the “purpose and unity found in months that we’d once taken years to accomplish.”

headline: Recording India’s Linguistic Riches as Leaders Push Hindi as Nation’s Tongue
abstract: Ganesh Devy has spent decades documenting India’s hundreds of distinct languages. Up next: a 12,000-year history of India he hopes will help counter the government’s Hindu-first campaign.
lead_paragraph: DHARWAD, India — The task was gargantuan: assembling a team of more than 3,500 language specialists, academics and enthusiastic amateurs to determine just how many distinct languages still exist in India, a country of stunning linguistic diversity.

headline: U.S. Gas Prices Hit a New High: $5 a Gallon
abstract: The unrelenting march higher continues as the average price touches a new milestone, according to AAA.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Gasoline prices reached a grim milestone on Saturday, as the national average for regular gasoline reached $5 a gallon.

headline: H.B.C.U. Students Show Us Their Campus Spirit
abstract: To capture the essence of life at an H.B.C.U., or historically Black college and university, eight Howard University photography students documented a meaningful part of campus culture.
lead_paragraph: To capture the essence of life at an H.B.C.U., or historically Black college and university, eight Howard University photography students documented a meaningful part of campus culture.

headline: How Do I Force My Unresponsive Landlord to Make Needed Repairs?
abstract: Tenants have a few tools at their disposal when a landlord or management company turns a blind eye. Here’s how to start the process.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in a medium-size, prewar building in Brooklyn. A couple of months ago, the ceiling in my shower started leaking. Then, a chunk of the ceiling above the leak collapsed. The super covered the hole with cardboard but never actually fixed the leak or ceiling. I have called numerous times, and he always says “tomorrow” but never fixes it. I have also called management twice and sent pictures. The wall seems to be becoming moldy. The cardboard is starting to fall apart. What should I do?

headline: How Long Does Covid Immunity Last? Will a Second Illness Be Worse? How Can I Prepare?
abstract: Some reinfection questions, answered.
lead_paragraph: If you’re one of the millions of Americans who have already had Covid-19, you may be wondering how long you will have immunity from the coronavirus. Earlier in the pandemic, most people assumed that getting infected had at least one upside: that you would be protected against future encounters with the virus. But as the latest wave heads toward the Western region of the country and the virus shows no signs of easing up, reinfections seem to have become common. Already, many people are reporting second or even third infections with newer variants.

headline: The Very Human Pleasure of Being Read To
abstract: From a Terry Pratchett fantasy to memoirs set in Northern Ireland and on a pig farm, these stories are most memorable for the voices telling them.
lead_paragraph: While many turn to audiobooks out of convenience, there is also a sense of comfort to be found in spending hours with a voice and a story. For me, audiobooks come with a generous helping of nostalgia; a harking back to bedtime stories and the warm fuzziness of being read to. Three recent audiobooks have stuck with me not just for their content, but also for the narrators’ delivery.

headline: It Works for Sneakers. Now It’s for Baby PJs and Skateboards, Too.
abstract: A wide range of retailers are manufacturing excitement, and scarcity, with limited-edition product “drops.”
lead_paragraph: Little Sleepies are pajamas and play clothes for children made out of bamboo cellulose.

headline: Eavesdropping on the Secret Lives of Dolphins in New York Harbor
abstract: For two years, an array of six underwater microphones tracked the feeding noises of marine mammals newly prevalent in New York waters.
lead_paragraph: It’s a riddle. No one knows for sure why dolphins are being spotted more frequently and for longer periods in and around New York Harbor, the giant estuary where salty ocean tides mix with fresh water from the Hudson River.

headline: DeSantis Event at Chelsea Piers Faces Backlash Over L.G.B.T.Q. Rights
abstract: The Florida governor who signed the so-called Don’t Say Gay bill spoke at a site long connected to the gay rights movement.
lead_paragraph: For the second time this spring, a New York City institution is facing a backlash over a conservative Jewish conference, long in the planning, because of one of its featured speakers: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.

headline: Should Biden Run in 2024? Democratic Whispers of ‘No’ Start to Rise.
abstract: In interviews, dozens of frustrated Democratic officials, members of Congress and voters expressed doubts about the president’s ability to rescue his reeling party and take the fight to Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Midway through the 2022 primary season, many Democratic lawmakers and party officials are venting their frustrations with President Biden’s struggle to advance the bulk of his agenda, doubting his ability to rescue the party from a predicted midterm trouncing and increasingly viewing him as an anchor that should be cut loose in 2024.

headline: Here’s What You Need to Know About America’s Super-Hot Inflation
abstract: Inflation is a tricky problem, but it has a few clear causes and consequences, and policymakers are working to bring it to heel.
lead_paragraph: The government reported on Friday that consumer prices climbed 8.6 percent over the year through May, the fastest rate of increase in four decades.

headline: DNA Can Now Identify Unknown Soldiers. It Also Reveals Tangles of Old Mistakes.
abstract: With modern tools, the U.S. military is learning that some unidentified remains from 20th-century battles are those of service members it thought were found and sent home long ago.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: A Night on Governors Island? Be Prepared to Spend for It.
abstract: Though no one is allowed to live permanently on the island, a small number of people can stay there overnight during the summer — for a price.
lead_paragraph: This story is part of an occasional series exploring nightlife in New York.

headline: Color, Craft and Comfort at Milan Design Week
abstract: Trends from the largest global design event, celebrating its 60th year.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a stretch to call Milan Design Week the design world’s largest annual global event. The commercial anchor of the yearly fair is Salone Internazionale del Mobile — the trade show, held this year from June 7 through 12 at the Rho fairgrounds, where design lovers, curators and the industry’s key players convened to discover and unveil the latest product and furniture releases from around the world.

headline: ‘We Buried Him and Kept Walking’: Children Die as Somalis Flee Hunger
abstract: The worst drought in four decades and a sharp rise in food prices caused by the war in Ukraine have left almost half of Somalia’s people facing acute food shortages.
lead_paragraph: DOOLOW, Somalia — When her crops failed and her parched goats died, Hirsiyo Mohamed left her home in southwestern Somalia, carrying and coaxing three of her eight children on the long walk across a bare and dusty landscape in temperatures as high as 100 degrees.

headline: Why Students Are Choosing H.B.C.U.s: ‘4 Years Being Seen as Family’
abstract: Many in a generation that grew up with a Black president and Black Lives Matter are embracing Black colleges and universities.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Pralines, Pecan Log Rolls and Nostalgia Fueling the Stuckey’s Revival
abstract: The pandemic reinvigorated car travel and, with it, the market for snacks and Americana. Will it last?
lead_paragraph: In June 2020, having used her life savings to buy back the failing roadside franchise that bears her family name, Stephanie Stuckey was in a Marion, Ark., parking lot in tears. The Stuckey’s in front of her was beyond decrepit; it was disreputable. A storm had opened a hole in the signature teal tile roof, and the owners hadn’t bothered to repair it. Sobbing, she called her vice president and said, “I can’t even walk into this store.” Without missing a beat he replied, “Welcome to your empire.”

headline: Saving Somalia’s Starving Babies
abstract: Doctors and nurses in Somalia are racing against time to save children from starvation because of the drought sweeping the country. In hospitals and clinics, here’s how medical workers are saving babies.
lead_paragraph: Doctors and nurses in Somalia are racing against time to save children from starvation because of the drought sweeping the country. In hospitals and clinics, here’s how medical workers are saving babies.

headline: ‘A Mass Invasion of Privacy’ but No Penalties for Tim Hortons
abstract: A scathing report by four privacy commissioners found that the coffee and doughnut chain collected data on customers’ daily lives.
lead_paragraph: One way to figure out how deeply Tim Hortons is woven into Canada’s fabric is a cross-border comparison. If McDonald’s, perhaps its closest analogue in the United States, wanted to have the same per capita reach in that market as Tim Hortons boasts in Canada, it would have to roughly triple its 13,000-plus American outlets.

headline: Five Decades, Three Generations of Runners, at the New York Mini
abstract: Julianne Grace “felt like a spectacle” when she lined up for her first Mini in 1975. Now she’s joined by her daughter and granddaughters.
lead_paragraph: Julianne Grace began running in 1971 after her husband encouraged her to give it a try. They started with a half-mile run. She hated it.

headline: The Phone Booth of the Mind
abstract: Phone booths may be obsolete, but they still offer a good model for keeping our phones from taking over our lives.
lead_paragraph: A crowd gathered in Times Square recently for the removal of what the city promoted as New York’s last public pay phone. “End of an Era,” declared the news release headline, even though the era when pay phones played any meaningful role in New Yorkers’ lives certainly ended long ago.

headline: Howard Schultz: Starbucks Is Battling for the ‘Hearts and Minds’ of Workers
abstract: Mr. Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, discussed the challenges he’s faced since returning to lead the company as it faces rising worker discontent and China’s ever-increasing role in global business.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of June 6, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: Rumbling Through Modern Jordan, a Railway From the Past
abstract: Once an ambitious project to unite the Middle East, the antique Hejaz Railway is a relic of that bygone dream before wars, borders and more advanced modes of transport rendered its services obsolete.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Astride century-old tracks that cut through the modern metropolis of Amman, a historic train blared a horn to announce its departure. That sound spurred families bearing bags of food, pots of coffee, coolers of soda, grills, hookahs and lots of children into action, scrambling up iron ladders to settle into the train’s wooden cars.

headline: Just How Burned Out Are Parents?
abstract: Take this Times test to find out.
lead_paragraph: Lately, I’ve been saying that my level of burnout feels like “Covid of the soul.” Which is to say I mostly feel normal, and that we’ve gradually been able to ease back into the rhythms of our prepandemic life, but there remains a residual exhaustion, partly psychic, that I haven’t had time to fully resolve. There are some days when my alarm goes off and the first thought that occurs to me is: I can’t believe I have to get up and do all the things again.

headline: Newly United, French Left Hopes to Counter President in Upcoming Vote
abstract: Left-wing parties have joined forces ahead of France’s two-stage parliamentary elections, hoping to revive their fortunes and put a brake on President Emmanuel Macron’s agenda.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live news updates of France’s parliamentary elections.

headline: Donald Trump, American Monster
abstract: A man of pure narcissistic psychopathy feels no guilt and has no sense of the damage he does.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Monsters are not what they used to be.

headline: The Dream of the Open Road Collides With the Reality of $5-a-Gallon Gas
abstract: Inflation at the diner. Sky-high prices at the pump. The view of the country from a 5,000-mile car journey is clear: It’s expensive out there.
lead_paragraph: Gas prices have risen nearly every day since our trip began on May 12. According to AAA’s tracker, the national average hit $5 a gallon on Saturday. We had no choice but to adapt to the high prices, and in retrospect I think that was for the best. Instead of hitting museums and cool restaurants and the big cities of the Southeast — inflation made all that stuff too expensive — we leaned into the road itself, letting America reveal itself serendipitously. Since it cost a small fortune to be on the road, why not make it the focus of our trip?

headline: England’s Traffic-Clogged North Bitter Over Stalled High-Speed Rail Plan
abstract: Transport problems are just one symptom of the economic neglect that has long hobbled the region, where growth, employment and health care mostly lag far behind the south.
lead_paragraph: BRADFORD, England — As Haniyya Ejaz boards her crowded morning train in the northern city of Bradford, an automated announcement tinged with a cheery Yorkshire accent chimes, “Welcome aboard this northern service to Leeds.”

headline: A Stalled High-Speed Line in North England
abstract: Transport problems have long hobbled northern England, and an ambitious rail project was meant to ease these woes. I went to the region to explore the initiative and to see how northerners felt after a portion of it didn't go as initially planned.
lead_paragraph: Transport problems have long hobbled northern England, and an ambitious rail project was meant to ease these woes. I went to the region to explore the initiative and to see how northerners felt after a portion of it didn't go as initially planned.

headline: A Caravan of Migrants Set Off Toward U.S. During Americas Summit
abstract: Some 6,000 migrants, many of them from Venezuela, set off from southern Mexico last week as leaders from across the Americas met in Los Angeles to discuss issues including migration.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of migrants set off from southern Mexico last week in one of the largest caravans seeking to reach the United States in recent years. The mass movement coincided with a recent meeting in Los Angeles, of leaders from the Western Hemisphere, where migration was a key focus.

headline: A Social Media Takedown Is a Blessing in Disguise for Sweden
abstract: Social media users around the world fixated on the curious Swedish tradition of not automatically offering food to guests.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM, Sweden — On a warm day in late May, life was humming along, punctuated by fika breaks, with pastries, coffee and conversation, when Sweden found itself thrust into the center of a global Twitter storm. Usually known for its generous social safety nets, latte papas and midsummer frolics, the Scandinavian nation was trending — and not in a good way.

headline: If You Must Point Fingers on Inflation, Here’s Where to Point Them
abstract: The Fed continues to evade accountability for inflation.
lead_paragraph: As the midterm elections draw nearer, a central conservative narrative is coming into sharp focus: President Biden and the Democratic-controlled Congress have made a mess of the American economy. Republicans see pure political gold in this year’s slow-motion stock market crash, which seems to be accelerating at the perfect time for a party seeking to regain control of Congress in the fall.

headline: Civil Rights Activists Fought for America’s Democracy. They Should Be Honored as Veterans.
abstract: Those who fought for America’s democracy should be treated as the war heroes they are.
lead_paragraph: History books have called my father an activist, a community organizer, a freedom fighter, among other things. But they don’t use a phrase that my dad has used to describe himself: a war general.

headline: Actors’ Roles: Should There Be a Limit?
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Pamela Paul about how actors have been criticized for playing people they do not resemble in real life.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: John Merriman, Eminent Historian of France, Is Dead at 75
abstract: An indefatigable researcher, he wrote books about terrorists, anarchists, leftists and ordinary people and spent a lot of time in France’s archives.
lead_paragraph: John Merriman, a revered professor of history at Yale University who plumbed dozens of French governmental archives for the information that invigorated his fast-paced books about anarchists, terrorists, leftists and ordinary people in France, died on May 22 in New Haven, Conn. He was 75.

headline: ‘Scared and Tired’: Thousands Across the U.S. Rally Against Gun Violence
abstract: As hundreds of demonstrations unfolded around the country on Saturday, supporters of gun control legislation cried out for action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Uvalde, after Buffalo, after Parkland and Newtown and El Paso and hundreds of other mass shootings over the past two decades, thousands of protesters rallied against gun violence on Saturday in Washington, D.C., and in cities across the country.

headline: In Uvalde, a Bishop Makes an Impassioned Plea: Tighten Gun Laws
abstract: In South Texas, where guns are woven into the culture, Archbishop Gustavo García-Siller is urging his community to reconsider. “We have to!” he says.
lead_paragraph: UVALDE, Texas — The day after an 18-year-old gunman massacred 21 students and teachers at an elementary school, state political leaders expressed fury over the shooting but quickly swatted away the possibility of new gun laws to stem further violence. Archbishop Gustavo García-Siller was listening.

headline: Jan. 6 Committee Appears to Lay Out Road Map for Prosecuting Trump
abstract: The first prime-time hearing into the Jan. 6 attack confronted the fundamental question that has haunted Donald J. Trump since he left office: Should he be prosecuted in a criminal court?
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the House committee hearing on the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.

headline: A Secret City With a Secret African American History
abstract: The U.S. government built Oak Ridge in 1942 to develop the world’s first atomic weapon.
lead_paragraph: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.

headline: Pentagon Chief Warns China Over ‘Provocative’ Activity Near Taiwan
abstract: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said that the United States opposed any changes to the status quo between China and Taiwan, and that it would continue assisting Taiwan in maintaining self-defense capabilities.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said that the United States opposed any changes to the status quo between China and Taiwan, and that it would continue assisting Taiwan in maintaining self-defense capabilities.

headline: What Would Happen if Fashion Actually Slowed Down?
abstract: Marco de Vincenzo, the newly appointed creative director of Etro, is not only asking the question, but attempting to answer through action.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion, and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.

headline: Protests Over Prophet Muhammad Comments Turn Deadly in India
abstract: Two young protesters were killed in eastern India on Friday amid demonstrations by Muslims across South Asia.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Two young demonstrators were killed on Friday in India’s eastern Jharkhand State amid protests across South Asia by Muslims angered by a comment from an official in India’s governing party that they believe profaned the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: Woman Gets 5-Year Ban From Grand Teton for False Report on Missing Hiker
abstract: Heather Mycoskie told investigators she had seen Cian McLaughlin on the day he disappeared. An investigation revealed she had not, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A woman accused of providing false information about a missing hiker in Grand Teton National Park has been banned from the park for five years, officials said.

headline: Photos From the Belmont Stakes
abstract: New York Times photographers capture images from the 154th Belmont, the last leg of the Triple Crown.
lead_paragraph: The 154th Belmont Stakes on Saturday came with no promise of a Triple Crown winner, but that wasn’t unusual. It’s a rare horse that can win the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes and still arrive at the Belmont in top form. Only 13 horses have won all three races.

headline: Why the Memory of Jan. 6 Can’t Prevent a Trump Resurgence
abstract: How an anti-Trump establishment undercuts itself.
lead_paragraph: There are two metrics for the success of the House’s Jan. 6 committee. One is within the committee’s control: A fair and comprehensive accounting of how far Donald Trump and his inner circle went in their effort to overturn the 2020 election, and how that effort interacted with mob violence, can serve future generations of Americans regardless of how it’s received today.

headline: Was a British Journalist the Latest Victim of Bolsonaro’s War on the Amazon?
abstract: The disappearance of Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira signals another tipping point in the Amazon.
lead_paragraph: Monday began, for me, with a call that became a horror story. I discovered that Dom Phillips, a British journalist and friend, disappeared a day earlier in the Javari Valley, one of the Amazon’s most dangerous regions.

headline: Peter Lamborn Wilson, Advocate of ‘Poetic Terrorism,’ Dies at 76
abstract: His concept of a “temporary autonomous zone” became an inspiration for protests like Occupy Wall Street and for gatherings like Burning Man.
lead_paragraph: Peter Lamborn Wilson, a counterculture intellectual, anarchist, poet, musicologist and utopian who coined the term “temporary autonomous zone,” which became a cri de coeur for the organizers behind both Burning Man and Occupy Wall Street — as well as for ravers, cyberpunks and other late-20th-century antiestablishmentarians — died on May 23 at his home in Saugerties, N.Y. He was 76.

headline: Where Can I Find a Great Travel Jacket?
abstract: A reader is looking for something light, wrinkle-proof and dressy-ish to take on trips.
lead_paragraph: Not only does such a garment exist, there is even a special name for it: a shacket! Like many newly relevant sartorial inventions (the megging, the jort), it is a hybrid garment (shirt plus jacket) well-suited for meeting contemporary needs.

headline: Momentum in Ukraine Is Shifting in Russia’s Favor
abstract: With the Ukrainians running short of guns and ammunition, and pressures growing on Western governments, Moscow’s fortunes may be rising.
lead_paragraph: A war in Ukraine that began with a Russian debacle as its forces tried and failed to take Kyiv has seemingly begun to turn, with Russia now picking off regional targets, Ukraine lacking the weaponry it needs and Western support for the war effort fraying in the face of rising gas prices and galloping inflation.

headline: Didn’t We Just Have This?
abstract: You’re not seeing double — there’s an echo in this Will Nediger puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Will Nediger is a professional crossword constructor from London, Ontario, who contributes regularly to The New Yorker and other outlets as well as The Times. He said, “I enjoy architecturally challenging constructions — like this puzzle, which was tricky to create, because the theme content had to be placed in a specific order.”

headline: You’re Reading One Right Now
abstract: Hoang-Kim Vu and Jessica Zetzman play their cards right.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — What makes a Monday puzzle great? Is it the theme’s wordplay? The liveliness of the fill entries? Some other intangible X factor? After solving today’s undeniably great crossword puzzle from the husband-and-wife constructing team Hoang-Kim Vu and Jessica Zetzman, I posed this question to the puzzle editors Sam Ezersky and Wyna Liu.

headline: Mo Donegal Wins the Belmont, Ending Rich Strike’s Magical Story
abstract: The favorite at post time, Mo Donegal won by three lengths, becoming the third horse to win a Triple Crown race in 2022. The Kentucky Derby winner Rich Strike was sixth.
lead_paragraph: So, fairy tales do not have legs in horse racing.

headline: Pence Aide Warned Against Blocking Electoral College Count, Memo Shows
abstract: Shortly before Jan. 6, Vice President Mike Pence’s chief counsel wrote that holding up the certification of the election results would violate federal law.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the House committee hearing on the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.

headline: Lightning Will Go for a Third Straight Stanley Cup Against the Avalanche
abstract: No team has been to three Stanley Cup finals in a row since the Edmonton Oilers in the mid-1980s, and the Islanders were the last team to win three consecutive Cups 40 years ago.
lead_paragraph: No matter the sport, winning back-to-back championships titles is rare because it’s so hard. Injuries, egos, contract demands and the N.H.L. salary cap often derail second title runs.

headline: From Santo Domingo to the N.B.A. Finals, Al Horford Is at Home
abstract: Horford, the Boston Celtics center, is the first Dominican player in the N.B.A. finals. With the way he’s competing, it’s hard to tell he hasn’t been here before.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When Al Horford was 14 years old, he moved from the Dominican Republic, where he’d been raised by his mother in Santo Domingo, to Michigan, where his father and four of his half-siblings lived.

headline: Dozens of White Supremacists Arrested in Idaho Had Planned to Riot, Authorities Say
abstract: Members of the right-wing group Patriot Front who were charged on Saturday were preparing to disrupt a nearby Pride event, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: COEUR D’ALENE, Idaho — Dozens of members of a white supremacist group were arrested on Saturday in Idaho before they could act on plans to riot at a local Pride event, the police said.

headline: China Won’t Hesitate to Fight for Taiwan, Defense Minister Warns
abstract: The general said China wouldn’t “flinch from the cost” of defending its claims to the island. He spoke at a Singapore forum where he met with the U.S. defense secretary.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — China will not flinch from war if Taiwan takes a decisive step toward independence, and it does not trust the United States’ assertions that it opposes that course for the island, the Chinese defense minister warned on Sunday, a day after Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III accused Beijing of increasingly bellicose activity near Taiwan.

headline: Quotation of the Day: After Hearings, a Tenuous Path to Indict Trump
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 12, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “That’s a hill that no federal prosecutor has tried to climb, prosecuting a former president. It’s very fraught. It’s a massive undertaking as an investigation, as a trial, as a national saga and trauma.”

headline: Corrections: June 12, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 12, 2022.
lead_paragraph: A highlighted quotation with an article last Sunday about California’s housing crisis mis­stated Scott Wiener’s role. He is a current state senator, not a former state senator.

headline: The Secret Pentagon Photos of the First Prisoners at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: The Times obtained the pictures, taken by military photographers assigned to the elite Combat Camera team, as part of a continuing effort to chronicle the 20-year-old detention operation.
lead_paragraph: The Times obtained the pictures, taken by military photographers assigned to the elite Combat Camera team, as part of a continuing effort to chronicle the 20-year-old detention operation.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: She Disagreed With Everything He Wrote About Housing. They Had Coffee.
abstract: An invitation from a reader led to a two-year correspondence with a Times reporter — and now a profile.
lead_paragraph: Conor Dougherty, an economics reporter for The New York Times who focuses on the West Coast, receives upward of 100 emails per day.

headline: A Trove of Guantánamo Photos
abstract: A Times reporter who covers Guantánamo Bay tracked down military photographs of the early days of the U.S. detention center there.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Like so many articles, our project in Sunday’s newspaper on the once-secret Pentagon photos from the earliest days of U.S. detention operations here, in 2002, started out with a tip.

headline: The Celtics Got Lucky by Not Getting What They Wanted
abstract: Other teams’ superstars kept getting traded, and the Celtics wanted in on the action. Boston (mostly) missed out, and is probably better off for it.
lead_paragraph: Moments after Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals ended last month, Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown embraced each other.

headline: ‘I Was Riding Downstairs on My Building’s Service Elevator’
abstract: A quick stop, a Brooklyn accent gets noticed in Coney Island and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: What to Know About France’s Parliamentary Elections
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron is looking to secure a majority that will pass his bills during his second term, but a reinvigorated alliance of left-wing parties hopes to thwart him.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live news updates of France’s parliamentary elections.

headline: The Main Draw at Andrew Giuliani’s Campaign Events? His Father.
abstract: Andrew Giuliani’s bid to win the Republican primary for governor of New York has not drawn many donors, but it has drawn fans of Rudy Giuliani, the former New York City mayor.
lead_paragraph: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y. — On a blazing Saturday afternoon in central Long Island, after hours of sun-baked stump speeches by candidates of little renown, it was finally Giuliani time.

headline: How Fashion Giants Recast Plastic as Good for the Planet
abstract: An influential system overseen by retailers and clothing makers ranks petroleum-based synthetics like “vegan leather” as more environmentally sound than natural fibers.
lead_paragraph: It’s soft. It’s vegan. It looks just like leather.

headline: Abortion Politics, Money and the Reshaping of the G.O.P.
abstract: In “Dollars for Life,” Mary Ziegler argues that, over the course of decades, the anti-abortion movement laid the groundwork for an insurgent candidate like Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: What About the Men?
abstract: Two speculative novels imagine rather drastic rearrangements to our existing gender relations.
lead_paragraph: Are women, when you get right down to it, better than men?

headline: At the Met This Season, Opera Was Icing on the Cake
abstract: Amid a labor battle, the continuing pandemic and war in Ukraine, it often felt as though the real drama was in simply putting on a show.
lead_paragraph: Has there ever been a Metropolitan Opera season like the one that just ended? In which the stuff onstage — the homicidal brides, mystical pharaohs and longing stepsons — felt so anticlimactic? Over the past eight months, amid a labor battle, a pandemic that surged again and again, and a war, it was as if the real drama was in simply getting the doors open. Once that was achieved, what followed was almost beside the point.

headline: Always an Outlier, Kelsie Whitmore Just Wants to Play Baseball
abstract: Whitmore, a pitcher and outfielder for the Staten Island FerryHawks, is the first woman to play in a league partnered with Major League Baseball since 1994.
lead_paragraph: Scott Whitmore stood along the concourse on a recent spring night watching the final inning of a Staten Island FerryHawks home game wind down when a New York City police officer approached him from the third-base side.

headline: When You’re Forced to Cash Out in a Bear Market
abstract: You can’t leave money in your I.R.A. forever, as dictated by I.R.S. rules. This can put retired investors in a tough spot.
lead_paragraph: Financial planners warn investors against trying to time the market. It is notoriously difficult to guess exactly when sentiment on Wall Street will reverse course — even professionals are likely to get it wrong.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Crop Circles Were Made by Supernatural Forces. Named Doug and Dave.
abstract: Intricate patterns carved in fields across England in the 1980s were a viral phenomenon long before the internet fed us such prankster curiosities daily.
lead_paragraph: CONHOLT, England — Standing hip-high in a large wheat field in southern England, one can make out an odd series of depressions in the swaying green crop, where some of the wheat has been pushed down lower than the rest.

headline: They Inhabited Separate Worlds in Taiwan. Decades Later, They Collided in a California Church.
abstract: The 68-year-old suspect in a May mass shooting harbored resentment dating back to his formative years in Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: David Chou and Pastor Billy Chang spent their whole lives forging parallel paths. They were born in early 1950s Taiwan, grew up just miles apart during martial law and later rebuilt their lives in the United States.

headline: Poland Shows the Risks for Women When Abortion Is Banned
abstract: Poland’s abortion ban has had many unintended consequences. One is that doctors are sometimes afraid to remove fetuses or administer cancer treatment to save women’s lives.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: A Restored Painting Recalls the Colosseum’s Christian Past
abstract: The restoration of a wall painting depicting an idealized Jerusalem is a reminder that the Roman monument, known best for gladiatorial combat, was a sacred Christian space for centuries.
lead_paragraph: ROME — For most people, the Colosseum conjures up scenes of bloody gladiatorial combat, or doomed encounters between Christians and vicious lions and tigers.

headline: There Has to Be a Better Way to Run the Government
abstract: Congestion pricing in Manhattan should have happened years ago. The reason it hasn’t is instructive.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, I wrote a column about the need for a liberalism that builds, and why it requires Democrats to confront their own role — Republican obstruction notwithstanding — in making government action difficult. This week, I want to offer a case study.

headline: The World Can’t Keep Fishing Like This
abstract: With help from their governments, fishing boats are able to range farther, remain at sea longer and catch more fish.
lead_paragraph: The World Trade Organization has been struggling for over two decades to reach an agreement among its members to restrict global subsidies to the fishing industry that are pushing some fish stocks to the brink of collapse. As recently as last November, trade negotiators seemed poised to rein in these subsidies, until a spike in Covid-19 delayed the deal.

headline: Why Strangers Are Good for Us
abstract: Random engagement is at the core of our social contract.
lead_paragraph: One Saturday morning, I took my 5-year-old son to the playground. A few minutes into his “ninja training” regimen, he attracted a fan. The other boy was younger, but the plastic glint of my son’s dollar-store sword slicing evil from the air proved irresistible. He edged closer and mimicked his moves, until they began to play together, shouting “Ya!” in unison, kicking with the verve of Rockettes. I smiled at the child’s father on the next bench and made an effort at playground banter, asking the boy’s age and whether they lived nearby. But after a few half-answers he pointed to the AirPods in his ears.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The “E-Pimps” of OnlyFans’
abstract: Clever marketers have figured out how easy it is to simulate online intimacy at scale, ventriloquizing alluring models with cheap, offshore labor.
lead_paragraph: Ezra Marcus takes a deep dive into the world of OnlyFans and self-described e-pimps, and untangles the vast web of models, agencies and “chatters” (the people who often act as the OnlyFans models in private messages with the customers) that support these lucrative businesses.

headline: The Week in Business: Trouble for Tesla?
abstract: Inflation recorded another increase; the Fed will probably follow with a new rate bump. And Wells Fargo is under criminal investigation.
lead_paragraph: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration announced on Thursday that it was ramping up an investigation into Tesla’s Autopilot driver-assistance system, which uses cameras and other sensors to control vehicles with little input from drivers. The agency had been conducting a preliminary evaluation of the system but upgraded to an engineering analysis, looking into whether Autopilot fails to keep drivers’ attention on the road. The new analysis brings more intense scrutiny, covering 830,000 vehicles sold between 2014 and 2021 in the United States and involving all four Tesla models; it’s also a necessary step before a recall can be ordered. Tesla tells drivers to stay alert while using the system, but many experts worry that Autopilot and similar technology can lead drivers to mistakenly believe their vehicles are completely self-driving.

headline: The Scene at the Border
abstract: We break down why border crossings are so high and who’s trying to come to the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Eileen Sullivan, a Times reporter who covers immigration, recently reported from both sides of the U.S.-Mexico border. The number of people crossing the border is the highest it’s been in at least two decades. We spoke to her about what she saw.

headline: Zahn McClarnon Sets His Thousand-Yard Stare on the Lead
abstract: AMC’s new thriller “Dark Winds” represents several firsts for the Indigenous actor, who has built a long career playing roles of quiet intensity.
lead_paragraph: For 30 years onscreen, Zahn McClarnon — stone-faced, soft-spoken and simmering with quiet intensity — has made a name for himself, in large part, by playing some pretty tough characters.

headline: Review: In ‘Spindle Shuttle Needle,’ History With Strings Attached
abstract: With war as a backdrop, Gab Reisman’s lively comedy is content to hang out with a motley group of women at the dawn of modern capitalism.
lead_paragraph: A siege is terrifying. It is profoundly disorienting. It is also, as Gab Reisman argues in her lively, quasi Marxist comedy “Spindle Shuttle Needle,” kind of a bummer.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Try Nicole A. Taylor’s newest recipes for Juneteenth, and then make a plan for saag paneer, spicy shrimp masala and more.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Juneteenth is next weekend. Nicole A. Taylor put together a new menu for the holiday that’s worth considering today — recipes for those celebrating and for all those interested in the delicious: peach and molasses grilled chicken (above), for instance, and a very green coleslaw made with roasted poblanos, with watermelon ginger beer to wash it all down and a strawberry sumac cake for dessert.

headline: She Wrote a Dystopian Novel. What Happened Next Was Pretty Dystopian.
abstract: Without having even been read, a book is attacked online for its fantastical premise.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a world in which all the men disappear from the planet in a single moment: Planes they were piloting are left unmanned (literally), their female passengers abandoned in midair; men in bed with their girlfriends mysteriously vanish; boys in the playground dematerialize before their mothers’ eyes. The girls and women left behind are given no apparent reason for the sudden absence of half the world’s population.

headline: ‘I Ache for Change’: Students on School Shootings After Uvalde
abstract: Students told us what it’s like to go to school during a time of frequent shootings and what America should be doing about it.
lead_paragraph: I never feel comfortable returning to school after hearing about another shooting. I feel immense sadness, intense anger and fear. School shootings are no longer unimaginable or incomprehensible, but common and anticipated. I am 17, and many school shootings have occurred throughout my lifetime, yet I’ve seen no significant change. Instead of passing stricter gun laws, politicians have proposed armed teachers, and designing schools with a single exit.

headline: 11 Small Ways You Can Help Mend the World
abstract: Our problems can feel big and overwhelming. Here are everyday ways to be part of the solution.
lead_paragraph: In Christian liturgical churches, today is Trinity Sunday, which kicks off a long sweep of “ordinary time.” This period — which will last till mid-November — is the longest season in the church year. Ordinary time is what we call the weeks that are not included in the major seasons of feasting or fasting in the church calendar, such as Easter and Lent.

headline: Alexander Nikitin, Who Coached a Chess Champion, Dies at 87
abstract: Garry Kasparov was just 10 when Mr. Nikitin took him on as a student. By age 17, with Mr. Nikitin as his coach, he was a grandmaster.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Nikitin, the principal coach of the world chess champion Garry Kasparov from the time Mr. Kasparov was 10 until years after he had become the titleholder, died on June 5 in Moscow. He was 87.

headline: Palin Leads Special Election for House Seat in Alaska
abstract: The top four candidates will advance to an August vote to finish the term of Representative Don Young, who died in March.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska leads the 48-candidate field in a special primary election for the state’s sole congressional seat, according to a preliminary count of ballots on Sunday.

headline: Senators Reach Bipartisan Deal on Gun Safety
abstract: The agreement, which falls short of the sprawling changes championed by Democrats, is a significant step toward ending a yearslong impasse over gun reform legislation.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the Senate vote on the bipartisan gun control bill.

headline: Tony Award Winners 2022: Complete List
abstract: The Tony Awards were held Sunday at Radio City Music Hall.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Awards were back at Radio City Music Hall for the first time since June 2019. The awards ceremony, which honors the plays and musicals staged on Broadway and resumed its traditional calendar after a long pandemic disruption, honored work that opened on Broadway between Feb. 20, 2020, and May 4, 2022. (“Girl From the North Country” opened on March 5, 2020, just a week before theaters shut down for the pandemic.)

headline: Meet The Times’s New Chess Columnist
abstract: For Daniel Naroditsky, a career in the royal game may not be as lucrative as one at a hedge fund, but he is exactly where he wants to be.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Naroditsky is a chess grandmaster, the highest title given to competitors by the International Chess Federation, and he has used that talent to parlay it into a career. In addition to working as a commentator, author and chess tutor, he will be publishing his first chess puzzle on Monday in The New York Times.

headline: The Art World Loves Basketballs. And Hoops and Jerseys and Backboards.
abstract: Fine art inspired by the sport is everywhere. One gallery filled nearly 5,000 square feet, and its curator said she “could do a Part 2 and Part 3 because there is that much work out there.”
lead_paragraph: The basketballs are deflated, doused in spray paint or covered in 24-karat gold leaf. They’re sculpted from porcelain, plopped in cement or layered into enormous pyramids. They’re splashed onto canvases, carved into cheeky jack-o’-lanterns, flattened out like flower petals.

headline: Heat Wave Persists in Southwest as Temperatures Reach Record Highs
abstract: More than 75 million people were under heat advisories or warnings on Sunday, a day after record high temperatures were set in more than a dozen places.
lead_paragraph: Heat advisories and excessive heat warnings were in effect for more than 75 million people in the southern and central United States on Sunday, a continuation of a scorching heat wave that resulted in record high temperatures on Saturday in 16 cities from the Southwest to the Southern Plains, according to the National Weather Service.

headline: Trump Is Still a Threat
abstract: The Jan. 6 committee hearings show how deeply Trump has altered our country.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is a cancer on this country.

headline: Hostile Crowds. $3,500 Tickets. Worth It to See Stephen Curry.
abstract: Some Golden State fans traveled thousands of miles to Boston to watch their team face the Celtics in the N.B.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As Stephen Curry emerged from an arena tunnel for his pregame warm-up routine, he was the center of gravity, drawing fans to him as he often does defenders on the court.

headline: Google Sidelines Engineer Who Claims Its A.I. Is Sentient
abstract: Blake Lemoine, the engineer, says that Google’s language model has a soul. The company disagrees.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google placed an engineer on paid leave recently after dismissing his claim that its artificial intelligence is sentient, surfacing yet another fracas about the company’s most advanced technology.

headline: Bolsonaro’s New Ally in Questioning Brazil’s Elections: The Military
abstract: Despite little evidence of past fraud, President Jair Bolsonaro has long raised doubts about Brazil’s electoral process. Now the military is expressing similar concerns.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil has for months consistently trailed in the polls ahead of the country’s crucial presidential race. And for months, he has consistently questioned its voting systems, warning that if he loses October’s election, it will most likely be thanks to a stolen vote.

headline: Two Gems of June: Premieres at Carnegie Hall and Harlem School of the Arts
abstract: The festival circuit may be getting underway but the city offers fine fare with programs of work by Sarah Kirkland Snider and Adegoke Steve Colson.
