lead_paragraph: This month, you might feel the momentum in classical music swinging to the domestic festival circuit, with splashy premieres and revivals coming courtesy of Spoleto, Ojai and the Opera Theater of St. Louis. But New York isn’t finished yet, either.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Encircles Sievierdonetsk
abstract: The last Ukrainian-held city in Luhansk is teetering on the brink.
lead_paragraph: Moscow’s forces could encircle the key city of Sievierodonetsk in eastern Ukraine and cut it off within days, the governor of Luhansk said.

headline: McDonald’s Reopens in Russia Under New Ownership
abstract: The American fast-food giant sold its 840 stores to a Siberian oil mogul after pulling out from Russia this spring to protest President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The American fast-food giant sold its 840 stores to a Siberian oil mogul after pulling out from Russia this spring to protest President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Goldman Sachs Is Being Investigated Over E.S.G. Funds
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has stepped up scrutiny of sustainable investing, which has become popular but is said to lack accountability.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating Goldman Sachs over its E.S.G. investment funds — funds that invest in companies that say they are committed to environmental, social and governance principles, according to two people familiar with the matter.

headline: Newly Alarmed Sweden Concludes Military Drill With U.S. Marines
abstract: The drill took place on Gotland, a Swedish island in the Baltic Sea that was demilitarized after the fall of the Soviet Union, but now again seems a critical military site.
lead_paragraph: With tensions raised across Europe over a newly belligerent Russia, Sweden’s military and the United States Marines concluded a drill on Sunday on Gotland, a Swedish island with strategic significance for control of the Baltic Sea.

headline: John R. Allen Resigns as Brookings President After Qatar Revelations
abstract: Mr. Allen, a retired four-star general, had been on administrative leave amid a federal inquiry into whether he had secretly lobbied for the government of Qatar.
lead_paragraph: John R. Allen, the retired four-star general who once commanded American troops in Afghanistan, resigned on Sunday as president of the Brookings Institution, six days after a court filing revealed evidence that he had secretly lobbied for Qatar.

headline: Pro-Macron Forces Expected to Prevail but Face Left-Wing Challenge
abstract: The French president’s party and its centrist allies were neck and neck with a left-wing alliance in France’s first round of parliamentary elections.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live news updates of France’s parliamentary elections.

headline: The Cubs Flirted With Success. The Yankees Define It.
abstract: Chicago’s inability to maintain momentum after its 2016 championship underscores how unusual the Yankees’ consistency is: They are on their way to a 30th straight winning season.
lead_paragraph: David Ross has won the World Series twice since the last time the Yankees got there, in 2009. Both his championship teams were big spenders in big markets — first the Boston Red Sox and then the Chicago Cubs. But he never thought either team would always contend.

headline: Trump’s inner circle pushed back as he claimed the election was stolen.
abstract: In videotaped testimony, former Attorney General William P. Barr outlined how the former president became ‘detached from reality’ in his claims of widespread fraud in the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President Donald J. Trump’s attorney general testified that he believed the president had grown delusional as he insisted on pushing false claims of widespread election fraud that he was told repeatedly were groundless, according to a videotaped interview played on Monday by the special committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack.

headline: Tough Questions for West as Ukraine Cities Teeter
abstract: Sievierodonetsk is nearly encircled. Lysychansk may be next. The momentum of the war has shifted, and Ukraine’s allies may soon start rethinking their goals.
lead_paragraph: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — With Russia about to encircle Sievierodonetsk, a city critical to its goal of seizing Ukraine’s east, and with a neighboring city squarely in Moscow’s sights, the question of how realities on the ground will shape the next phase of the war became still more pressing Sunday for Ukraine’s Western allies.

headline: U.S. Navy Plans ‘Safety Pause’ After Series of Aircraft Crashes
abstract: All non-deployed aircraft will stand down for one day to “review risk-management practices and conduct training,” the Navy said.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of three crashes, two of them fatal, the U.S. Navy has said it will ground all nondeployed aircraft for a day on Monday to focus on safety protocols.

headline: Kathy Hochul Is the Best Choice for Democrats in the June 28 Primary
abstract: Kathy Hochul deserves another four years as New York's governor.
lead_paragraph: Kathy Hochul deserves another four years as New York's governor.

headline: Angela Lansbury wins the lifetime achievement Tony. Read her Times reviews over the decades.
abstract: Lansbury, 96, was not present to accept the award in person, but the New York City Gay Men’s Chorus sang “Mame” as a special tribute.
lead_paragraph: Angela Lansbury, a beloved star of stage, film and television, was honored on Sunday night with a special Tony Award for lifetime achievement.

headline: Andrew Giuliani’s Vaccination Status Will Bar Him From Debate Studio
abstract: The Republican candidate for governor of New York is unvaccinated and says he has “natural immunity” to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — With the first Republican debate in the governor’s race scheduled for Monday night on WCBS-TV, the roster of in-person candidates has shrunk by one, as Andrew Giuliani — proudly unvaccinated against the coronavirus — announced on Sunday that he will not be allowed to attend.

headline: ‘A Start’: Gun Deal Stirs Hope but Also Frustration in Places Scarred by Shootings
abstract: In Uvalde, Buffalo and Orlando, some residents see progress but lament that there hasn’t been more.
lead_paragraph: Americans in communities where lives have been forever changed by gun violence reacted to the bipartisan deal that was reached by Senate negotiators on Sunday with a glint of hope but more than a tinge of frustration.

headline: The New York Times Editorial Board’s Interview With Tom Suozzi
abstract: The Long Island congressman speaks to the New York Times editorial board.
lead_paragraph: The Long Island congressman speaks to the New York Times editorial board.

headline: The New York Times Editorial Board’s Interview With Kathy Hochul
abstract: New York's governor speaks to the New York Times editorial board.
lead_paragraph: New York's governor speaks to the New York Times editorial board.

headline: The New York Times Editorial Board’s Interview With Jumaane Williams
abstract: New York City's public advocate speaks to the New York Times editorial board.
lead_paragraph: New York City's public advocate speaks to the New York Times editorial board.

headline: Ivermectin Has Little Effect on Recovery Time From Covid, Study Finds
abstract: A new clinical trial is the largest to date testing the antiparasitic drug on people with Covid.
lead_paragraph: The antiparasite drug ivermectin does not meaningfully reduce the time needed to recover from Covid, according to a large study posted online Sunday. It is the largest of several clinical trials to show that the drug, popular since the early pandemic as an alternative treatment, is not effective against the virus.

headline: Phylicia Rashad wins Tony for best featured actress in a play for ‘Skeleton Crew.’
abstract: “It’s wonderful to present humanity in its fullness and to feel it received,” said Rashad, who played the factory worker Faye.
lead_paragraph: The actress, director and educator Phylicia Rashad, 73, won the Tony for best featured actress in a play for her performance in “Skeleton Crew,” which was also nominated for best new play.

headline: Gun Deal Is Less Than Democrats Wanted, but More Than They Expected
abstract: Though the compromise does not go as far as many would have preferred, it is still seen as a serious step that could save lives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The bipartisan gun safety deal announced Sunday is far from what Democrats would have preferred in the aftermath of the racist gun massacre in Buffalo and the mass shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, but it is considerably more than they hoped for initially.

headline: Reawakening: the original cast of ‘Spring Awakening’ reunites at the Tonys.
abstract: More than 15 years after they stormed Broadway as an angsty set of adolescents, cast members sang a soulful edition of “Touch Me.”
lead_paragraph: More than 15 years after they stormed Broadway as an angsty set of adolescents, the original cast of the musical “Spring Awakening” reunited Sunday night at the Tonys and offered a special rendition of one of the musical’s most enduring songs.

headline: Google Agrees to Pay $118 Million to Settle Pay Discrimination Case
abstract: The tech giant admitted no wrongdoing as it resolved four women’s claims of widespread pay biases. The company will also allow an outside monitor to review its practices.
lead_paragraph: Google has settled a class-action lawsuit that accused it of systematically underpaying women, promising to provide $118 million in monetary relief and invite outsiders to review its pay practices.

headline: Pfizer Vaccine Effective in Children Under 5, the F.D.A. Says
abstract: Outside experts will make their recommendations this week on how the agency should rule on applications from Pfizer and Moderna to vaccinate the nation’s youngest children.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said on Sunday that three doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine appeared to be effective in preventing Covid illness in children under 5, judging by the level of virus-blocking antibodies the shots induced.

headline: Jennifer Hudson becomes an EGOT as a co-producer of the winning musical, ‘A Strange Loop.’
abstract: The singer and actress was added as a producer of the show as it transitioned to Broadway.
lead_paragraph: With a win for “A Strange Loop” in the best new musical category, Jennifer Hudson, one of the show’s co-producers, joins a select group of people who have won an Emmy, Grammy, Oscar and Tony.

headline: ‘A Strange Loop’ Wins Best Musical as Tonys Celebrate Broadway’s Return
abstract: “The Lehman Trilogy” won best play, “Company” won best musical revival and “Take Me Out” won best revival of a play at the 75th Tony Awards.
lead_paragraph: “A Strange Loop,” a scalding story about a gay, Black theater artist confronting self-doubt and societal disapproval, won the Tony Award for best new musical Sunday night, giving another huge accolade to a challenging contemporary production that had already won a Pulitzer Prize.

headline: Where Have You Gone, Arthur Ashe? LIV Tour Golfers Need You.
abstract: Our columnist asks whether players who have defected to the Saudi-financed golf series will use their platform to bring awareness to human rights violations. Don’t hold your breath.
lead_paragraph: Maybe some good for the world can come out of the lavish new golf tour backed by Saudi Arabia, among the most repressive governments in the world in the eyes of human rights groups.

headline: Stephen Curry Is More Human, and Brilliant, Than Ever
abstract: Golden State was good. Then too good. Then very, very bad. The worst. Back among the N.B.A. elite, Curry’s team has been humbled by the journey.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Stephen Curry was demoralizing the Celtics when he decided to improvise. After he dribbled to spin past Marcus Smart, who happens to be one of the N.B.A.’s most ferocious defenders, Curry found himself sizing up Robert Williams, a 6-foot-9 center whose sneakers might as well have been filled with concrete.

headline: Red Carpet From the 75th Tony Awards
abstract: Looks from the 75th Tony Awards at Radio City Music Hall.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the 75th Tony Awards at Radio City Music Hall.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Since Childhood, She’s Stood Out. In Pro Baseball, Kelsie Whitmore Wants to Fit In.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 13, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “You’d hear the doubters. ‘Hey, the boys are going to get stronger, and she’s not going to be able to hang with them.’ They said that at age 12, and it never happened.”

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Old Man’ and Juneteenth Specials
abstract: Jeff Bridges stars in a new thriller series on FX. And several networks air programs recognizing Juneteenth.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 13 - 19. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Gun control in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after 19 children and two teachers died in a gun massacre at a Texas elementary school, a bipartisan group of U.S. senators yesterday struck a deal on a gun control bill. The agreement includes enhanced background checks for people under the age of 21 and a provision to close the “boyfriend loophole” by extending to dating partners a prohibition on gun ownership for domestic abusers.

headline: Photos of Tony Award Winners 2022
abstract: Photos of Tony Award Winners 2022
lead_paragraph: Photos of Tony Award Winners 2022

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Two Targets of Trump’s Ire Take Different Paths in South Carolina
abstract: Representative Nancy Mace, after criticizing the president for the Jan. 6 riot, has tried to focus on other issues. Representative Tom Rice, however, isn’t backing down.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on primary elections and results in South Carolina.

headline: The Hotel Is 642 Feet Tall. Its ‘Architect’ Says He Never Saw the Plans.
abstract: An architect lent his license to a New York City developer to approve buildings he didn’t design, according to an investigation by The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Amid the glittering geometric towers that dot the Manhattan skyline, the hotel on 11th Avenue in Hudson Yards was designed to stand out. At 642 feet tall, the building soars above the Hudson River, featuring jagged sets of floor-to-ceiling windows that shimmer in the sun.

headline: India’s Economy Is Growing Quickly. Why Can’t It Produce Enough Jobs?
abstract: The disconnect is a result of India’s uneven growth, powered and enjoyed by the country’s upper strata.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On paper, India’s economy has had a banner year. Exports are at record highs. Profits of publicly traded companies have doubled. A vibrant middle class, built over the past few decades, is now shelling out so much on movie tickets, cars, real estate and vacations that economists call it post-pandemic “revenge spending.”

headline: Just 5 Months Into His Term, Adams Is Busy Raising Money to Win Another
abstract: The mayor has kicked off a cross-country fund-raising blitz for re-election, taking his tour to Chicago and Beverly Hills, even as he confronts major challenges in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Not long after celebrating his first 100 days as mayor this spring, Eric Adams was poolside in Beverly Hills, Calif., already thinking about the future.

headline: Did This High-Rise Get an Architect’s Seal of Approval?
abstract: A retired architect lent his license to approve plans for a Hudson Yards building. But he says he never actually reviewed them.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at an architect who lent his license to a New York City developer to approve buildings he says he didn’t design. We’ll also look at whether to expect an economic payday from casinos.

headline: Who Will Remember the Horrors of Ukraine?
abstract: A patch of land on the north side of Kyiv is the site of recurring horror, repressed memories, and bloody historical echoes. But there are glimmers of a justice to come.
lead_paragraph: A patch of land on the north side of Kyiv is the site of recurring horror, repressed memories, and bloody historical echoes. But there are glimmers of a justice to come.

headline: Tom Hanks Explains It All
abstract: The iconic actor on his wild new Elvis movie, his faith in America, and why his Oscar-winning movies might not get made today.
lead_paragraph: The iconic actor on his wild new Elvis movie, his faith in America, and why his Oscar-winning movies might not get made today.

headline: The Planet Is Burning. Are Billionaires the Answer?
abstract: The billionaire venture capitalist John Doerr offers his views on what Silicon Valley’s elite can — and can’t — do to stop, or at least slow, climate change.
lead_paragraph: What if Silicon Valley’s next big frontier were not web3 but climate change? That’s the bet the venture capitalist John Doerr is making: Doerr, the billionaire author of “Speed and Scale: An Action Plan for Solving Our Climate Crisis Now,” recently donated $1.1 billion to Stanford University to fund a new school focused on climate and sustainability, describing climate science as “the new computer science.” But with the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s latest assessment noting that the dangers of climate change are building rapidly, piles of cash and a burst of brain power may prove too little, too late.

headline: Helping Very Hungry Caterpillars Become Butterflies — It’s Complicated
abstract: This is the trouble with trying to help a natural world in so much peril. It’s never entirely clear when it’s right to intervene and when it’s wrong.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — After all my blue false indigo was killed by a late frost, I went down to the garden center at the farmer’s market looking for more. Blue false indigo is a host plant of the clouded sulphur butterfly, and clouded sulphurs are the most reliable guests in my pollinator patch. I would hate to be caught short-handed when they returned in all their yellow glory. There have been so few butterflies lately.

headline: New Tools Can Make Our Covid Immunity Even Stronger
abstract: How to make Covid immunity even more durable.
lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 pandemic has been a protracted battle between a generation-defining virus and scientists working at a breakneck pace to fight it. Following the development of the remarkably effective first-generation Covid-19 vaccines, the virus made its response: More infectious variants have emerged, capable of infecting people who have been vaccinated or were previously infected. This is by no means a failure of the vaccines, which continue to keep millions of people protected from the most devastating consequences of the virus. But science should be ready to make its next move.

headline: It’s Not Easy Being President
abstract: But we do have a few suggestions.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Joe Biden’s presidency is in deep political trouble. His approval ratings are plumbing sub-Trumpian depths. If inflation keeps rising and the economy tanks, it’s going to get worse.

headline: What It Took for a Country With a Strong Gun Culture to Give Them Up
abstract: Australia’s success with gun reform was mostly a result of timing, luck and the idiosyncrasies of its Constitution. But it does hold important lessons for the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Within hours of the school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, last month, as President Biden flew home from a trip to Asia, he found himself wondering why liberal democracies like Australia, Canada and Britain can get gun violence under control, while America has tried for decades without success. “They have mental health problems. They have domestic disputes,” he said in an address to the nation later that night. “They have people who are lost. But these kinds of mass shootings never happen with the kind of frequency that they happen in America. Why?”

headline: How Covid Did Away With the Sick Day
abstract: Some workers have no choice but to clock in. Others find the flexibility of remote work leads them to log in from their sick beds.
lead_paragraph: The tone of the typical isolation postcard is sunny, insistent and aspirational as a holiday greeting: “Thanks to everyone who sent well wishes for @VP,” wrote Doug Emhoff, the second gentleman, on Twitter. “She is feeling good and is working from home.”

headline: Can Carbon Capture Be Part of the Climate Solution?
abstract: Jennifer Wilcox, who has a leading role in the U.S. Department of Energy’s Office of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management, says yes, though there are significant challenges.
lead_paragraph: This is the final installment in the Visionaries series, which looks at figures who are trying to transform the way we live.

headline: Moved During the Pandemic? You May Need to Update Your Insurance.
abstract: Many people changed where and how they lived, but “upgrading their policies for all of these experiences fell by the wayside,” an appraisal executive said.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus pandemic hit in 2020, Carolyn Richmond, a longtime New Yorker, packed several bags and drove to her weekend home in Sag Harbor, N.Y., with the intention of staying a week or two. She never left.

headline: At More Homes, Every Square Foot Is a Stage (for Rent by the Hour)
abstract: Booking stylishly decorated private residences as alternatives to sets and studios is a growing niche in the short-term rental market.
lead_paragraph: When Bethany Morrison, a model, contacted Braylen Dion, a photographer, early last year with an idea for a photo shoot, Ms. Morrison had worked out every detail except for a location.

headline: Shopping for Media Consoles
abstract: The newest media consoles don’t scream “entertainment center” — they look more like stylish credenzas.
lead_paragraph: As televisions and speakers have become increasingly smart, streamlined and wireless, the mess of components and cables that once cluttered living spaces has been gradually disappearing. But it’s still helpful to have a good media console, whether you have the newest ultrathin TV, vintage stereo equipment or both.

headline: The Corpse of a Russian Soldier, and the Cold but Human Urge to Look
abstract: Why does war’s wreckage — the downed helicopters, the destroyed tanks and the dead — draw crowds? A former Marine ponders the question as he stands before the badly burned body of a Russian fighter.
lead_paragraph: HUSARIVKA, Ukraine — There’s a dead guy in there.

headline: Capturing the Joyful Spirit of a Montana General Store
abstract: The state’s oldest continually open general store serves customers in Fishtail from all walks of life, from ranchers and miners to doctors and C.E.O.s.
lead_paragraph: My husband probably thought I had found someone else. Why else would I keep detouring off Interstate 90 to a town whose population is smaller than my daughter’s high school class?

headline: Sonia Gandhi, India’s opposition leader, is hospitalized with ‘Covid-related issues’.
abstract: Sonia Gandhi, a towering public figure in India and the president of the opposition Indian National Congress party, has been hospitalized in Delhi with “Covid-related issues,” the party said on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Sonia Gandhi, a towering public figure in India and the president of the opposition Indian National Congress party, has been hospitalized in Delhi with “Covid-related issues,” the party said on Sunday.

headline: As the Large Hadron Collider Revs Up, Physicists’ Hopes Soar
abstract: The particle collider at CERN will soon restart. “There could be a revolution coming,” scientists say.
lead_paragraph: In April, scientists at the European Center for Nuclear Research, or CERN, outside Geneva, once again fired up their cosmic gun, the Large Hadron Collider. After a three-year shutdown for repairs and upgrades, the collider has resumed shooting protons — the naked guts of hydrogen atoms — around its 17-mile electromagnetic underground racetrack. In early July, the collider will begin crashing these particles together to create sparks of primordial energy.

headline: They Conflated ‘The Wire’ With Reality
abstract: A Baltimore photographer considers the HBO drama’s impact on the city where he was raised, 20 years after the show’s debut.
lead_paragraph: I was born and raised in Baltimore. I was in middle school when “The Wire” was made — it filmed near McCulloh Homes and also sometimes near Harlem Park, where my school was located. Back then everybody thought, wow, this is Baltimore’s moment. It was a very exciting experience for the city.

headline: Best and Worst Moments of the 75th Tony Awards
abstract: With Joaquina Kalukango’s high notes and Billy Crystal’s lowbrow jokes, the Tonys celebrated Broadway’s return after a tumultuous season.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Awards returned to Radio City Music Hall on Sunday for the first time since June 2019. And after such a roller-coaster ride of a year, the ceremony was a welcome chance to celebrate all those people (from understudies and swings to stage managers and Covid safety officers) who made sure the show went on again (and again). Ariana DeBose, the former theater understudy turned recent Oscar winner, was the host of the three-hour broadcast portion of the ceremony on CBS. But it was Darren Criss and Julianne Hough, hosts of the first hour of the ceremony on Paramount+, who delighted one of our writers with their endearing eagerness to put on a show. As for the awards themselves: There were a few pleasant surprises but voters showed that they were craving the familiar. Here are the highs and lows as our writers saw them. NICOLE HERRINGTON

headline: The Bloody Echoes of Babyn Yar
abstract: A World War II burial ground in Ukraine is struck by Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

headline: Bear Market Sends Grim Signal of Economic Fears
abstract: The S&P has declined 22 percent since January, amid converging worries about inflation, the Ukraine war, Covid and the Fed’s response to the economy.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks ago, Wall Street narrowly escaped a bear market, with stocks rebounding at the last minute from a brutal drop that had brought the S&P 500 down 20 percent from a record high in January. The next few weeks offered a glimmer of hope that the worst of the losses might be over.

headline: The Incomplete Picture of the War in Ukraine
abstract: Information blind spots could have serious implications for U.S. military aid.
lead_paragraph: In the nearly four months since the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the United States has been giving officials in Kyiv a steady stream of intelligence to aid them in the fight.

headline: The Politics of Abortion
abstract: Polls show that support for abortion rights is rising. Will that help Democrats this fall?
lead_paragraph: Regular readers of this newsletter may remember the thermostat theory of politics. It’s the idea, developed by the political scientist Christopher Wlezien, that public opinion often moves in the opposite direction as government policy.

headline: After 10 Years, Barrie Kosky Leaves His Opera House Dancing
abstract: To say goodbye to a transformative tenure at the Komische Oper in Berlin, this director staged an “All-Singing, All-Dancing Yiddish Revue.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It’s difficult to pinpoint the most outrageous moment of “Barrie Kosky’s All-Singing, All-Dancing Yiddish Revue,” which opened at the Komische Oper here on Friday. Is it the 1960s-era pilot and flight attendant in drag belting “My Way” (sorry, “Mayn Veg”) under a shower of golden confetti? The subtle camp of an imaginary Choir of Temple Beth Emmanuel singing with straight-faced sincerity? The “message from our sponsors” advertising “delectably light, always right, gefilte fish in jars”?

headline: Striking truck drivers in South Korea snarl supply chains.
abstract: Automakers and steel companies reported disruptions as a job action entered a seventh day.
lead_paragraph: A truck-driver strike in South Korea stretched into a seventh day on Monday, forcing the country’s manufacturers to scale back production and slowing traffic at its ports.

headline: New Experimental Therapy for A.L.S. Approved in Canada
abstract: The F.D.A. is also reviewing the treatment, Albrioza, but the agency’s scientists have raised questions about its effectiveness.
lead_paragraph: An experimental therapy for A.L.S., the paralyzing and fatal neurological disorder, has been approved in Canada, adding a new treatment option for a disease for which there are few effective therapies.

headline: Mets Fight Through Long Trip and Come Home (Still) on Top
abstract: By upping their communication on the field, the Mets absorbed the worst blows of an 11-day California adventure. But Atlanta, having shaken off the rust, is in hot pursuit.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Closer Edwin Díaz emphatically wrapped up the Mets’ 10-game West Coast trip with a five-out save to preserve a 4-1 win over the Los Angeles Angels on Sunday night. But it was a decidedly smaller moment in the series that spoke volumes about the chemistry and character of these National League-leading Mets.

headline: U.N. Human Rights Chief Decides Not to Seek a Second Term
abstract: The announcement by Michelle Bachelet, the U.N. high commissioner for human rights, came a month after she was criticized by rights groups for traveling to China.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations’ top human rights official announced Monday that she was stepping down when her term expires at the end of August, less than a month after a visit to China that drew fierce criticism from human rights groups.

headline: A Saharan Dust Cloud Stretching to Texas
abstract: Some 100 million tons of dust from the Sahara Desert blow out over the Atlantic Ocean each year — enough to be visible in satellite photos. A plume is expected to reach Texas this week.
lead_paragraph: Some 100 million tons of dust from the Sahara Desert blow out over the Atlantic Ocean each year — enough to be visible in satellite photos. A plume is expected to reach Texas this week.

headline: How to Read and Write a Chess Game
abstract: Algebraic notation is the standard way chess players record their moves.
lead_paragraph: The standard method of recording moves in a chess game is known as algebraic notation. The name isn’t quite accurate; no math is required. Being able to read and understand notation is a vital skill for any chess player looking to read tournament coverage or solve puzzles. In many online chess games or tournaments, this notation is automatically generated. In over-the-board or in-person tournaments, players are often required to write down their moves using this system.

headline: How to Play Chess
abstract: Your guide to getting started with chess, and the New York Times chess puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Chess is an ancient game that traces its roots back to India. Some strategies in today’s top tournaments can also be found in games that happened hundreds of years ago, while others were spawned in the last two or three decades with the advent of artificial intelligence. Let reading this guide be your first step toward learning one of the most popular board games of all time.

headline: A man who carried a Confederate flag into the Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack goes on trial.
abstract: Kevin Seefried of Delaware was one of the first in a wave of pro-Trump rioters to breach the building where Congress was certifying electoral votes on Jan. 6, 2021.
lead_paragraph: In a reminder that Congress and the Justice Department are each conducting their own investigations of the events surrounding the attack on the Capitol last year, a criminal trial connected to the riot will begin on Monday, even as the House select committee holds its second in a series of hearings on its findings.

headline: The Words You Need to Know to Play Chess
abstract: A vocabulary list.
lead_paragraph: There are a number of terms used in chess discussions that may not be immediately understandable to every reader. This is by no means a complete list, but it should be enough to get you started with classic chess, as well as The Times’s puzzle, Chess Replay.

headline: Efforts to Form a New Government in Iraq Descend Into Chaos
abstract: The powerful Shiite cleric Muqtada al-Sadr, who controls the largest bloc in Parliament, has directed dozens of lawmakers loyal to him to resign.
lead_paragraph: Seven months of efforts to form a new government in Iraq were in turmoil on Monday, a day after the powerful Shiite cleric Muqtada al-Sadr directed members of Parliament who are loyal to him to resign from the seats they won in an October election.

headline: What you should know about bear markets.
abstract: There have been several instances of near-bear markets in recent decades, but it’s rare for them to hit the threshold.
lead_paragraph: Bear markets, or when stocks drop at least 20 percent from their most recent peaks, are relatively rare and signal that investors are viewing the economy with serious pessimism.

headline: World Cup Will Allow Five Substitutes and Bigger Rosters
abstract: A rule change means coaches will for the first time have the option to make as many as five changes per game, and draw them from deeper benches.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — The use of extra substitutes in matches, a change to longstanding soccer tradition brought about by the coronavirus pandemic, was formally written into the sport’s rules on Monday, only five months before the start of this year’s World Cup in Qatar.

headline: Preet Bharara’s New Gig
abstract: It’s the former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York’s first legal role since he was fired by Donald Trump in 2017.
lead_paragraph: Preet Bharara, the former federal prosecutor, high-profile Donald Trump critic and host of a popular podcast, is joining WilmerHale, the law firm that has become home to a number of former government officials, report The Times’s Benjamin Weiser and Ben Protess in an exclusive for DealBook.

headline: Nipsey Hussle Murder Trial: What to Know, as Closing Arguments Near
abstract: More than three years after the Los Angeles rapper was shot and killed, the trial of Eric Holder Jr., the accused gunman, is nearing its conclusion.
lead_paragraph: More than three years after the fatal shooting of the rapper Nipsey Hussle, a proudly local Los Angeles artist whose killing reverberated far beyond the world of West Coast hip-hop, the trial of the accused gunman, Eric R. Holder Jr., is nearing its conclusion. The case, which had been repeatedly delayed because of the Covid-19 pandemic, began earlier this month, with closing arguments expected later this week and jury deliberations to follow.

headline: California Prepares to Launch a Mental Health Hotline
abstract: Going live nationwide on July 16, the hotline is intended to be like 911 but for psychiatric instead of medical emergencies.
lead_paragraph: It’s Monday. California is preparing to launch a new mental health hotline. Plus, gas prices are higher than ever.

headline: $1 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1923 bungalow in Monrovia, a two-bedroom condominium unit in Oakland and a Spanish-style house in San Diego.
lead_paragraph: A 1923 bungalow in Monrovia, a two-bedroom condominium unit in Oakland and a Spanish-style house in San Diego.

headline: $1 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1923 bungalow in Monrovia, a two-bedroom condominium unit in Oakland and a Spanish-style house in San Diego.
lead_paragraph: This house is in the northern part of Monrovia, a few blocks from one of the city’s main thoroughfares, which has a Vons supermarket, a frozen yogurt shop and a gym. Several hiking trails that wind up to Mount Wilson, in the San Gabriel Mountains, are about 20 minutes away by car.

headline: Chess Replay: You Versus Frumkin
abstract: Take on Edward A. Frumkin in a recreation of a tournament game in New York, 1987. Solve for the best series of moves.
lead_paragraph: About Daniel

headline: Control of Luhansk, and the wider Donbas region, could hinge on the battle for Sievierodonetsk.
abstract: Russian-backed forces already control an estimated 80 to 90 percent of the Donbas, which is a prize for President Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: The battle for Sievierodonetsk, which could fall to the Russians within days, is about far more than one city. Its capture would give Russia a key victory in its drive to seize the entire Donbas region of eastern Ukraine.

headline: We Are Our Own Architects
abstract: We tend to gravitate toward ideas that fit our already established notions of reality — but it’s never too late to change.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Trump’s former campaign chief pulls out of Jan. 6 hearing on election lies.
abstract: Bill Stepien said an hour before the hearing was scheduled to start that he was sending his attorney to read a statement on his behalf.
lead_paragraph: Bill Stepien, President Donald J. Trump’s campaign manager during the 2020 election, will not appear in person as scheduled to testify on Monday before the Jan. 6 committee because his wife went into labor, two people familiar with the events said.

headline: Ohio Makes It Easier for Teachers to Carry Guns at School
abstract: A new law requires educators and other school staff members who want to carry a weapon to undergo no more than 24 hours of training — compared with more than 700 hours previously.
lead_paragraph: Teachers and other school employees in Ohio will be able to carry firearms into school with a tiny fraction of the training that has been required since last year, after Gov. Mike DeWine signed a bill into law on Monday.

headline: Britain Moves Ahead With Plans to Scrap Trade Rules on Northern Ireland
abstract: The action by the government of Prime Minister Boris Johnson to scuttle the post-Brexit trade arrangement risks a clash with the European Union and upsetting the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain moved ahead on Monday with plans to scuttle the post-Brexit trade rules in Northern Ireland, risking a clash with the European Union, a rift with neighboring Ireland, and tensions with the United States.

headline: Russia’s Oil Revenue Soars Despite Sanctions, Study Finds
abstract: Rising oil prices more than offset a decline in export volumes during the first 100 days of the assault on Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine triggered global condemnation and tough sanctions aimed at denting Moscow’s war chest. Yet Russia’s revenues from fossil fuels, by far its biggest export, soared to records in the first 100 days of its war on Ukraine, driven by a windfall from oil sales amid surging prices, a new analysis shows.

headline: Preet Bharara, the former federal prosecutor and Trump critic, has a new job: private practice.
abstract: The firm’s partners have included Robert S. Mueller III and Alejandro Mayorkas.
lead_paragraph: Preet Bharara, the former federal prosecutor, high-profile Donald Trump critic and host of a popular podcast, is joining WilmerHale, a well-connected law firm that has become home to a number of former government officials.

headline: Disney loses bid for the rights to stream Indian Premier League cricket matches.
abstract: The rights, which sold for nearly $3 billion, went to Viacom18, a joint venture between Paramount and Reliance Industries
lead_paragraph: Viacom18 has won the rights to stream a package of popular cricket matches from the Indian Premier League, according to two people with knowledge of the bidding, snatching a significant weapon in the streaming wars away from one of its chief rivals, the Walt Disney Company.

headline: As the Biennale Expands, Locals Ask, ‘Whose Venice Is It?’
abstract: A plan to give more space to the event in a waterside heritage site has kicked off a debate over the future of one of the city’s largest public properties, and, by extension, of the city itself.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — Since its founding in 1895, the Venice Biennale has become one of the world’s most important venues for contemporary art, attracting hundreds of thousands of visitors to the city for its influential exhibitions and performances.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Bryan Washington’s recipe for korokke is perfect with shredded cabbage, or between slices of milk bread.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Korokke (above) is a Japanese take on the French croquette: a golden-fried patty of mashed potatoes, simmered vegetables and, sometimes, a protein. “You could eat one or two or 10 on their own,” Bryan Washington wrote in The New York Times Magazine this weekend. “You could pair them with shredded cabbage. And, with the croquettes nestled between slices of milk bread and lavished in kewpie mayo, a korokke sandwich is a revelation.”

headline: Microsoft Pledges Neutrality in Union Campaigns at Activision
abstract: The accord could ease the path for thousands of workers to unionize at the game company, which Microsoft is acquiring, and addresses an antitrust objection.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft and the Communications Workers of America union announced an agreement on Monday that would make it easier for employees to unionize at the video game maker Activision Blizzard, which Microsoft is acquiring for $70 billion.

headline: The Fight to End ‘Cyberflashing’
abstract: Payton Iheme, the head of public policy for Bumble in the Americas, is working to advance legislation that penalizes the act of sending unwanted sexual images.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Chris Stirewalt defended his team’s calling the election for Biden. Fox News fired him.
abstract: Mr. Stirewalt, a former politics editor at Fox News, is among those testifying on Monday.
lead_paragraph: When Chris Stirewalt watched rioters attack the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, he was a journalist for Fox News, which was trying to recover from a ratings slump in the weeks after President Donald J. Trump lost his re-election campaign.

headline: As China Rattles Sabers, Taiwan Asks: Are We Ready for War?
abstract: Ukraine’s stubborn resistance to invasion, and the help that has poured in as a result, has both inspired Taiwan and made it rethink its own military strategy.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Russia’s brutal war in Ukraine has jolted Taiwan into confronting the specter of a sudden attack from the island’s own larger and more powerful neighbor: China.

headline: Tennessee’s Superteam Comes Up Short of College World Series
abstract: Even 57 wins do not necessarily get you a baseball championship, as the Volunteers found out the hard way.
lead_paragraph: The University of Tennessee was widely heralded as the best college baseball team in a generation. But like so many other top seeds through the years, the Volunteers couldn’t navigate the N.C.A.A baseball playoffs and were eliminated without even making it to the eight-team College World Series.

headline: Doug Mastriano names Jenna Ellis, a former Trump campaign lawyer, as a senior legal adviser.
abstract: Mr. Mastriano, the Republican nominee for governor in Pennsylvania, appointed a like-minded Trump loyalist who, just as he did, tried to overturn the 2020 election results.
lead_paragraph: Doug Mastriano, the Republican nominee for governor in Pennsylvania, has appointed Jenna Ellis, a former lawyer for the Trump campaign who worked to overturn the 2020 election, as a senior legal adviser, his campaign announced on Monday.

headline: Celsius Network Leads Crypto Markets Into Another Free Fall
abstract: The value of cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and Ether plummeted over the last day as investors continued to show nervousness about their stability.
lead_paragraph: The offer seemed too good to pass up: Deposit your cryptocurrency, and receive a yield as high as 18 percent.

headline: Five Years On, Five Lives Shattered by the Grenfell Tower Fire
abstract: After 72 people died in the blaze in 2017, there were vows of reform and accountability. But for those whose lives were upended by the disaster, there have been few answers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The shell of Grenfell Tower, the scene of Britain’s deadliest residential fire since World War II, still looms over the northwest London neighborhood where it burned on June 14, 2017. Now, shrouded in white plastic, it stands as a visible reminder of the 72 lives lost.

headline: London Police Charge Kevin Spacey With Sexual Assault
abstract: The actor will appear in a London court on Thursday to start what could be a lengthy trial process over multiple allegations of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The actor Kevin Spacey was charged with four counts of sexual assault on Monday in London, the city’s police force said in a news release.

headline: Byung J. Pak, a former U.S. attorney in Atlanta, is testifying about his investigation of voter fraud in Georgia.
abstract: Mr. Pak has said he resigned rather than be fired by Trump for failing to find evidence of fraud.
lead_paragraph: Byung J. Pak, a former U.S. attorney in Atlanta, is testifying Monday on his decision to resign in January 2021 before President Donald J. Trump fired him for refusing to say that widespread voter fraud had been found in Georgia.

headline: Will the Jan. 6 Hearings Lead to a Trump Indictment?
abstract: If it does not, the hearings will have been “a cruel tease,” one reader opines. Also: Gender terms; postpartum care; gun maker liability; moral injury.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: All Glammed Up
abstract: What they wore to the Time 100 gala, the MoMA Party at the Garden and Free Arts benefit.
lead_paragraph: There were Hollywood stars, athletes and even a wartime president (Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, in a recorded video). Time held its 100 Most Influential People in the World gala on Wednesday at Jazz at Lincoln Center, with a dinner and a performance by Mary J. Blige.

headline: Al Schmidt: A Philadelphia Republican who continued counting votes as Trump’s pressure mounted.
abstract: Mr. Schmidt said he received threats over his role in counting ballots.
lead_paragraph: On the night of Thursday, Nov. 5, 2020, Joseph R. Biden Jr. had at least 253 electoral votes. A win for him in Pennsylvania, with its 20 electoral votes, would decide the presidential election.

headline: Benjamin Ginsberg, an election lawyer, has been one of Trump’s foremost Republican critics.
abstract: Mr. Ginsberg has also become disenchanted with the Republican Party, arguing the GOP was “destroying itself on the altar of Trump.”
lead_paragraph: For 30 years, Benjamin Ginsberg was one of the top election lawyers in Republican politics. He played a central role in the party’s redistricting efforts; the George W. Bush campaigns, including the 2000 Florida recount; and Mitt Romney’s two presidential campaigns.

headline: Britain Plans to Fly Refugees to Rwanda on Tuesday
abstract: A court refused two appeals Monday, clearing the way for Britain to begin implementing the controversial plan to process and resettle people who crossed the English Channel to get to England.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government planned to proceed on Tuesday with flying immigrants to Rwanda for processing and resettlement, after a court blocked two appeals to the contentious plan on Monday, according to Care4Calais, one of the aid groups involved in the appeal.

headline: Ottessa Moshfegh’s ‘Lapvona’ Is Gloomy Folk Horror Set Long Ago
abstract: Moshfegh’s latest novel, which takes place in a fictional medieval village, fixates on ugliness and pain.
lead_paragraph: Ottessa Moshfegh has a glittering intellect and an unquenchable dark turn of mind. Only the latter is on display in “Lapvona,” her fourth novel. It’s a pungent book but a flat one, narrow in its emotional range, a bleak, meandering and muddy-soled mix of fairy tale and folk horror.

headline: Investors are nervously eyeing the Fed.
abstract: Traders now expect a three-quarter-point interest rate increase, the largest since 1994, by September. Wall Street is bracing for the fallout.
lead_paragraph: American stock indexes dropped sharply Monday, and a key bond market signal pointed to recession risks, indicating that investors are bracing for economic fallout as central banks — including the Federal Reserve — try to rein in rapid inflation.

headline: New York Philharmonic Agrees to Restore Pay for Musicians
abstract: After a stronger-than-expected season, the orchestra said it would reverse pay cuts imposed at the height of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus pandemic erupted in 2020, battering the cultural sector and forcing the New York Philharmonic to cancel a season, the orchestra worked to cut costs, slashing its musicians’ pay by 25 percent.

headline: Authorities Find Belongings of Missing Journalist and Expert in Amazon
abstract: Search crews found clothes and other belongings of the two men who went missing in the Amazon last week. Authorities are also testing blood from a suspect’s boat and human remains found elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — A British journalist and a Brazilian expert on Indigenous peoples have now been missing deep in the Amazon rainforest for more than a week, and increasing signs suggest that the two men may not be found alive.

headline: Barr Says Trump Was ‘Detached From Reality’
abstract: In video testimony, William P. Barr, the former attorney general, said that the widespread claims of electoral voter fraud that Donald J. Trump repeated to his supporters were nonsense.
lead_paragraph: In video testimony, William P. Barr, the former attorney general, said that the widespread claims of electoral voter fraud that Donald J. Trump repeated to his supporters were nonsense.

headline: They Were Cigarette Smokers. Then a Stroke Vanquished Their Addiction.
abstract: Patients whose brain injury coincidentally relieved their nicotine cravings may help unravel the neural underpinnings of addiction, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Taking a scan of an injured brain often produces a map of irretrievable losses, revealing spots where damage causes memory difficulties or tremors.

headline: Eric Kim’s Essential Korean Recipes
abstract: “If I could have only 10 Korean dishes for the rest of my life, these would be the ones.” The Times Magazine columnist, cookbook author and son of South Korean immigrants shares the dishes that define the cuisine for him.
lead_paragraph: “Daebak!” — pronounced DEH-bahk, often with a long, guttural emphasis on the first syllable — can be a noun, an adjective or an interjection that expresses approval when something is truly great.

headline: Trump’s attorney general said the president showed no interest in ‘actual facts.’
abstract: William P. Barr said Mr. Trump was doing a “disservice” to the country by promoting claims of a stolen election.
lead_paragraph: Former attorney general William P. Barr delivered some of the starkest assessments of President Trump’s obsession with voter fraud in the weeks following the election, saying in a recorded deposition that he believed the former president had become “detached from reality” as he pushed the Justice Department to investigate increasingly far-fetched fraud claims.

headline: How to Help a Loved One Having Suicidal Thoughts
abstract: An adult can’t be forced into treatment, but experts say there are many ways to be there for someone contemplating self-harm.
lead_paragraph: Emily Nixon was 34 the first time she tried to take her own life, in 2014. She had wrestled with depression most of her life and was prescribed anti-depressants at 19. But she often forgot to take her medication, and she drank too much alcohol. Life was, she said, “overwhelming.”

headline: 4 takeaways from Day 2 of the Jan. 6 hearings.
abstract: The big theme on the second day was that former President Trump was told repeatedly — including by his own attorney general — that his “big lie” about a fraudulent election was baseless.
lead_paragraph: The one big theme on the second day of hearings by the Jan. 6 committee was that former President Trump was told repeatedly — including by his own attorney general — that his “big lie” about a fraudulent election was baseless. But he made the fake claim on election night anyway, and hasn’t stopped since.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Bail Hearings for Jailed Immigrants
abstract: A federal law, the justices ruled, does not require immigration judges to consider whether immigrants may be released while their challenges are pending.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that a federal law does not require that immigrants detained for long periods while they are fighting deportation be granted hearings to decide whether they may be released on bond as their cases move forward.

headline: Kate Bush Rides ‘Stranger Things’ to a New High on the Singles Chart
abstract: “Running Up That Hill (A Deal With God)” hit No. 4 on the U.S. singles chart this week, 37 years after its release. Harry Styles’s “As It Was” is still No. 1.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-seven years ago, the British singer-songwriter Kate Bush released the song “Running Up That Hill (A Deal With God)” as part of her album “Hounds of Love.” The single went to No. 3 in Britain and No. 30 in the United States, and took its place as a signature piece of Bush’s catalog — an intense ballad with a driving beat, a playful synthesizer melody and Bush’s dramatic vocals.

headline: Never Missing a Curtain This Season, the Met Opera Takes a Final Bow
abstract: As it ended a challenging pandemic return, the Met had one last marathon: a matinee, an evening performance, and then moving out as American Ballet Theater moved in.
lead_paragraph: In a season dogged by wave after wave of the coronavirus, there were moments when the Metropolitan Opera was on the verge of cancellation.

headline: Courses at Horses
abstract: A noteworthy Cornish game hen, bowls of ice-cold oysters, fresh ravioli and more.
lead_paragraph: A noteworthy Cornish game hen, bowls of ice-cold oysters, fresh ravioli and more.

headline: A Hollywood Hangout Where the Food Is Actually the Point
abstract: Horses is that rare animal in Los Angeles: a hot reservation with serious cooking behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — I don’t want to be that person who recommends the chicken. Especially not here, at a restaurant you’ll likely wait months or weeks to get into — a bit less, maybe, if you can maintain a healthy working relationship with Resy’s “notify” button.

headline: Iran Suspects Israel Killed Two Scientists With Poison
abstract: If Iran’s suspicions about the deaths are confirmed, these would be the latest killings in a shadow war that is reaching new intensity as Iran moves closer to nuclear weapons capability.
lead_paragraph: They both graduated from Iran’s top universities — young, healthy and athletic — before they suddenly fell ill in late May. The two scientists grew sicker and sicker, and ended up in the intensive care units of hospitals in two different cities nearly 400 miles apart.

headline: SpaceX Wins Environmental Approval for Launch of Mars Rocket
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration placed conditions on the flights, but ruled that a more extensive environmental impact statement that would have caused delays was not required.
lead_paragraph: There are no environmental showstoppers in SpaceX’s plans to launch a giant new rocket to orbit from South Texas, the Federal Aviation Administration said on Monday.

headline: Former Fox News Editor Testifies at Jan. 6 Committee Hearing
abstract: Chris Stirewalt was ousted from Fox News after he and his team decided to call Arizona for Joseph R. Biden Jr. shortly before midnight on Election Day in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Chris Stirewalt was ousted from Fox News after he and his team decided to call Arizona for Joseph R. Biden Jr. shortly before midnight on Election Day in 2020.

headline: How Extreme Heat Kills, Sickens, Strains and Ages Us
abstract: Researchers are drilling down into the ways life on a hotter planet will tax our bodies, and looking for protections that, unlike air-conditioning, don’t make the problem worse.
lead_paragraph: When W. Larry Kenney, a professor of physiology at Pennsylvania State University, began studying how extreme heat harms humans, his research focused on workers inside the disaster-stricken Three Mile Island nuclear plant, where temperatures were as high as 165 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: Fred the Mastodon’s Tusks Reveal a Life of Fighting and Roaming
abstract: By studying chemical signatures in fossilized tusks, researchers have pieced together one of the elephant-like animal’s movements and maladies.
lead_paragraph: Over 13,000 years ago, an American mastodon roamed what is today the American Midwest. Year after year, he returned to an area in northeast Indiana — believed to be a mating ground. It was there that he died in battle.

headline: Philip Baker Hall, Actor Familiar as Authority Figures, Dies at 90
abstract: He appeared in “Secret Honor,” “Boogie Nights,” “Seinfeld” and dozens of other movies and television shows.
lead_paragraph: Philip Baker Hall, the gravelly-voiced character actor who radiated equal amounts of quiet authority, unshakable confidence and effortless unflappability onscreen for five decades, died on Sunday at his home in Glendale, Calif. He was 90.

headline: Ratings for the Tony Awards Rebounded, but Remained Low
abstract: The Tonys drew an audience of 3.9 million viewers on CBS on Sunday, about a million viewers more than last year. It was the second-lowest viewership on record.
lead_paragraph: The Tonys bounced back.

headline: Attacked at home, Boris Johnson is honored in Ukraine with a pastry in his image.
abstract: A croissant is the latest homage in Ukraine to the British prime minister, who has also had a road named after him in a town near Odesa.
lead_paragraph: He is fighting for his political survival at home, but Britain’s embattled prime minister, Boris Johnson, can take some comfort: He has been immortalized as a croissant in Kyiv.

headline: Can Supplements Really Help With Depression or Anxiety?
abstract: Here’s what the evidence says about what works (and what doesn’t).
lead_paragraph: St. John’s wort “promotes a positive mood.” Valerian root reduces “levels of anxiety and stress.” Lavender oil is “calming for body and mind.”

headline: The Frozen Foods Brand Ipsa Branches Out to Pizza
abstract: David Kay, a former Gramercy Tavern cook, is their collaborator for new pizzas, including a monthly special with market produce.
lead_paragraph: Micah Fredman, a chef, and Joshua Brau, who worked in food sustainability, believe in frozen food. Since early 2020, their company, Ipsa, has been selling ready-to-heat preparations like Moroccan chicken, beef and kimchi stew, and pozole verde, of particularly high quality. Now they have introduced pizza. David Kay, a former Gramercy Tavern cook who has spent a year and a half making and selling pizza under the name Pies Upstairs, from his Crown Heights apartment, is their collaborator. Pop a fully baked frozen pizza (margherita, white with potatoes and onions, and a monthly special liberally laden with greenmarket goods, all baked in commercial ovens) into a 450 degree oven at home, and in about eight minutes you have a really good pizza with a thin but chewy crust tinged with char on its bubbled edge. Limited delivery is available only in the New York City, Westchester County and parts of New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In ‘Breadsong,’ a Story of Baking Through Depression
abstract: Kitty Tait baked her way out of depression and opened a successful bakery in England with her father.
lead_paragraph: Making bread is often considered to be therapeutic. For Kitty Tait, a teenager who overcame clinical depression by baking, it led to a successful bakery, the Orange Bakery in Watlington, England, near Oxford, and a book. At 14, Ms. Tait’s formerly sunny outlook was plunging into despair. In less than a year of baking with her father, an experienced amateur, they began selling their goods from home and soon opened the bakery. The story of Kitty’s recovery and the challenges of opening the business is told by each of them, in alternating segments. It’s an honest, lively read. Recipes for yeast breads, sourdough loaves, earthy soda bread, buns, croissants, crackers, custard tarts, and cookies, including fine brown butter chocolate chip, fill about half the book.

headline: The Airmail Cocktail Connects Miami and Cuba
abstract: The signature drink of the new Miami bar Airmail was created around 1930 in Cuba by Bacardi.
lead_paragraph: The rum-based airmail is the signature cocktail at Airmail, a new bar in Alton Food Hall in Miami Beach. The drink’s history links Miami and Cuba: It is thought to have been created around 1930 by Bacardi, when the company was still based in Cuba, to mark the start of airmail service to Miami. The cocktail was once garnished with a real postage stamp; at the lounge, it comes with a postcard ready to mail, and a paper plane. Sofia Present, the manager and head bartender, uses two ounces of dark rum with 1 ½ tablespoons lime juice and a tablespoon of honey mixed with one-half tablespoon water, all well shaken with ice. Strain it into a coupe and top with about 1 ½ ounces of sparkling wine. Ms. Present prefers dark rum to the more usual white or gold rum for a smoother cocktail.

headline: The Fancy Food Show Returns With Trends and New Awards
abstract: The annual trade show with scores of food companies was held for the first time since 2019.
lead_paragraph: The Fancy Food Show, an annual trade show held this week by the Specialty Food Association, covers less territory at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York than in prepandemic years. More than 1,800 companies displayed foods, drinks and related items, down from about 2,400 in 2019, the last year the show was held. (Pandemic caution drove the decision to shrink the show.) But that’s still plenty of pasta sauces, cheeses, chips and chocolates to discover in the United States’ $175 billion specialty food industry. New flavors and ingredients like Lapsang souchong tea, seaweed, bourbon and black truffle are showing up in products like coffee, cheeses and candies. According to the association, sustainability, ethical sourcing and products to “support the livelihoods of underserved communities” are increasingly important features for a growing list of products, including for Black Mamba Foods from South Africa, with a line of sauces and condiments. South Africa was among the 60 countries that also included Botswana, Taiwan and Croatia in the international pavilion.

headline: Gin Made With Wild Blackberries and a Hollywood Pedigree
abstract: MF Libations uses fruit from Mischief Farm, a 100-acre property owned by the actors Jeffrey Dean Morgan and Hilarie Burton Morgan.
lead_paragraph: An excellent stand-in for sloe gin in that bright summer fizz is the Blackberry Gin from MF Libations. The wild blackberries come from Mischief Farm, in Rhinebeck, N.Y., the 100-acre property owned by the actors Jeffrey Dean Morgan, best known for his role as Negan on “The Walking Dead,” and Hilarie Burton Morgan, who portrayed Peyton Sawyer on “One Tree Hill.” It’s a working farm with an oversupply of cute thanks to a rescued donkey and emu sharing the pastures with Highland cattle, alpacas, ducks and geese. The pale pink gin, infused with blackberries to provide a fruity finish, is made for Mischief Farm’s MF Libations by Vale Fox Distillery in nearby Poughkeepsie. Also from MF Libations is Bonfire Smoky Rye Whiskey, a honeyed, brooding spirit infused with Chinese black Lapsang souchong tea to accompany s’mores for grown-ups on a summer evening, or to please a lover of Islay Scotch. Dad would qualify.

headline: Officer Eugene Goodman Recounts How He Held Off Mob on Jan. 6
abstract: In a trial of two people who stormed the Capitol, Officer Goodman testified for the first time about confronting the “aggressive” throng that had unlawfully entered the building.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Eugene Goodman, the Capitol Police officer who led a pro-Trump mob away from the entrance to the Senate chamber during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, testified for the first time on Monday about his experience holding off the rioters.

headline: The Rolling Stones postpone a concert in Amsterdam after Mick Jagger tests positive.
abstract: The band said the show would be rescheduled. Hugh Jackman, who plays Professor Harold Hill in a strong-selling revival of “The Music Man,” on Monday said he had tested positive for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The Rolling Stones postponed a stadium concert in Amsterdam on Monday, after Mick Jagger tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: The B.Q.E. Is Crumbling. There’s Still No Plan to Fix It.
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams wants to jump-start the project, but some critics have raised safety concerns.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-Queens Expressway is slowly crumbling from the road salt and moisture that has weakened its concrete-and-steel foundation, and from all the overweight trucks that it was never designed to carry.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Alopecia Drug That Restores Hair Growth in Many Patients
abstract: The drug, made by Eli Lilly, is already used for rheumatoid arthritis, and could be followed by two more drugs from other companies.
lead_paragraph: The disease can vary in severity, but for some, it can be life-altering — a total loss of body hair, including eyelashes and eyebrows, even nose hair and hair in the ears. And, until recently, for those with alopecia areata, there was no treatment to make the hair grow back.

headline: How to invest during a bear market.
abstract: History shows that the U.S. stock market has always recovered from declines in the past.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: California Wildfire Scorches Nearly 1,000 Acres and Prompts Evacuations
abstract: The Sheep Fire northwest of San Bernardino, Calif., is one of more than 30 wildfires that have burned about one million acres across five states.
lead_paragraph: A fast-moving wildfire in California’s Angeles National Forest has grown to nearly 1,000 acres in a little more than a day, prompting road closures and the evacuation of a large portion of a community about 30 miles northwest of San Bernardino.

headline: Phil Mickelson, Fresh From LIV Golf Series, Stays on Message at U.S. Open
abstract: “I’m grateful for all that the PGA Tour has given me, but I’m excited about this new opportunity as well,” Mickelson said of the Saudi-financed rebel golf start-up.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — He was unwavering. He has made peace with his decision. For someone with a reputation as a gambler, on and off the golf course, Phil Mickelson played it as straight as a Ben Hogan 1-iron on Monday.

headline: Former U.S. Attorney Disputes Fraud Claims in 2020 Election
abstract: Byung J. “BJay” Pak, a former U.S. attorney in Atlanta, testified that his investigation did not find any credible evidence of voter fraud in Fulton County, Ga.
lead_paragraph: Byung J. “BJay” Pak, a former U.S. attorney in Atlanta, testified that his investigation did not find any credible evidence of voter fraud in Fulton County, Ga.

headline: This Company Knows How to Increase Students’ Test Scores
abstract: NewGlobe Schools uses some of the world’s most successful educational techniques.
lead_paragraph: Some of the world’s most successful educational techniques are being applied today in Kenya, Uganda, Liberia, Nigeria, Rwanda and India, in schools serving poor children that are run or advised by NewGlobe Schools, a company founded by Americans with headquarters in Nairobi, Kenya. These techniques deserve to be applied more widely, including in wealthy nations such as the United States.

headline: The Fed May Discuss the Biggest Interest Rate Increase Since 1994
abstract: Central bankers had signaled that they would raise rates by half a point if data shaped up as expected. Inflation is instead running hotter.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is likely to discuss making its biggest interest rate increase since 1994 at its meeting this week, as a range of new data suggest that inflation is coming in hotter and proving more stubborn than policymakers had hoped.

headline: What Happens When Stock Markets Become Bears
abstract: Steep downturns of stocks by 20 percent or more are relatively rare, but how long they last could portend damage — for you and the economy.
lead_paragraph: The S&P 500 on Monday dropped into its second bear market of the pandemic, crossing a symbolic and worrisome threshold as stocks plunge following a meteoric rise over the last two years.

headline: The Lessons Liberal Prosecutors Are Drawing From San Francisco’s Backlash
abstract: Voters ousted Chesa Boudin as the city’s district attorney, but his allies across the country say policies like his can still succeed.
lead_paragraph: When Chesa Boudin, the district attorney of San Francisco, was ousted in a definitive recall vote last week, his loss was a setback for a national movement to remake the justice system.

headline: Australian Paper Deletes Rebel Wilson Column but Denies Outing Her
abstract: The actress disclosed her relationship with Ramona Agruma a day before The Sydney Morning Herald published a column about it. The writer, Andrew Hornery, said he had made mistakes and would learn from them.
lead_paragraph: Before Rebel Wilson, the Australian actress and comedian, publicly revealed her new relationship, an Australian columnist who covers celebrities had given her representatives less than two days to comment before he published a column about the new couple.

headline: Netanyahu vs. Olmert: A Lurid Libel Case Grips Israel
abstract: A sensational legal drama between the two ex-prime ministers, centered on a claim of mental illness, comes as Israel’s year-old government teeters and one of the former leaders eyes a comeback.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Benjamin Netanyahu, who left office a year ago, his wife, Sara, and their eldest son, Yair, are suing his predecessor as Israel’s prime minister, Ehud Olmert, for libel after his description of them as “mentally ill” and in need of psychiatric treatment.

headline: A History of Bear Markets
abstract: From the Great Depression to the 2008 financial crisis, here are some examples of past bear markets.
lead_paragraph: From the Great Depression to the 2008 financial crisis, here are some examples of past bear markets.

headline: A top Ukrainian official says urgency is missing in the West’s response to the war.
abstract: KYIV, Ukraine — For weeks, Ukrainian officials have pleaded for powerful Western weapons as a way to stave off battlefield defeats. A senior adviser to President Volodymyr Zelensky shifted this messaging on weapons on Monday by laying out for the first time the total number of howitzers, rocket launchers and tanks Ukraine thinks it would need to win the war against Russia.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — For weeks, Ukrainian officials have pleaded for powerful Western weapons as a way to stave off battlefield defeats. A senior adviser to President Volodymyr Zelensky shifted this messaging on weapons on Monday by laying out for the first time the total number of howitzers, rocket launchers and tanks Ukraine thinks it would need to win the war against Russia.

headline: In Missouri, Battles Over Birth Control Foreshadow a Post-Roe World
abstract: The demise of Roe v. Wade would make the need for effective birth control more urgent than ever. Yet many American women still have a hard time obtaining it.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the latest abortion news and the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Europe Recalculates on Ukraine
abstract: Plus the Jan. 6 hearings continue and truckers in South Korea strike.
lead_paragraph: As Russia advances in the east, European leaders are under mounting pressure to forge a cohesive strategy to outline what might constitute Ukrainian victory — or Russian defeat.

headline: Why Your Preferred Tampons May Be Hard to Find
abstract: Supply chain issues have hit tampons, and inflation has driven up prices. Here’s why there’s a shortage — and what you can do if you run out.
lead_paragraph: First, it was baby formula. Now, the latest supply chain issue complicating daily life for women across America is a nationwide tampon shortage, set against a backdrop of rising consumer prices because of inflation.

headline: Will Sievierodonetsk Fall?
abstract: Russian forces seem poised to take the eastern city.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Massacre Leader’s Name Is Removed From Yellowstone Mountain
abstract: Mount Doane, a 10,551-foot peak, has been renamed First Peoples Mountain in an acknowledgment of the park’s historical connections with Indigenous people, the National Park Service said.
lead_paragraph: A mountain in Yellowstone National Park, named for an Army officer who participated in a massacre in which at least 173 Native Americans were slaughtered, has been renamed in honor of America’s Indigenous people, the National Park Service said.

headline: The Public Campaign to #FreeBrittneyGriner
abstract: Supporters of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner are loudly pleading for her release from Russian detention.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner are loudly pleading for her release from Russian detention.

headline: How Is the Return to Office Going for You?
abstract: We’re looking for stories and advice for adjusting to new routines.
lead_paragraph: Many office employees across the U.S. have been called back to the workplace. We want to know how that’s going.

headline: The Pandemic’s Next Phase
abstract: A look at where we’re headed.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. is in a peculiar moment in the pandemic.

headline: Toby Keith Says He Has Stomach Cancer, but ‘So Far, So Good’
abstract: The country music star has been undergoing treatment, including chemotherapy, radiation and surgery, for the last six months, he said in a statement.
lead_paragraph: Toby Keith, the country music star, announced on Sunday afternoon on social media that he was treated for stomach cancer over the past six months.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: On Russia, Europe Weighs Competing Goals: Peace and Punishment
abstract: Arming Ukraine is not turning the tide. Is the answer vastly more weapons, as Ukraine says, or a bitter truce?
lead_paragraph: Follow the today’s latest news on Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Jan. 6 Hearings Focus on Fox News Call That Made Trump’s Loss Clear
abstract: At Fox News, there was little drama over the decision to project Joseph R. Biden the winner of Arizona. But the relationship between Trump and the network was never the same.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before 11:20 p.m. on Nov. 3, 2020, Bill Sammon, the managing editor for Fox News in Washington, picked up the phone in the room where he and others had been reviewing election returns. On the other end of the line was the control room.

headline: Kenneth Dam, Deputy in Reagan and George W. Bush Cabinets, Dies at 89
abstract: He served under George Shultz at the State Department as the Soviet Union began crumbling and later, at Treasury, led a crackdown on funding for terrorism after 9/11.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth W. Dam, who was deputy secretary of state when the Soviet Union began to implode during the Reagan administration, and who choreographed a global chokehold on funding for terrorist groups as deputy treasury secretary under George W. Bush, died on May 31 at his home in Long Grove, Ill. He was 89.

headline: Is Nevada Turning Red?
abstract: No state was walloped harder by the economic impact of the pandemic, and voters may take out their anger on Democrats.
lead_paragraph: If a red wave arrives in November, as many expect, it will likely wash ashore in landlocked Nevada, a state whose recent history of Democratic victories masks just how hard-fought those triumphs have been.

headline: What a Dying Lake Says About the Future
abstract: If we can’t save the Great Salt Lake, what can we save?
lead_paragraph: A few days ago The Times published a report on the drying up of the Great Salt Lake, a story I’m ashamed to admit had flown under my personal radar. We’re not talking about a hypothetical event in the distant future: The lake has already lost two-thirds of its surface area, and ecological disasters — salinity rising to the point where wildlife dies off, occasional poisonous dust storms sweeping through a metropolitan area of 2.5 million people — seem imminent.

headline: Brittney Griner’s Team Meets With U.S. State Department Over Her Detention
abstract: The Phoenix Mercury were encouraged to continue their public campaign for the W.N.B.A. star’s release from Russia, where the U.S. government has said she has been “wrongfully detained.”
lead_paragraph: U.S. State Department officials met on Monday with Brittney Griner’s W.N.B.A. team, the Phoenix Mercury, to discuss the status of Griner’s monthslong detention in Russia and efforts made toward securing her release.

headline: The Fractious Night That Began Trump’s Bid to Overturn the Election
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s advisers urged him not to declare victory on election night in 2020. He listened to the one who told him what he wanted to hear.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rudolph W. Giuliani seemed drunk, and he was making a beeline for the president.

headline: Jan. 6 Committee Asserts Trump Knew Election Claims Were False
abstract: The second day of hearings included video testimony from some of Donald J. Trump’s closest allies who said they had repeatedly told the former president that his “big lie” about electoral fraud was baseless.
lead_paragraph: The second day of hearings included video testimony from some of Donald J. Trump’s closest allies who said they had repeatedly told the former president that his “big lie” about electoral fraud was baseless.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Tracks How Trump Created and Spread Election Lies
