abstract: In its second hearing this month, the committee showed how the former president ignored aides and advisers in declaring victory prematurely and relentlessly pressing claims of fraud he was told were wrong.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol made a wide-ranging case on Monday that former President Donald J. Trump created and relentlessly spread the lie that the 2020 election had been stolen from him in the face of mounting evidence from an expanding chorus of advisers that he had been legitimately defeated.

headline: Fealty to Trump Arises as Litmus Test in G.O.P. Debate for N.Y. Governor
abstract: Rep. Lee Zeldin sought to attack a less conservative rival, Harry Wilson, by calling him a “Never Trumper.”
lead_paragraph: If there was any question that the first debate among Republican contenders for governor of New York would be more combative than last week’s Democratic skirmish, it was put to rest quickly on Monday.

headline: Military Clears Crew of Plane That Took Flight as Afghans Fell to Their Deaths
abstract: Crowds of people had surged onto the runway at the airport in Kabul during the final days of the U.S. evacuation of Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Air Force has cleared the crew of an American military C-17 cargo plane that took off from Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul last August with people hanging onto the wings, during the frenzied days of the Afghanistan evacuation.

headline: Young Kim, a Republican congresswoman from California, survives her House primary.
abstract: Ms. Kim and other conservatives have been vying to reclaim Orange County, a Republican stronghold that shifted to the left during the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: Representative Young Kim of California, a Republican who is one of the first Korean American women in Congress, advanced to the general election in November after a hard-fought primary that became one of the most expensive races in the state.

headline: Commander of Afghan Insurgency Pleads Guilty at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: Abd al-Hadi al-Iraqi agreed that his subordinates committed war crimes in attacks in 2003 and 2004 on allied forces that invaded Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — An Iraqi prisoner who commanded insurgents during the U.S. war in Afghanistan pleaded guilty on Monday to war crimes charges related to lethal attacks on allied soldiers in 2003 and 2004, in a deal that could hand him off to the custody of another country by 2024.

headline: Exclamation of Epiphany
abstract: Robert Won makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I just love a good revealer, and boy, does today’s puzzle from the debut constructor Robert Won deliver! The satisfaction of puzzling over an ambiguous theme that leaves you guessing to the last moment; finally reaching a clever, pithy revealer; and the exclamation of epiphany that inevitably follows — these are the things I most enjoy about themed puzzles.

headline: The battle for Ukraine’s Donbas will be remembered for its brutality, Zelensky says.
abstract: Ukraine’s fight to defend the Donbas region against Russia will “go down in military history as one of the most brutal battles in Europe and for Europe,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said in his nightly address on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s fight to defend the Donbas region against Russia will “go down in military history as one of the most brutal battles in Europe and for Europe,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said in his nightly address on Monday.

headline: Golden State 1 Win From Title After Beating Celtics in Game 5
abstract: Andrew Wiggins powered Golden State’s victory on an off night for Stephen Curry, who went 0 for 9 from 3-point range.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Golden State had been mucking up its offense for nearly the entire third quarter on Monday night when Andrew Wiggins pushed the ball ahead to Jordan Poole, a young guard with enormous confidence. Just before time expired, Poole launched a 3-pointer from 33 feet that banked off the glass before rattling through the hoop.

headline: Lawmaker’s Capitol Complex Tour on the Eve of Jan. 6 Was Innocent, Police Say
abstract: The tour led by Representative Barry Loudermilk of Georgia, which had come under scrutiny by the Jan. 6 committee, was a “visit by constituents,” the Capitol Police chief wrote.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A tour of parts of the Capitol complex given by a Republican lawmaker the day before the Jan. 6 riot appears to have been innocuous, the Capitol Police said on Monday, describing a visit that had attracted scrutiny from the House committee examining the attack as simply a meeting with constituents.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Ukraine War Cues Taiwan to Get Ready
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 14, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Ukraine showed us that you need to first show to others that you have the resolve to defend yourself; only then will others come and help.”

headline: Corrections: June 14, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 14, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about fashion giants’ efforts to promote synthetic materials in garments misstated the share of global carbon dioxide emissions produced by the fashion industry. It is as much as 8 percent, not 8 to 10 percent.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: A bear market in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street stocks tumbled yesterday, with the S&P 500 falling 3.9 percent to close the day nearly 22 percent below its Jan. 3 peak. The steep decline — the seventh bear market in the past 50 years — is a rare and grim marker of investors’ concerns as a crucial report showed inflation accelerating and the World Bank issued a dire warning on global growth.

headline: Germany’s Chancellor Promised to Deter Putin. Then He Did Nothing.
abstract: Olaf Scholz’s indecisiveness is more than a political failure.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In a time of war, every day counts.

headline: Ukraine’s resistance to invasion prompts Taiwan to rethink its own military strategy.
abstract: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Russia’s brutal war in Ukraine has jolted Taiwan into confronting the specter of a sudden attack from the island’s own larger and more powerful neighbor: China.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Russia’s brutal war in Ukraine has jolted Taiwan into confronting the specter of a sudden attack from the island’s own larger and more powerful neighbor: China.

headline: Late Night Blames It on the Alcohol
abstract: Rudy Giuliani’s intoxication on election night was the focus of Monday’s Jan. 6 hearings and late-night monologues.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Stocks edge lower as Fed decision looms over markets.
abstract: The S&P 500 closed in bear market territory on Monday, down 22 percent from its Jan 3. peak.
lead_paragraph: Stocks on Wall Street were lower on Tuesday but far calmer than the day before, when a rush of selling pushed the S&P 500 into a bear market, as the Federal Reserve’s upcoming interest rate decision kept investors on edge.

headline: Zelensky broke from his usual speech attire to wear a Singapore teen’s T-shirt design.
What Can Be Done About the Crumbling B.Q.E.?
abstract: Everyone agrees that the infamous highway urgently needs repairs. But there’s no consensus on a fix.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at the highway everybody loves to hate — the B.Q.E. We’ll also catch up on what the Republican candidates for governor said during their debate last night.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: How Many Languages Could a Child Speak?
abstract: In theory, a young person could master a broad array of tongues. But there are some inherent limits.
lead_paragraph: If a newborn child grows up hearing people speaking in many different languages, will it later be able to speak all those languages?

headline: Official Inquiries About Grenfell Tower Blaze Go On, 5 Years After the Fire
abstract: The fire quickly engulfed the apartment building, fueled by cladding now banned. An investigation is continuing. But the families of the 72 who died find accountability slow in coming.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Five years ago, a fire in a tower block in West London killed 72 people, shattered a community, unsettled a country and exposed harsh inequalities in one of London’s richest neighborhoods. It also set off a broad reckoning into British fire regulations and building safety.

headline: Risking a Society’s Retribution, Growing Numbers of Girls Resist Genital Cutting
abstract: Sierra Leone is one of a few countries in sub-Saharan Africa that have not banned cutting. Now, young women are defying mothers and grandmothers by refusing to undergo the procedure.
lead_paragraph: KAMAKWIE, Sierra Leone — When Seio Bangura’s final high school exam results arrived not long ago, she learned she had earned grades high enough to get into college. It was a thrilling moment for the daughter of farmers who never finished primary school. But Ms. Bangura is not making plans for university. Instead, she spends most days sitting on a bench, watching others head to class or work.

headline: A.B. Yehoshua, Politically Engaged Israeli Writer, Dies at 85
abstract: In 11 novels, three short-story collections and four plays, he tackled a variety of narrative forms and delved into knotty and uncommon subjects.
lead_paragraph: A.B. Yehoshua, the Israeli novelist who, along with other acclaimed storytellers, planted his nation on the map of world literature with human portraits that captured the discordant condition of living in a land fraught with moral and political conundrums, died on Tuesday in Tel Aviv. He was 85.

headline: Inside the Minds of Antiwar Russians: ‘Silence Is My Punishment Now’
abstract: Some Russians who oppose the war in Ukraine are experiencing an existential crisis marked by sorrow and regret.
lead_paragraph: Some Russians who oppose the war in Ukraine are experiencing an existential crisis marked by sorrow and regret.

headline: F.D.A. Advisers Back Authorizing Moderna Vaccine for Children 6 to 17
abstract: If the vaccine receives the agency’s authorization, it may have little immediate impact, since the age group has had access to Pfizer-BioNTech shots for months.
lead_paragraph: An expert committee advising the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday unanimously recommended Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine for use in children and adolescents ages 6 to 17, an important step before emergency authorization.

headline: Why Gas Prices Are So High
abstract: How much people pay for gas is the result of trading on a sprawling international market. Like many other facets of the global economy, it comes down to a matter of supply and demand.
lead_paragraph: How much people pay for gas is the result of trading on a sprawling international market. Like many other facets of the global economy, it comes down to a matter of supply and demand.

headline: How to Wash Your Hair in Space
abstract: Water is limited. If globules escape, gently scoop them back to your head.
lead_paragraph: “Some of the water always floats away,” says the retired astronaut Karen Nyberg, who spent 180 days in space, including 166 as a flight engineer on the International Space Station in 2013. In orbit, there is no running water, which means no showers. During her decades as an astronaut, people constantly asked Nyberg how she accomplished basic hygiene. One day on the International Space Station, she decided to film herself giving a hair-washing tutorial. NASA put the video on YouTube, where it has been viewed nearly six million times.

headline: America’s Hospitals Are in Transition
abstract: I am not taking care of a single patient with the coronavirus. But is that as good as it gets?
lead_paragraph: The intensive care unit is full. A patient coded early in the morning, and my pager alerts me that an older man is intubated in the emergency department and a woman with cystic fibrosis is coughing up blood. There is so much sickness that I am almost too busy to notice what once would have been a remarkable fact: I am not taking care of a single patient with the coronavirus.

headline: Welcome to the Farm! Prepare to Get Dirty and Be Dazzled.
abstract: In her memoir, “Pig Years,” Ellyn Gaydos shows readers what it’s like to be a farmhand.
lead_paragraph: Memoirs about farming tend to slide in one of two directions: the farce or the ode. Neither of those genres is as satisfying as what we have in Ellyn Gaydos’s debut memoir, “Pig Years,” about her life as a farmhand in New York and Vermont. What this young writer has given us is more of a memento mori, rendering realistic scenes full of vivid and sometimes bizarre detail, always with an acknowledgment — on the surface or just under it — of the inescapable facts that life entails death, and growth, and arises from decay.

headline: What Should I Do With My Late Son’s Gun?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to sell or surrender a firearm — and more.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, our son died by suicide. Since his tragic death, our family set up a memorial fund to support need-based scholarships for young classical musicians from underrepresented communities, as well as prize money for talented young musical artists.

headline: Inflation Isn’t Going to Bring Back the 1970s
abstract: The Federal Reserve has the tools that it needs. Now it should use them.
lead_paragraph: We had another bad inflation report last week.

headline: We Know How America Got Such a Corporate-Friendly Court
abstract: Can the right really be realigned with the working class?
lead_paragraph: With the potential overturning of Roe v. Wade, the Federalist Society appears poised for a triumph. This organization of conservative and libertarian lawyers and law professors and students turns 40 this year.

headline: The Gerontocracy of the Democratic Party Doesn’t Understand That We’re at the Brink
abstract: Millions of Democratic voters can see and feel that American politics has changed in profound ways since at least the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: If you want a sense of what separates much of the leadership of the Democratic Party from many of its supporters — of what illustrates their profound disconnect from younger cohorts of liberal and progressive voters — you could do much worse than to read this recent statement from Senator Dianne Feinstein of California.

headline: He Knew What Jackie Gave Up for the Kennedys. This Is His Story.
abstract: In a new novel, “Jackie & Me,” Louis Bayard imagines the road to Camelot from the perspective of a loyal friend.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and short-story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.

headline: You Need a Horror Movie Friend for a More Frightening, Less Lonely Life
abstract: You can’t undo what is terrible about the universe, but you can stand against it together.
lead_paragraph: I was in graduate school when I realized the importance of having a Designated Horror Friend. I spent a lot of time in creative-writing workshops, moderating my tone to sound “productive” while offering my peers feedback on their work. We were all careful with one another, but a layer of brutality ran just below the surface, an implicit understanding that sometimes calling a classmate’s story “interesting” meant you actually thought it was trash. Our politeness kept the program from descending into violence, but it sometimes left me craving a more honest, instinctual response.

headline: Inside the Minds of Antiwar Russians: ‘Silence Is My Punishment Now’
abstract: Some Russians who oppose the war in Ukraine are experiencing an existential crisis marked by sorrow and regret.
lead_paragraph: With Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine in February, it suddenly became very difficult to be Russian in this world. A nation, it seemed, had become a global pariah overnight.

headline: The Pearl Rush
abstract: Lizzie Pook’s novel about a young woman in the 19th-century outback, “Moonlight and the Pearler’s Daughter,” examines the perils — moral, physical and otherwise — of the pearling industry.
lead_paragraph: In 1861, the largest known species of pearl oyster, Pinctada maxima, was found in bulk off the northern coast of Western Australia. This discovery made Broome — a sweltering, remote town at the edge of the Indian Ocean — the center of the world’s lucrative mother-of-pearl industry in the late 19th century. At its peak, pearl shell was Australia’s fourth-largest export, trading at 400 British pounds a ton, the equivalent of around $44,000 today. Prospectors came in force to seek their fortune.

headline: Why Is My Sleep So Messed Up in the Summer?
abstract: Though seasonal shifts can derail your sleep, there are things you can do to snooze more soundly when it’s hot out.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: What Does It Mean to Be Brave, in Art and in Love?
abstract: “Diary of a Film,” a novel by Niven Govinden, follows a film director struggling to balance his artistry with real life.
lead_paragraph: To read “Diary of a Film,” Niven Govinden’s splendid and heartfelt new novel, is by necessity to recall another splendid and heartfelt novel, William Maxwell’s “The Folded Leaf.” As “Diary of a Film” opens, its unnamed narrator, a film auteur in his 50s whom everyone but his husband calls Maestro, has just arrived at an esteemed film festival in the Italian city of B. for the premiere of his “liberal” adaptation of “The Folded Leaf.” Joining him are his longtime co-producer, Gabi; his editor, Stjepan; and Lorien and Tom, the up-and-coming young American actors whom Maestro has cast in the lead roles of Spud and Lymie.

headline: If Housing Is a Health Care Issue, Should Medicaid Pay the Rent?
abstract: With federal housing money in short supply, state and local authorities are looking to health dollars to help tackle homelessness.
lead_paragraph: Living on the streets, Hanif Hightower learned which Philadelphia shelters were likely to have an open bed during the cold months or where he could get a meal or a hot shower. But his resourcefulness had limits. Addicted to crack cocaine and struggling with clinical depression, he cycled in and out of jail and temporary rehab programs, returning to the streets each time he was released. Years passed this way. Then one day, in May 2019, an outreach worker for a local nonprofit offered him a way out: an apartment of his own, no strings attached.

headline: A New Student Movement Wants You to Log Off
abstract: Emma Lembke, 19, is encouraging her peers to reduce their time on the internet and rethink their relationship to it.
lead_paragraph: Millennials may have been the first generation to come of age online, but their Gen Z successors have truly grown up with it — and hardly ever log off.

headline: What Has Mass Tourism Done to Europe? A Novelist Digs In.
abstract: Ilja Leonard Pfeijffer’s “Grand Hotel Europa” combines a comedy of manners with cultural commentary.
lead_paragraph: A middle-aged Dutch writer checks into a hotel in an unnamed Italian city, seeking to rebound from a failed love affair and “regain control over my thoughts.” So begins “Grand Hotel Europa,” the sprawling new autofiction by Ilja Leonard Pfeijffer, a Dutch novelist, poet and scholar who has long resided in Italy.

headline: Don’t Add Curbs on Guns. Repeal Liability Protections for Gun Makers and Sellers.
abstract: Freedom and responsibility, in equal measure.
lead_paragraph: BIGFORK, Mont. — As a lifelong sportsman with a personal history rich with shotguns, pistols and rifles, I understand why so many of my fellow gun owners — especially the ones who have been spoon-fed fear and angst from organizations they trust — are hesitant to engage in a political discussion that began long before the actor and Second Amendment activist Charlton Heston equated guns with human dignity and liberty.

headline: Do You Have Insight Into How the I.R.S. Vets New Charities?
abstract: The Times is looking for tips about how the Internal Revenue Service scrutinizes new nonprofits — and what they might miss.
lead_paragraph: Since 1969, the Internal Revenue Service has been the gatekeeper for America’s nonprofits — deciding which groups deserve tax-exempt status.

headline: When the Dead Can Talk
abstract: Erin Kimmerle’s “We Carry Their Bones” describes efforts to uncover the graves and crimes at a boys’ school in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Colson Whitehead’s Pulitzer Prize-winning 2019 novel, “The Nickel Boys,” closes with a fictional news conference. A main character, the survivor of a traumatic boyhood at a reform school in Jim Crow Florida, attends the presser hoping to learn more about a professor’s excavation of a burial ground at the school. Survivors like him, the novel says, had long known the truth of what happened there, but few others listened: “No one believed them until someone else said it.”

headline: ‘Is Climate Change a Reason to Avoid Having Children?’ and Other Listeners’ Questions Answered
abstract: Ezra Klein responds to your questions.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year, when we invite listeners to send in questions, and I answer them on the air. And as usual, you delivered. I’m joined by my producer Annie Galvin, who asks me some of the most intriguing questions of the many we received: Is climate change a reason to forgo having kids? What would happen if Trump were allowed to return to Twitter, in the event of an Elon Musk acquisition? Should Biden run again in 2024? Is wokeness killing the Democratic Party?

headline: The Recluse Who Confronted the Mystery of the Universe
abstract: Frank Close’s “Elusive” looks at the life and work of the man who changed our ideas about the basis of matter.
lead_paragraph: In early October 2013, the Nobel Prize committee was preparing to announce the winner of its award in physics. The leading candidate — as pretty much everyone knew — was an 84-year-old Scottish scientist named Peter Higgs, who was not feeling nearly as joyful as you might think. Yes, he wanted to win the award, yes, he wanted to be recognized for his pioneering insights into how subatomic particles build our universe. He just wanted to be recognized for it quietly.

headline: Furniture Flippers Will Take That Dresser You’re Done With, Thank You
abstract: Fueled by the pandemic’s convergence of endless scrolling, supply chain woes and the thrill of quick cash, furniture flipping has become D.I.Y. that, for many, is worth a try.
lead_paragraph: In July 2019, Elle Woodworth was raising three children with her husband in Fort Myers, Fla. when she had an idea to generate income that would change the course of their lives.

headline: Getting the Most Bang for Your Buck While Traveling Overseas
abstract: The strong American dollar is the upside of a volatile economy. For U.S. travelers headed abroad, that may help make up for the rising cost of travel.
lead_paragraph: For American travelers heading abroad, the growing strength of the dollar is the upside of a volatile economy. Currently, the exchange rate with the euro is about $1.04, meaning each 100 euros will cost about $104. One euro was worth about $1.22 this time last year. The present rate is down significantly from its high in 2008, when each euro was worth $1.58.

headline: Alexei Ratmansky’s Epic Ballet Arrives in a Changed World
abstract: Getting its delayed New York premiere, “Of Love and Rage,” at Ballet Theater, is like a time capsule of a more carefree period of Ratmansky’s life and art.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Alexei Ratmansky sat, looking intent but a bit glassy eyed, at the front of a studio at American Ballet Theater’s headquarters near Union Square. He had arrived in New York just a few days earlier from Australia, where he was setting another ballet — one more stop in a busy schedule that, since the coronavirus pandemic began to loosen its grip, has returned to its usual hectic pace.

headline: From a Childhood in News Choppers to the Anchor’s Seat
abstract: In her second memoir, “Rough Draft,” the journalist Katy Tur recounts growing up alongside her parents’ news-gathering exploits and her father’s outlandish, then violent, behavior.
lead_paragraph: It’s little wonder that Katy Tur is one of America’s top TV journalists, given that her parents were obsessive reporters. On their first date, they went looking for a serial killer who was targeting homeless people in Los Angeles. They didn’t find him, but they found a shared passion for chasing news that they passed on to their daughter, who was practicing pieces for the camera from age 4.

headline: Can Virtual Reality Help Autistic Children Navigate the Real World?
abstract: One company, Floreo, is hoping their tools will lead the way, despite some criticisms from autism self-advocates.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Upstart, a series on young companies harnessing new science and technology.

headline: Bosnia on the Brink
abstract: Caught up in a 21st-century stew of ethnonationalism and fake history, the country’s Serbs are now endangering its fragile peace.
lead_paragraph: The Bosnian Valley of the Pyramids, near the medieval town Visoko, features three hills that Sam Osmanagich, a Sarajevo-educated anthropologist who “discovered” them in 2005, claims were built by humans 29,000 years ago. During the so-called Little Ice Age, he says, a highly developed civilization chose this spot to erect, block by block, three symmetrical structures ranging in height from 290 to 1,100 feet: the Pyramid of the Dragon, the Pyramid of the Moon and the Pyramid of the Sun. In his telling, the three structures possibly functioned as an advanced communication system, emitting “energy beams” that followed the path of the sun. “Russian scientists say that the speed of scalar waves is one hundred million times faster than the speed of light,” he says, “so that information moves instantly from one end of the galaxy to the other.”

headline: An Oakland Loft With a Sense of Serenity
abstract: The loft, in a former ironworks in Oakland, had a heavy-handed industrial vibe. She gave it a ‘spalike’ makeover that recalls the hotels of Sonoma County.
lead_paragraph: The loft, in a former ironworks in Oakland, had a heavy-handed industrial vibe. She gave it a ‘spalike’ makeover that recalls the hotels of Sonoma County.

headline: A Northern California Loft Gets a Sophisticated Update
abstract: The loft, in a former ironworks in Oakland, had a heavy-handed industrial vibe. She gave it a ‘spalike’ makeover that recalls the hotels of Sonoma County.
lead_paragraph: Martha Hill, a real estate agent in Oakland, Calif., was merely keeping on top of new listings in 2019 when she spotted a remarkable loft about to go on the market.

headline: On Climate Change’s Front Lines, Hard Lives Grow Even Harder
abstract: Hundreds of millions of humanity’s most vulnerable live in South Asia, where rising temperatures make it more difficult to address poverty, food insecurity and health challenges.
lead_paragraph: FATEHGARH-SAHIB, India — When the unseasonably heavy rains flooded the fields, and then the equally unseasonable heat shriveled the seeds, it didn’t just slash Ranjit Singh’s wheat harvest by nearly half.

headline: The Long Emergency of Homelessness
abstract: If we understood the loss of housing as a collective challenge engulfing our communities, how would it guide our response?
lead_paragraph: In October 2018, the city of Chico, Calif., bowed to a grim reality — too few shelter beds for too many people without places to sleep — and declared an emergency shelter crisis. The following month, the most destructive wildfire in California’s history ripped through the neighboring town of Paradise, destroying thousands of homes.

headline: Three Years in Shelters. Ten Months to Find a Home.
abstract: Scenes from one woman’s journey out of homelessness in Houston.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Marcum became homeless during a divorce. She was evicted from the rental house she’d lived in with her younger son and former husband. Losing her home and her marriage led to a debilitating depression. She couldn’t even muster the energy to take a proper shower. Eventually, she got psychiatric care and medication. But she struggled to find a way out of homelessness.

headline: How Houston Moved 25,000 People From the Streets Into Homes of Their Own
abstract: The nation’s fourth-largest city hasn’t solved homelessness, but its remarkable progress can suggest a way forward.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Long-Haul Travelers Are Wary About the U.S. Dropping Covid Test Requirements
abstract: Despite worries about greater infection risk on planes, members of the travel industry expected more tourists to seek out travel to and from the United States.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — The travel industry applauded the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s decision to lift the Covid-19 testing requirement for people entering the United States, but some travelers were wary.

headline: For Its Next Zero Covid Chapter, China Turns to Mass Testing
abstract: Residents in many cities must show negative P.C.R. tests to go shopping or use public services. The policy may hamper efforts to revive the economy.
lead_paragraph: For an hour every day, Xu Xinhua waits in line for a health worker to push a swab down his throat and swirl it around. Each time, he hopes his Covid test will be negative so that he may continue delivering food, medicine and flowers to residents across Shanghai.

headline: Senator Chris Murphy on the Bipartisan Gun Safety Deal
abstract: The lawmaker at the center of the effort explains how the proposal came together and what changes it would make.
lead_paragraph: The Senate has reached a bipartisan deal that could lead to the most significant federal response to gun violence in decades.

headline: The loss of a final bridge to Sievierodonetsk may hurt Ukraine’s ability to hold its ground.
abstract: The last bridge linking the eastern city with Ukrainian-controlled territory to the west has been destroyed.
lead_paragraph: As Ukrainian and Russian soldiers engage in street battles in Sievierodonetsk and scores of civilians remain stranded under unrelenting bombardment, the last bridge linking the eastern city with Ukrainian-controlled territory to the west has been destroyed, according to officials from both nations.

headline: Inflation and Price Gouging
abstract: We look at whether “greedflation” is causing higher prices.
lead_paragraph: As prices have increased faster than at any other point in four decades, lawmakers have scrambled for explanations. In recent months, some Democrats have landed on a new culprit: price gouging.

headline: Zimbabwe Court Convicts Reporter for The New York Times
abstract: The reporter, Jeffrey Moyo, is unlikely to spend time in prison, but analysts said the case was part of a wider assault on press freedoms in the country.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — A court in Zimbabwe on Tuesday convicted a freelance reporter for The New York Times on charges of breaching the country’s immigration laws, in another blow for the free press in the increasingly authoritarian country in southern Africa.

headline: ‘Halftime’ Review: Let’s Get Loud
abstract: In the Netflix documentary about Jennifer Lopez’s life and career by the director Amanda Micheli, the political moments are brief, and then it’s back to rehearsal.
lead_paragraph: A film about Jennifer Lopez and her performance at the Super Bowl in 2020 was bound to generate headlines, but the Netflix documentary “Halftime” makes sure it happens. The multihyphenate’s accomplishments can stand on their own without, for instance, a single publicity baiting remark from her fiancé, the actor Ben Affleck.

headline: At the U.S. Open, Saving the House That Built Golf
abstract: Francis Ouimet, an amateur who improbably won the 1913 U.S. Open at the Country Club, grew up across the street. Now his home will be given back to the game, and the course, that made him famous.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — The small, 19th-century home with the golf course view is hardly noticeable to the hundreds of drivers whizzing by at 40 miles an hour on Clyde Street in the Boston suburb of Brookline. While the two-story house once stood like a sentry overlooking acres of cow pasture, the neighborhood is now replete with luxury housing, four-lane roads and a bustle worthy of a community just seven miles from downtown.

headline: Court Ruling Halts Deportation of Asylum Seekers From Britain to Rwanda
abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s plan to fly asylum seekers to Rwanda to address arrivals across the English Channel has been criticized as unworkable and unethical.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last-minute legal challenges on Tuesday grounded a flight that was scheduled to take asylum seekers from Britain to Rwanda, in an unexpected setback to a new, hard-line migration policy from the British government and an eleventh-hour reprieve for those facing deportation.

headline: The Celtics Stopped Stephen Curry. Everyone Else Made Them Pay.
abstract: For the first time in a long time, Golden State’s Curry couldn’t hit a single 3-pointer. His teammates had better luck with their shots.

headline: Officer Who Displayed Nazi Insignia Will Receive $1.5 Million to Resign
abstract: Derek Kammerzell, an assistant police chief in Kent, Wash., was investigated and disciplined after he taped the insignia of an SS officer to his office door in September 2020.
lead_paragraph: The City of Kent, Wash., will pay more than $1.5 million to an assistant police chief to resign after he was disciplined for displaying a Nazi insignia on his office door.

headline: Biden Trip to Saudi Arabia Is Set, but Energy Help Is Not
abstract: The White House formally announced that President Biden would visit the oil-rich kingdom in mid-July despite having denounced it as a “pariah” state after the assassination of a dissident.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s much-anticipated trip to Saudi Arabia has been formally set for next month, the White House announced on Tuesday, but officials played down the chances of securing much immediate help in stabilizing energy markets roiled by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Why Water Use Varies So Widely Across California
abstract: In April, San Francisco residents used an average of 40 gallons of water per day, compared with 137 by those living in Riverside County.
lead_paragraph: It’s Tuesday. The latest drought figures reveal how water use varies across the state. Plus, California lawmakers pass a $300 billion budget framework.

headline: Chess Replay: You Versus Mason
abstract: Take on James Mason in a recreation of a Paris chess tournament game in Paris, 1878. Solve for the best series of moves.
lead_paragraph: About Daniel

headline: Developers Embrace Passion for Pickleball
abstract: The growing sport has lured investors eager to cash in on its popularity, opening courts in former warehouses and vacant big-box stores, and adding food and other entertainment options.
lead_paragraph: Vandalism, claims of torture and pressure campaigns are just some of the heavy-handed tactics enthusiasts have encountered in their quest to find a decent court to play their favorite sport: pickleball.

headline: ‘The Cheech,’ a Game Changer for Chicano Art, Opens in Riverside
abstract: As the Cheech Marin Center for Chicano Art and Culture debuts, its founder hopes to inspire a renaissance in a region of California lacking public arts funding.
lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — As a child, Cheech Marin loved collecting objects — baseball cards, stamps, marbles — and then organizing them obsessively.

headline: Amber Heard: I ‘Stand by Every Word’ of Testimony in Defamation Trial
abstract: In her first public interview since losing a defamation case brought against her by Johnny Depp, her ex-husband, Ms. Heard said she had told the truth when she accused him of abuse.
lead_paragraph: Almost two weeks after losing a high-profile defamation trial, Amber Heard said in a television interview on Tuesday that she had told the truth on the stand about her accusations of abuse against her ex-husband, Johnny Depp. She also took issue with the judge’s handling of evidence that she said helps prove her account of the relationship.

headline: Happy the Elephant Isn’t Legally a Person, Top New York Court Rules
abstract: An advocacy group had argued that the elephant was being illegally detained at the Bronx Zoo, in a case involving ethical questions about the rights of highly intelligent animals.
lead_paragraph: An Asian elephant named Happy that has been at the Bronx Zoo for more than 40 years will remain there after New York’s highest court ruled on Tuesday that she is not a person, in a legal sense, and therefore not entitled to a fundamental human right.

headline: When Bears Attack
abstract: What the second bear market since the start of the pandemic might signal.
lead_paragraph: The stock market fell 3.9 percent yesterday as measured by the S&P 500, closing the day nearly 22 percent below its Jan. 3 peak and firmly entering the second bear market since the pandemic began.

headline: Yellowstone Park, Staggered by Rain and Floods, Will Stay Closed for Days
abstract: Parts of the national park may stay off-limits for the rest of the season. Visitors were evacuated after record rainfall washed away roads and bridges, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Yellowstone National Park, punished over four days by record rains and melting snow that caused floods and mudslides and drove more than 10,000 visitors to safety, will remain closed for about a week, and the most severely damaged northern section may stay closed for the rest of the season, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Serena Williams Plans to Play at Wimbledon
abstract: Williams hasn’t competed since she was injured during the first round of Wimbledon last year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Serena Williams, absent from competitive tennis for nearly a year, said on Tuesday that she intends to return for Wimbledon, which begins on June 27.

headline: Coinbase says it will cut 18 percent of its work force.
abstract: The cryptocurrency exchange’s chief executive said it had “over-hired” during the bull market as adoption of crypto products was booming.
lead_paragraph: The cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase is cutting 18 percent of its work force amid depressed markets and concerns of a looming recession.

headline: Our Flag Was Still There
abstract: In his comprehensive study of the national anthem, a historian and musicologist examines our complicated relationship to a famously challenging song.
lead_paragraph: Mark Clague knows everything about “The Star-Spangled Banner,” including how you feel about it.

headline: South Carolina: How to Vote, Where to Vote and What’s on the Ballot
abstract: Not sure if you can vote? Or where to cast your ballot? Here’s what to know about voting in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Not sure if you can vote? Or where? We’ve got you covered. Here is a handy, last-minute guide to voting in South Carolina.

headline: Severe Flooding Forces Yellowstone National Park to Close
abstract: Record flooding caused by heavy rain forced visitors and residents to be evacuated from parts of Yellowstone National Park. The severe weather triggered landslides and demolished roads, threatening houses along the river bank.
lead_paragraph: Record flooding caused by heavy rain forced visitors and residents to be evacuated from parts of Yellowstone National Park. The severe weather triggered landslides and demolished roads, threatening houses along the river bank.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Answers Listener Questions
abstract: A conversation with the host of “The Ezra Klein Show”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters. Today, Ezra answers questions from listeners about climate change and the decision to have children, whether Biden should run again in 2024, a liberalism that builds, free will, aliens and more. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Hints at Fresh Revelations as Hearing Is Delayed
abstract: The panel postponed a session but released video of a White House lawyer saying he told the architect of Donald J. Trump’s plan to overturn the election that he was vulnerable to criminal charges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A day after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, Eric Herschmann, a White House lawyer, received an unexpected call from the conservative lawyer John Eastman, who had been working with President Donald J. Trump to try to overturn the results of the 2020 election.

headline: Maine: How to Vote, Where to Vote and What’s on the Ballot
abstract: Not sure if you can vote? Or where to cast your ballot? Here’s what to know about voting in Maine.
lead_paragraph: Maine offers same-day voter registration, so there’s still time to cast a ballot in person today.

headline: Deceptive Mailings, False Billboards: Voting Disinformation Is Not Just Online
abstract: A survey by election researchers argues that efforts to confuse or scare away prospective voters disproportionately target minority groups in battleground states.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to elections, disinformation is not just a problem online.

headline: Indian Cricket Broadcast Rights Fetch a Record Price
abstract: The auction cemented the league’s position among the world’s most valuable sports properties, as a once-staid game has become a commercial juggernaut.
lead_paragraph: India’s governing body for cricket said on Tuesday that it had sold television and digital broadcasting rights for a record $6.2 billion, about three times the value of its previous contracts, fortifying the Indian Premier League’s place among the world’s most valuable sports properties.

headline: Bloomberg News Employee Detained by China Has Been Released on Bail
abstract: Haze Fan was taken into custody in 2020 and has not been heard from since. Chinese officials announced last month that she had been freed in January, but many questions remain.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese employee at Bloomberg News, Haze Fan, was released on bail in January, according to the Chinese embassy in Washington, more than a year after plainclothes security officials detained her.

headline: David Morse Steadies Himself With Daily Devotions and His Own Cooking
abstract: The actor, who was just in “How I Learned to Drive” on Broadway, also has an affection for bluegrass, reading out loud and his Mercedes Sprinter van.
lead_paragraph: In 1997 David Morse and Mary-Louise Parker racked up raves and Off Broadway awards in Paula Vogel’s Pulitzer Prize-winning “How I Learned to Drive.”

headline: North Dakota: How to Vote, Where to Vote and What’s on the Ballot
abstract: Not sure if you can vote? Or where to cast your ballot? Here’s what to know about voting in North Dakota.
lead_paragraph: Nervous that you forgot to register to vote? Don’t sweat it. North Dakota does not require people to register to vote.

headline: Canada and Denmark End Their Arctic Whisky War
abstract: The two countries agreed to divide an island that sits between Canada and Greenland and defined the area’s international border.
lead_paragraph: Hans Island is just a desolate, kidney shaped piece of rock in the Arctic. But for 49 years, it has been the source of a rare territorial dispute for Canada because it sits right in the middle of the international boundary between that country and Greenland, an autonomous territory of Denmark.

headline: Lizzo’s Lyric Offended Fans. She Changed It, and They Forgave.
abstract: The song “Grrrls” was released Friday and updated Monday to remove a derogatory term for people with disabilities, which she said she did not use with an intent to offend.
lead_paragraph: Lizzo, a Grammy-winning singer and rapper seen by many fans as a champion of inclusivity, changed a lyric on a new song within days of its release after it was criticized for containing a word considered derogatory toward people with disabilities.

headline: Cambodia Sends U.S. Activist and Other Opposition Members to Prison
abstract: Theary Seng, a Cambodian American lawyer, and dozens of other critics of Prime Minister Hun Sen were convicted of conspiracy to commit treason.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Theary Seng, a Cambodian American lawyer and a human rights activist, was sentenced to six years in prison on Tuesday as part of Cambodia’s wide-ranging crackdown on opponents of the nation’s prime minister, Hun Sen.

headline: Fire Breaks Out on 10th Avenue
abstract: Burning wood is the fuel for all the cooking at Mel’s, a new pizza restaurant in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Burning wood is the fuel for all the cooking at Mel’s, a new pizza restaurant in Chelsea.

headline: The Party at Mel’s Includes Ice Cream and a Disco-Ball Pizza Oven
abstract: The first restaurant to rise from the ashes of Del Posto emphasizes fun, while the chef Melissa Rodriguez strays from tradition.
lead_paragraph: Mel’s, a pizza place that opened in Chelsea in March, seems determined to show everybody a good time. Most pizza places accomplish this with pizza alone, but Mel’s doesn’t stop there.

headline: Nevada: How to Vote, Where to Vote and What’s on the Ballot
abstract: Not sure if you can vote? Or where to cast your ballot? Here’s what to know about voting in Nevada.
lead_paragraph: Nevada voters can weigh in on some key contests today. Here’s a last-minute guide for Election Day.

headline: Chewed and Rolled: How Cats Make the Most of Their Catnip High
abstract: A new study finds that the feline reaction to catnip and silver vine helps to stave off mosquitoes and other bloodsucking insects.
lead_paragraph: Cats, so often, are a mystery, even to those that know them best. Why do they sleep so much? Why do they want your full attention one minute, none the next? How can they find their way back home after being stranded miles away for years? The writer Haruki Murakami, who is known for putting cats in his novels and essays, once confessed to not knowing why he does so; a cat “sort of naturally slips in,” he said.

headline: What Makes a Bathing Suit So Expensive?
abstract: Inside the construction of a one-piece swimsuit, a complicated symbol of “the most vulnerable time of the year.”
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Once Upon a Time, Two Lives Collided
abstract: Marina Warner tells the story of her parents’ unlikely marriage as memoir, fairy tale and tragedy.
lead_paragraph: How many of us have fantasized about chucking in the daily grind and opening a bookshop? In the immediate aftermath of the Second World War, this exact dream enticed the writer and academic Marina Warner’s father, Esmond.

headline: Wildfires Continue to Rage Out West
abstract: Wildfires have burned about one million acres across five states, including California and Arizona, forcing thousands of people to evacuate.
lead_paragraph: Wildfires have burned about one million acres across five states, including California and Arizona, forcing thousands of people to evacuate.

headline: Five Years After the Grenfell Fire, Families Grieve and Ask for Justice
abstract: Survivors, friends and families gathered in London to honor lost loved ones, but a hunger for accountability permeated the ceremony.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As 18 green balloons, one for each child who died in the Grenfell Tower fire, floated up into the sky on Tuesday alongside the abandoned building, 8-year-old Aicha, who survived the blaze, took the stage at the foot of her former home, which is now wrapped in a protective white covering.

headline: U.S. efforts to help supply Europe with natural gas take a hit.
abstract: Officials said fire damage at the Freeport LNG terminal in Texas would take months to repair, blocking exports to Europe and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Ever since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, Europe has desperately tried to find new sources of natural gas, including from the United States, to reduce its dependence on Russian natural gas supplies.

headline: Mashama Bailey and Owamni Win Top Honors at James Beard Awards
abstract: The awards were on hiatus for the past two years amid concerns about the diversity among finalists, accusations against nominees and the pandemic’s effects on the hospitality business.
lead_paragraph: Mashama Bailey of the Grey in Savannah, Ga., was named Outstanding Chef, and Owamni by the Sioux Chef in Minneapolis, owned by the chef Sean Sherman and Dana Thompson, was named Best New Restaurant at the James Beard Foundation awards on Monday night.

headline: Southern Baptists Elect New Leader Amid Deepening Divisions
abstract: The nation’s largest Protestant denomination, a bellwether for conservative Christianity, chose a rural Texas pastor and approved actions to address its sex abuse crisis.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Minutes before thousands of Southern Baptists voted for their next president, the most famous man in the room made a surprise appearance at a microphone on the convention floor.

headline: Hunger in Somalia
abstract: The drought in the country has a lesson: We know how to ease human suffering. We need to do it.
lead_paragraph: My colleague Abdi Latif Dahir has written a terrifying article that no one should have to write in 2022: Children are dying of hunger in Somalia. On top of war and political instability, now come soaring food and fertilizer prices, and forecasts of a fifth consecutive below-average rainy season. Nearly half of the country’s estimated 16 million people don’t have enough food.

headline: Saving a Texan Bayou, ‘16 Bottles’ at a Time
abstract: Bayou Dave, a modern-day Sisyphus, has spent the last dozen years ridding a trash-choked Houston waterway of plastic and Styrofoam.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much Bayou Dave hunts, his quarry never goes away. He finds it each time he sets out on Buffalo Bayou, a slow moving river that wends through the country’s fourth largest city and out to its port. And so it was one recent sweltering morning when he and his longtime deckhand, Trey Dennis, headed on a small barge to a floating boom they’d set out on the water the day before.

headline: Kyiv City Ballet to Make Its First Tour of the United States in Fall
abstract: The company, which had been on tour in France when the Russian invasion of Ukraine began, will make a stop at Fall for Dance at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Kyiv City Ballet will make its inaugural tour of the United States this fall, the company announced on Tuesday. Since February the company has been in France, where it had a temporary residency at the Théâtre du Châtelet in Paris and performed charity concerts around the country to help Ukrainian civilians.

headline: City Center’s Season to Feature an International Fall for Dance
abstract: The festival welcomes foreign troupes for the first time since 2019; other City Center highlights include Twyla Tharp and “The Light in the Piazza” at Encores!
lead_paragraph: “Oliver!,” the return of the National Ballet of Canada and a Twyla Tharp program are among the offerings for New York City Center’s 2022-23 season, the theater announced on Tuesday.

headline: Gun Safety Plan: A ‘Band-Aid’ for a Hemorrhage
abstract: Readers criticize a bipartisan gun bill as falling far short of what’s needed. Also: Misogyny and mass murder; the Jan. 6 hearings; the Biden foreign policy team.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Massachusetts Court Throws Out Gig Worker Ballot Measure
abstract: The ruling ends a $17.8 million campaign by companies like Uber and Lyft that would have led to the classification of their drivers as independent contractors.
lead_paragraph: A Massachusetts court ruled on Tuesday that a proposed ballot measure concerning the job status of gig drivers violated state law and was not eligible to be put to voters this fall.

headline: Here’s a look at what’s next after F.D.A. advisers voted to recommend Moderna’s vaccine for children 6 to 17.
abstract: The panel’s recommendation was a key step in the process as federal regulators weigh authorizing the vaccine for those children, but it is not the final say.
lead_paragraph: An independent panel of experts advising the Food and Drug Administration voted on Tuesday on to recommend to the agency that Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine be authorized for children and adolescents ages 6 to 17.

headline: Chambers, the Evolution of Racines NY, Opens in TriBeCa
abstract: A Bushwick dining room for a farm delivery service, a Chelsea Market space with immigrant and refugee chefs in the kitchen, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Racines NY, a wine bar and restaurant loosely associated with Racines in Paris, opened sporadically during the pandemic, but closed permanently last summer. It severed its ties with the Paris location, began renovations and has reinvented itself as Chambers. David Lillie, an owner of Chambers Street Wines, remains a partner, along with the beverage director, Pascaline Lepeltier, an award-winning French sommelier; the general manager, Jared David, who had that role at Racines NY; and Jonathan Karis, a former chef de cuisine at Gramercy Tavern and the new executive chef. He describes his food as home cooking, though partly boning a chicken and serving it richly marinated and sizzled on a plancha might not be a home cook’s idea of weeknight dinner. Nonetheless, his food is homier than Racines’s. Black bass with braised artichokes and saffron seasoning, grilled sweetbreads with sauerkraut, Little Gem lettuce with a creamy feta dressing and, for dessert, a phyllo mille-feuille with honey-lemon mascarpone are some other dishes he’s planning. Though the restaurant maintains its substantial cellar, the working wine list is brief, rotates seasonally and has an eye on the environment, with an interest in who made the wine and how. Ms. Lepeltier plans to feature hybrid grapes and have wines from Red Hook Winery and others on tap. “I don’t want to serve wines for the 1 percent,” she said. The renovations have resulted in a somewhat more gracious and coherent space framed by curved pale wood panels, brick walls, a long marble bar, a roomier dining counter at the open kitchen and a communal table in front. There are fewer seats, 55 down from 69, reflecting reduced staffing. (Opens Wednesday)

headline: In a Jam-Packed Weekend at Ojai, a Musical Family Gathers
abstract: Specializing in energetic interdisciplinary collaborations, the American Modern Opera Company, or AMOC, organized this year’s Ojai Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: OJAI, Calif. — “We are multiple, fractious and free,” a trio of voices sang with mock formality here on Saturday evening. “We call you to the table of a loving family.”

headline: Fed Set to Lift Rates as ‘Soft-ish Landing’ Becomes a Harder Sell
abstract: The central bank has hoped to cool down the economy without pushing unemployment much higher. Stubborn inflation narrows that path.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are meeting this week with one major goal in mind: cooling the economy enough to slow rapid inflation.

headline: ‘Official Competition’ Review: Madness in Their Methods
abstract: In this very meta comedy, Antonio Banderas, Penélope Cruz and Oscar Martínez deliver a master class on actors and their egos.
lead_paragraph: For more than 20 years, I’ve spent at least part of every week thinking about actors, but exactly what they do remains mysterious to me. Is a great performance the result of technique, of natural charisma, or of some unrepeatable chemical reaction between talent and material? Is acting a sublime feat of self-transformation, or just a fancy kind of lying?

headline: U.S. Open Will Allow Russian and Belarusian Tennis Players to Compete
abstract: The move leaves Wimbledon as the only Grand Slam tournament to bar Russians and Belarusians in the wake of the invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Open will not follow Wimbledon by barring Russian and Belarusian players from this year’s tennis tournament.

headline: Our Virtual Lives Are Real Lives
abstract: We invest meaning into the physical world — and we can do the same in digital worlds.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: China Is Taking Notes
abstract: The lessons the rising superpower is learning from Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.

headline: Tech Hiring Is Still Bonkers
abstract: The market for tech talent, and for workers of all types at tech companies, remains hot.
lead_paragraph: The technology industry is filled with frowny faces right now. Stock and cryptocurrency prices are sinking and anxiety is up. It feels as though each day brings news of some tech company or start-up laying off workers or putting hiring on hold. It happened again on Tuesday when Coinbase, the crypto exchange, said it was cutting 18 percent of its work force.

headline: The Most Dangerous Game: Surrealism
abstract: A famed zoologist returns to his first love, art, in a colorful portrait of the British avant-garde.
lead_paragraph: Desmond Morris, now a sprightly 94, is properly famous in Britain as a zoologist, author of over 40 books and a ubiquitous television presence on all matters animal. A leading academic ethnologist, Morris became a household name through his gargantuan 1967 best seller “The Naked Ape: A Zoologist’s Study of the Human Animal,” which sold some 20 million copies and was translated into 23 languages. Morris also propounded the ape’s creative abilities and organized a successful exhibition of their paintings. Certainly his star chimpanzee, “Congo,” proved this was more than a publicity stunt; Picasso supposedly owned one of his explosive abstractions, whose excellence still serves as a convincing refutation of anthropocentrism.

headline: Moscow Court Orders Brittney Griner Held in Jail for Another 18 Days
abstract: The American basketball star was arrested in February in a Russian airport amid tensions over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and attempts to win her release have repeatedly failed.
lead_paragraph: A Russian court on Tuesday extended the pretrial detention of the W.N.B.A. basketball star Brittney Griner on drug smuggling charges until July 2, pushing her jail stint past the four month mark, according to the official state news agency TASS.

headline: Russian gas flows to Germany get snarled in Canada.
abstract: A critical piece of pipeline equipment was sent to Canada for repairs. Its return has been held up by sanctions against Russia.
lead_paragraph: A machine used in shipping Russian natural gas to Germany has been caught up in Canadian sanctions imposed against Moscow, prompting a steep drop in flows in a key Russian pipeline and contributing to a surge in European natural gas prices on Tuesday.

headline: How America Lost Its Edge
abstract: Are we forgetting how to be a society?
lead_paragraph: I’ve just finished a long European tour. No, I wasn’t playing Very Important Pundit, interviewing political and business leaders (although there were a few conferences along the way). Mostly I was visiting friends, biking in Portugal, hiking in the English countryside, strolling around Berlin, etc. By the way, I had forgotten that Berlin has a massive monument to the Soviet Army:

headline: ‘Raisin in the Sun’ and ‘The Harder They Come’ Part of Public Theater Season
abstract: Two new works by Suzan-Lori Parks will be included in a season that delves into “relationships between Black and white America.”
lead_paragraph: The Public Theater’s 2022-23 season will feature a mix of works rooted in history and new pieces that speak to current cultural shifts — toward racial justice, equity and disability rights. The season kicks off with a production of Lorraine Hansberry’s 1959 play “A Raisin in the Sun,” about a Black family’s bid to move into a house in a white neighborhood of Chicago, directed by Robert O’Hara (“Slave Play,” “A Long Day’s Journey Into Night”). Performances are scheduled to begin Sept. 27.

headline: Republicans Want to ‘Harden’ Schools. That’s an Awful Euphemism.
abstract: Preparing schools to repel and return gunfire isn’t a mature society’s response.
lead_paragraph: I must admit that, as the armchair sort that I am, I hadn’t heard the term “hardening” in relation to school security until lately, in the wake of our current spate of mass shootings. But now we are hearing earnest officials urging that we “harden” schools against attackers by, for example, requiring single points of entry to school facilities; locking all other doors; placing more guards on school grounds, drawn from the ranks of former service members; and training teachers to carry and use firearms while on campus.

headline: Will Hypebeasts Shop at the Hypebeast Store?
abstract: To the streetwear giant’s founder, opening the store, which will double as its New York headquarters, is more than just a pre-I.P.O. flex.
lead_paragraph: As influencers saturate the sneakerhead community with unboxing videos and guides on where to get the latest trends with little more overhead than a ring light, Hypebeast, one of the first online platforms to arrive as a source for streetwear culture, is doubling down to the tune of seven stories.

headline: They Know Every Page of ‘The Book of Mormon’
abstract: Three original cast members, who are still with the audacious musical as it celebrates its 4,000th performance, discussed its history, reception and staying power.
lead_paragraph: In the run up to the 2011 Broadway opening of “The Book of Mormon,” there was — perhaps justifiably — some concern among some cast members about just how audiences would receive a show in which performers joyfully and repeatedly give the middle finger to God.

headline: Adams Announces Plan to Fix New York City’s Growing Housing Crisis
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams laid out a blueprint to increase homeownership, reduce street homelessness and improve public housing. But housing groups say his budget, $1 billion short of what he had promised, will not be enough.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams on Tuesday unveiled a multiyear plan to address New York City’s growing housing crisis, pledging to make rentals and homeownership more affordable, to help homeless people find permanent housing and to invest in the New York City Housing Authority, the largest public housing entity in the United States.

headline: Want to Understand Mondrian’s Paintings? Try Dancing to Them.
abstract: “You can say that Mondrian wasn’t even a visual artist,” said the curator of an exhibition celebrating the 150th anniversary of his birth. “He was a composer.”
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — The best way to understand the work of Piet Mondrian, said Caro Verbeek, the curator of a show devoted to the Dutch artist at the Kunstmuseum here, is to dance in front of one of his paintings.

headline: ‘Lightyear’ Review: Infinite Buzz
abstract: The new Pixar movie recounts the adventures of Star Command’s most famous Space Ranger before he was a toy.
lead_paragraph: The simple, charming premise of “Lightyear” is explained in an onscreen text. “In 1995, a boy named Andy got a toy from his favorite movie. This is that movie.” In other words, it’s the origin story not of a hero but of a piece of merchandise, one that started out fictional but long ago crossed the boundary into real life. More than one hard plastic Buzz Lightyear lived in my house for a long time, just like in Andy’s. To be part of the “Toy Story” universe is to be intimately acquainted with the metaphysics of the commodity form.

headline: In ‘Also a Poet,’ a Search for Frank O’Hara and for Peace With Dad
abstract: Ada Calhoun hoped to finish a biography of O’Hara once started by her father, the art critic Peter Schjeldahl. Instead, she wrote a searching memoir about creativity and family.
lead_paragraph: Children of the rich or famous are often said to be “born on third base.” Ada Calhoun, a Mets fan (with all the depth of feeling that implies), was caught in a rundown. Success would require some darting and weaving.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘A Woman Who Had Only Dated Men’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Transaction complete, the little girl grips her bag of Skittles and lingers at the concession table. She looks me in the eye and says, “You’re pretty.” Stunned, because I can’t remember when I last received an unsolicited compliment, and unsure I heard her correctly over the excited chatter of the crowd, I respond, “Thanks. So are you.” I tell her to enjoy her sister’s dance recital and smile. She studies me for another moment then turns away. The next customer hands me a five. As I make change, I wonder why this child’s words brought tears to my eyes. — Beth Meleski

headline: Nigeria Sought a $1.7 Billion Refund From JPMorgan. A London Judge Said No.
abstract: Lawyers for the country’s government tried to convince a court that the bank had violated its duty to protect Nigerian funds from fraud.
lead_paragraph: An effort by the Nigerian government to force JPMorgan Chase to restore funds that it claimed former officials had looted from a government bank account failed on Tuesday when a judge in London ruled in favor of the bank.

headline: The Future Criminal Case Against Donald Trump
abstract: The Jan. 6 committee is laying the foundations for a Justice Department investigation.
lead_paragraph: Congress and the Justice Department now find themselves in a complex dance, set to the tempo of the Jan. 6 hearings. The House select committee has already uncovered evidence suggesting that former President Donald Trump committed serious federal crimes.

headline: The U.S. says it won’t pressure Ukraine to negotiate an end to the war.
abstract: WASHINGTON — The United States will not pressure Ukraine into negotiating a cease-fire even as Russia grinds out steady gains on the ground in the country’s embattled east, a top Pentagon official said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States will not pressure Ukraine into negotiating a cease-fire even as Russia grinds out steady gains on the ground in the country’s embattled east, a top Pentagon official said on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Topdog/Underdog’ to Star Yahya Abdul-Mateen II and Corey Hawkins
abstract: The 20th anniversary Broadway revival will be directed by Kenny Leon. Previews begin in September at the John Golden Theater.
lead_paragraph: Corey Hawkins and Yahya Abdul-Mateen II will star this fall in a Broadway revival of Suzan-Lori Parks’s Pulitzer-winning comic drama “Topdog/Underdog.”

headline: North of Kyiv, the Russians Retreated. But the War Never Left.
abstract: In the Ukrainian villages near the Russian border, shells still explode and checkpoints and trenches dot the landscape. And wary civilians live in fear the enemy will return.
lead_paragraph: MOSHCHENKA, Ukraine — The tanks are gone now, and the thousands of Russian soldiers who poured into northern Ukraine in February have retreated back across the border.

headline: BTS Says It’s Taking a Break, but Promises It’s Not Permanent
abstract: Members of the K-pop juggernaut said in a video conversation that they wanted time to explore their individual artistic identities.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a decade together, the seven members of BTS need some time apart.

headline: Five New Restaurants to Try Near the Catskills
abstract: A Filipino deli with incredible views, an unfussy cafe with a rich, varied menu, very good pizza in the mountains and more.
lead_paragraph: Do you remember the first time you drove or took a train toward the Catskills? Is there anything more magical? Just beyond this incredible, but at times overwhelming, metallic metropolis there are trees and rivers and rolling hills as far as the eye can see, which always surprises me, no matter how many times I visit.

headline: In an eastern city, desperate fighting as the last bridge goes down.
abstract: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — As the battle for Sievierodonetsk appears to be entering its final stages, it remains unclear what will happen to the Ukrainian forces and thousands of civilians who are practically trapped there.
lead_paragraph: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — As the battle for Sievierodonetsk appears to be entering its final stages, it remains unclear what will happen to the Ukrainian forces and thousands of civilians who are practically trapped there.

headline: House Approves Supreme Court Security Bill, Sending It to Biden
abstract: A measure extending police protection to the immediate families of Supreme Court justices passed the House overwhelmingly.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved legislation that would extend police protection to the immediate families of Supreme Court justices, clearing the bill for President Biden at a time of rising concern about threats to justices as a potentially momentous abortion ruling looms.

headline: An Exhibition by and About Hermès Showcases Process and Precision
abstract: Up now just outside of Detroit, the show features stations at which artisans, many of them flown in from Paris, stitch, paint and engrave.
lead_paragraph: The latest incarnation of “Hermès in the Making,” a roving exhibition that’s already stopped in Copenhagen and Turin, Italy, has landed at the Somerset Collection shopping center in Troy, Michigan, just outside of Detroit. If this seems like a slightly surprising place for the French luxury brand to have set up shop, the show serves as a reminder, even if it’s an unspoken one, that both Hermès and the area have long and rich histories of craftsmanship, the latter as the longtime seat of the American auto industry and a locus of midcentury modern design, and the former as a producer of everything from saddles to scarves to porcelain.

headline: Live Primary Results: Tuesday’s Key Races
abstract: We’re watching the top races in Tuesday’s primary elections in Maine, Nevada, North Dakota and South Carolina and special election in Texas.
lead_paragraph: We’re watching the top races in Tuesday’s primary elections in Maine, Nevada, North Dakota and South Carolina and special election in Texas.

headline: Tracking the War in Real Time
abstract: How the Institute for the Study of War helps provide a clearer picture of the conflict.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Hold Onto Your Hats (and Bags). Travelers to Europe Face Chaos.
abstract: Hours in security lines. Canceled flights. Lost baggage. Here’s a look at how you could be affected by travel disruptions this summer and tips on how to prepare.
lead_paragraph: The start of the summer travel season in Europe has been marred by chaos at airports and popular tourist destinations as airlines, government agencies and industry operators struggle to meet travel demand, which, in some spots, has already surpassed 2019 levels.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: Sievierodonetsk, Isolated
abstract: The key Ukrainian city lost its last bridge as fighting intensifies.
lead_paragraph: The eastern city of Sievierodonetsk is now cut off from Ukrainian-controlled territory after the last bridge to the west was destroyed. The development could intensify a humanitarian crisis at a critical point in the brutal battle for the Donbas region: Hundreds of civilians are trapped in the city.

headline: G.O.P. primary victories in Nevada set the stage for Trump-centered battles in the fall.
abstract: The Nevada primaries capped a series of elections on Tuesday that saw key wins for Trump-inspired candidates in South Carolina and Texas.
lead_paragraph: Republican voters in Nevada on Tuesday elevated conservative candidates who have ardently embraced Donald J. Trump’s false claims of election fraud, turning a key swing state into a contest this fall between embattled Democrats and Republicans who insist President Biden stole the 2020 election.

headline: Biden Blames Republicans for Blocking Efforts to Aid Economy
abstract: President Biden defended his economic record during a speech at an A.F.L.-C.I.O. meeting, blaming at least some of the country’s problems on uncooperative Republicans who are resisting his initiatives.
lead_paragraph: President Biden defended his economic record during a speech at an A.F.L.-C.I.O. meeting, blaming at least some of the country’s problems on uncooperative Republicans who are resisting his initiatives.

headline: Eric Adams to Give Gov. Hochul a Valuable, if Belated, Endorsement
abstract: The backing from Mr. Adams, the New York City mayor, could help the governor shore up support among Black and Latino voters.
lead_paragraph: As Gov. Kathy Hochul seeks a full term as New York’s first female governor, she has moved quickly to secure the backing of nearly every major New York Democrat. One surprising holdout: Mayor Eric Adams.

headline: ‘The Music Has Stopped’: Crypto Firms Quake as Prices Fall
abstract: Crypto companies are laying off staff, freezing withdrawals and trying to stem losses, raising questions about the health of the ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — No one wanted to miss out on the cryptocurrency mania.

headline: Charles Kernaghan, Scourge of Sweatshops, Is Dead at 74
abstract: He specialized in taking down high-profile brands that used low-wage labor, including a line of clothing licensed by Kathie Lee Gifford.
lead_paragraph: Charles Kernaghan, who with a single-minded passion and tireless energy exposed the prevalence of sweatshop-made goods in America’s toy sections, department stores and celebrity fashion lines, died on June 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: A Link to Besieged Ukrainians Is Cut, as Allies Question Strategy
abstract: The last bridge to the city of Sievierodonetsk fell as street battles raged, and some Western officials questioned Ukraine’s ability to keep resisting the Russian onslaught.
lead_paragraph: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — The last bridge to the last city standing between the Russian army and control of easternmost Ukraine has collapsed, as soldiers engaged in pitched street battles for what little is left of the city and scores of civilians remained stranded under unrelenting bombardment.

headline: Ahead of U.S. Open, Top Players Take Swings at LIV Golf
abstract: Rory McIlroy has criticized LIV Golf, the Saudi-backed series splintering the men’s game, as more exhibition than competition. On Tuesday, he found an ally in Jon Rahm.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — For six months, Rory McIlroy, now in his 13th year on the PGA Tour and a four-time major champion, has been the most outspoken critic of the Saudi-backed LIV Golf circuit rattling the professional ranks.

headline: James Patterson Apologizes for Saying White Writers Face a ‘Form of Racism’
abstract: The comments by Mr. Patterson, the prolific author of best-selling thrillers, had been widely criticized.
lead_paragraph: James Patterson, the prolific author of best-selling thrillers and other books, apologized on Tuesday after saying in an interview that older white male writers face “just another form of racism” that makes it hard for them to find work.

headline: Canadians traveling within the country’s borders will no longer need to show proof of vaccination.
abstract: The mandate, which was implemented last fall, will end on June 20 for people traveling domestically, Canadian officials said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Canada, which has slowly scaled back travel restrictions as the number of coronavirus cases has continued to fall, will suspend another mandate. Starting on June 20, people traveling domestically and federal transport workers will no longer have to show proof of vaccination, officials said Tuesday, citing in large part the country’s high vaccination rate.

headline: Boy Swept Into Drainage Ditch Is Found Dead After Milwaukee Thunderstorms
abstract: Two men who attempted to rescue him were missing. Storms swept the Midwest on Monday, bringing an inch and a third of rain to the Milwaukee area within a half-hour.
lead_paragraph: A 10-year-old boy died and two men were missing after they were swept away in a drainage ditch in Milwaukee during severe thunderstorms that passed through the region overnight on Monday, bringing heavy rains and flooding to the area, the authorities said.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Sharon Oster, Barrier-Breaking Economist, Dies at 73
abstract: She was the first woman to win tenure as a professor at the Yale School of Management and the first woman to be named its dean.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Oster, an economist who shattered glass ceilings in academia as the first woman to become a tenured professor of the Yale School of Management and later as the first woman to be named its dean, died on Friday at her home in New Haven, Conn. She was 73.

headline: Toronto Mass Killer Sentenced Under Shadow of Supreme Court Ruling
abstract: The Supreme Court of Canada ruled recently that even the worst offenders can seek parole after 25 years, declaring life sentences without parole to be unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — A Toronto court filled with victims, relatives and others to tell the city’s worst killer how he had ruined their lives — breaking bones, injuring brains and dragging loved ones to death — when he steered a van onto a sidewalk and plowed through pedestrians, transforming the city’s main street into a horrific crime scene four years ago.

headline: When will we get election results from Tuesday’s primary contests?
abstract: Several factors can affect how quickly votes are tallied and results are released. Here’s what we know.
lead_paragraph: It’s never easy to predict when races will be called, but there are some pieces of information that provide clues to how the night might unfold.

headline: Biden Weighs Tariff Rollback to Ease Inflation, Even a Little Bit
abstract: While lifting some levies on China is unlikely to put a large dent in inflation, administration officials concede they have few other options to address surging prices.
