lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden is weighing whether to roll back some of the tariffs that former President Donald J. Trump imposed on Chinese goods, in hopes of mitigating the most rapid price gains in 40 years, according to senior administration officials.

headline: In villages north of Kyiv, residents still feel the war’s presence.
abstract: MOSHCHENKA, Ukraine — The tanks are gone now, and the thousands of Russian soldiers who poured into northern Ukraine in February have retreated back across the border. But fear still prevails in Moshchenka, a quiet village only six miles from Ukraine’s border with Russia and Belarus.
lead_paragraph: MOSHCHENKA, Ukraine — The tanks are gone now, and the thousands of Russian soldiers who poured into northern Ukraine in February have retreated back across the border. But fear still prevails in Moshchenka, a quiet village only six miles from Ukraine’s border with Russia and Belarus.

headline: Unexplained hepatitis is not more common in U.S. children than before the pandemic, a C.D.C. study suggests.
abstract: Officials have also been trying to determine whether the cases represent a new phenomenon or are simply a new recognition of one that has long existed; there have always been a subset of pediatric hepatitis cases with no clear cause.
lead_paragraph: Unexplained hepatitis does not appear to have become more common among American children than it was before the Covid-19 pandemic began, according to a new review of three large medical databases by researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: The Strange Tale of Herschel Walker and the Chicken Empire That Wasn’t
abstract: The Senate candidate keeps telling puzzling stories about his poultry business.
lead_paragraph: There’s a biographical story Herschel Walker tells that illustrates why so many questions linger about his Senate run in Georgia.

headline: Saudi Arabia Should Take a Mulligan on Golf. Here’s What It Can Do Instead.
abstract: There’s a better way to improve the kingdom’s international standing than starting a golf tour.
lead_paragraph: In 1989, I published a book about the Middle East, “From Beirut to Jerusalem,” and after it came out my editor, Jonathan Galassi, asked me what my next book would be about. I told him that I wanted to write a book about golf. He looked at me quizzically and asked, “The Persian Gulf?” “No,” I said. “Golf. Golf.”

headline: There Are No Winners on Team Chicken
abstract: What constitutes “normal” in today’s Republican Party still has rot at its heart.
lead_paragraph: “Team Normal” and “Rudy’s Team.” This is how Bill Stepien, Donald Trump’s former campaign manager, categorized the two camps of advisers swirling around Mr. Trump in the chaotic days after the 2020 election.

headline: Five Blunt Truths About the War in Ukraine
abstract: It’s time for Biden to take greater risks for victory.
lead_paragraph: Five sentences sum up the war in Ukraine as it stands now.

headline: Earth’s Largest Rodents Were Smaller Than We Once Thought
abstract: A new study found that primeval rodents, which were estimated to be the size of bison, were closer to modern-day ponies.
lead_paragraph: Modern rodents range in size from pygmy mice weighing less than an ounce to stocky capybaras pushing 175 pounds. But even the largest capybara is a pipsqueak compared with some prehistoric rodents that resembled a cross between a supersized capybara and a hairy hippopotamus. Paleontologists estimate that one, Phoberomys pattersoni, may have weighed as much as 1,300 pounds. Another, Josephoartigasia monesi, was believed to be around 2,000 pounds, as big as a bison.

headline: One Site, 95 Tons of Methane an Hour
abstract: In January, a satellite detected 13 plumes of methane, a potent planet-warming gas, coming from the largest coal mine in Russia.
lead_paragraph: A remote-sensing satellite has detected one of the largest releases of methane from a single industrial site, an underground coal mine in south-central Russia. The finding is another indication of the scope of the problem of curbing emissions of methane, a potent planet-warming gas.

headline: The U.S. Open will allow Russian and Belarusian tennis players to compete.
abstract: The U.S. Open will not follow Wimbledon by barring Russian and Belarusian players from this year’s tennis tournament.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Open will not follow Wimbledon by barring Russian and Belarusian players from this year’s tennis tournament.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Puts Trump Fund-Raising Tactics Under Scrutiny
abstract: Questions about misleading donors with claims of election fraud are one facet of the committee’s examination of the former president’s ongoing, aggressive solicitations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since Election Day in 2020, Donald J. Trump and his close allies have raised more than $390 million through aggressive fund-raising solicitations promising bold political actions, including fighting to overturn his re-election campaign defeat, helping allied candidates win their own campaigns and fighting “to save America from Joe Biden and the radical left.”

headline: A Striking Contrast: Trump Officials Then and Now
abstract: Many officials have told the Jan. 6 committee that they tried to dissuade the former president from his bid to overturn the election. But in public at the time, their words were far different.
lead_paragraph: The letter was lavish.

headline: Kyiv City Ballet plans its first U.S. tour in the fall.
abstract: With the war in Ukraine giving added symbolic resonance to the presence of Ukrainian culture on the global stage, the Kyiv City Ballet said on Tuesday that it would make its inaugural tour of the United States this fall.
lead_paragraph: With the war in Ukraine giving added symbolic resonance to the presence of Ukrainian culture on the global stage, the Kyiv City Ballet said on Tuesday that it would make its inaugural tour of the United States this fall.

headline: Raft by Raft, a Rainforest Loses Its Trees
abstract: The Congo River Basin rainforest, vital in the fight against climate change, has long been protected in part by its remoteness. But the river acts as a highway for sprawling flotillas of logs, sent downstream by tiny villages and international lumber companies alike, all seeking profit from a vulnerable forest.
lead_paragraph: The Congo River Basin rainforest, vital in the fight against climate change, has long been protected in part by its remoteness. But the river acts as a highway for sprawling flotillas of logs, sent downstream by tiny villages and international lumber companies alike, all seeking profit from a vulnerable forest.

headline: Corrections: June 15, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, June 15, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about testimony from Day 2 of the Jan. 6 hearings misstated Chris Stirewalt’s role in Fox News’s election night projection that Joseph R. Biden Jr. won Arizona in the 2020 election. While Mr. Stirewalt was part of the team that made the decision, he did not make the call himself.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Belarusians and Russians Can Compete At U.S. Open
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 15, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “But I think at the end of the day, we chose not to hold the individual athletes accountable for the decisions of their respective governments.”

headline: Search for Journalist and Expert in Amazon Becomes Homicide Investigation
abstract: The police arrested a second suspect after Dom Phillips, a British journalist, and Bruno Araújo Pereira, a Brazilian expert on Indigenous people, went missing.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Brazilian authorities said on Tuesday that they had arrested a second man in the disappearance of a British journalist and a Brazilian expert on Indigenous people deep in the Amazon, confirming that their efforts were shifting from a search-and-rescue operation to a homicide investigation.

headline: Drop a Line
abstract: Rob Baker’s debut brings us a quip with a twist.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor, Rob Baker, who is making his New York Times Crossword debut today. As Mr. Baker mentions in his notes, he has been submitting puzzles on and off for more than 15 years, so major kudos to him for his perseverance!

headline: Herschel Walker, Critic of Absentee Fathers, Has a Second Son He Doesn’t See
abstract: The football star and G.O.P. Senate candidate has often praised his relationship with his 22-year-old son, Christian. Left unmentioned: He also has a 10-year-old son.
lead_paragraph: Herschel Walker, the Republican nominee for Senate from Georgia, who has often spoken out against absentee fathers, particularly in Black households, on Tuesday publicly acknowledged having fathered a second son with whom he is not in contact.

headline: In South Carolina, a Republican congressman who voted to impeach Trump loses his primary to a Trump-backed rival.
abstract: Representative Tom Rice was the first of the 10 House Republicans who supported impeachment to test the will of the primary voters and lose.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tom Rice, a staunch conservative who voted to impeach former President Donald J. Trump for fomenting the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, was defeated Tuesday by a Trump-endorsed primary challenger, the first of the 10 House Republicans who backed impeachment to test the will of the primary voters and lose.

headline: Representative Nancy Mace holds off a Trump-endorsed challenger in South Carolina.
abstract: Ms. Mace had said the former president’s false claims of a stolen election contributed to the Jan. 6 riot.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Representative Nancy Mace, a Republican who clashed with former President Donald J. Trump after the Jan. 6 attack, fended off a primary challenge on Tuesday from Katie Arrington, a former state representative who had Mr. Trump’s backing. The race was called by The Associated Press.

headline: Republicans flip a Democratic-held House seat in South Texas, at least for now.
abstract: The district in the border city of Brownsville has sent Democrats to Congress for years.
lead_paragraph: A U.S. House district in South Texas will send a Republican to Congress for the first time in its 10-year history.

headline: Making Three Straight Finals Is Hard. Winning Them All Is Harder.
abstract: Only a few North American pro teams have won three straight championships. Can the Tampa Bay Lightning join them?
lead_paragraph: Winning a championship is the peak achievement for a professional sports team. Repeating the next year is a rarity. But trades get made, and players retire. Injuries happen, and so do upsets. Postseason play is a grueling gantlet to run, and it keeps expanding. Winning a third straight title is one of the toughest feats in team sports, and it is seemingly getting tougher.

headline: Longtime Voice of the Celtics Hopes He Cheered On a Championship Run
abstract: Mike Gorman, who has done local play-by-play in Boston for more than 40 years, considered retiring. Staying on may have made him the soundtrack to a title team.
lead_paragraph: To generations of Celtics fans, Mike Gorman is just as revered as many of the beloved Hall of Fame players who have taken the floor in Boston.

headline: Happy the Elephant Doesn’t Have Human Rights, Court Finds
abstract: Animal advocates had argued that the longtime resident of the Bronx Zoo was imprisoned.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at a court ruling that said Happy the Elephant does not have the same rights as a human. We’ll also look at Mayor Eric Adams’s planned endorsement of Gov. Kathy Hochul and his blueprint for tackling the city’s housing crisis.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Ukraine falters in the east.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. will not pressure Ukraine into negotiating a cease-fire even as Russia grinds out steady gains on the ground in the country’s embattled east, Colin H. Kahl, a top Pentagon official, said yesterday. “We’re not going to tell the Ukrainians how to negotiate, what to negotiate and when to negotiate,” he added. “They’re going to set those terms for themselves.”

headline: Biden Makes Staff Changes as White House Counsel Departs, Midterms Loom
abstract: Dana Remus, the president’s top lawyer, will be replaced by her deputy, and Keisha Lance Bottoms, the former Atlanta mayor, is joining the White House staff.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Wednesday appointed Keisha Lance Bottoms, the former mayor of Atlanta, as a senior adviser in the White House, further shuffling his senior staff amid a series of high-profile departures heading into the midterm campaigns.

headline: Adam Laxalt wins the Republican Senate primary in Nevada, setting up a high-stakes November fight.
abstract: Mr. Laxalt, a former attorney general of the state who was endorsed by Donald Trump, will face Senator Catherine Cortez Masto, a Democrat, in one of this year’s pivotal Senate races.
lead_paragraph: Adam Laxalt, a former Nevada attorney general, has won the state’s Republican primary for Senate and will face Senator Catherine Cortez Masto, a Democrat, in what is likely to be a highly competitive November general election.

headline: Life pauses at a funeral for another soldier killed in the east.
abstract: LVIV, Ukraine — People dropped to their knees in silence, clasping their hands and muttering prayers from the sidewalk, as a van carried the remains of a fallen soldier through the streets of Lviv on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — People dropped to their knees in silence, clasping their hands and muttering prayers from the sidewalk, as a van carried the remains of a fallen soldier through the streets of Lviv on Tuesday.

headline: NATO’s leader pledges more military aid as Ukraine says weapons are slow to arrive.
abstract: BRUSSELS — NATO member countries will continue to provide Ukraine with heavy weapons and long-range systems, and a new package of assistance to Kyiv will be agreed on by allies in consultation with Ukraine’s defense minister, NATO’s secretary general said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — NATO member countries will continue to provide Ukraine with heavy weapons and long-range systems, and a new package of assistance to Kyiv will be agreed on by allies in consultation with Ukraine’s defense minister, NATO’s secretary general said on Wednesday.

headline: Jim Marchant, a Trump loyalist, is G.O.P. voters’ choice to be Nevada’s top election official.
abstract: Mr. Marchant, an organizer of the ‘America First’ slate of candidates who deny the 2020 election’s validity, won the Republican primary for secretary of state in a key political battleground.
lead_paragraph: Jim Marchant, one of the organizers of a Trump-inspired “America First” slate of candidates who continue to question the legitimacy of the 2020 election, easily won the Republican nomination for secretary of state in Nevada, a key political battleground.

headline: Trevor Noah Tricks His Audience Into Singing ‘Happy Birthday’ for Trump
abstract: After the boos ceased, Noah joked that “the haters can’t even give the poor man a day off.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: How the Institute for the Study of War tries to provide a clearer picture of the fighting.
abstract: Since the start of Russia’s invasion, the Institute for the Study of War has provided daily updates about the situation on the front. The assessments from the Washington-based research group have become required reading for people following the war.
lead_paragraph: Since the start of Russia’s invasion, the Institute for the Study of War has provided daily updates about the situation on the front. The assessments from the Washington-based research group have become required reading for people following the war.

headline: Who won and who lost in Tuesday’s primary elections.
abstract: Nevada voters elevated election deniers, while South Carolina split on two House members facing Trump-endorsed challengers. Here’s a rundown.
lead_paragraph: Voters in several states weighed in on key contests in Tuesday’s primaries. Here are some of the most notable wins and losses:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Joseph Lombardo, Backed by Trump, Will Challenge for Nevada Governor
abstract: Mr. Lombardo, the sheriff of the Las Vegas area, will face Gov. Steve Sisolak, a Democrat, in what is expected to be one of the most competitive governor’s races in the country.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Lombardo, the sheriff who oversees the Las Vegas area and was endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump, has won Nevada’s Republican primary for governor.

headline: Newly Published, From Teenage D.J.s to the Pope
abstract: A selection of books published this week.
lead_paragraph: THE AGATHAS, by Kathleen Glasgow and Liz Lawson. (Delacorte, $18.99, ages 13 and up.) In this murder mystery inspired by the works of Agatha Christie, two teenagers try to figure out who killed a classmate.

headline: What if This Wasn’t Menopause After All?
abstract: The patient had the full suite of symptoms — and a jaw that somehow moved out of alignment. That was the clue something was wrong.
lead_paragraph: The 53-year-old woman bit into her salad, enjoying the crispness. But as she swallowed, a chunk of lettuce stuck in her throat. She coughed, and it loosened and came back up. It was a problem she had frequently these days. Her teeth on the right side of her jaw didn’t touch anymore. It was hard to chew her food well. What was really upsetting was that she’d had this problem before — for most of the previous year. When she couldn’t put up with it anymore, she’d gone to her dentist, Dr. Robert Souferian, in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, who confirmed that her bite had shifted a little. He was reassuring, said that it happened sometimes and offered to file her teeth a little to make the fit better. That worked beautifully — for a few months. But it was now clear that her jaw had shifted again.

headline: Read Your Way Through Paris
abstract: Leïla Slimani, winner of France’s Goncourt Prize, describes her Paris and recommends books that reveal hidden facets of the city.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, a young Japanese tourist approached me on the Boulevard Saint-Germain. In a shy voice, she asked, “Where are the writers?” I didn’t understand what she meant. “I would like to see the writers,” she added. “In my guidebook it says that Paris is full of them.” Of course, I smiled and explained to her that times had changed and it was rather rare to see famous writers working in cafes. But I wouldn’t have dreamed of making fun of her, because that’s what I came to Paris for too.

headline: The Magical Thinking Behind Gun Culture
abstract: What the Buffalo livestream reveals about the limits of practical regulations in a country so enamored with firearms.
lead_paragraph: In the minutes before an 18-year-old self-proclaimed white supremacist from Conklin, N.Y., drove to a Buffalo grocery store, where he is suspected of shooting 13 people while livestreaming the carnage, he obsessed over his equipment and, implicitly, his legacy.

headline: Who Can Write About What? A Conversation With Roxane Gay and Jay Caspian Kang.
abstract: Two writers debate writing across identity lines — and how to respond when an author gets it really wrong.
lead_paragraph: When does creative license become cultural appropriation? Take “American Dirt” and “The Help,” two books by white authors that drew criticism for their portrayals of characters of color. Artists’ job is to imagine and create, but what do we do when they get it wrong?

headline: ‘Meet Me by the Fountain’ Takes a Tour of the Mall
abstract: The design critic Alexandra Lange’s new book considers the rise and fall and dicey future of an American institution.
lead_paragraph: Like people and clouds and cars, malls come in many shapes and colors. But malls have certain bedrock commonalities. A handful of these are physical: food courts, escalators, kiosks, benches, plants, restrooms, parking. Others are intangible. Malls are an ambiguous blend of public and private space — open to all in theory but inaccessible to many in practice. They are recreational zones, community hubs, surveillance centers, temples to consumerism, places where loitering is encouraged until the mall cops kick you out for loitering too much or in the wrong fashion.

headline: Meet the Self-Described ‘Bimbos’ of TikTok
abstract: Can talking about how dumb and hot you are be a feminist act?
lead_paragraph: “Are you a leftist who likes to have their tits out? Do you like to flick off pro-lifers?” Chrissy Chlapecka asks the camera in a 51-second TikTok captioned “BIMBOS, RISE 💖‼️” In the video, Ms. Chlapecka, a 22-year-old comedian who lives in Chicago and has about 4.6 million TikTok followers, is wearing a tight pink minidress, a pink coat trimmed with faux fur and tall white leather boots; her bleach-blond hair is in pigtails. “Are you good at math?” she asks, scribbling “2+2=<3” into a notebook. She holds a pose while reading a book upside down. “Are you good at reading? Well, if you are, how?” At the end of the video, she yells out the window: “I’m a bimbo and I’m proud!”

headline: Raphael Warnock: I Can Still Hear My Father’s Voice
abstract: Pvt. Jonathan Warnock was a walking sermon.
lead_paragraph: I can still hear my father’s voice.

headline: The Fed Should Make Amends for Its Mistakes
abstract: A 75-basis-point increase, along with the will to tackle inflation aggressively, would shore up the bank’s shaky credibility.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s powerful Open Market Committee will conclude a regular two-day meeting early Wednesday afternoon with an announcement on its next move on interest rates.

headline: We’re Staring at Our Phones, Full of Rage for ‘the Other Side’
abstract: Once upon a time, social media was going to bring us all together.
lead_paragraph: In theory, American federalism allows a thousand flowers to bloom, as cities and states serve as laboratories of democracy. Transparent governance — sunlight is said to be the best of disinfectants — empowers the electorate to see what its representatives are up to. The internet gives both voice and access to virtually everyone regardless of their status. The surge in small-dollar campaign contributions democratizes the financing of elections, lessening the power of the rich.

headline: Secondhand Wedding Dress Shopping? It’s a Buyer’s Market.
abstract: “You can find a dress that makes you feel beautiful on a budget — you can save thousands of dollars,” said one bride. “You just have to be willing to do a little digging.”
lead_paragraph: Beverly Yip had always envisioned getting married in a gown from a bridal line like Monique Lhuillier, Berta or Casablanca. The former owner of a rental business that provided linens, glassware and other supplies for weddings, Ms. Yip, who sold that company in 2017, had identified favorite designers by taking note of what other brides were wearing.

headline: The U.S. Is Losing Its Military Edge in Asia, and China Knows It
abstract: America can no longer deter China without help from its allies.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese fighter jet veered in front of an Australian military surveillance aircraft over international waters in the South China Sea last month and released metallic debris that was sucked into the Australian plane’s engines.

headline: New York Faces New Commuter Surge, Ready or Not, Study Suggests
abstract: The study appears to underscore the need for a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River, part of the huge and long-planned Gateway project.
lead_paragraph: The shift from commuting caused by the pandemic left empty seats on the once-packed trains and buses bringing commuters from New Jersey to New York City. But those crowded conditions will return and may worsen over the next decade as the region’s population grows and more employers call workers back to their offices, a new study concluded.

headline: Trump and Sanders Opened Doors. Inflation Is Closing Them.
abstract: What a climate of fiscal constraint means for the populist right and the socialist left.
lead_paragraph: There were many bad things about the period in American politics between Donald Trump’s escalator descent in summer 2015 and the arrival of the Covid pandemic: chaos, polarization, corruption, hysteria, the usual list.

headline: Far-Right Republicans Press Closer to Power Over Future Elections
abstract: Midway through primary season, the party has nominated several candidates who deny the 2020 outcome for posts that will have significant sway over the 2024 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: The potential for far-right Republicans to reshape the election systems of major battleground states is growing much closer to reality.

headline: If Those Chairs Could Talk
abstract: The house of Hubert de Givenchy is going up for auction. This week. Christie’s will auction more than 1,200 lots of furniture, sculpture and art that belonged to the designer. His inner circle tells the stories behind the stuff.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When guests arrived at the Hotel d’Orrouer, the French couturier Hubert de Givenchy’s stately 18th-century mansion here, they rang a polished brass doorbell on the limestone wall. Once the bell was rung — no sound was made — the guardian would open the right side of the monumental evergreen-lacquered double doors and usher in the guests.

headline: These Cupcakes Are Pure Childhood Magic
abstract: Yotam Ottolenghi’s cream-soda-and-raspberry cupcakes can’t heal the troubles of the world. But they help for a moment.
lead_paragraph: Whenever one of my children reaches a milestone, I become hopelessly teary. Tears of joy? I don’t think so. My tears are for a moment so precious and fleeting that I fear it may be lost. It’s a confusing place in the sad-to-happy range that makes me strangely gloomy.

headline: What Europe’s Universal Charger Mandate Means for You
abstract: From power bricks to cables, it’s time to incorporate USB-C or wireless charging into your setup.
lead_paragraph: Most of us own multiple types of chargers to replenish our devices. That’s because many products, like Apple phones and Microsoft Surface computers, are plugged in with wires that use unique connectors.

headline: Brutal Beating of Women in China Highlights Risk of Saying ‘No’
abstract: Graphic footage of an attack in a restaurant fueled online debate that showed both the growing awareness of women’s rights and how divisive feminism still remains.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The man walked into a barbecue restaurant in northern China and approached a table of three women. He put his hand on the back of one, who shook him off. In response, he slapped her — then, with several other men, savagely beat her and the other women, hitting them with chairs, kicking them and dragging them outdoors.

headline: Some Clinics Aren’t Waiting for Roe Decision to Stop Abortions
abstract: Women can no longer get a legal abortion in two states.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

headline: Yes, You Can Do Better Than the Great American Lawn
abstract: There are any number of ecologically friendly alternatives to that lawn you’re so proud of — and they look nice, too. Here’s how to start slowly.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Jaffe Wilder still remembers the conversation he had maybe six years ago with a former colleague, when they were working at Garden in the Woods, the native-plant garden in Massachusetts.

headline: When #Vanlife Meets the $300 Tank
abstract: Remaining in destinations longer, using gas apps and signing up for fuel cards allow nomadic travelers to stay on the road.
lead_paragraph: Britt Ruggiero and Justin Giuffrida bought a 2002 Bluebird school bus in February 2021, with plans to convert it into a 30-foot home on wheels. At the time, diesel fuel prices in their home state of Colorado were averaging around $3 per gallon, the same as the national average.

headline: Who Will Repair Their Birkins Now?
abstract: Artbag, the Madison Avenue shop that socialites and celebrities have trusted to restore their chic handbags for 90 years, is closing.
lead_paragraph: June 30 will mark the end of era for a particular set of New Yorkers. That is when Artbag, the go-to store for ladies who lunched (when lunch was a verb) and who needed their choicest handbags repaired and restored for those tony lunches, leaves town.

headline: Billy Cotton, an Interior Designer for Blue-Chip Artists
abstract: How the once-struggling decorator became a favorite of Cindy Sherman and other artists.
lead_paragraph: Billy Cotton was in his 20s, newly arrived in Manhattan in the early 2000s and coasting on a cocktail of youthful exuberance, weed and amphetamines, when a fire consumed his apartment in Chelsea, and with it, his sense of a future.

headline: In ‘Corsicana,’ Will Arbery Puts Art, Family and Down Syndrome Onstage
abstract: Arbery, a Pulitzer finalist in 2020, is back with a play inspired by his relationship with his sister. But don’t call it an “issue” play.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, Will Arbery scored an unlikely hit with “Heroes of the Fourth Turning,” his darkly comic, boundary-pushing play about young Catholic conservatives debating God, love, friendship and Donald Trump at a late-night party in a Wyoming backyard. A finalist for the 2020 Pulitzer Prize, it won praise both from the heavily liberal New York theater world and from traditionalist Christians who often feel caricatured by it, if they are depicted at all.

headline: A Decade After DACA, the Rise of a New Generation of Undocumented Students
abstract: A vast majority of undocumented teenagers are graduating high school this year without protection from deportation and the ability to legally work.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Battle Over Gender Therapy
abstract: More teenagers than ever are seeking transitions, but the medical community that treats them is deeply divided about why — and what to do to help them.
lead_paragraph: Scott Leibowitz is a pioneer in the field of transgender health care. He has directed or worked at three gender clinics on the East Coast and the Midwest, where he provides gender-affirming care, the approach the medical community has largely adopted for embracing children and teenagers who come out as transgender. He also helps shape policy on L.G.B.T. issues for the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry. As a child and adolescent psychiatrist who is gay, he found it felt natural to work under the L.G.B.T. “umbrella,” as he put it, aware of the overlap as well as the differences between gay and trans identity.

headline: Romania Sees an Opening to Become an Energy Power in Europe
abstract: The Ukraine war could lead to breakthroughs in nuclear power and natural gas, with Washington’s help.
lead_paragraph: CERNAVODA, Romania — A row of hulking concrete domes loom along the Danube-Black Sea Canal in Cernavoda, about two hours east of Bucharest. Two of the structures house nuclear reactors feeding Romania’s electrical grid.  Two others were begun decades ago and are still waiting for completion — though, perhaps, not for long.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Tuesday’s Voting
abstract: Nevada shapes up as a fall battleground between vulnerable Democrats and election-denying Republicans. South Carolina G.O.P. voters punished one House incumbent who broke with Donald Trump, but forgave another. And Texas Republicans scored at least a short-term victory.
lead_paragraph: From Las Vegas to Lewiston, Maine, the contours of critical midterm contests came into focus on Tuesday as Americans voted in major federal and state races across five states.

headline: Stocks rise as policymakers chart a new path.
abstract: Investors appeared mostly unsurprised by the Federal Reserve’s announcement of a large rate increase, with the S&P 500 closing up 1.4 percent.
lead_paragraph: Global markets recouped some of their recent losses on Wednesday as investors reacted to pivotal meetings by economic policymakers trying to rein in inflation without denting economic growth or destabilizing markets.

headline: The Claws of a Bear Market
abstract: Can the Federal Reserve and the White House tamp down inflation without sending the U.S. economy into a recession?
lead_paragraph: The meteoric rise of the U.S. stock market over the past two years has come to an abrupt end.

headline: A Medical Frontier
abstract: Doctors who provide gender-affirming care are split on how to evaluate teens.
lead_paragraph: This summer, the World Professional Association for Transgender Health, an international group of health care professionals, plans to release an update to its guidelines for giving care. The guidelines include a chapter on adolescents that is already generating heat from across the political spectrum.

headline: What are the next steps for Moderna and Pfizer’s vaccines for very young children?
abstract: As eagerly anticipated as the shots are for some parents, the F.D.A. advisory committee’s decisions are just one step in a process federal regulators must follow before the vaccines become available to children as young as 6 months old.
lead_paragraph: An independent panel of experts advising the Food and Drug Administration voted on Wednesday to recommend to the agency that very young children be allowed to receive pediatric doses of the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccines.

headline: $1.1 Million Homes in New Jersey, California and Connecticut
abstract: A 1908 riverfront estate in Ewing, a 1927 Spanish-style house in Los Angeles and an 1852 home in Essex.
lead_paragraph: A 1908 riverfront estate in Ewing, a 1927 Spanish-style house in Los Angeles and an 1852 home in Essex.

headline: $1.1 Million Homes in New Jersey, California and Connecticut
abstract: A 1908 riverfront estate in Ewing, a 1927 Spanish-style house in Los Angeles and an 1852 home in Essex.
lead_paragraph: This house is about three miles from Washington Crossing State Park — a 500-acre expanse marking the site of George Washington’s 1776 crossing of the Delaware River — which draws visitors with its hiking trails and collection of historic buildings. Directly across the street from the house is an entrance to the Delaware and Raritan Canal State Park Trail, which makes use of a towpath once employed in barge transport during the years before steam power.

headline: After a spring surge, confirmed new U.S. cases are leveling off.
abstract: The national outlook is improving, but as new Omicron subvariants spread fast, a few places are turning to mask orders again.
lead_paragraph: After a rise in known infections this spring, new coronavirus cases in the United States have leveled off in recent weeks, even as hospitalizations continue to inch upward and new Omicron subvariants rapidly circulate.

headline: Weaknesses in the Social Safety Net Disrupt the U.S. Work Force
abstract: “Does worker organizing not work because there’s all this monopoly power?” said Julie Su, deputy secretary of labor. “Why don’t we question whether the monopoly power is the problem.”

headline: Nuclear Is Back on the Table for a Green Future
abstract: Shifting from dependency to energy sources that are completely sustainable, affordable and clean isn’t technically feasible overnight. Can nuclear power help fill the gap?
lead_paragraph: It is the third rail of the energy debate: nuclear.

headline: As Crypto Tanks, Tech Veterans Question Blockchain’s Promise of Economic Salvation
abstract: Crypto fans say the technology promotes financial inclusion. Critics contend that the space is rife with predators putting unwary investors at risk.
lead_paragraph: Crypto champions say that digital assets can bring excluded communities into the financial system and help marginalized investors to grow wealth. But some critics question whether the new tools present a true opportunity or a threat.

headline: Constructive Communication Between the U.S. and China Gets Harder
abstract: Later this month, the United States and China may face another threat in their already fraught relations.
lead_paragraph: At the outset of Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidency, many people hoped that relations between the United States and China, after four years of battering, would slowly start to improve. That hasn’t been the case.

headline: A 19th-Century Tudor Revival House in Rural England
abstract: This six-bedroom Tudor Revival-style home, built in 1820 in the city of Calne, in South West England, is on the market for $2.1 million.
lead_paragraph: This six-bedroom Tudor Revival-style home, built in 1820 in the city of Calne, in South West England, is on the market for $2.1 million.

headline: House Hunting in England: A Six-Bedroom Starter Castle for $2 Million
abstract: The country home markets in South West England have benefited from a shift in what buyers want, though the region remains a relative bargain.
lead_paragraph: This Tudor Revival-style house, built in 1820 around a 17th-century core and expanded in 1920, sits on the periphery of Calne, a medieval market town in Wiltshire County, in South West England. Known as Castlefields, the six-bedroom home was originally part of a 200-acre estate used for hunting grouse and partridge, and is a protected historic property with a “grade two” on the National Heritage List for England.

headline: How Nike Won the Cultural Marathon
abstract: As the brand turns 50, it’s not letting up.

headline: Dangerously Hot Weather Descends on 60 Million Americans
abstract: A large swath of the U.S. population was under an extreme heat warning, with high temperatures breaking daily records in multiple cities this week.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people were expected to suffer through blistering conditions again on Thursday with heat-related warnings and advisories in effect, mostly in the Midwest and Southeast, the National Weather Service said, adding that it may take weeks to see relief.

headline: How Much Can the Fed Do?
abstract: The Fed will conclude its two-day policy meeting today and announce what it will do with the short-term interest rate it sets.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the government reported last week that inflation had sped up in May, economists and investors have been on high alert to see how the Federal Reserve would respond to the threat of surging prices.

headline: Macron says he wants a Ukrainian victory, but underlines that talks will still be necessary.
abstract: During a visit to Romania, the French president appeared intent on addressing criticism that he was placing pressure on Kyiv to enter into peace talks.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Wednesday called on Europe to ramp up support for Kyiv, saying he hoped for a Ukrainian victory over Russia, but emphasized that the conflict would eventually have to end at the negotiating table.

headline: U.K. Vows to Press Ahead With Deportations to Rwanda
abstract: The government said it would stick with a plan to send asylum seekers to the African country, despite the first flight’s grounding after a ruling by the European Court of Human Rights.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The plane was preparing for take off, and the small group on board seemed destined to become the first asylum seekers flown 4,000 miles to Rwanda under Britain’s new hard-line migration policy.

headline: What the Changing Tech Market Means for California’s Economy
abstract: Venture capital is sounding the alarm, but economists say the broader impacts are likely less dire.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been steeped in the start-up world, you’d be forgiven for thinking that the end of the world — or, at least, the tech bubble — was nigh.

headline: Chess Replay: You Versus Suetin
abstract: Take on Alexey Suetin in a recreation of a Goglidze Memorial Tournament game in Tbilisi, 1970. Solve for the best series of moves.
lead_paragraph: About Daniel

headline: Tesla Autopilot and Other Driver-Assist Systems Linked to Hundreds of Crashes
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration released data on 10 months of crashes involving cars with automated components. A few were fatal.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 400 crashes in the United States in 10 months involved cars using advanced driver-assistance technologies, the federal government’s top auto-safety regulator disclosed Wednesday.

headline: Disney’s ‘Lightyear,’ With a Same-Sex Kiss, Faces a Backlash in Some Muslim Countries
abstract: The United Arab Emirates banned the animated film, an offshoot of the “Toy Story” movies, from its cinemas. Censors in Indonesia and Malaysia are also considering restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Disney’s new movie “Lightyear,” an offshoot of the “Toy Story” franchise, faces bans or restrictions in parts of Southeast Asia and the Middle East over a scene that features a kiss between two women. The animated film opens around the world this week.

headline: China’s Xi offers closer cooperation with Russia in a call with Putin.
abstract: The Chinese government has tried to keep good ties with Moscow while maintaining that it wants to be an impartial broker for peace in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: China’s president, Xi Jinping, offered to deepen cooperation with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, in a phone call on Wednesday, signaling that Mr. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine had not dented Mr. Xi’s basic commitment to their partnership.

headline: Can a Law Protecting Endangered Animals Stop New Oil Drilling?
abstract: Environmentalists say the government failed to study the threats to endangered species from climate change before issuing oil and gas drilling permits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A coalition of environmental groups sued the Biden administration on Wednesday for failing to consider the harms caused to endangered species from the emissions produced by oil and gas drilling on public lands.Using a novel legal argument based on the Endangered Species Act, the groups are arguing that oil burned from a well drilled in Wyoming adds to the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere that is heating the planet and devastating coral reefs in Florida, polar bears in the Arctic and monk seals in Hawaii.

headline: Russia’s oil output rose last month, despite sanctions.
abstract: Oil production in Russia remained lower than it was before the war, the International Energy Agency said, but was creeping higher.
lead_paragraph: Russia continues to find buyers for its oil despite Western sanctions.

headline: Lego plans to build a factory in the United States.
abstract: The toymaker said it would invest $1 billion in the plant, which will be in Virginia, in an effort to shorten its supply chain in the Americas.
lead_paragraph: Hoping to shorten the supply chain for its popular building sets, the toymaker Lego said on Wednesday that it was planning to invest $1 billion in a new factory in Chesterfield County, Va.

headline: Athens Court Opens Appeals Hearing for Imprisoned Golden Dawn Members
abstract: Dozens of members of the extreme-right party, which was deemed a criminal organization by the Greek judiciary, were convicted in 2020.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Just over a year-and-a-half after the leaders of Greece’s Golden Dawn party and dozens of supporters were imprisoned after the neo-fascist group was deemed a criminal organization, an Athens court on Wednesday began hearing appeals against the convictions.

headline: U.S. and NATO allies send more military aid to Ukraine to counter Russia.
abstract: After announcing a major new wave of long-range weaponry for Ukraine, Western leaders will turn their sights toward other potential threats to NATO from Russia and China.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Amid increasingly urgent calls by Ukraine for heavy weapons to fend off Russian’s invasion, President Biden on Wednesday announced an additional $1 billion in weapons and aid for the country, and the United States and its allies sought to present a united front against the Kremlin.

headline: Many Realities, or None at All
abstract: In a meditation from a bench in Tompkins Square Park, the Hungarian author Laszlo Krasznahorkai explores a philosophical question.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Can Luke Combs, Country’s Everyman, Grow Up Without Losing Touch?
abstract: The unflashy 32-year-old star makes irrepressibly catchy and relatable country anthems. Now he’s walking a tricky line: finding ways to evolve without straying too far from his roots.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, Tenn. — On a warm, clear Tuesday in May, Luke Combs offered a visitor a ride around his property in rural Tennessee on one of his Polaris utility vehicles. The 140-acre parcel of forests, fields and streams is about an hour from Nashville. It includes a pool, a beach volleyball court, a chicken coop and a large, white house at the top of a hill where he lives with his wife, who was then eight months pregnant with the couple’s first child.

headline: The Boston Celtics Have Faced Elimination, but Not Like This
abstract: The Celtics have drawn confidence from previous season-saving wins. But watching a championship trophy drift away is another challenge altogether.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Jayson Tatum offered a resigned chuckle when he was asked about the Boston Celtics’ confidence level after losing Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Living In ... Chappaqua, N.Y.
abstract: Those looking for a home outside the city praise the Westchester hamlet for its variety of housing and small-town feel.
lead_paragraph: Those looking for a home outside the city praise the Westchester hamlet for its variety of housing and small-town feel.

headline: Chappaqua, N.Y.: A Westchester Hamlet That’s ‘Not Cookie-Cutter’
abstract: Those looking for a home outside the city praise Chappaqua for its variety of housing and small-town feel.
lead_paragraph: Tara Watnik knew that she and her family would leave their Bronx co-op for a house in Westchester — eventually. But her husband, Scott Watnik, a partner in a Manhattan law firm, grew up in Riverdale, and they liked living in his childhood neighborhood, which was close to her job as a communications director at a private school and an easy commute for him. Then Covid hit, and they decided it was time to get serious about moving.

headline: European Central Bank announces efforts to end bond market turmoil.
abstract: The bank is concerned about a widening divergence in borrowing costs among the countries that use the euro.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank said Wednesday that it would take new steps to ward against spiraling borrowing costs in some highly indebted European countries. The announcement followed an unexpected meeting of bank policymakers looking to soothe growing concerns in the bond market.

headline: Saying Goodbye to Tommy Shelby, a Traumatized TV Antihero
abstract: Over the six seasons of “Peaky Blinders,” its central character has grappled with his post-traumatic stress disorder and what redemption could look like.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for Season 6 of “Peaky Blinders.”

headline: In Dakar, African Art Speaks in All Its Voices
abstract: In its first pandemic-era edition, the Dakar Biennale, Africa’s biggest art gathering, is uneven, hectic — and full of possibility.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Despite the rise to prominence of African contemporary art, its terms are still largely influenced by foreign validators: the mainly Western museums, galleries, collectors and auction houses whose attention anoints stars and assigns value.

headline: Ukraine has only a fraction of the weapons it needs from the West, a Kyiv official says.
abstract: The refrain from Ukraine to its Western allies has been the same since the war began: Give us weapons, and we will beat the Russians so that the rest of Europe can be safe.
lead_paragraph: The refrain from Ukraine to its Western allies has been the same since the war began: Give us weapons, and we will beat the Russians so that the rest of Europe can be safe.

headline: Biden slaps oil companies for profiteering at the pump.
abstract: In a letter to seven large energy firms, the president said excessive margins were “worsening that pain” for American consumers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden chastised some of the largest oil companies for profiteering off surging energy prices and “worsening that pain” for consumers, as he increased the pressure on them to boost refining capacity and bring down costs at the pump.

headline: A top F.D.A. official says very young children need protection from Covid.
abstract: The remarks by Dr. Peter Marks came at a meeting of an advisory panel weighing whether to recommend that the F.D.A. authorize pediatric vaccines from Moderna and Pfizer.
lead_paragraph: A meeting of outside advisers to the Food and Drug Administration to consider coronavirus vaccines for young children kicked off Wednesday morning with a plea from Dr. Peter Marks, the agency’s top vaccine regulator, about the need to protect children 5 and younger from Covid-19.

headline: The Korean Recipes Eric Kim Can’t Live Without
abstract: Eric wrote, “If I could have only 10 Korean dishes for the rest of my life, these would be it.”
lead_paragraph: Good morning. “If I could have only 10 Korean dishes for the rest of my life, these would be it.” Eric Kim wrote this week in the Food section of The Times.

headline: Real estate companies lay off workers amid ‘clear signals’ of a housing downturn.
abstract: Redfin and Compass are letting employees go, citing a drop in home sales and rising mortgage rates.
lead_paragraph: The real estate brokerages Compass and Redfin are laying off employees, a sign that the housing market is cooling as higher interest rates make mortgages more expensive and rising inflation squeezes incomes.

headline: Ryanair Drops South African Passport Test After Protests
abstract: The Irish budget airline had imposed a test in Afrikaans, a language with a racist legacy and that many South Africans don’t speak, to weed out fake documents.
lead_paragraph: Ryanair has dropped a requirement that South African passport holders pass a test written in Afrikaans — a language with a racist legacy that many South Africans don’t speak — to prove their nationality before boarding certain flights after the policy was widely criticized as discriminatory and nonsensical.

headline: Buffalo Shooting Suspect Is Charged With Federal Hate Crimes
abstract: The Justice Department has charged the suspect with 26 counts of hate crimes and weapons violations, and could seek the death penalty for some charges.
lead_paragraph: The suspect in the Buffalo massacre that left 10 Black residents dead was charged on Wednesday with federal hate crimes and weapons violations, in a complaint that included new details about the depth of his racist hatred.

headline: Federal Reserve Takes Swing at Inflation With Largest Rate Increase Since 1994
abstract: Central bankers raised interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point, and signaled that they expect rates to be sharply higher by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve took its most aggressive step yet to try to tame rapid and persistent inflation, raising interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point on Wednesday and signaling that it is prepared to inflict economic pain to get prices under control.

headline: From Homeless to Home
abstract: I met Wendy Marcum last summer at The Beacon, a homeless shelter in downtown Houston. Wendy told me she was 56 years old and had been homeless for three years.  I asked for her number so we could stay in touch
lead_paragraph: I met Wendy Marcum last summer at The Beacon, a homeless shelter in downtown Houston. Wendy told me she was 56 years old and had been homeless for three years.  I asked for her number so we could stay in touch

headline: Yellowstone National Park Endures Record Flooding
abstract: Over 10,000 visitors have evacuated Yellowstone after heavy rains and severe flooding slammed the national park, destroying roads and threatening homes.
lead_paragraph: Over 10,000 visitors have evacuated Yellowstone after heavy rains and severe flooding slammed the national park, destroying roads and threatening homes.

headline: Saudi Arabia relaxes some Covid rules before the hajj.
abstract: Even as coronavirus cases rise steadily, the kingdom has announced the lifting of most Covid precautions as it prepares to receive roughly a million Muslim pilgrims.
lead_paragraph: Even as coronavirus cases rise steadily in Saudi Arabia, the kingdom has announced the lifting of most of its Covid precautions as it prepares to receive roughly a million pilgrims for the annual hajj season, the most since the start of the pandemic.

headline: Supreme Court Dismisses Bid by G.O.P.-Led States to Defend Trump Immigration Plan
abstract: The case concerned revisions to the “public charge” rule that made it harder for immigrants who had relied on public assistance to gain permanent legal status.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday dismissed an appeal from several states led by Republicans that had sought to step in to defend a Trump-era immigration policy that the Biden administration has abandoned.

headline: Where Did the Black Death Begin? DNA Detectives Find a Key Clue.
abstract: By fishing shards of bacterial DNA from the teeth of bodies in a cemetery, researchers found the starting point for the plague that devastated Eurasia, they say.
lead_paragraph: Where and when did the Black Death originate? The question has been asked for centuries and led to heated debate among historians.

headline: Abortions Increase in the U.S., Reversing a 30-Year Decline, Report Finds
abstract: A new survey of the nation’s abortion providers found increases in every region of the country from 2017 to 2020.
lead_paragraph: The number of abortions in the United States has increased, reversing what had been a three-decade decline, according to a new report.

headline: ‘Want to Play Some Chess?’
abstract: The sounds of a late-night game around New York City.
lead_paragraph: Chess can be a nearly silent game when two people are in the zone. Green felt quietly brushing against plastic or stone; perhaps a clock clicking back and forth as the time dwindles down.

headline: From the Wreckage of Caribbean Migration, a New Kind of Beauty
abstract: Four artists created stories of resilience from the traumatic histories of ancestors, on view at the Ford Foundation Gallery.
lead_paragraph: It was curiosity about his own family’s fraught history of migration, from India to Trinidad, that persuaded Andil Gosine, a curator, artist and professor, to begin thinking about ways to connect with other artists who shared his history.

headline: Parents Anxious to Vaccinate Young Children Describe an Agonizing Wait
abstract: Times readers with babies, toddlers or preschoolers who are unvaccinated against the coronavirus wrote in about worries and strains, loneliness and lost time.
lead_paragraph: Tyfanee Pratt’s son Julian was born in November 2019 in Burlington, N.J. Before long, Ms. Pratt was ready to introduce him to the world. But then, she wrote, “Covid-19 slammed the door on us — locked us in and hid away the key.”

headline: The Hands-Off Tech Era Is Over
abstract: More government intervention will slow tech down. Is that good or bad?
lead_paragraph: It’s clear more than ever that governments will no longer leave technology alone.

headline: Monkeypox Outbreak Poses ‘Real Risk’ to Public Health, W.H.O. Official Says
abstract: Dr. Hans Kluge, the organization’s director for Europe, said that the longer the virus circulated, the wider its reach would be.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The World Health Organization’s top official in Europe on Wednesday called for urgent action by the authorities and civic groups to control fast-rising cases of monkeypox that he said posed a real risk to public health.

headline: Flooding Chaos in Yellowstone, a Sign of Crises to Come
abstract: Record rainfall and mudslides forced closures just as tourism season ramped up. Virtually none of America’s national parks are untouched by extreme weather and climate change.
lead_paragraph: GARDINER, Mont. — Before evacuating their rental cabin on the edge of Yellowstone National Park, the Manning family watched a nearby house plunge from the riverbank into the raging, flood-swollen waters.

headline: The E.U. looks to tap gas from Egypt and Israel.
abstract: A new agreement could pave the way for more natural gas exports from these countries to reach Europe.
lead_paragraph: An agreement reached by the European Union, Israel and Egypt in Cairo on Wednesday could pave the way for more natural gas exports from these countries to reach Europe.

headline: Pregnancy Can Affect the Body Forever. Have Abortion Foes Reckoned With That?
abstract: Yes, if women are required to go through the ultimate stress test, their liberty is curtailed.
lead_paragraph: Lately, I’ve been thinking a lot about Alexandra of Denmark, Great Britain’s queen from 1901 to 1910. Called “Alix” by her loved ones, she was the wife of King Edward VII, the notoriously promiscuous son of Queen Victoria, called “the playboy prince” by the biographer Jane Ridley.

headline: Abortion Bans With Mental Health Exceptions
abstract: Readers discuss the role that psychiatrists may have in determining access to abortions. Also: Trump and Jan. 6; younger gunmen; mariachis in Uvalde.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Three-Peat in Sight, Tampa Bay May Face Its Toughest Test Yet
abstract: The two-time N.H.L. defending champion Lightning faced elimination in the first round and fell behind, 2-0, in the Eastern Conference finals. Still, a deep Colorado team may be their biggest obstacle.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The last minutes were ticking away for the Tampa Bay Lightning, along with the dream of hockey immortality. Winners of the last two Stanley Cups, the Lightning trailed the talented Toronto Maple Leafs by a goal late in the third period of a first-round elimination game last month.

headline: Duncan Hannah, Artist and ’70s Chronicler, Dies at 69
abstract: He immersed himself in the wild New York scene of Warhol and CBGB, then emerged in the ’80s as a respected painter.
lead_paragraph: Duncan Hannah, who immersed himself in the boisterous art-and-club scene of 1970s New York — vividly documenting it in a 2018 book drawn from diaries he kept — and then in the 1980s became a well-regarded artist himself, died on Saturday at his home in Cornwall, Conn. He was 69.

headline: Army Veteran Gets G.O.P. Nomination for a Hotly Contested Nevada House Seat
abstract: Mark Robertson’s message centered on protecting freedom of speech and pushing back against government mandates.
lead_paragraph: Mark Robertson, an Army veteran and business owner, has clinched the Republican nomination for a House seat in Nevada with a large campaign war chest and a message centered on protecting freedom of speech and pushing back against government mandates.

headline: 15 Father’s Day Recipes That Are No Joke
abstract: For the dad who has it all, make a meal he won’t soon forget.
lead_paragraph: This Father’s Day, skip the whiskey stones, the razor subscriptions, the graphic tees, mugs and ties in favor of a gift that won’t take up cabinet or closet space: a meal so delicious he won’t want to crack jokes between bites. Whether prepared with the help of the littlest assistants or the inevitable fatherly supervision (“Just checking in!”), he’s sure to feel celebrated.

headline: Israel Convicts Palestinian Aid Worker on Charges of Funding Hamas
abstract: Mohammad El Halabi was charged with funneling millions from a Christian charity to the militant group. The charity, World Vision, said there was no evidence to support that and the trial lacked transparency.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli court convicted a Palestinian aid worker on Wednesday of diverting funds from the charity he worked for to the Palestinian militant group Hamas in a case that spanned six years and drew criticism from rights groups, which said he had been denied a fair and transparent trial.

headline: The TikTok Star and Political Chameleon Vying for Colombia’s Presidency
abstract: Rodolfo Hernández bills himself as a paragon of democracy and a successful businessman who cares for the poor. A trip to Bucaramanga, the mountain-fringed city where he built his empire, reveals a different picture.
lead_paragraph: BUCARAMANGA, Colombia — As mayor, he called himself “the king,” punched a councilman who offended him and told a city employee pushing him to follow the rules that he’d wipe his own buttocks with the law.

headline: Combat Veteran Wins Nevada House Primary, Playing to Trump’s Base
abstract: Sam Peters, a retired Air Force major and Bronze Star recipient, will challenge the Democratic incumbent, Steven Horsford, in the Fourth District.
lead_paragraph: A decorated Air Force combat veteran who lined up support from the Trump wing of the Republican Party will face a Democratic incumbent in a tossup congressional race in Nevada.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Says Capitol Marcher Toured With G.O.P. Congressman
abstract: The committee released surveillance footage of a Capitol complex tour on Jan. 5 and video of a man it said was part of the tour marching toward the Capitol during the riot.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A man who toured the Capitol complex with a Republican lawmaker the day before the Jan. 6, 2021, attack later marched on the building while making threats against Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other prominent Democrats, the House committee investigating the attack said on Wednesday.

headline: Josh Jensen, Visionary Vintner of Pinot Noir, Is Dead at 78
abstract: His belief in limestone soils led him on a two-year quest for the ideal site for what became the Calera Wine Company: a remote mountain south of San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Josh Jensen, who, after a single-minded quest in the 1970s to find the perfect site in California to grow the pinot noir grape, became the first producer of consistently excellent American pinot noir through his Calera Wine Company, inspiring a new generation of West Coast winemakers, died on Saturday at his home in San Francisco. He was 78.

headline: Russia tightens gas supplies to Germany and Italy.
abstract: Germany says Gazprom aims to drive up fuel prices.
lead_paragraph: Gazprom, the Russian gas monopoly, said on Wednesday that it was further tightening natural gas supplies through a key pipeline to Germany. The company said flows through the pipeline, Nord Stream 1, would be cut by 60 percent, a day after announcing a 40 percent reduction.

headline: ‘The Old Man’ Review: Jeff Bridges Comes to TV and Goes on the Run
abstract: An American treasure, from “The Last Picture Show” to the Dude, plays an aging but still lethal operative in a moody thriller on FX.
lead_paragraph: With the advent of peak TV, and its bidding wars for talent, came a rush of film legends to smaller screens. Within the last decade, performers at the level of Al Pacino, Jane Fonda, Julia Roberts and Christopher Walken suddenly discovered that it wasn’t beneath their dignity to star in a regular old television series.

headline: ‘Good Luck to You, Leo Grande’ Review: Pleasure Principles
abstract: Emma Thompson and Daryl McCormack bring knowing vulnerability to this amusing story of a foxy prostitute and the woman who hires him.
lead_paragraph: If “Good Luck to You, Leo Grande” were a book, it might make a fine choice for a tipsy book club evening. And although the film about an older woman hiring a male prostitute feels ever so briefly like an updated tease of romance-novel fantasies, as directed by Sophie Hyde and written by Katy Brand, “Leo Grande” proves to be a tart and tender probe into sex and intimacy, power dynamics and human connection.

headline: Inside a Corporate Culture War Stoked by a Crypto C.E.O.
abstract: Jesse Powell, who leads the crypto exchange Kraken, has challenged the use of preferred pronouns, debated who can use racial slurs and called American women “brainwashed.”
lead_paragraph: Jesse Powell, a founder and the chief executive of Kraken, one of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchanges, recently asked his employees, “If you can identify as a sex, can you identify as a race or ethnicity?”

headline: Ballet Theater Returns to the Met With a Gimmicky ‘Don Quixote’
abstract: American Ballet Theater opens its summer season at the Metropolitan Opera House with a triple cast, comic production. Where will it go next?
lead_paragraph: Two years of canceled seasons should have been ample time to hatch a comeback plan. So why did American Ballet Theater return to the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday with so little imagination? In honor of its first opening night at the Met since 2019, the company dusted the cobwebs off a war horse, the three-act ballet “Don Quixote.” But still, dust remained.

headline: F.D.A. advisers recommend authorizing Moderna’s vaccine for children 6 to 17.
abstract: An expert committee advising the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously on Tuesday to recommend Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine for use in children and adolescents ages 6 to 17. The vote was an important step toward an emergency use authorization.
lead_paragraph: An expert committee advising the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously on Tuesday to recommend Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine for use in children and adolescents ages 6 to 17. The vote was an important step toward an emergency use authorization.

headline: The battle for Mariupol came down to a single factory. Will Sievierodonetsk go the same way?
abstract: The United Nations says that hundreds of civilians are trapped with besieged Ukrainian forces at a chemical plant and “are suffering and experiencing constant shelling and bombardment.”
lead_paragraph: In the end, the battle for the Ukrainian city of Mariupol came down to a showdown over a single big industrial plant. Now, it looks like the fight over Sievierodonetsk in Ukraine’s east might go the same way.

headline: Photos of Flooding Damage in Yellowstone
abstract: Flooding and mudslides from recent storms have collapsed bridges and washed away roads in the national park.
lead_paragraph: Yellowstone National Park employees led 10,000 visitors to safety this week as storms washed away roads and bridges, while nearby residents escaped as their homes were battered by mudslides and flooding brought on by record rainfall and melting snow.

headline: Why Dogs Can Be So Healing for Kids
abstract: A new study suggests that spending time with therapy dogs may help lower children’s stress levels even more than relaxation exercises.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Review: Exploring Plato and Online Dating, Gibney Dancers Give Their All
abstract: Gibney Company presents “Up Close, a program of boundary-teasing works by three choreographers.
lead_paragraph: From the first moments of the Gibney Company’s “Up Close” program, at New York Live Arts, the troupe’s superpower is clear: its strong and versatile dancers, artists who appear to be physically capable of anything. Since reinventing itself last year — with a shift toward presenting commissioned works by a variety of choreographers, rather than those of its founder and artistic director, Gina Gibney — the company has seemed to both fill a gap and replicate more of the same in American contemporary dance.

headline: Emma Thompson and the Challenge of Baring All Onscreen at 63
abstract: The actress made the choice to disrobe. Still, she says, it was the most difficult thing she’s ever done in her four-decade career.
lead_paragraph: It’s the shock of white hair you notice first on Emma Thompson, a hue far more chic than anything your average 63-year-old would dare choose but one that doesn’t ignore her age either. It’s accompanied by that big, wide smile and that knowing look, suggesting both a wry wit and a willingness to banter.

headline: What if We Had Spent the Money on Climate?
abstract: Along with everything else, the pandemic was a huge missed opportunity.
lead_paragraph: When the inflation crisis really arrived last fall, most Americans hoped it would be a passing one — perhaps so “transitory,” some liberals expected, that even if it caused some temporary pain, it need not interfere with anyone’s policy ambitions or basic view of the political moment. As recently as a few weeks ago, many economists believed that the price spikes had peaked, and the country might already be downsloping back to something like normal.

headline: The LIV Golf Controversy Raises Critical Antitrust Questions
abstract: When is restraint of trade a good thing?
lead_paragraph: Neither antagonist in the fight over golf’s newest league arouses much sympathy. On one side there’s LIV Golf, which is lavishly financed by the sovereign wealth fund of Saudi Arabia, a nation with an execrable record on human rights. On the other there’s the PGA Tour, which is fighting hard to keep its golfers from earning bigger paychecks with LIV Golf, suspending 17 of them for taking part in the LIV Golf Invitational Series. It’s tempting to wish a plague on both their clubhouses.

headline: Who Is Financing Trump’s ‘Big Lie’ Caucus? Corporations You Know.
abstract: The flow of corporate money to politicians who voted to overturn the 2020 election is helping fund a continuing attack on our democracy.
lead_paragraph: Immediately after the Jan. 6 attack, hundreds of corporations announced freezes on donating money to Republican lawmakers who had voted against certifying Joe Biden’s victory. “Given recent events and the horrific attack on the U.S. Capitol, we are assessing our future PAC criteria,” a spokesperson for Toyota said a week after the attack.

headline: Review: In ‘Queen,’ the Numbers Don’t Always Add Up
abstract: Two ambitious scientists are concerned with honey bees in this heady and data-heavy new play, a production of the National Asian American Theater Company.
lead_paragraph: Math is a tool to make sense of the way things work. A minuscule discrepancy becomes the catalyst for a crisis in “Queen,” a heady and data-heavy new play by Madhuri Shekar that opened on Tuesday night at the A.R.T./New York Mezzanine Theater. A hair’s breadth deviation upends not just the outcome of a yearslong study, but how a team of scientists conceive of themselves and life’s purpose.

headline: Investors Deserve to Know the Climate Risks Their Assets Face
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is pushing for more openness by corporations.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Pacific Gas and Electric estimated that the rise in wildfires, partly driven by climate change, could cost the company $2.5 billion in payouts for recent fires started by its electricity transmission lines and other operations north of San Francisco, and as much as $15 billion in the future.

headline: Toiling to Complete a Gun Bill, Two Parties Part Ways on Its Reach
abstract: Democrats are praising a bipartisan agreement on guns as sweeping and significant while Republicans point to its limits, a sign of the political divide standing in the way of a final deal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the first bipartisan agreement on gun safety measures in years takes shape on Capitol Hill, Republicans and Democrats are laboring to keep their compromise on track by sending disparate messages about its scope and implications.

headline: Why Does a Hard Workout Make You Less Hungry?
abstract: In a study done with mice, horses and people, researchers found clues as to which types of exercise suppress appetite and why.
lead_paragraph: Why are we so peckish after some workouts but uninterested in eating after others?

headline: For Cuban Stars, the World Baseball Classic Remains a Dream
abstract: Banned from representing their former country, a breakaway group of Cuban major leaguers is pushing to form its own team. Meet the Cubanos.
lead_paragraph: Every few years, the same feeling of longing returns for Yuli Gurriel and Aledmys Díaz.

headline: Dr. Anthony Fauci Tests Positive for Coronavirus
abstract: The director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the face of the U.S. pandemic response, Dr. Fauci had mild symptoms after testing positive on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Maybe it was only a matter of time.

headline: Internet Explorer Is Shutting Down in a Burst of Nostalgia
abstract: Microsoft will be disabling IE and directing Windows users to its modern Edge web browser in coming months. The news inspired jokes, memes and even some fond memories.
lead_paragraph: It was Aug. 16, 1995. “Waterfalls” by TLC was the No. 1 song in the country. Bill Clinton was in the White House. And Microsoft introduced a new way to surf the web: Internet Explorer.

headline: A Younger Man
abstract: She had a clear vision for the next phase of her life. Dating across an age gap was not part of the plan.
lead_paragraph: Heather von Rohr had moved to Los Angeles with aspirations: to make it as a screenwriter and to fall in love, marry and have a child. In need of a day job, she took an entry-level position at the research library of a prestigious film academy.

headline: With Northern Ireland and Migrants, Johnson Swings Cudgel of Survival Politics
abstract: Critics say the British leader’s hardened stances on Northern Ireland and immigration are cynical pandering to the pro-Brexit Tories he needs to stay in power.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Prime Minister Boris Johnson survived a potentially lethal challenge to his leadership last week, he said he wanted to pull politics in Britain back to “the issues I think the people in this country want to talk about.”

headline: What the Fed’s rate increase means for mortgages.
abstract: Rates on 30-year fixed mortgages track the yield on 10-year Treasury bonds, which are influenced by inflation and the Fed’s actions, among other things.
lead_paragraph: What does the Fed’s decision to raise its key interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point mean for mortgages? [Here’s what the Fed’s decision means for credit cards, car loans and student loans.]

headline: What the Fed’s rate increase means for credit cards, car loans and student loans.
abstract: Consumers can expect to pay more for some of life’s most common kinds of borrowing.
lead_paragraph: The Fed’s decision to raise its key interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point is good news for savers, but less so for borrowers: They can expect to pay more on credit card debt, car loans and certain student loans. [Here’s what the Fed’s decision means for mortgages.]

headline: A Rapper’s Delight: Hip-Hop Memorabilia Goes Up for Auction
abstract: Original vinyl records, turntables and other ephemera belonging to the hip-hop pioneer D.J. Kool Herc will be included in a sale at Christie’s.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, D.J. Kool Herc and his sister Cindy Campbell were famous for throwing parties in the rec room of their Bronx high-rise at 1520 Sedgwick Avenue, which became known as the “birthplace of hip-hop.”

headline: Lavish Money Laundering Schemes Exposed in Canada
abstract: Government officials in the province of British Columbia were aware that suspicious money was entering their revenue stream, but took insufficient steps to stop it.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER — Self-professed students were buying multimillion-dollar homes in the Vancouver area, with dubious sources of income, or none at all.

headline: Man Confesses to Killing Journalist and Activist and Leads Police to Remains, Police Say
abstract: Dom Phillips, a freelance reporter for The Guardian, and Bruno Araújo Pereira, a Brazilian expert on Indigenous peoples, had been missing in the Amazon since June 5.
lead_paragraph: TABATINGA, Brazil — A fisherman confessed to killing a British journalist and a Brazilian expert on Indigenous peoples deep in the Amazon and then showed authorities where he had hid their bodies, the Brazilian federal police said Wednesday. It was a grim breakthrough in the 10-day search for the missing men that has transfixed Brazil and provoked international outrage.

headline: U.S. and Allies Pledge Additional Arms for Ukraine, but Kyiv Wants More
abstract: Some NATO countries are wary of sending heavy weapons, hoping for a negotiated truce, but the alliance insists publicly that it is committed to helping Ukraine defeat Russia.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — President Biden on Wednesday announced a further $1 billion in weapons and aid for Ukraine, as the United States and its allies met to craft a response to Ukraine’s increasingly urgent calls for advanced arms to beat back Russia’s invasion.

headline: At the U.S. Open, Two Friends Look to Channel Francis Ouimet
abstract: In 1913, Ouimet, a Massachusetts native and 20-year-old amateur, won the U.S. Open at the Country Club. Michael Thorbjornsen will try to make a run this year, with his longtime friend as his caddie.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — The golf ball was buried in a bunker behind the green, and Drew Cohen thought to himself: “He’s in jail. He’s going to need to pull off the bunker shot of his life.”

headline: Shauneille Perry Ryder, Pioneering Theater Director, Dies at 92
abstract: As a Black woman, she blazed a path Off Broadway with an intuitive grasp of “how a story should be told, particularly a Black story,” Giancarlo Esposito said.
lead_paragraph: Shauneille Perry Ryder, an actress, playwright and educator who was one of the first Black women to direct plays Off Broadway, most notably for the New Federal Theater, died on June 9 at her home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 92.

headline: Another $1 Billion in Weapons
abstract: The U.S. will give Ukraine more artillery, anti-ship missile launchers and ammunition.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: $1 Billion to Ukraine
abstract: Plus the Fed raised interest rates and a video of an assault in China went viral.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said the U.S. would send another $1 billion in equipment and arms to Ukraine. Several other NATO allies also pledged more military help, including ammunition, long-range artillery rocket systems and helicopters.

headline: A brutal urban artillery battle sends civilians running in eastern Ukraine.
