lead_paragraph: BASEL, Switzerland — War is raging in Ukraine. Stocks are down 20 percent; inflation is up more than 8 percent. The crypto economy is collapsing.

headline: An Underappreciated Burgundy Wine Region Is Upward Bound
abstract: Savigny-lès-Beaune has long been dismissed, but longtime producers and an energetic newer generation are leading a quality revolution.
lead_paragraph: SAVIGNY-LÈS-BEAUNE, France — The soaring demand and high regard for Burgundy around the world means that little of the Côte d’Or, the region’s heart, has been left unturned. But if an off-the-beaten-trail source for relative bargains still exists, it would be this well-known but little-understood village.

headline: Review: Watching Paul Taylor’s Road Not Taken (and Lessons Learned)
abstract: Programs at the Joyce Theater feature early works that show how Taylor integrated the radical and the popular.
lead_paragraph: It might have been the most consequential move that the choreographer Paul Taylor ever made. Considered early on to be a possible heir to Martha Graham, the modern dance pioneer in whose company he performed, he was also seen — appropriately, if paradoxically, for a modernist heir — as a rebel. His rebellious move in 1962, more contrarian than calculated, was to make a dance to the not-modern, easy-on-the-ear music of Handel, a dance so light and lyrical it was almost a ballet.

headline: How to watch the World Cup host city announcement.
abstract: The program to choose the host cities for soccer’s 2026 World Cup will begin Thursday at 5 p.m., Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: The program to choose the host cities for soccer’s 2026 World Cup will begin Thursday at 5 p.m., Eastern time.

headline: ‘The Old Man’ Brought Jeff Bridges to TV. John Lithgow Had No Advice.
abstract: The two award-winning actors had never worked together before this brooding FX thriller came along. Who knew the journey would become so existential?
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — It’s a pretty safe bet that any show called “The Old Man” that opens with a scene about frequent urination is going to have a few things to say about mortality — as indeed it does. (Yes, it’s a thriller; don’t worry, it gets more exciting.)

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Diva’ and More
abstract: I’m a deputy editor on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a deputy editor on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: As European Leaders Visit Kyiv, Putin Cuts Their Gas Supply
abstract: At a critical moment in the war, Russia is strategically reducing gas flows to drive up prices and hurt European economies already reeling from high inflation.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As the leaders of Europe’s three biggest economies appeared in Kyiv on Thursday to send a message of support to Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had his own message for them: Don’t forget, your industries are at my mercy.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: A wake-and-bake comedy returns to Showtime, and a sumptuous new drama set on the Italian Riviera comes to PBS.
lead_paragraph: ‘Flatbush Misdemeanors’When to watch: Sunday at 11 p.m., on Showtime.

headline: How Houston Is Fixing Homelessness
abstract: Homelessness bundles together so many problems: a broken mental health system, racial inequity, the affordable housing crisis. The headlines can be overwhelming. Last year I started talking with experts. They had a different view. They told me about Houston.
lead_paragraph: Homelessness bundles together so many problems: a broken mental health system, racial inequity, the affordable housing crisis. The headlines can be overwhelming. Last year I started talking with experts. They had a different view. They told me about Houston.

headline: On the edge of embattled twin cities, an uncovered mass grave for civilians grows.
abstract: As Russia solidifies control in Sievierodonetsk and shifts its focus to neighboring Lysychansk, civilian casualties there continue to mount.
lead_paragraph: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — A mass grave on the edge of this eastern Ukrainian city remains uncovered. Dirt mounds and yellow-petaled weeds surround a pit filled with a dozen or so body bags. They reek of death in the warm summer wind.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: European Leaders Travel to Ukraine
abstract: Also, China rewrites Hong Kong’s history textbooks and a Trumpian candidate emerges in Colombia.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of France, Italy, Germany and Romania met with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Thursday in Kyiv, where they expressed support for making Ukraine a candidate for E.U. membership and said they would continue to back Ukraine’s military efforts, despite suggestions to the contrary.

headline: European Leaders Offer Support
abstract: In Kyiv, the leaders of France, Germany and Italy backed Ukraine’s E.U. candidacy.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: There’s a character in Adam White’s debut novel, “The Midcoast,” who at one point starts to chafe against her small-town circumstances and decides to do something about it. “She went to the library,” White writes, “and started checking out every kind of book — romance novels, spy novels, biographies, memoirs, history books, cookbooks — anything in print.” That’s my kind of character, I thought when I reached that passage, and if it’s your kind of character too then you could do worse than adding “The Midcoast” (think “Ozark” meets “The Great Gatsby” in Maine) to your reading list this week.

headline: BuzzFeed News names a new editor in chief.
abstract: Karolina Waclawiak, its executive editor of culture, takes over the newsroom at a difficult moment for the digital media company.
lead_paragraph: BuzzFeed News announced on Thursday that Karolina Waclawiak, its executive editor of culture, would become the next top editor.

headline: Ripley’s Denies Any Damage to Marilyn Monroe Dress
abstract: Ripley’s Believe It or Not! said the garment was already fraying before Kim Kardashian wore it to the Met Gala. And everything else you need to know about the continuing drama.
lead_paragraph: The long-running saga otherwise known as “Much ado around Kim Kardashian’s decision to borrow Marilyn Monroe’s ‘Happy Birthday, Mr. President’ dress for her Met Gala entrance” continues, more than six weeks after the event itself.

headline: Europe Offers Ukraine a Hope of Joining the E.U., but Not a Vast Arsenal
abstract: In their first wartime visit to Kyiv, the leaders of France and Germany countered doubts about their commitment to Ukraine defeating Russia, but did not promise the weapons Ukrainians have called for.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — European leaders on Thursday pledged support for putting Ukraine on a path to membership in the European Union but did not promise the country additional heavy weapons on the scale it says it needs to repel a bloody Russian advance in the east.

headline: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver misses Game 6 of the finals after testing positive.
abstract: If Golden State wins the N.B.A. championship on Thursday, the league’s commissioner, Adam Silver, will not be there to hand over the trophy. Silver is missing his second straight game because of the league’s coronavirus health and safety protocols.
lead_paragraph: If Golden State wins the N.B.A. championship on Thursday, the league’s commissioner, Adam Silver, will not be there to hand over the trophy. Silver is missing his second straight game because of the league’s coronavirus health and safety protocols.

headline: Dorothy E. Smith, Groundbreaker in Feminist Sociology, Dies at 95
abstract: Starting in the 1960s, she sought to re-center her discipline on the experiences of women, people of color and other marginalized groups.
lead_paragraph: Dorothy E. Smith, a feminist scholar and sociologist whose extensive criticism of her own field led her to establish groundbreaking theories and sub-disciplines that pushed sociology away from its foundations as a male-dominated, male-centered endeavor, died on June 3 at her home in Vancouver, British Columbia. She was 95.

headline: The State Department says a third American fighter may be missing in Ukraine.
abstract: A State Department spokesman did not provide specifics. Earlier reports that two U.S. veterans had been captured by Russian forces remain unconfirmed.
lead_paragraph: A third American who traveled to Ukraine to fight Russia’s invasion may be missing in action, the State Department said on Thursday, a day after the families of two U.S. veterans fighting in Ukraine said the two men had disappeared together as their platoon came under fire this month.

headline: Tell Us the Story of Your Family Heirloom
abstract: Add your voice to a new project examining items that tell stories of history, culture and race in America.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times is interested in documenting the stories of family heirlooms from all cultures and backgrounds across the United States. These heirlooms do not need to possess extraordinary monetary value — in fact, everyday items with emotional resonance are of particular interest — but these items, and their stories, should represent something special to you and your family.

headline: Ex-Ranger Sean Avery Convicted of Ramming Minivan With Scooter
abstract: The player, who was noted for his pesky methods on the ice, stood trial after an altercation with a family on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Sean Avery was on the witness stand defending himself Thursday when he said he wasn’t sure he was in the wrong during an encounter that ended with his electric scooter lodged in the minivan of a Manhattan family.

headline: Synagogue Sues Florida, Saying Abortion Restrictions Violate Religious Freedoms
abstract: A South Florida congregation said that under Jewish law, abortion “is required if necessary to protect the health, mental or physical well-being” of a pregnant woman.
lead_paragraph: Religion, particularly the influence of Christian conservatives, has been at the heart of the anti-abortion movement and the push to overturn Roe v. Wade, the 1973 ruling legalizing abortion throughout the United States.

headline: Sotomayor Says Supreme Court Can ‘Regain the Public’s Confidence’
abstract: Speaking to a liberal legal group, she praised Justice Clarence Thomas and urged her audience not to lose faith in the court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Sonia Sotomayor urged an audience of progressive lawyers on Thursday not to give up on the Supreme Court.

headline: Forty-nine states preordered vaccine doses for very young children. Florida did not.
abstract: It was not immediately clear how much the State Health Department’s decision not to take part in distributing the pediatric shots would impede access to them in Florida in the coming days.
lead_paragraph: Florida did not preorder any doses of coronavirus vaccines for very young children from the federal government, state officials said Thursday, arguing that the state had no need to be involved in what they called a “convoluted vaccine distribution process.”

headline: Yes, May Was Definitely Hot
abstract: In May, temperatures in the United States were 1.7 degrees above normal with triple digit temperatures in some parts.
lead_paragraph: In May, temperatures in the United States were 1.7 degrees above normal with triple digit temperatures in some parts.

headline: Russia’s bank chief calls for economic ‘perestroika,’ away from raw exports.
abstract: The governor of Russia’s Central Bank, credited with steering the economy and the Russian ruble through the early, turbulent months of stringent international sanctions, called on Thursday for the country to end its dependence on exporting raw materials such as oil and gas for income.
lead_paragraph: The governor of Russia’s Central Bank, credited with steering the economy and the Russian ruble through the early, turbulent months of stringent international sanctions, called on Thursday for the country to end its dependence on exporting raw materials such as oil and gas for income.

headline: Trial of New Alzheimer’s Drug Reports Disappointing Results
abstract: The drug, crenezumab, failed to prevent early symptoms or slow cognitive decline, the latest setback in the long quest to find effective therapies for the disease.
lead_paragraph: A closely watched clinical trial of a potential Alzheimer’s drug failed to prevent or slow cognitive decline, another disappointment in the long and challenging effort to find solutions for the disease.

headline: A Businessman Is Acquitted in a Georgetown Admissions Trial
abstract: Amin Khoury was accused of giving $180,000 in cash to a tennis coach. The not-guilty verdict comes after a string of guilty pleas and convictions.
lead_paragraph: A wealthy businessman accused of bribing his daughter’s way into Georgetown University as a tennis player was acquitted on all counts Thursday by a federal jury in Boston, the first not-guilty verdict related to the government’s Varsity Blues investigation into corrupt college admissions.

headline: France and Germany Stand With Ukraine, and Putin Can Wait
abstract: Seeking to overcome tensions with Kyiv, President Emmanuel Macron of France and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany backed away from Moscow diplomacy, at least for now.
lead_paragraph: ODESA, Ukraine — It was late in the day, almost four months after Russia’s unprovoked invasion of Ukraine, but when the leaders of the European Union’s three largest nations at last journeyed to Kyiv, their intent was clear: to dispel any doubt that they would waver in backing Ukraine’s quest for sovereignty, territorial integrity, freedom and membership in what Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany called “the European family.”

headline: Fears Grow Over Iran’s Nuclear Program as Tehran Digs a New Tunnel Network
abstract: The conflict over the program is about to flare again as President Biden travels next month to Israel and Saudi Arabia, Iran’s two biggest regional rivals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Israeli and American intelligence officials have been watching each day as Iran digs a vast tunnel network just south of the Natanz nuclear production site, in what they believe is Tehran’s biggest effort yet to construct new nuclear facilities so deep in the mountains that they can withstand bunker-busting bombs and cyberattacks.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Recession Would Hurt Democrats. Some Warn It’d Also Hurt Democracy.
abstract: By trying to tame inflation, some commentators say, the Federal Reserve could bring about a recession — just as an unrepentant Donald Trump appears to be eyeing another White House bid.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Powell, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, made the understatement of the year on Wednesday when he noted offhandedly to reporters, “Clearly, people do not like inflation.”

headline: What Is Golf’s Problem? Sellout Culture.
abstract: The Bone Saw Tour is a symptom of broader corruption.
lead_paragraph: Even if you don’t play or follow golf — which I don’t — you’re probably aware of the controversy now engulfing the game. A number of the world’s top-ranked pro players, notably Phil Mickelson, made extremely lucrative deals to play in a new tour, the LIV Golf International Series, sponsored by Saudi Arabia. The PGA Tour, which has traditionally dominated the sport, responded by suspending 17 of these players.

headline: Nydia Velázquez endorses city councilwoman in New York House race, bypassing a House colleague
abstract: Ms. Velázquez is backing Carlina Rivera, a Manhattan councilwoman, for an open seat that is also being sought by Representative Mondaire Jones and Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: The Aug. 23 Democratic primary for an open House seat in New York City has attracted a who’s who of hopefuls, including a current congressman, a former congresswoman, a former two-term mayor and a handful of state lawmakers.

headline: Here’s what that ‘Ayesha Curry CAN cook’ T-shirt is all about.
abstract: Golden State’s Stephen Curry wore a T-shirt at Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals defending the culinary skills of his wife, Ayesha. It has to do with beef and Boston.
lead_paragraph: After Game 5, Stephen Curry walked into his postgame news conference wearing a gray T-shirt that said “Ayesha Curry CAN cook.”

headline: Phil Tippett’s World in (Stop) Motion
abstract: The animator and visual effects artist, whose credits include “Jurassic Park” and “The Empire Strikes Back,” has directed his passion project, “Mad God.”
lead_paragraph: A maverick of stop-motion animation and a restless Renaissance man, Phil Tippett is the visual effects alchemist responsible for emblematic sequences in some of the most popular American film productions of the 1980s and ’90s.

headline: Homeland Security Department Will Make Changes to Its Disciplinary Process
abstract: The announcement comes as Congress investigates the removal of damaging findings from reports on domestic violence and sexual misconduct by department employees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Homeland Security announced on Thursday that it would overhaul the disciplinary process for its employees after The New York Times reported that the agency’s inspector general removed damaging findings from investigative reports about domestic violence and sexual misconduct committed by employees.

headline: Yellowstone Towns Had Big Summer Plans Until Floods Struck
abstract: The deluge of rain has shut down a park entrance that is a lifeline for neighboring tourist communities. “Seventy-five percent of my business has been cut off at the knees,” one shop owner said.
lead_paragraph: GARDINER, Mont. — The ominous gray clouds have vanished after deluging Yellowstone National Park with floodwaters over the weekend, leaving sunshine and blue skies as the park’s eponymous river and its tributaries recede. The weather would have been perfect for the tens of thousands of tourists who normally kick off their summer vacations this week in the country’s oldest national park.

headline: YouTube deleted a Jan. 6 committee video that included Trump’s election lies.
abstract: The clip included some of former Attorney General William P. Barr’s recorded testimony, but also footage of former President Trump speaking on the Fox Business channel.
lead_paragraph: The House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 riot has been trying to draw more eyes to its televised hearings by uploading clips of the proceedings online. But YouTube has removed one of those videos from its platform, saying the committee was advancing election misinformation.

headline: For Mike Pence, Jan. 6 Began Like Many Days. It Ended Like No Other.
abstract: An angry mob chanting “hang Mike Pence” came within 40 feet of the vice president. He spent nearly five hours in an underground loading dock. And the president called him a “wimp” and worse.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He started the day with a prayer.

headline: At U.S. Open, Betrayal, Greed, a LIV Golf Star and, Above All, Decorum
abstract: PGA Tour loyalists golfed alongside tour defectors for the first time, and for Phil Mickelson, LIV Golf’s highest-paid star, it was business as usual down to his score.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — Historic moments are common at the U.S. Open, which is to be expected for a championship first held in 1895. But Thursday, in the opening round of the 122nd playing of the event, there was a notable first that would have been unthinkable even a month ago.

headline: The U.S. announces a 3-year agriculture partnership with Ukraine to address the food crisis.
abstract: The U.S. secretary of agriculture on Thursday announced at the United Nations a three-year agriculture partnership between the United States and Ukraine to address global food insecurity, which has been exacerbated by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. secretary of agriculture on Thursday announced at the United Nations a three-year agriculture partnership between the United States and Ukraine to address global food insecurity, which has been exacerbated by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Review: In High-Tech ‘Orchard,’ It’s Hard to See the Forest for the Trees
abstract: Jessica Hecht, Mikhail Baryshnikov and Chekhov himself too often get overwhelmed by this ambitious Arlekin Players Theater adaptation.
lead_paragraph: A black-clad figure shuffles a curving path through the cherry blossom petals carpeting the ground. Ancient, dignified, slightly stooped, he is searching for his cane in this strange and beautiful landscape where almost everything, including the cherry blossoms, is a shade of swimming-pool blue.

headline: How a Globetrotting Family Learned to Love Soccer and the ‘Grey Wiggle’
abstract: Over many years and locations, we had come to almost worship the World Cup, something that let us bond with almost anyone, anywhere.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — I woke up early Tuesday morning, figuring that the World Cup qualifier in Qatar between Australia and Peru would already be over — but no. It was still scoreless after extra time.

headline: Hochul Spars With Rivals Over Crime, Credentials and Cream Cheese
abstract: Sharp attacks typified the final debate among Gov. Kathy Hochul and her two Democratic rivals, Jumaane Williams and Representative Tom Suozzi.
lead_paragraph: In the second and final debate in the Democratic primary race for governor of New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul and her two opponents tangled over highly volatile issues, including rising crime, dwindling affordable housing, looming environmental catastrophe — and how they take their bagel.

headline: Spread Some Dirt
abstract: Pao Roy returns with a wonderfully lively themeless crossword puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Pao Roy, who uses they/them pronouns, they were getting down, so to speak, by making arrows out of the letters I and V. This is Mx. Roy’s third crossword puzzle in The New York Times and their first themeless. In short order, Mx. Roy has become a constructor whose byline I look forward to seeing because it’s obvious how much they care about what they create.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon’s tricky puzzle will help you work up an appetite.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — It’s Father’s Day in the United States, and knowing this will help you a tiny bit if you’re still stumped by this acrostic. (I just gave you exactly one word in the passage — barely a hint.) I dived in with vigor and four incorrect answers, which almost merited starting over and made for a meandering path to completion.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the Last Democratic Debate for New York Governor
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul touted her record and beat back criticism from her rivals during their second and final debate ahead of the June 28 primary.
lead_paragraph: The stakes in Thursday’s Democratic debate for governor of New York State were relatively low for Gov. Kathy Hochul, the race’s front-runner. She had to withstand an onslaught of attacks from her rival candidates, while making no major errors. She appeared to achieve those modest aims.

headline: Shooting at Alabama Church Potluck Leaves Three Dead
abstract: The gunfire ended after a parishioner subdued a man who opened fire inside an Episcopal church, the police said. Capital murder warrants were issued on Friday for the man, Robert Findlay Smith.
lead_paragraph: What started out as a relaxing potluck dinner at an Episcopal church in Alabama on Thursday evening took a sudden and deadly turn when a man pulled out a handgun and opened fire, killing three people, the authorities said.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: European leaders visit Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of France, Italy, Germany and Romania met with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Thursday in Kyiv, where they pledged support for putting Ukraine on a path to membership in the E.U. and said they would continue to back Ukraine’s military efforts, despite suggestions to the contrary.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Says Trump Pressured Pence to Overturn Election Results
abstract: President Donald J. Trump continued his pressure campaign, even after he was told it was illegal, to get former Vice President Mike Pence to reject the Electoral College results.
lead_paragraph: President Donald J. Trump continued his pressure campaign, even after he was told it was illegal, to get former Vice President Mike Pence to reject the Electoral College results.

headline: Golden State Beats Boston Celtics to Win N.B.A. Championship
abstract: It’s the fourth championship in eight seasons for Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson and Draymond Green.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It turns out the dynasty had just been paused.

headline: Bowling Green Fraternity Brothers Sentenced in Hazing Death of Student
abstract: Three men convicted in connection with the death of Stone Foltz, 20, received jail sentences of up to 28 days. Two others were sentenced to probation.
lead_paragraph: Five men convicted on charges relating to the March 2021 hazing death of a 20-year-old Bowling Green State University student were sentenced in Ohio on Thursday, with three of them receiving jail sentences of up to 28 days.

headline: Willing to Run Errands in Pursuit of Romance
abstract: When Dean Dafis got up the courage to ask George Forbes out after their workout class, Mr. Forbes declined, saying he had errands to run. Mr. Dafis didn’t want to take no for an answer.
lead_paragraph: By the time that Konstantinos Dean Dafis introduced himself to George Symmonds Forbes in November 2010, it seemed to Mr. Dafis like he was running into Mr. Forbes almost every weekend.

headline: A Texting Lifeline During a Difficult Time
abstract: As her father struggled with cancer, a flirtation provided distraction — and then something more.
lead_paragraph: I chose my college based on the vibes of the people in the school’s accepted students Facebook group. This one blond boy commented on my introduction post saying he also liked a favorite artist of mine, and my friend told me that was proof enough — if there’s one, there’s bound to be more.

headline: For Two Foodies, ‘Love at First Bite’
abstract: Kung-Gene Chu knew he had found someone special in Paige Rechtman while watching her devour dumplings on their first date.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Paige Rechtman made her way to Kung-Gene Chu’s heart not through his stomach, but through hers.

headline: Falling for Each Other, Then a First Date
abstract: Julie Hagenbuch and Eddy López Noguera enjoyed spending time together, but they shied away from anything romantic — until they couldn’t.
lead_paragraph: Though Julie Louisa Hagenbuch and Eddy Arturo López Noguera developed a friendship not long after meeting in September 2016, it would take 11 months for them to consider one of their outings as an actual date. And by that point, both say they had already started to fall in love.

headline: Catching His Eye on the (Ecstatic) Dance Floor
abstract: After several dates, Sanjay Amin drove 15 hours to quarantine with Rachael Cruthirds in Portland, Ore. They have barely been apart since.
lead_paragraph: When Sanjay Aakash Amin told his therapist that, one year after breaking off an engagement, he still had reservations about meeting people in bars or on apps, she suggested he attend an ecstatic dance party.

headline: A Cheesy Romance From the Start
abstract: Elizabeth Moroney and Jeremy Blaustein met at Formaggio Kitchen, a Massachusetts cheese shop where both have been working for the past several years.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Rose Moroney met Jeremy Carl Blaustein on her first day of work at Formaggio Kitchen, a cheese shop in Cambridge, Mass. Both were cashiers behind the bread counter.

headline: At the Union of Activists, a Cause for Celebration
abstract: Emily Mayer and Waleed Shahid, who met in college, deepened their love as each inspired the other to promote change in their communities.
lead_paragraph: Emily Ann Frank Mayer was wearing a red cardigan with a sizable hole in the armpit when she caught Waleed Shahid’s eye while reciting a poem during an open mic night at Haverford College in September 2010.

headline: The New Geography of the Russian Elite
abstract: European cities were playgrounds for Russia’s superwealthy. But sanctions have closed off much of the world.
lead_paragraph: European cities were playgrounds for Russia’s superwealthy. But sanctions have closed off much of the world.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Sotomayor Says the Court Can ‘Regain’ the Public’s Confidence
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 17, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Justice Thomas believes that every person can pull themselves up by their bootstraps. I believe that some people can’t get to their bootstraps without help.”

headline: Corrections: June 17, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, June 17, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about flooding in Yellowstone National Park and climate change’s expected impact on U.S. national parks misstated where 1.3 million Joshua trees were destroyed by a wildfire in 2020. The tree deaths occurred in the nearby Mojave National Preserve, not in Joshua Tree National Park.

headline: BTS Ponders Its Future, and South Korea’s Economy Warily Takes Note
abstract: The band’s label saw its stock price plunge, and the possibility that the K-pop group won’t tour as pandemic restrictions ease threatens to reverberate through South Korea’s economy.
lead_paragraph: The fallout from BTS’s announcement on Tuesday that the K-pop juggernaut will be taking a break as members explore solo careers was immediate and drastic.

headline: Democratic Candidates for Governor Bicker in Debate
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul faced barbs from her rivals, Representative Tom Suozzi and Jumaane Williams, the public advocate.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at last night’s fractious debate among the three candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for governor. We’ll also discover a large-scale musical work that was cut off during a long-ago radio broadcast. It will be performed tonight in anticipation of Juneteenth.

headline: SpaceX Said to Fire Employees Involved in Letter Rebuking Elon Musk
abstract: In an email, Gwynne Shotwell, SpaceX’s president, said the letter had made other employees “feel uncomfortable, intimidated and bullied.”
lead_paragraph: SpaceX, the private rocket company, on Thursday fired employees who helped write and distribute an open letter criticizing the behavior of its chief executive, Elon Musk, said three employees with knowledge of the situation.

headline: The European Commission recommends E.U. candidacy for Ukraine and Moldova, but not Georgia.
abstract: The Commission’s blessing is just the first step on a long road. The final decision will be in the hands of European Union leaders, who will meet June 23 and 24 in Brussels to tackle the thorny question.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s executive branch recommended on Friday that Ukraine be granted candidate status in the country’s bid to become a member, the first formal step in a process that normally lasts longer than a decade.

headline: Mariupol, a symbol of the war’s human cost, likely was Ukraine’s ‘deadliest place’ through April.
abstract: The southern port of Mariupol has become a potent emblem of the human toll of the war in Ukraine, a besieged city where trapped residents went for weeks without electricity or water, and where people dug trenches to accommodate the mounting numbers of bodies.
lead_paragraph: The southern port of Mariupol has become a potent emblem of the human toll of the war in Ukraine, a besieged city where trapped residents went for weeks without electricity or water, and where people dug trenches to accommodate the mounting numbers of bodies.

headline: Late Night Delves Into Day 3 of the Jan. 6 Hearings
abstract: Trevor Noah joked that Donald Trump “lives his entire life as if he is the bad kid in one of those antismoking P.S.A.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Is Avalanche Defenseman Cale Makar the Stephen Curry of Hockey?
abstract: “You think you’ve got him, but you don’t,” Lightning defenseman Mikhail Sergachev said. “He just uses you as bait and as a screen. He’s very, very dangerous.”
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The name floats in the ether, now, alongside Cale Makar’s, put there by Wayne Gretzky. On TNT’s hockey program, Gretzky, arguably the best to ever play the game, compared Makar to Bobby Orr, the transcendent defenseman some insist was even better than Gretzky.

headline: Gun Talks Snag on Tricky Question: What Counts as a Boyfriend?
abstract: Among the sticking points holding up a final agreement on gun legislation is how to define a boyfriend in a provision meant to keep guns away from domestic abusers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Among the sticking points standing in the way of a final deal on what could be the first significant bipartisan gun safety legislation in decades is an age-old question: How do you define a boyfriend?

headline: Reflecting on a Deep Investigation
abstract: Azmat Khan, the journalist behind a Times series that revealed how U.S. air wars were resulting in a staggering number of civilian casualties, shares how the investigation changed how she thinks about reporting.
lead_paragraph: In early 2016, Azmat Khan, a journalist for The New York Times Magazine, began an investigation that lasted more than five years and was part of a group of Times articles that won the Pulitzer Prize this year for international reporting. In the series, Ms. Khan uncovered systemic flaws behind the air wars conducted by the United States in Afghanistan, Iraq and Syria and the lack of transparency surrounding more than 1,300 reports of civilian casualties. In a recent interview, Ms. Khan reflected on the reporting challenges and what the experience taught her. This interview has been edited.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, June 17, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the new Pixar film "Lightyear."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the new Pixar film "Lightyear."

headline: New in Paperback: Dana Spiotta and Juan Gonzalez
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: WAYWARD, by Dana Spiotta. (Vintage, 336 pp., $17.) Spiotta’s fifth novel, about female aging in contemporary America, follows a woman who reckons with the trappings of wealth and comfort after spontaneously buying a home in Syracuse and divorcing her husband. Our reviewer, Joanna Rakoff, called the book a “virtuosic, singular and very funny portrait of a woman seeking sanity and purpose in a world gone mad.”

headline: How to Feel Better Naked
abstract: Whether you want to find joy in your body, or just greater self-acceptance, these four strategies from psychologists and activists — and, yes, nudists — might help.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: To Meme or Not to Meme
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Kate-Yeonjae Jeong, age 17.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Kate-Yeonjae Jeong, age 17, from Kinder High School for the Performing and Visual Arts in Houston, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s Ninth Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 16,664 entries.

headline: N.Y.C. Tried to Fix High School Admissions. Some Parents Are Furious.
abstract: In an attempt to democratize schools, the city is focusing less on grades, attendance and test scores. Instead, it relies heavily on a lottery.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Ginni Thomas Has a Lot of Explaining to Do
abstract: If the tables were turned, Republicans would not hesitate to use every argument and every tool at their disposal.
lead_paragraph: Again and again, during the years that Donald Trump was in the White House, liberals would ask themselves a single question: “Can you imagine if Barack Obama had done this?”

headline: The Stock Market Is Plummeting. Welcome to the End of the ‘Everything Bubble.’
abstract: The financial journalist Rana Foroohar shares her long view on what’s going on with the economy.
lead_paragraph: This week, the S&P 500 entered what analysts refer to as a bear market. The index has plunged around 22 percent from its most recent peak in January. Many growth stocks and crypto assets have crashed double or triple that amount.

headline: Father’s Day Can Be Hard. Here’s How to Handle the Holiday.
abstract: For people grieving a loss or facing thoughts “about what could have been or what may never be,” there are ways to find solace.
lead_paragraph: Father’s Day is complicated for Collie James. On one hand, it’s a day to celebrate with his two young sons “and get that wonderful hand-drawn card.” On the other, it’s a stark reminder that his firstborn child — Maddie, who died of brain cancer at age five in 2012 — isn’t there to sign it.

headline: Love Your Dog, but Beware of Your Homeowners’ Insurance
abstract: Many firms have long refused coverage or charge more for pit bulls and other dogs considered more dangerous, but New York and other states say policies shouldn’t be breed specific.
lead_paragraph: When Brian English applied for renters’ insurance a few years ago, he described his dogs, Venom and Jean, as “mixed breed.” — a category that certainly covers pit bulls. Another time on an application, he wrote, “American Staffordshire terrier,” a fancier-sounding name for a type of pit bull.

headline: The Future Isn’t Female Anymore
abstract: Where is the women’s movement when we need it most?
lead_paragraph: The Drift, a buzzy literary journal founded by Kiara Barrow and Rebecca Panovka, left-leaning women in their late 20s, published a series of short essays earlier this year under the rubric, “What to Do About Feminism.” “For a long time now, we’ve had the sense that feminism is in trouble,” Barrow and Panovka wrote in the introduction. They described an ambient feeling that feminism has been sapped of cultural vitality, even as an anti-feminist backlash is gathering momentum, and that young people especially were turning against the movement.

headline: Colombia Is Slipping Back Toward Violence. The Next President Can Stop That.
abstract: Neither candidate has a clear plan to contain rising levels of conflict and armed violence in the countryside.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Last month a criminal armed group shut down much of the northern third of Colombia — largely uncontested. “We decree four days of Armed Strike from this moment,” read the May 5 pamphlet ordering the population to stay indoors, the shops to close and the roads to be empty. The Gulf Clan, a paramilitary-style drug trafficking group, initiated the strike against the Colombian government in retaliation for the capture and extradition of its leader, Dairo Antonio Úsuga, known as Otoniel, to the United States. “We are not responsible for what happens to those who do not comply,” the group warned ominously.

headline: This Is Going to Hurt
abstract: Inflation is expected to remain high later this year even as the economy slows and layoffs rise. Already, signs of financial stress are surfacing.
lead_paragraph: Kat Johnston didn’t expect the pandemic to make her less stressed about her finances. After all, she temporarily lost her job at the library where she worked full time. But, like many Americans, she found an unexpected reprieve from money worries: Months at home limited her spending, and she received expanded unemployment insurance and two one-time checks from the government.

headline: Fast-Tracked Bill Stokes Fears of Private Development in 1,200-Acre Park
abstract: Proponents of a free and open park, who have batted back decades of for-profit proposals for Liberty State Park, worry new legislation could set a dangerous precedent for parks nationwide.
lead_paragraph: With just weeks to go before the state budget deadline, a powerful assortment of New Jersey politicians introduced an expansive new bill tied to an explosive old controversy.

headline: How Can You Travel for Less Than $100 a Day, Everything Included? Find a Cruise Deal.
abstract: As companies bring their full fleets back online, many ships still have room. That means bargains are being offered outside the winter “wave season,” making some sailings unexpectedly cheap, even in an era of inflation.
lead_paragraph: A $50-a-day offer to sail on a Caribbean cruise ship with pools, water slides, restaurants and Broadway-style entertainment says a lot about the turbulence some cruise companies are facing.

headline: Need to Find a Bathroom in New York City? Try TikTok.
abstract: Frustrated by the feat of locating a free restroom in New York City, residents and visitors are compiling and sharing tips.
lead_paragraph: It is a plight familiar to New York City’s nearly nine million residents, and to the millions of tourists who visit each year: nowhere to go to the restroom in a city where public facilities are few and hard to find.

headline: How Louis Theroux Became a ‘Jiggle Jiggle’ Sensation at Age 52
abstract: Decades into his career, the British American journalist has an unlikely TikTok hit that could be the song of the summer. “I am not trying to make it as a rapper,” he says.
lead_paragraph: Four or five times a week these days, some old friend will contact Louis Theroux and tell him, “My daughter keeps going around the house singing your rap,” or, “My wife was exercising to your rap in her Pilates class.” Passing by a primary school, Mr. Theroux has the feeling he is being watched, a sense confirmed when he hears a kid call out behind him: “My money don’t jiggle jiggle.”

headline: Gun Control Advocates Have More Money Now, but Money Can’t Buy Zeal
abstract: After more mass shootings, one side is gaining donors and political will; the other is galvanized by gun rights. Will anything be different?
lead_paragraph: After the massacre of schoolchildren at Sandy Hook Elementary in Newtown, Conn., in 2012, the gun-control movement was small and badly outspent by the National Rifle Association. Parents seeking an outlet for their grief and rage congregated on Facebook, where they formed their own group, Moms Demand Action, to push for stricter gun laws.

headline: She Won a Tony. But Deirdre O’Connell ‘Can’t Think About That.’
abstract: We spoke to the veteran actress as she returned to work, preparing for the opening of her new Off Broadway show “Corsicana.”
lead_paragraph: When Deirdre O’Connell returned to work two days after winning this year’s Tony Award for best performance by a leading actress in a play, the production staff of her current show, “Corsicana” at Playwrights Horizons, greeted her with a balloon arch and cake. O’Connell, 68, enjoyed it. For a little while, anyway. But “Corsicana,” a lonesome, oblique quartet by Will Arbery, is in previews. It begins press performances soon. O’Connell needed to rehearse. So she put the celebration aside.

headline: Colombia Will Soon Have Its First Black Female Vice President. Will It Be Her?
abstract: A few months ago, Marelen Castillo was a top director of a Catholic university. Now, she is one of two Afro-Colombian women who could become the country’s next second in command.
lead_paragraph: CALI, Colombia — At a hotel in Cali, a major city near Colombia’s Pacific Coast, hundreds of people packed a ballroom for the woman at the center of the stage.

headline: A Filmmaker Imagines a Japan Where the Elderly Volunteer to Die
abstract: The premise for Chie Hayakawa’s film, “Plan 75,” is shocking: a government push to euthanize the elderly. In a rapidly aging society, some also wonder: Is the movie prescient?
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese film director Chie Hayakawa was germinating the idea for a screenplay when she decided to test out her premise on elderly friends of her mother and other acquaintances. Her question: If the government sponsored a euthanasia program for people 75 and over, would you consent to it?

headline: How a Celebrity Divorce Lawyer Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Nancy Chemtob is committed to meditation and self-help books, as well as her clients, family members and new husband.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Chemtob, a matrimonial lawyer, has helped Mary-Kate Olsen, Tory Burch, Bobby Flay and other celebrities get divorced. After practicing for decades as the founding partner of Chemtob Moss Forman & Beyda, one of the largest matrimonial firms in New York City, Ms. Chemtob went through a divorce herself, in 2012.

headline: As Some Office Workers Return, Happy Hour Sees a Wobbly Comeback
abstract: Even as companies struggle to coax employees back to the office, some bars report that their after-work crowds are nearing prepandemic levels.
lead_paragraph: With the unsteady return of workers to the office comes the shaky return of the happy hour.

headline: Court Sides With Girls Who Sued Over School’s Skirt Requirement
abstract: A North Carolina school’s dress code perpetuated “harmful” gender stereotypes and violated the 14th Amendment’s equal protection clause, a U.S. appeals court found.
lead_paragraph: A North Carolina charter school violated female students’ constitutional rights by requiring that they wear skirts, a federal court ruled this week, in a case that weighed whether a privately operated institution should be subject to similar rules as public schools run by local school boards.

headline: High on Helping: The Dangers of Voluntourism
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Ketong Li, age 17.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Ketong Li, age 17, from Miss Porter’s School in Farmington, Conn., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s Ninth Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 16,664 entries.

headline: Erin Doherty Shape Shifts in ‘Chloe’
abstract: The actress, known for playing Princess Anne in “The Crown,” embodies a working class con woman in a new limited series on Amazon Prime Video.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After playing Princess Anne in two seasons of “The Crown,” Erin Doherty realized that people assumed she had a similar — if not quite as regal — background.

headline: Extradition Order for Julian Assange Approved by Britain
abstract: Priti Patel, Britain’s home secretary, approved the order. But Mr. Assange, the WikiLeaks founder who faces charges in the U.S. under the Espionage Act, will appeal.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government approved an extradition order on Friday for Julian Assange, the embattled WikiLeaks founder, confirming a court decision that he can be sent to the United States to stand trial on espionage charges, though his legal fight against the decision is not over.

headline: Stolen Art: Why We Need Repatriation
abstract: We are honoring each of the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Serena Liu, age 15.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Serena Liu, age 15, from Parkway West High School in Chesterfield, Mo., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s Ninth Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 16,664 entries.

headline: What the Jan. 6 Hearings Have Revealed So Far
abstract: The House committee investigating the Capitol riot is laying out the extent of former President Donald Trump’s attempts to remain in power after the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language.

headline: Relief for Parents
abstract: Covid vaccines for young children are finally coming.
lead_paragraph: After months of delays, children under 5 are set to get vaccines next week.

headline: C.D.C.’s science advisers grapple with assessing two very different vaccines for the youngest Americans.
abstract: On Saturday, the scientists are expected to recommend the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines for young children. Doses could be available next week.
lead_paragraph: In deliberations over whether to recommend Covid vaccines for young children, scientific advisers to the Centers for Disease Control and Evaluation on Friday wrestled with the complexities of evaluating two very different vaccines, and with limited data.

headline: My Dad Wasn’t Around, but I Had No Shortage of Black Father Figures
abstract: For me, fatherly affection came from coaches and the men in my Black Baptist church.
lead_paragraph: I knew about Father’s Day, but I did not celebrate it as a child. It was someone else’s holiday, much like St. Patrick’s Day, which belonged to the Irish and had no hold on me. In grade school I endured the pinch that went along with failure to wear green. Similarly, since I grew up without a father around, the annual June celebration passed without comment.

headline: ‘They Watch Us From the Sky.’
abstract: Sandy Alcantara and Pablo López of the Miami Marlins have been the N.L.’s best pitchers this season. They are motivated by the loss of a parent and bound by a sense of purpose.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Most baseball players stopped wearing high-cut stirrups years ago, well before Pablo López was born to Danny López and Agnedis Serra in Venezuela in 1996. López, one of two young aces for the Miami Marlins, likes the throwback style but wears stirrups to remind him of Danny, who died of a heart attack two summers ago.

headline: Walking on Hot Coals: A Company Event Goes Wrong
abstract: More than two dozen employees of a Swiss company were injured while walking in bare feet over hot coals, an ancient religious tradition that has become popular on corporate retreats.
lead_paragraph: Walking barefoot across hot coals, an ancient religious ritual popularized in recent years as a corporate team-building exercise, has once again bonded a group of co-workers through the shared suffering of burned feet.

headline: Putin denounces the U.S. as a fading world power.
abstract: He also mocked what he called the country’s view of itself as “the messenger of the Lord on Earth.”
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday reprised his critique of the United States as a declining power that treats its allies as colonies, while declaring itself exceptional and “the messenger of the Lord on Earth.”

headline: Stephen Curry Left His Critics With Nothing Else to Say
abstract: Four N.B.A. championships. Two Most Valuable Player Awards. And yes, a finals M.V.P. Golden State’s Curry has nothing else to prove.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A few seconds remained in Stephen Curry’s N.B.A. season when he spotted his father, Dell, sitting along one of the baselines. He went over to embrace him, then fell to the court in tears.

headline: How the Proud Boys Breached the Capitol on Jan. 6: Rile Up the Normies
abstract: A Times investigation of court documents, text messages and hundreds of videos shows how the Proud Boys coordinated to instigate multiple breaches of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: A Times investigation of court documents, text messages and hundreds of videos shows how the Proud Boys coordinated to instigate multiple breaches of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6.

headline: Proud Boys Led Major Breaches of Capitol on Jan. 6, Video Investigation Finds
abstract: A monthslong Times investigation using court documents, text messages and videos reveals how teams of Proud Boys instigated critical breaches of the Capitol on Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: For almost 18 months, the Proud Boys have been at the center of the criminal and congressional investigations of the violent attack on the Capitol last year.

headline: She Spoke Out Against Vietnam’s Plans for Coal. Then She Was Arrested.
abstract: The prosecution of Vietnam’s most prominent environmental activist, as well as others, has cast doubt on the country’s commitment to cut coal.
lead_paragraph: When the Vietnamese government decided in 2016 to cut the use of coal in its next energy plan, it followed the advice of an unusual source: one of the country’s most prominent environmentalists.

headline: Arrest of Colorado 14-Year-Old Over a Slap Prompts Excessive-Force Suit
abstract: The lawsuit claims that a man and his 14-year-old daughter were arrested by officers who used excessive force during the encounter in 2020.
lead_paragraph: The father of a teenage girl filed a lawsuit on Wednesday against three police officers in Loveland, Colo., who arrested her in 2020, saying the men used excessive force when they slammed the 14-year-old onto concrete, fired a Taser at him and choked the family’s Jack Russell terrier.

headline: An ugly week for stocks leaves the S&P 500 with its biggest loss since March 2020.
abstract: The selling was fueled by persistently high inflation and fears that the Fed’s efforts to tame it with higher interest rates will choke growth.
lead_paragraph: A tumultuous week on Wall Street, which began with stocks plunging into a bear market for the second time during the pandemic, ended with a small gain on Friday. That was little comfort after a brutal period for investors, who have seen the value of their portfolios and retirement funds lurch downward.

headline: Eurovision rules out Ukraine as host of next year’s song contest.
abstract: The Eurovision Song Contest’s organizers said on Friday that Russia’s invasion meant Ukraine could not stage next year’s event, even though it won this year’s contest.
lead_paragraph: Kalush Orchestra, a Ukrainian rap act, gave a huge morale boost last month to its war-torn country by cruising to victory at the Eurovision Song Contest — the world’s most watched and glitziest song contest.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 2: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by June 24 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 6.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Week Two of our 13th Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: Chess Replay: You Versus Eisenschmidt
abstract: Take on Friedrich Eisenschmidt in a recreation of a tournament game in Tartu (then known as Dorpat), 1862. Solve for the best series of moves.
lead_paragraph: About Daniel

headline: Why Some States Are Expanding Tax-Free Periods
abstract: The “holidays” are aimed at helping consumers, but they’re also politically attractive. Tax experts say they provide only modest benefits.
lead_paragraph: This year, the back-to-school tax “holidays” that many states offer each summer are being expanded with new types of tax-free periods that are aimed at giving beleaguered consumers a break on rising prices.

headline: Your Backyard Is Actually a Lucrative Private Dog Park — if You Say It Is
abstract: A new generation of apps is allowing homeowners to make extra money by renting out their pools, yards and living rooms for an hour at a time.
lead_paragraph: Greg Jessup likes to squeeze money out of his five-bedroom house in Wilton, Conn., wherever possible, frequently listing it on Airbnb. But this spring, he took a good look at the space around the house and saw its potential, too.

headline: The Iconic Morro Bay Smokestacks Are Coming Down
abstract: The smokestacks that have defined a stretch of Central California coastline for decades are on their way out.
lead_paragraph: MORRO BAY, Calif. — From the shore of this otherwise quaint fishing village rises a pair of imposing landmarks, one built by nature and the other by man.

headline: F.D.A. Authorizes Moderna and Pfizer Covid Vaccines for Youngest Children
abstract: A recommendation from the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention would be the final step before doses are rolled out for the roughly 20 million children younger than 5.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration authorized both the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccines for the nation’s youngest children on Friday, a relief to parents who have waited 18 months to protect their babies, toddlers and preschoolers since shots first became available.

headline: China Launches Third Aircraft Carrier in Major Milestone for Xi Jinping
abstract: The vessel, named Fujian after the Chinese province that sits across from Taiwan, is China’s most modern.
lead_paragraph: China launched its third and most advanced aircraft carrier on Friday, bringing the country one step closer to a modern navy capable of competing with the United States’ military naval power.

headline: Tracking Fear on Wall Street
abstract: Plus, with Revlon’s bankruptcy, Wall Street bankers get ready for a wave of distressed situations.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. stock market, as measured by the S&P 500, tumbled more than 3 percent yesterday, dragging it deeper into bear market territory. This morning, futures markets suggest there will be a rebound, but the S&P is still well on track to record its 10th weekly decline of the past 11 weeks.

headline: A Better Way to Measure Immunity in Children
abstract: Some scientists believe that a clearer picture of Covid vaccine efficacy could have emerged sooner if investigators had tracked certain immune cells, not just antibodies.
lead_paragraph: For Jacqueline Almeida, next week cannot come soon enough.

headline: Meet the Peecyclers. Their Idea to Help Farmers Is No. 1.
abstract: A shortage of chemical fertilizer, worsened by the war in Ukraine, has growers desperate. It just so happens that human urine has the very nutrients that crops need.
lead_paragraph: BRATTLEBORO, Vt. — When Kate Lucy saw a poster in town inviting people to learn about something known as peecycling, she was mystified. “Why would someone pee in a jug and save it?” she wondered. “It sounds like such a wacky idea.”

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Rana Foroohar
abstract: A conversation with the financial journalist Rana Foroohar.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Rana Foroohar. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: A Really Radical Fashion Idea
abstract: When is a cruise show not just a cruise show? Ask Maria Grazia Chiuri of Dior.
lead_paragraph: I am beginning to think that Maria Grazia Chiuri, the artistic director of Dior women’s wear, may be the most subversively political, even radical, designer in charge of a big French fashion brand.

headline: A Gull Flaps Its Wings and a Deadly Virus Explodes
abstract: This year’s outbreak of the H5N1 virus has resulted in the deaths of nearly 400,000 wild birds worldwide. Scientists are studying the pathways of contagion among species.
lead_paragraph: A great black-backed gull migrating from Europe to Eastern Canada last winter may have been the first carrier to North America of the deadly strain of avian influenza that has killed tens of millions of domestic poultry and devastated wild bird populations.

headline: The surprising story of ‘warming stripes’
abstract: One of the most popular ways to visualize rising temperatures is a simple graphic known as warming stripes. Here’s the backstory.
lead_paragraph: June 21 is Show Your Stripes Day.

headline: Vince McMahon Steps Down as Head of W.W.E. During Misconduct Investigation
abstract: Mr. McMahon, the pro wrestling company’s chairman and chief executive, agreed to pay a secret settlement to an employee with whom he was said to have had an affair, The Wall Street Journal reported this week.
lead_paragraph: Vince McMahon, a longtime executive for World Wrestling Entertainment who led professional wrestling from a sideshow curiosity into a mainstream phenomenon, has stepped down as chairman and chief executive while the company’s board investigates allegations of misconduct against him, the company said on Friday.

headline: Torched Trains and Burning Tires: India’s New Military Recruitment Plan Fuels Angry Protests
abstract: Young people seeking job security in a long-term military career saw the announcement as another blow to their dreams amid rising unemployment.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Thousands of young Indians took to the streets in angry demonstrations on Friday, blocking trains and setting fire to railroad cars and tires to protest a cost-cutting move by the government that they say will shatter their dreams of a more secure job in the military.

headline: Cooper Raiff, Arriving Early to the Party
abstract: At 25, the indie writer, director and actor is making waves in Hollywood. His second feature, “Cha Cha Real Smooth,” could start a new career chapter.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For a while, working behind the camera didn’t appeal much to Cooper Raiff.

headline: Andy Garcia Is the Father of the Bride in More Ways Than One
abstract: The actor, who’s playing the role onscreen and in reality, understands his rigid character: “He’s an amalgamation of everybody I’ve ever known, including myself.”
lead_paragraph: Andy Garcia still believes in the American promise of prosperity for all. “If you come here and you work hard, there’s a future for you,” he said. “There will always be obstacles, but the opportunity is there.”

headline: New York Philharmonic Chooses Arts Veteran as Leader
abstract: Gary Ginstling, executive director of the National Symphony Orchestra, will replace Deborah Borda as the orchestra’s president and chief executive next year.
lead_paragraph: Come this fall, the New York Philharmonic will have a transformed home, when David Geffen Hall reopens after a $550 million renovation. In the not-so-distant future, the orchestra will also get a new music director to replace its departing conductor.

headline: Ready Player Two (or Three)
abstract: “You can learn a lot from video games: hand-eye coordination and being able to lose.” Fathers talk gaming with their children.

headline: Egypt, America’s Middle Eastern ally, maintains warm relations with Putin.
abstract: The St. Petersburg International Economic Forum being held in Russia on Friday will feature a speech from a surprising world leader: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt, a longtime U.S. ally that has for decades been the second-largest recipient of American aid in the world.
lead_paragraph: The St. Petersburg International Economic Forum being held in Russia on Friday will feature a speech from a surprising world leader: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt, a longtime U.S. ally that has for decades been the second-largest recipient of American aid in the world.

headline: How Houston Is Overhauling Homelessness and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: N.Y.C.’s vaccine plan for children younger than 5 relies on pediatricians and vaccine hubs.
abstract: The city hopes to start vaccinating children under 5 on June 22 at many kinds of locations.
lead_paragraph: Health officials in New York City are preparing to distribute vaccines for children younger than 5 starting on Wednesday, according to a new plan announced on Friday by Mayor Eric Adams.

headline: Ukraine’s path to the E.U. will be long and arduous.
abstract: A recommendation to grant Ukraine candidate status has important symbolism. But the country faces a difficult road ahead, including more than 80,000 pages of rules and regulations.
lead_paragraph: It was an impassioned plea: As war raged in his country, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine asked in early March that his country be allowed to join the European Union, the world’s biggest trading bloc, which had helped preserve peace in Europe for decades.

headline: Drake Releases ‘Honestly, Nevermind,’ an LP Dedicated to Virgil Abloh
abstract: The rapper’s 14-track seventh studio album came out at midnight, about six hours after it was announced on social media.
lead_paragraph: For his last album, Drake kept his fans in anticipation for nearly a year. For his newest one, the wait was about six hours.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Juneteenth and Father’s Day are coming, and we have loads of recipes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. With Juneteenth and Father’s Day on Sunday, it’ll be a busy weekend for those who celebrate. Naturally we have loads of recipes for each.

headline: What to Know About the Covid Vaccine for Little Kids
abstract: Here are answers to five common questions.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, has signed off on two Covid-19 vaccines for children over 6 months of age and under 5.

headline: British prime minister pays a second surprise visit to Kyiv.
abstract: Boris Johnson promised new military aid that would train up to 10,000 Ukrainian soldiers every 120 days.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s prime minister, Boris Johnson, on Friday paid a second, surprise, visit to the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, offering a training program for the country’s military in a fresh show of support for Ukraine’s government just a day after key European leaders made a similar trip.

headline: Russians Breached This City, Not With Troops, but Propaganda
abstract: As they batter towns and cities in Ukraine with artillery, the Russians are also bombarding them with messaging aimed at eroding Ukrainians’ trust in their military and their government.
lead_paragraph: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — Gesturing to the artillery shell lodged in the ground and a rocket protruding from the wall, Maksym Katerynyn was in a rage. These were Ukrainian munitions, he shouted. And it was Ukrainian artillery that struck his home the day before and killed his mother and stepfather.

headline: Greek Court Rejects Effort to Toughen Punishment After Killing of an American
abstract: Bakari Henderson, a college graduate from Texas, was beaten to death in a resort area in July 2017. The court on Friday upheld the original convictions.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — A Greek court on Friday rejected an effort to toughen the punishment for a group of men convicted in the beating death of an American on a holiday island in 2017, upholding the original convictions of six men for grievous assault and spurning a call to find them guilty of murder.

headline: Overlooked No More: William B. Gould, Escaped Slave and Civil War Diarist
abstract: He served nearly three years in the U.S. Navy and documented almost all of it, leaving an invaluable record of Black life during the war.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Infighting Overshadows Big Plans at The Washington Post
abstract: The aim of Sally Buzbee, The Post’s editor, is to broaden the newspaper’s reach. A year into the job, she’s dealing with internal tumult over some longstanding grievances.
lead_paragraph: When Sally Buzbee joined The Washington Post a year ago this month, she took over a newsroom that had nearly doubled to more than 1,000 journalists under the ownership of Jeff Bezos, who bought it in 2013. Its coverage regularly won Pulitzer Prizes.

headline: A High-Flying Italian Surgeon’s Fall From Grace
abstract: Dr. Paolo Macchiarini became a star by creating a “bioartificial” windpipe. But it did not work, and a court in Sweden has found him criminally liable for the harm inflicted on a patient.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It sounded like real-life science fiction — a 3-D printed organ, a groundbreaking artificial windpipe, built in a laboratory and made to order. The charismatic Italian surgeon who designed it foresaw a future where hearts and lungs could be made from plastic, and organ donations became a thing of the past. Almost overnight, he became a superstar.

headline: Drake Looks for Love, Repeatedly, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by beabadoobee, Perfume Genius, the Beths and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Rafael Nadal, Chasing Grand Slam, Will Head to Wimbledon
abstract: Nadal, hobbled by a foot injury while winning the French Open, said he would play in the grass-court tournament, which begins on June 27.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Grand Slam is still in play.

headline: Why Is the World’s Best Swimmer Not Swimming at the Worlds?
abstract: Ariarne Titmus of Australia has a perfectly good reason for missing a renewal of her rivalry with Katie Ledecky at the world championships: She didn’t feel like going.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — When the women’s 400-meter freestyle final is swum and won on Saturday at swimming’s world championships in Budapest, the reigning world and Olympic champion in the event, the race’s new world record-holder, will be halfway around the world — and fast asleep.

headline: ‘Jurassic World Dominion’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: Colin Trevorrow narrates a dinosaur escape sequence featuring Bryce Dallas Howard.
lead_paragraph: Colin Trevorrow narrates a dinosaur escape sequence featuring Bryce Dallas Howard.

headline: Young, Gifted and Searching for a Sense of Self
abstract: A quiz bowl winner and students at an elite music camp struggle to figure out who they really are in novels by Kate Egan and Mariama J. Lockington.
lead_paragraph: GOLDEN TICKET, by Kate EganIN THE KEY OF US, by Mariama J. Lockington

headline: Watch Bryce Dallas Howard’s Slow Escape in ‘Jurassic World Dominion’
abstract: The director Colin Trevorrow narrates a sequence featuring the actor, a testy Therizinosaurus and a murky pond.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Minnie Driver Paddles Out to Sea
abstract: The English actress began her memoir, “Managing Expectations,” in the early months of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Minnie Driver clambered into a pink-and-green kayak, adjusted her legs against the foot pegs, grabbed her paddle and pushed off the wobbling dock into a choppy Hudson River. “See you in Weehawken,” she said, yelling over her shoulder. A Canada goose looked on, mildly impressed.

headline: A Teenage Chef Who Brings Soul to California Cuisine
abstract: Rahanna Bisseret Martinez was a finalist on “Top Chef Junior” and has her own cookbook.
lead_paragraph: Name: Rahanna Bisseret Martinez

headline: Here is what to know about the Covid vaccine for infants and toddlers.
abstract: Millions of U.S. parents are crossing their fingers again this week that Covid-19 vaccines will soon be available for younger age groups. An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously on Wednesday to recommend that the agency authorize the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines for use in very young children.
lead_paragraph: Millions of U.S. parents are crossing their fingers again this week that Covid-19 vaccines will soon be available for younger age groups. An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously on Wednesday to recommend that the agency authorize the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines for use in very young children.

headline: Jackie, Before Marrying Jack
abstract: Elisabeth Egan talks about Louis Bayard’s “Jackie & Me,” and Matthew Schneier discusses Paula Byrne’s biography of Barbara Pym.
lead_paragraph: Elisabeth Egan, an editor at the Book Review, curates our Group Text column — a monthly choice of a book that she feels is particularly well suited to book clubs and their discussions. On this week’s podcast, she talks about her latest pick: “Jackie & Me,” by Louis Bayard, which imagines the friendship between Jacqueline Bouvier and Lem Billings, a close friend of the Kennedys.

headline: The Coin That Could Wreck Crypto
abstract: As cryptocurrencies have plunged, attention has focused on a potential point of vulnerability: the market’s reliance on a so-called stablecoin called Tether.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Cryptocurrency prices are plummeting. A so-called stablecoin lost all its value in a matter of days. A newfangled crypto bank halted withdrawals. And investors have been plunged into financial ruin.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: A journey along the Congo River. Also in this edition: photos of flooding damage in Yellowstone and a wobbly comeback for happy hour.
lead_paragraph: A journey along the Congo River. Also in this edition: photos of flooding damage in Yellowstone and a wobbly comeback for happy hour.

headline: In ‘First Kill,’ Hunter and Prey Fall in Love
abstract: This Netflix series about a star-crossed teenage romance between a bloodsucker and a monster hunter has roots in both “Romeo and Juliet” and “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.”
lead_paragraph: When Victoria Schwab sat down to write a short story for an anthology about vampires in 2019, she already knew that she would adapt whatever she wrote for television. So one of the first questions the author, better known by her pen name, V.E. Schwab, asked herself was, what kind of vampire show did she want to watch?

headline: Soccer Rediscovers the No. 9
abstract: The signings of Erling Haaland and Darwin Núñez were not mere summer coups for Manchester City and Liverpool. They could signal the start of a new tactical phase.
lead_paragraph: It took Erling Haaland a couple of seconds to notice something had changed. Late last month, Haaland, the Norwegian striker, was inside the Manchester Institute of Health and Performance, patiently and quietly going through the many and monotonous steps of the medical exam that was part of his move to Manchester City.

headline: The Dutch intelligence service says it prevented a Russian spy from infiltrating the International Criminal Court.
abstract: Sergey Vladimirovich Cherkasov spent years building an identity as a Brazilian citizen, polishing a résumé that got him an internship at the court, officials say.
lead_paragraph: It has all the elements of an espionage thriller: An accused Russian spy who concocted an identity as a Brazilian. The creation of an elaborate cover story. And what Dutch authorities said appeared to be a foiled plot to gain access to the International Criminal Court as it investigates Russian war crimes.

headline: Through Sweat and Tears, a Cheesemongering Champion Is Crowned
abstract: At the Cheesemongers Invitational, the competition is fierce, but the feeling of cheese community is strong.
lead_paragraph: Cara Condon was a dark horse heading into the 2022 Cheesemonger Invitational in Brooklyn last Sunday.

headline: We Should Thank Mike Pence for His Courage on Jan. 6
abstract: A reader praises the former vice president; another reluctantly suggests pardoning Donald Trump. Also: Ukraine what-ifs; Covid mandates; paid internships.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Covid Vaccine and Fisheries Deals Close a ‘Roller Coaster’ W.T.O. Meeting
abstract: Members of the global trade group were forced to scale back plans for more ambitious agreements, but they were ultimately able to reach several deals at a meeting in Geneva.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of the World Trade Organization announced several agreements on Friday at the close of their first in-person ministerial conference in four years, pledging to rein in harmful government policies that have encouraged overfishing and relax some controls on intellectual property in an effort to make coronavirus vaccines more widely available.

headline: Not Your Average Pride Event
abstract: Dyke Day LA takes a homespun approach to a month typically packed with corporate-sponsored parties, parades and concerts.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, droves of people descended on a 15-acre park in northeast Los Angeles for an afternoon of picnicking, mingling, cheering on drag performances and a puppy costume competition, and more.

headline: How a TV Series Undersells the Danger of the Sex Pistols
abstract: A music critic who teaches college students about the punk movement takes stock of “Pistol,” the new FX drama about the 1970s British punk band.
lead_paragraph: Punk is something you can study in school these days. Students across the world earn class credit with essays examining the movement and its legacy. My niece learned about punk in the British equivalent of ninth grade. And I teach punk-related topics like DIY at California Institute of the Arts. So when I watched FX’s “Pistol,” Danny Boyle’s new limited series about the Sex Pistols, I couldn’t help looking for “teachable moments” to bring up in class next year.

headline: The Good, the Bad and the Cringe of the Juneteenth Gold Rush
abstract: Juneteenth was made a federal holiday in 2021, but this year big-box stores like Walmart have been going all out with themed party supplies, sometimes crowding out smaller vendors.
lead_paragraph: Brandy Goodner first learned about Juneteenth when she was 14. Although she didn’t begin celebrating the holiday — a commemoration of the day in 1865 that enslaved people in Texas were told that they had been freed two years earlier — until she was an adult, Ms. Goodner now parties like she’s making up for lost time.

headline: Repainting the Canvas, One Pixel at a Time
abstract: Amid bytes and blockchains, artists are exploring worlds buoyed by technology and fueled by imagination.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Bartees Strange Ponders Success in Dire Times
