El acuerdo consistía en que los rebeldes dejaran las armas, mientras que el gobierno inundaba las zonas de conflicto con oportunidades de trabajo, aliviando así la pobreza y la desigualdad que originaron la guerra.
lead_paragraph: Se suponía que el acuerdo de paz de Colombia, firmado en 2016 por el gobierno y las Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia, o FARC, sería el inicio de una nueva era de tranquilidad en un país que soportó más de cinco décadas de conflicto. El acuerdo consistía en que los rebeldes dejaran las armas, mientras que el gobierno inundaba las zonas de conflicto con oportunidades de trabajo, aliviando así la pobreza y la desigualdad que originaron la guerra.

headline: Chess Replay: You Versus Ossipov
abstract: Take on Ossipov in a recreation of a Tuesday Night Marathon game in San Francisco, 2006. Solve for the best series of moves.
lead_paragraph: About Daniel

headline: A Queen in Any Other Language
abstract: The history of how the queen became the most powerful piece in chess.
lead_paragraph: The queen is known as the most powerful piece on the chess board, so the prospect of sacrificing it invokes an unparalleled excitement among chess enthusiasts. There is something inherently satisfying about giving up the strongest piece on the board in order to checkmate the enemy king. I hope that this week’s puzzles served as a worthy reminder that all of us — beginners and grandmasters alike — can unite around an appreciation of the unique, almost otherworldly beauty of the royal game.

headline: What is Uribismo and why are Colombians voting against it?
abstract: When Colombia chooses its next president on Sunday, the pivotal election will represent a blow to the country’s dominant political force as voters have become increasingly disillusioned by chronic poverty, inequity and growing insecurity.
lead_paragraph: When Colombia chooses its next president on Sunday, the pivotal election will represent a blow to the country’s dominant political force as voters have become increasingly disillusioned by chronic poverty, inequity and growing insecurity.

headline: What hundreds of photos of weapons reveal about Russia’s brutal war strategy.
abstract: Reflecting a shockingly barbaric and old-fashioned wartime strategy, Russian forces have pummeled Ukrainian cities and towns with a barrage of rockets and other munitions, most of which can be considered relatively crude relics of the Cold War, and many of which have been banned widely under international treaties, according to a New York Times analysis.
lead_paragraph: Reflecting a shockingly barbaric and old-fashioned wartime strategy, Russian forces have pummeled Ukrainian cities and towns with a barrage of rockets and other munitions, most of which can be considered relatively crude relics of the Cold War, and many of which have been banned widely under international treaties, according to a New York Times analysis.

headline: The ‘Hard Yakka’ of Defining Australian English’s Many Quirks
abstract: It took a while for Australians to appreciate their linguistic distinctiveness. The editors at the Australian National Dictionary Center work to document it.
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — Amanda Laugesen scrolled through the spreadsheet of 7,000 words and idioms being considered for the next edition of the Australian National Dictionary, but no matter how hard she looked, she just couldn’t find the phrase.

headline: A Rebranded ‘92NY’ Is Getting a Long-Awaited Renovation
abstract: After a lengthy closure during the pandemic, the Upper East Side institution has begun the first major phase of a $200 million plan to redevelop its campus.
lead_paragraph: Changes are afoot at the 92nd Street Y. For starters, that’s not technically its name anymore.

headline: National Juneteenth Museum Takes Shape in Fort Worth
abstract: The brainchild of Opal Lee, the institution will be part of an economic development project aimed at revitalizing the city’s Historic Southside neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, at 89, Opal Lee walked from her home in Fort Worth to Washington, D.C., to help get Juneteenth made a federal holiday, which it finally was in 2021. And for nearly 20 years, she has operated a modest Juneteenth Museum in a property on Rosedale Street, which also served as a filming location for the 2020 movie “Miss Juneteenth.”

headline: As the Colombian presidential race tightens, the two candidates turn up their attacks.
abstract: The two candidates competing to become Colombia’s next president — Gustavo Petro, a leftist and a former insurgent, and Rodolfo Hernández, a wealthy businessman — are not known for pulling punches.
lead_paragraph: The two candidates competing to become Colombia’s next president — Gustavo Petro, a leftist and a former insurgent, and Rodolfo Hernández, a wealthy businessman — are not known for pulling punches.

headline: Ataques, rumores y acusaciones en una contienda muy reñida por la presidencia
abstract: Los dos candidatos que compiten para ser el próximo presidente de Colombia —Gustavo Petro, un izquierdista y ex insurgente, y Rodolfo Hernández, un próspero empresario— no son conocidos por andarse con rodeos.
lead_paragraph: Los dos candidatos que compiten para ser el próximo presidente de Colombia —Gustavo Petro, un izquierdista y ex insurgente, y Rodolfo Hernández, un próspero empresario— no son conocidos por andarse con rodeos.

headline: At Cliburn Competition, Pianists From South Korea, Russia and Ukraine Triumph
abstract: The war in Ukraine loomed over the prestigious contest in Texas, named for the pianist Van Cliburn, who won a victory in Moscow at the height of the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: For 17 days, the young artists competed in what some have called the Olympics of piano-playing: the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition in Texas, one of classical music’s most prestigious contests.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Peanut butter-glazed salmon, chicken Caprese, fried egg quesadillas and more recipes to make very soon.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I had some wild salmon thawing in the refrigerator and was all set for Sunday supper: peanut butter-glazed salmon and green beans (above). Peanut butter is a smart shortcut ingredient, used to anchor the savory five-ingredient sauce. But then a neighbor stopped by with some tuna he’d caught 55 miles off Brooklyn in the blazing sun: a couple of collars, some loin, some scrapings for tuna tartare. I thanked him and came up with a new plan. (But you should make that salmon tonight.)

headline: How Churches Can Do Better at Responding to Sexual Abuse
abstract: “We often have a very twisted understanding of authority and unity, and it is wielded in a way that keeps whistle-blowers silent.”
lead_paragraph: In May, a third-party investigation into the Southern Baptist Convention, the largest Protestant denomination in the United States, concluded that some former members of its top leadership committee, along with outside counsel, “closely guarded information about abuse allegations and lawsuits” and “were singularly focused on avoiding liability.”

headline: Transgender Women in the Sports World
abstract: The debate over whether they have physical advantages that make athletic competitions unfair. Also: Homeowners’ rights; marriages, happy and not.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Scenes from the polls as Rodolfo Hernández and Gustavo Petro cast their ballots.
abstract: Rodolfo Hernández, a construction magnate-and former mayor who has emerged as a surprise candidate in Colombia’s presidential election, has been largely absent from public life in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: Rodolfo Hernández, a construction magnate-and former mayor who has emerged as a surprise candidate in Colombia’s presidential election, has been largely absent from public life in recent weeks.

headline: Germany will fire up coal plants again in an effort to save natural gas.
abstract: It was one of a series of measures announced by Germany’s economy minister, as Europe takes steps to deal with reduced energy supplies from Russia.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany will restart coal-fired power plants in order to conserve natural gas, the country’s economy minister announced on Sunday, amid concerns about a looming supply shortage after Russia cut gas deliveries to Europe this week.

headline: Establishment conservatives quickly aligned with Hernández after his unexpected second-place win.
abstract: “Today the country of politicking and corruption lost,” Rodolfo Hernández, a right-wing anti-establishment candidate, said in a video message to his supporters, following the first-round election results in May that put him in second place behind Gustavo Petro.
lead_paragraph: “Today the country of politicking and corruption lost,” Rodolfo Hernández, a right-wing anti-establishment candidate, said in a video message to his supporters, following the first-round election results in May that put him in second place behind Gustavo Petro.

headline: ‘Lightyear’ Opens at No. 2, as ‘Jurassic World’ Holds Strong
abstract: The Pixar movie’s estimated $51 million in North American sales fell short of expectations.
lead_paragraph: Buzz Lightyear failed to reach box office hyperspace over the weekend. But it was unclear why.

headline: The far right wins a record number of seats.
abstract: The party of Marine Le Pen secured enough seats to form a parliamentary group, giving it more clout, for the first time in four decades.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French far right was projected to win a record number of seats in the election on Sunday, which could make it the third biggest political force in Parliament. It will also secure enough seats to form a parliamentary group for the first time since the 1980s, reflecting its solid political foothold and highlighting the success of Marine Le Pen’s longtime efforts to moderate her party’s image.

headline: FINA Restricts Transgender Women From Competing at Elite Level
abstract: The international swimming federation said transgender women who had experienced male puberty could not compete in women’s events.
lead_paragraph: The world governing body for swimming effectively barred transgender women from the highest levels of women’s international competition on Sunday, intensifying a debate over gender and sports that has roiled state legislatures and increasingly divided parents, athletes and coaches at all levels.

headline: Francia Márquez — a former housekeeper and activist — is Colombia’s first Black vice president.
abstract: Ms. Márquez’s biting analysis of social disparities cracked open a discussion about race and class in a manner rarely heard in the country’s powerful political circles.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in Colombia’s history, a Black woman is close to the top of the executive branch.

headline: Francia Márquez, activista y ex empleada doméstica, es la vicepresidenta de Colombia
abstract: Márquez llamó la atención hacia las disparidades del país y abrió una franca discusión nacional sobre el racismo y el clasismo, asuntos que rara vez se tocan en los círculos políticos del poder.
lead_paragraph: Por primera vez en la historia de Colombia, una mujer afrocolombiana está cerca de la cima del poder ejecutivo.

headline: Heat Wave to Shift East After Posing Dangerous Conditions in the Plains
abstract: More than 15 million people in the Northern and Central Plains were under heat alerts on Sunday, the National Weather Service said.
lead_paragraph: Heat continues to build in the Northern and Central Plains of the United States, with more than 15 million people there under heat alerts on Sunday. Temperatures in Minnesota and Nebraska were expected to climb to the triple digits.

headline: Ukraine rushes troops to reinforce its faltering defense of Sievierodonetsk.
abstract: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — Russian forces mounted an assault on Sunday against a key Ukrainian defensive position near two strategically important eastern cities, Ukrainian military officials said, bringing them a small step closer to encircling thousands of Ukrainian troops.
lead_paragraph: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — Russian forces mounted an assault on Sunday against a key Ukrainian defensive position near two strategically important eastern cities, Ukrainian military officials said, bringing them a small step closer to encircling thousands of Ukrainian troops.

headline: Drake Rebuilt Hip-Hop in His Image. Now He Wants You to Dance.
abstract: On his seventh album, “Honestly, Nevermind,” the pop disrupter who rethought rap’s relationship with melody opts for a new direction: nightclub abandon.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, the Drake factory has been operating at full capacity — recalibrating the relationship between hip-hop, R&B and pop; balancing grand-scale ambition with granular experimentation; embracing the meme-ification of his celebrity. But in recent years, for the first time, it’s felt like the machines might be grinding to a pause. Maintaining the throne is hard work, and the wear and tear were beginning to show.

headline: Over 200 Feared Dead in Ethiopia Massacre
abstract: The killings were the latest to roil the Horn of Africa nation, which is reeling from a civil war that began almost two years ago.
lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — An Ethiopian rebel group massacred more than 200 members of the Amhara ethnic group on Sunday, according to officials and news reports, the latest atrocity amid a civil war that threatens to tear apart Africa’s second-most-populous nation.

headline: ‘God’s Fool’ Review: A Singing, Beat Poet Saint
abstract: In Martha Clarke’s piece about St. Francis of Assisi, at La MaMa’s Ellen Stewart Theater, the song carries the dance.
lead_paragraph: The life of St. Francis of Assisi was a dramatic one. The child of a wealthy Italian merchant, he had a 12th-century playboy youth, went to war and spent a year in captivity. He had mystical visions, stole from his disapproving father to give to the church and devoted himself to a life of poverty in imitation of Christ, founding a religious order. He saw God in nature, thanking the sun, preaching to birds — setting an example of equality and ecology followed by many, including the current Pope.

headline: New York Firefighter Dies in North Carolina After Tree Falls on Car
abstract: An accident during a windstorm at the Biltmore Estate killed Casey Skudin, a decorated firefighter who had been driving with his family.
lead_paragraph: A decorated New York firefighter was killed in a freakish accident at a tourist attraction in North Carolina after a tree fell on the S.U.V. that he and his family had been riding in, according to his family.

headline: Children of Ukraine’s fallen soldiers spend Father’s Day in new grief.
abstract: As the war’s death toll continues to climb, families mourn the losses of fathers-turned-soldiers.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — In the heat of the late afternoon sun, Oksana Stepanenko’s sweat mingled with the tears streaming down her face as she rearranged the flowers on her husband’s grave.

headline: Russian Forces Tighten Noose Around Important Cities in Ukraine’s East
abstract: The area around Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk is about three-quarters encircled by Russians, leaving only a slender gap there for Ukrainian troops to maneuver.
lead_paragraph: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — Russian forces appeared poised to tighten the noose around thousands of Ukrainian troops near two strategically important cities in the fiercely contested Donbas region of eastern Ukraine on Sunday, mounting an assault on Ukrainian front lines that forced Ukraine to rush reinforcements to the area.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Makes Slow Gains in the Donbas Region
abstract: Also, France’s president lost a majority in Parliament and Colombians voted for their next leader.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces mounted an assault on Sunday against Toshkivka, a key Ukrainian defensive position near Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, highlighting Ukraine’s faltering defense of two of the last cities in the Luhansk province of the Donbas region that are not yet under Russian control.

headline: Review: ‘The Ordering of Moses’ Shines at Riverside Church
abstract: The Harlem Chamber Players presented R. Nathaniel Dett’s 1937 oratorio in honor of the centennial of the Harlem Renaissance, for the Juneteenth weekend.
lead_paragraph: The Harlem Chamber Players offered a rare, heartfelt performance of R. Nathaniel Dett’s 1937 oratorio “The Ordering of Moses” at Riverside Church on Friday, as part of a centennial celebration of the Harlem Renaissance that had been delayed by the pandemic.

headline: Paul Haggis Arrested on Sexual Assault Charges in Italy
abstract: Haggis, who wrote and directed the Oscar-winning crime drama “Crash,” was accused of assaulting a woman in Ostuni over the course of two days.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar-winning director and writer Paul Haggis was arrested on charges of aggravated sexual violence and aggravated personal injuries in the Southern Italian city of Ostuni on Sunday, according to the local police.

headline: New Yorkers Honor a Thriving Black Village Displaced by Central Park
abstract: On Juneteenth, a commemoration tells the story of Seneca Village, which was pushed out when the park was created in the 1850s.
lead_paragraph: Before the Civil War, a predominantly Black community flourished in Seneca Village, on the land that is now Central Park.

headline: Beginnerish
abstract: Christopher Youngs’s puzzle is a good place for a newbie to start solving.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Monday, Wordplay readers! Today we have a puzzle from Christopher Youngs, less than a month after his last appearance, that is sure to please demographers and baseball fans alike.

headline: Before he was a politician, Gustavo Petro was part of an urban guerrilla group.
abstract: Petro belonged to M-19, born in 1970 as a response to alleged fraud in that year’s presidential elections. It was far smaller than the country’s main guerrilla force, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.
lead_paragraph: Long before Gustavo Petro emerged as the apparently victorious leftist candidate for president, he was part of the M-19, an urban guerrilla group that sought to seize power through violence in the name of promoting social justice.

headline: Antes de dedicarse a la política, Petro formó parte de una guerrilla urbana
abstract: Gustavo Petro perteneció al M-19, surgido en 1970 en respuesta a un supuesto fraude en las elecciones presidenciales de ese año. Era más pequeño que la principal fuerza guerrillera del país, las FARC.
lead_paragraph: Mucho antes de que Gustavo Petro surgiera como un candidato de izquierda a la presidencia de Colombia, fue parte del M-19, un grupo guerrillero urbano que buscaba hacerse del poder en nombre de la justicia social.

headline: Macron Loses Absolute Majority as Opposition Surges, a Blow for New Term
abstract: For the first time in 20 years, a newly-elected French president failed to win an absolute majority in Parliament, forcing President Macron to deal with a defiant left and a resurgent far-right.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Voters in France’s legislative elections dealt President Emmanuel Macron a serious blow on Sunday as his centrist coalition lost its absolute majority in the lower house of Parliament to a resurgent far-right and a defiant alliance of left-wing parties, complicating his domestic agenda for his second term.

headline: Two Cast Members of ‘The Chosen One’ on Netflix Killed in Accident
abstract: The accident happened in transit to a local airport in Baja California Sur in Mexico. Six other cast and crew members were injured, Netflix confirmed.
lead_paragraph: Two cast members of the Netflix show “The Chosen One” died after an accident on Thursday in Baja California Sur, Mexico, that left six other cast and crew members injured, Netflix said.

headline: Arizona Wildfire Destroys Observatory Buildings
abstract: The Contreras fire has disrupted the work of astronomers, though the observatory’s scientific equipment remains safe for now.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers watched in fear over the past week as a growing wildfire crept up an Arizona mountainside toward the Kitt Peak National Observatory, forcing 40 people to evacuate days before the blaze destroyed four buildings early Friday morning.

headline: At U.S. Open, Matt Fitzpatrick’s First PGA Tour Win Comes at a Major
abstract: Will Zalatoris and Scottie Scheffler, who tied for second, made it interesting down the stretch at the Country Club, but Fitzpatrick held on to finish at six under par.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — This year’s U.S. Open began as the setting for an unprecedented showdown between golfers who had remained loyal to the established PGA Tour and a breakaway pack of ex-colleagues who recently joined the new, rebel Saudi-backed LIV Golf series. But the anticipated confrontation at the Country Club outside Boston fizzled in the first round on Thursday when golfers from both camps got along without friction.

headline: Collin Morikawa Descends, Then Climbs, the U.S. Open Leaderboard
abstract: Morikawa shared the lead after the second round and looked poised to vie for his third major championship. A 77 in the third round took him out of contention, but he closed the tournament strong.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — Midway through the U.S. Open, Collin Morikawa stood atop the leaderboard looking to add a third major championship to his résumé.

headline: Texas Republicans Approve Far-Right Platform Declaring Biden’s Election Illegitimate
abstract: The platform, which was voted on at the Republican state party convention in Houston, was the latest sign of Texas conservatives moving further to the right.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party in Texas made a series of far-right declarations as part of its official party platform over the weekend, claiming that President Biden was not legitimately elected, issuing a “rebuke” to Senator John Cornyn for his work on bipartisan gun legislation and referring to homosexuality as “an abnormal lifestyle choice.”

headline: Ukraine bans some Russian music and books.
abstract: The Ukrainian Parliament voted to ban some Russian media and sent two bills to President Zelensky to sign.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s Parliament voted to ban the distribution of Russian books and the playing or performance of Russian music by post-Soviet-era artists, the latest display of Kyiv fiercely distancing itself from Russian culture.

headline: Gustavo Petro Wins the Election, Becoming Colombia’s First Leftist Leader
abstract: The former rebel and longtime senator’s victory sets the third largest nation in Latin America on a sharply new path.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — For the first time, Colombia will have a leftist president.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Russia’s brutal campaign to capture Sievierodonetsk.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces mounted an assault on Sunday against Toshkivka, a key Ukrainian defensive position near Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk. The fight highlighted Ukraine’s faltering defense of two of the last cities in Luhansk Province of the Donbas region that are not yet under Russian control.

headline: In N.H.L. Finals, Avalanche Go From Chaser to Front-Runner
abstract: In taking a 2-0 series lead against the two-time defending champion Tampa Bay Lightning in the Stanley Cup finals, Colorado’s complete ascension to the top of the league is within reach.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals was described as the challenger catching up to the reigning champion. In Game 2, the challenger flew right on past.

headline: He Saw. He Believed. Now He Can Be an N.B.A. Star.
abstract: The former Duke center Mark Williams is expected to be picked at the N.B.A. draft this week. He’s quickly learning what going pro really means.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The training drill is named after LeBron James. Most people would be better off if they just let him do it.

headline: ‘We Want to Know Whose Brain Is Healing and Why’
abstract: In a study, Dr. Jennifer Coughlin observed brain activity that may help predict the onset of trauma-related illnesses and cognitive decline. N.F.L. players are helping to further her research.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Jonathan Martin believes he’s doing most things right.

headline: New Brand of Activist Takes Aim at Ukraine War and Climate Crisis, Together
abstract: Led by young women from Eastern Europe, they are cornering Europe’s leaders and pressing them for a total energy embargo on Russia — to end the fighting and to save the planet.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Emmanuel Macron, the president of France, had just finished a speech at a major conference on Europe.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Gun Proposals Rely on a Vast, Flawed System
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 20, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like going to the airport and being told that some people have to go through security and some don’t.”

headline: No Corrections: June 20, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 20, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: 15-Year-Old Is Killed and 3 Are Shot in Gunfire at D.C. Music Festival
abstract: The police had shut down the event, known as Moechella, a free street festival that they said was unauthorized, after previous disturbances.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old boy was killed and three adults, including a police officer, were shot when gunfire erupted Sunday night at an unauthorized music event in a Washington, D.C., neighborhood known for its nightlife, the authorities said.

headline: Surviving Russia’s ‘Filtration Camps’
abstract: Thousands of refugees from Ukraine have been sent to so-called filtration camps, where they have been interrogated and then forced to resettle to Russia. Some Ukrainians escaped to Estonia. They told us their stories.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of refugees from Ukraine have been sent to so-called filtration camps, where they have been interrogated and then forced to resettle to Russia. Some Ukrainians escaped to Estonia. They told us their stories.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: The Stanley Cup Finals and ‘Chernobyl: The Lost Tapes’
abstract: The Tampa Bay Lightning battles the Colorado Avalanche for the Stanley Cup. And HBO airs a new documentary about the Chernobyl disaster.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 20-26. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: A new brand of activist takes aim at the Ukraine war and the climate crisis, together.
abstract: BRUSSELS — Emmanuel Macron, the president of France, had just finished a speech at a major conference on Europe.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Emmanuel Macron, the president of France, had just finished a speech at a major conference on Europe.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: When Customers Say Their Money Was Stolen on Zelle, Banks Often Refuse to Pay
abstract: Federal law requires banks to reimburse customers for unauthorized electronic transfers, but they often refuse, stranding victims.
lead_paragraph: Argelys Oriach was on his way home from a shopping trip one evening in March when he was robbed at gunpoint. The thief demanded his iPhone and passcode. Mr. Oriach turned them over and fled.

headline: With Roe Set to End, Many Women Worry About High-Risk Pregnancies
abstract: Most states likely to outlaw abortions allow for exceptions to save a mother’s life. But many women and doctors ask: Where will lawmakers draw the line?
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the latest abortion news and the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

headline: China’s Once-Sizzling Property Market Has Started to Cool
abstract: New home prices in China have fallen, and would-be buyers are thinking twice. That’s bad news for the overall economy.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, business was humming for Liang Jiawei, a property salesman in Zhanjiang, a coastal city in southern China.

headline: Sisters Divided by China’s Divisions
abstract: Zhuqing Li’s “Daughters of the Flower Fragrant Garden” tells the story of a family ripped apart by the Communist victory in China.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1949, young Chen Wenjun (“Jun”) stepped off a ferry in Jinmen, an island off the coast of southeastern China. She did not know that the Communists’ People’s Liberation Army (P.L.A.) had occupied Fuzhou, her home city, the night after she left. But in Jinmen, the anti-Communist Nationalists held their territory. None of the 9,000 P.L.A. soldiers who fought on Jinmen’s beaches made it back home. Neither did Jun, who now effectively lived in a different country from her family. Jun’s short visit to a friend quickly became a long exile.

headline: ‘The Senate Needs a Soul’
abstract: Senator Raphael Warnock discusses the Jan. 6 hearings, Georgia politics and his history-making journey to the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Raphael Warnock claims he’s not a politician, though he certainly sounds like one and serves as one. The U.S. senator from Georgia, who has long been the pastor at Martin Luther King Jr.’s former church, says that his “entry into politics is an extension” of his work on a range of what he sees as moral issues, such as health care, criminal-justice reform and voting rights.

headline: Pregnancy, Guns and Politics in Alabama
abstract: Republicans and Democrats both seem to forget they represent people like me, too.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN, Ala. — I’m a left-leaning Democrat, but on May 24, I voted on the Republican ballot in Alabama’s primary election. The state’s primaries are open, which means Democrats can request a Republican ballot and vice versa. Alabama is a deep red state, and I wanted some say in electing the officials who will represent me, because they will almost all certainly be Republican.

headline: The Supreme Court, Public Opinion and the Fate of Roe
abstract: According to the conventional wisdom, the court rarely strays too far from the popular will. That view will face a reckoning in the coming weeks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, it has long been said, seldom gets very far out of step with public opinion.

headline: How Animals See Themselves
abstract: The most familiar of settings can feel newly unfamiliar through the senses of other creatures.
lead_paragraph: Spectacle floods into my eyes whenever I watch a wildlife documentary. A vortex of small fish is gradually picked off by waves of oceanic predators. Snakes chase after marine iguanas. Giraffes clash at sunset.

headline: How Real-Life and Fictional Horror Seeped Into ‘The Black Phone’
abstract: Influenced by “Rosemary’s Baby” and “The Devil’s Backbone,” the filmmaker wove details from his childhood into this supernatural movie starring Ethan Hawke.
lead_paragraph: After scoring a hit with the Marvel movie “Doctor Strange” in 2016, the director Scott Derrickson started working on its sequel, “Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness.” In January 2020, however, he abruptly left that movie because of creative differences.

headline: Mike Pence Was of Two Minds
abstract: The man who stood up to Trump is the man who didn’t stand up to Trump.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, I never did like Mike Pence at all — his far-right social values would have turned me off even if he didn’t call his wife “Mother.”

headline: Despite Another Covid Surge, Deaths Stay Near Lows
abstract: Most Americans now carry some immune protection, experts said, whether from vaccines, infection or both.
lead_paragraph: For two years, the coronavirus killed Americans on a brutal, predictable schedule: A few weeks after infections climbed so did deaths, cutting an unforgiving path across the country.

headline: Prosecute Trump? Put Yourself in Merrick Garland’s Shoes.
abstract: The attorney general will have to make three decisions, each more difficult than the previous and none with an obvious answer.
lead_paragraph: The evidence gathered by the Jan. 6 committee and in some of the federal cases against those involved in the Capitol attack poses for Attorney General Merrick Garland one of the most consequential questions that any attorney general has ever faced: Should the United States indict former President Donald Trump?

headline: Washington Might Be About to Do Something Right for America’s Wildlife
abstract: An “unthinkable level of bipartisan support” may just lead to a win for species in peril.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The media hasn’t paid much attention to the Recovering America’s Wildlife Act. With a war raging in Ukraine, a domestic economy in tumult, an attempted coup being explicated on national television, a virus that keeps evolving and a devastating heat wave enveloping parts of the United States and Europe, that’s not surprising. But this landmark legislation, known in conservation circles as RAWA, is poised to become the single most effective tool in combating biodiversity loss since the Endangered Species Act.

headline: Google Says It’s Time for Longtime Small-Business Users to Pay Up
abstract: Google is charging some small businesses for email and other apps after more than a decade of free use. Business owners say Google is being callous.
lead_paragraph: When Google told some small businesses in January that they would no longer be able to use a customized email service and other workplace apps for free, it felt like a broken promise for Richard J. Dalton Jr., a longtime user who operates a scholastic test-prep company in Vancouver, British Columbia.

headline: Red Flags for Forced Labor Found in China’s Car Battery Supply Chain
abstract: Ties to potentially coercive labor practices could prove a problem for an industry that is heavily dependent on China, once a new law barring Xinjiang products goes into effect.
lead_paragraph: The photograph on the mining conglomerate’s social media account showed 70 ethnic Uyghur workers standing at attention under the flag of the People’s Republic of China. It was March 2020 and the recruits would soon undergo training in management, etiquette and “loving the party and the country,” their new employer, the Xinjiang Nonferrous Metal Industry Group, announced.

headline: The Man Behind Fashion’s Most Famous Bob
abstract: Being Anna Wintour’s hairstylist may sound glamorous, but it’s his art practice that gets Andreas Anastasis talking.
lead_paragraph: For the past six years, at 8 a.m. sharp, Andreas Anastasis has walked to Anna Wintour’s Greenwich Village townhouse, where for about 20 minutes every weekday he maintains upkeep, whether it’s cutting, coloring, spraying, blow-drying or styling, of the most instantly recognizable bob in fashion — maybe the world. A short distance from there, “right across the street from Carrie Bradshaw’s house,” he has spent nearly a decade running his namesake salon, where he now works two days a week. The only magazine in the waiting area is Vogue.

headline: Failed Autopsies, False Arrests: A Risk of Bias in Death Examinations
abstract: Disastrous errors by medical examiners have raised questions about whether they are influenced by prejudgments and a close relationship with the police.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Incredible Journey of Three African Wild Dogs
abstract: Three sisters braved lions, crocodiles, poachers, raging rivers and other dangers on a 1,300-mile transnational effort to forge a new dynasty.
lead_paragraph: The three sisters knew they had to leave home. They were African wild dogs, elite predators of the sub-Saharan region and among the most endangered mammals on Earth. At 3 years old, they were in the prime of their vigor, ferocity and buoyant, pencil-limbed indifference to gravity. If they did not seize the chance to trade the security of their birth pack for new opportunities elsewhere, they might well die as they had lived: as subordinate, self-sacrificing maiden aunts with no offspring of their own.

headline: Celebrating ‘Legends’ Who Catwalk Among Us
abstract: “Legends of Drag: Queens of a Certain Age,” a book out this month, spotlights drag elders.
lead_paragraph: The idea came to Harry James Hanson and Devin Antheus while both were attending “church” — their word to describe a drag show.

headline: A Herd in Exile: Riding Horses on Mozambique’s Bazaruto Archipelago
abstract: A photographer spent a few weeks helping run a horseback riding program on the white-sand beaches of Benguerra Island. Here’s what she saw.
lead_paragraph: With a map in one hand and a cold beer in the other, I sat alone at the bar of the Baobab Beach Backpackers Lodge in the coastal town of Vilankulo, gazing out at the sweeping sandbars and vivid turquoise waters that surround Mozambique’s Bazaruto Archipelago. I’d planned to leave the following morning for Zimbabwe, and I was chatting with the bartender about the logistics of my trip. Then, suddenly, a car’s headlights lit up the bar, and I saw a familiar face heading toward me. I had a feeling my plans were about to change.

headline: The Killing of Shireen Abu Akleh: Tracing a Bullet to an Israeli Convoy
abstract: A New York Times investigation found that the bullet that killed a Palestinian-American journalist was fired from the approximate position of an Israeli military vehicle.
lead_paragraph: JENIN, West Bank — The journalists thought they were safe.

headline: In a Town Crippled by Grief, the Healing Power of a Perfect Pitch
abstract: Uvalde, Texas, was set to cancel its Little League All-Star Championship after a school shooting left 21 people dead. Then, the decision was made: The games would go on.
lead_paragraph: UVALDE, Texas — Young people in their crisp Little League uniforms ran up and down the field in giddy anticipation. The smell of nacho cheese and sizzling chicken fajitas spread through the bleachers on the hot summer night breeze.

headline: Inside One Abortion Clinic, Signs of Nationwide Struggles
abstract: The Planned Parenthood clinic in Fort Myers, Fla., has seen an increase in patients arriving from Texas, even as it struggles to keep up with increasing restrictions in its own state.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — At a Planned Parenthood health center on Florida’s Gulf Coast, new restrictions on who can get an abortion are shaking up routines and creating challenges for the clinic’s patients, doctors and nurses.

headline: Feminism Made a Faustian Bargain With Celebrity Culture. Now It’s Paying the Price.
abstract: How did modern feminism lose Roe v. Wade? An answer lies in Depp v. Heard.
lead_paragraph: One month almost to the day after Americans learned of Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito’s draft opinion that would eviscerate the constitutional right of women to control their bodies and so their lives, millions sat glued to their screens to witness the verdict in the Johnny Depp-Amber Heard defamation trial, in which the jury awarded more than $10 million to Mr. Depp. In a statement afterward, Ms. Heard said she was “disappointed with what this verdict means for women.” “It sets back the clock,” she said, “to a time when a woman who spoke up and spoke out could be publicly shamed and humiliated.”

headline: Are We Sure America Is Not at War in Ukraine?
abstract: If we have so far avoided calling it war, maybe that’s only because we’ve become so uncertain of the meaning of the word.
lead_paragraph: In the more than three months since Russia invaded Ukraine, the Biden administration has said a lot of things about the war. It had to walk a few of them back almost immediately, like when President Biden’s statement that Vladimir Putin “cannot remain in power” turned out not to be a call for regime change. On other points, its rhetoric has sharpened over time: In March, America’s goal was to help Ukraine defend itself; by the end of April it was a “weakened” Russia.

headline: A Wildfire Year
abstract: Three million acres have already burned in the West.
lead_paragraph: The American West is burning more quickly than it has in a decade. New Mexico has been fighting its two biggest wildfires on record for more than a month. About 3 million acres of U.S. land — almost the size of Connecticut — have already burned this year. And with summer starting tomorrow and a widespread heat wave already in place, the burning is likely to get worse.

headline: A Fragmented Parliament Brings Macron Back Down to Earth
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron largely sidelined Parliament during his first term. But now he has lost his absolute majority in the lower house, forcing him to seek compromise with a reinvigorated opposition.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron earned the nickname Jupiter in his first term for his top-down governing style, using the full powers of France’s executive branch and largely ignoring Parliament.

headline: Russia becomes China’s biggest crude-oil supplier as Europe cuts imports.
abstract: Russia surpassed Saudi Arabia to become China’s largest source of petroleum last month, as Chinese companies stepped in to buy oil that has fallen under widening sanctions in the West.
lead_paragraph: Russia surpassed Saudi Arabia to become China’s largest source of petroleum last month, as Chinese companies stepped in to buy oil that has fallen under widening sanctions in the West.

headline: Think All Viruses Get Milder With Time? Not This Rabbit-Killer.
abstract: The myxoma virus, fatal to millions of Australian rabbits, is a textbook example of the unexpected twists in the evolution of viruses and their hosts.
lead_paragraph: As the Covid death rate worldwide has fallen to its lowest level since the early weeks of the pandemic in 2020, it may be tempting to conclude that the coronavirus is becoming irreversibly milder. That notion fits with a widespread belief that all viruses start off nasty and inevitably evolve to become gentler over time.

headline: $2.9 Million Homes in California
abstract: A modern farmhouse in Los Angeles, a Spanish-style home in Kensington and a midcentury-modern retreat in Palm Springs.
lead_paragraph: A modern farmhouse in Los Angeles, a Spanish-style home in Kensington and a midcentury-modern retreat in Palm Springs.

headline: $2.9 Million Homes in California
abstract: A modern farmhouse in Los Angeles, a Spanish-style home in Kensington and a midcentury-modern retreat in Palm Springs.
lead_paragraph: This house sits on a large corner lot in the Sherman Oaks neighborhood, just south of Magnolia Boulevard, the San Fernando Valley thoroughfare that runs east into Burbank. It is in a quiet, residential area less than a five-minute drive from Louis Armstrong Middle School, a public school for students in sixth through eighth grades. Westfield Fashion Square, a popular shopping mall, is also about five minutes away, and the shopping and dining on Ventura Boulevard is just over a mile away.

headline: How Paintings Lost in a Small-Town Art Heist Were Recovered 50 Years Later
abstract: Two sleuths — a curator and a librarian — in New Paltz, N.Y., helped the F.B.I. track down 200-year-old paintings that were stolen from a historical society in 1972.
lead_paragraph: On a Wednesday evening in February 1972, as police officers and emergency responders in New Paltz, N.Y., flocked to a fire, somebody snatched a pair of 19th-century portraits of a wealthy local couple from a historical society elsewhere in town.

headline: Parts of Yellowstone Will Reopen This Week After Damaging Floods
abstract: The National Park Service also said it would spend $50 million on repairs that would restore access to about 80 percent of the park within two weeks.
lead_paragraph: Parts of Yellowstone National Park will reopen to a limited number of visitors on Wednesday, and the National Park Service will spend $50 million to fast-track repair work to restore access to about 80 percent of the park within two weeks, officials said on Sunday.

headline: God and Horses at the Pre-Apocalypse
abstract: The reality of climate change is upon us, but there’s reason for hope.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Take the time for a rewarding crispy fried tofu sandwich, made either on the stovetop or in the oven.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s difficult to imagine a more delicious thing to eat on a Monday night in the second half of June than a crispy fried tofu sandwich (above).

headline: Did You Start Therapy Recently?
abstract: Times Opinion would like to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: An “epidemic” of loneliness. Prolonged grief. Rising levels of anxiety and depression. And that feeling you didn’t have a name for — languishing.

headline: A Giant Stingray May Be the World’s Largest Freshwater Fish
abstract: In the Mekong River in Cambodia, fishers and researchers found a 13-foot-long, 661-pound stingray — a win for conservation efforts in the area.
lead_paragraph: For 17 years, Zeb Hogan, a biologist, has been searching for the world’s largest freshwater fish. On June 13, his team found it — a giant freshwater stingray, or Urogymnus polylepis.

headline: Parents Fearing for Their Children’s Lives
abstract: Parents express fears for their children in a time of mass shootings. Also: The gun bill; famine in East Africa; the irreligious right; college debt.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Joan Shelley’s New Songs Soothe Old Wounds
abstract: As a Kentucky farm kid, the singer and songwriter made music to have a voice in her troubled home. On her new album, “The Spur,” her songs finally process those times.
lead_paragraph: SKYLIGHT, Ky. — The second week of November 2016: Donald Trump was president-elect, and Leonard Cohen was dead. The songwriter Joan Shelley and the guitarist Nathan Salsburg — her collaborator for the better part of a decade and boyfriend for the better part of a year — were the opening act on a tour that suddenly seemed meaningless. They listened to Cohen’s haunted farewell, “You Want It Darker,” on repeat and bickered about the news.

headline: Will Zalatoris, Three-Time Major Runner-Up, Is Getting Impatient
abstract: Zalatoris came close to sending the U.S. Open to a playoff on Sunday, only to finish disappointed once again. “We’re talking inches,” he says.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — As his putt approached the hole on the 18th green on Sunday evening, Will Zalatoris thought he was headed to a thrilling playoff that would determine the U.S. Open champion. All the ball had to do was drop and Zalatoris and Matt Fitzpatrick would settle things in a two-hole playoff.

headline: BTS’s ‘Proof’ Opens at No. 1 as the K-Pop Powerhouse Takes a Break
abstract: The boy band’s new compilation marks its sixth time atop the Billboard 200 chart. The group’s seven members will focus on solo projects.
lead_paragraph: On June 10, the K-pop powerhouse BTS released a three-disc compilation album, “Proof.” It was sure to be a hit, and this week it opens at No. 1 on the Billboard 200 album chart, with the equivalent of 314,000 sales in the United States, according to the tracking service Luminate.

headline: Hear the stories of Ukrainians who were forcibly resettled to Russia and escaped.
abstract: Since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, thousands of refugees from Ukraine have been sent to so-called filtration camps, where they have been interrogated and then forced to resettle to Russia.
lead_paragraph: Since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, thousands of refugees from Ukraine have been sent to so-called filtration camps, where they have been interrogated and then forced to resettle to Russia.

headline: Israel’s Government Collapses, Setting Up 5th Election in 3 Years
abstract: The governing coalition decided to dissolve Parliament, plunging the country back into paralysis and throwing a political lifeline to Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s governing coalition will dissolve Parliament before the end of the month, bringing down the government and sending the country to a fifth election in three years, the prime minister said on Monday.

headline: ‘Hooded; or Being Black for Dummies’ Review: A Tragic Pageantry
abstract: Tearrance Arvelle Chisholm’s ambitious and sometimes metaphysical comedy playfully tries to tackle thorny issues at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: What defines Blackness? The idea that there might be a clear answer is absurd. But skin color is all it takes to land two diametrically opposed teenagers in the same jail cell. In the eyes of the law, at least, the connotations of race are obvious.

headline: In Ad, Shotgun-Toting Greitens Asks Voters to Go ‘RINO Hunting’
abstract: A right-wing Senate candidate accompanies a squad of heavily armed men as they storm a home looking for ‘Republicans in name only.’
lead_paragraph: Eric Greitens, a Republican candidate for the United States Senate in Missouri, released a violent new political advertisement on Monday showing himself racking a shotgun and accompanying a team of men armed with assault rifles as they stormed — SWAT team-style — into a home in search of “RINOs,” or Republicans in name only.

headline: Grenfell Tower Still Stands. So Do Questions About What to Do With It.
abstract: Five years ago a fast-moving blaze in the London high-rise left 72 people dead and the building a shell. Some want to see it torn down, but others feel it should remain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The blackened walls of Grenfell Tower, wrapped in white plastic, still cast their shadow over the surrounding neighborhood in West London, five years after the fire that killed 72 people. What to do with the 220-foot structure — or what to build in its place — is one of the tragedy’s many unresolved issues.

headline: Russia steps up bombardments of Kharkiv, where Ukraine had pushed back its forces.
abstract: KYIV, Ukraine — Shelling in and around Ukraine’s second largest city, Kharkiv, has grown worse, weeks after Ukrainian fighters pushed Russian forces back from the northeastern city.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Shelling in and around Ukraine’s second largest city, Kharkiv, has grown worse, weeks after Ukrainian fighters pushed Russian forces back from the northeastern city.

headline: The Life of Jean Rhys, a Uniquely Brilliant and Thorny Writer
abstract: Miranda Seymour’s “I Used to Live Here Once” is a biography of the author of “Wide Sargasso Sea,” who had a talent for facing hard truths.
lead_paragraph: Like George Orwell, Thomas Hardy and W.H. Auden, the British novelist Jean Rhys did not want to be the subject of a biography and took steps to muddy her trail. Rhys destroyed many letters; she tore sections from journals; throughout her life she maintained, in the words of Miranda Seymour, her latest biographer, a “maddening discretion.”

headline: Israel Confirms Regional Military Project, Showing Its Growing Role
abstract: The Israeli defense minister, Benny Gantz, said Israel was working with other countries in the Middle East to combat Iranian military threats.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government confirmed on Monday that it is part of a regional military partnership to combat threats from Iran, in the latest example of Israel’s growing engagement with some Arab governments and the recalibration of Middle Eastern alliances.

headline: 5 British Men Released by Taliban as U.K. Expresses Regret
abstract: Britain apologized for “any breach of Afghan culture, customs or laws” by the detainees and said their travel to Afghanistan was “a mistake.”
lead_paragraph: The Afghan government has released five British citizens from custody, British officials said Monday in a statement that included an apology on behalf of the men and an expression of regret from the U.K. government.

headline: Taxi Jumps Curb, Critically Injuring 3 People in Manhattan
abstract: The accident happened in the Flatiron district, a neighborhood packed with hotels, bars and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Three people were in critical condition on Monday afternoon after a taxi jumped the sidewalk in Manhattan’s Flatiron district. The driver hit a cyclist and several pedestrians with his vehicle, the authorities said.

headline: Dutch Government Activates ‘Early Warning’ Because of Russian Cutbacks on Gas
abstract: The government will allow more burning of coal to generate electricity as gas supplies tighten.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch government said on Monday that Russia’s tightening of gas supplies to Europe had prompted it to declare an “early warning” stage of a natural gas crisis, a move that will allow more electric power to be generated by burning coal.

headline: Russia’s blockade of Ukraine’s food exports is a ‘war crime,’ says the E.U.’s foreign policy chief.
abstract: The war is contributing to global food shortages and rising prices, and the United Nations warns of possible famine. Ukraine is usually a major grain exporter.
lead_paragraph: The Black Sea blockade that is preventing Ukraine from exporting food and other goods is a “war crime” and Russia will be held accountable if it continues, the European Union’s foreign policy chief, Josep Borrell Fontelles, said on Monday.

headline: Juneteenth Reminds Us to Think About Economic Freedom, Not Just Legal Liberty
abstract: Who is fully free, who is partly free, and who is not free at all?
lead_paragraph: For African Americans, the end of legalized slavery in the United States was the beginning of freedom — but only the beginning. The incompleteness of their liberation is clear in the proclamation by a Union general in Galveston, Texas, on June 19, 1865, which is remembered on America’s newest federal holiday, Juneteenth National Independence Day.

headline: In a Parallel Universe, Another You
abstract: As they probe the secrets of the cosmos, scientists question whether our reality is but one in a multiverse.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: The Mystery of Fleet Street: An Article on Boris Johnson Vanishes
abstract: What happened to a story published in The Times of London that was critical of Prime Minister Boris Johnson? The disappearance has London’s media world guessing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The most talked-about article in the British newspapers last weekend was one that featured juicy allegations of love, ambition and thwarted corruption at the pinnacle of the British government. Then it vanished abruptly from the pages of The Times of London in the early hours of Saturday.

headline: Harlem Shooting Kills 1 and Wounds 8 Amid Violent Weekend Across the Country
abstract: While massacres like those in Buffalo and Uvalde are much publicized, lower-profile attacks exact a dreadful toll.
lead_paragraph: Just after midnight on Father’s Day, a volley of gunshots crackled around 135th Street and Harlem River Drive, violently punctuating an otherwise beautiful holiday at a popular summer picnicking area.

headline: Dr. Paul M. Ellwood Jr., Architect of the H.M.O., Is Dead at 95
abstract: Often called the father of the health maintenance organization, he coined the term in 1970, envisioning a system that would compete for patients by providing the best care at the lowest price.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Paul M. Ellwood Jr., who changed the way millions of Americans receive private medical services by developing — and naming — the model for managed care known as the health maintenance organization, died on Monday in Bellingham, Wash. He was 95.

headline: In pictures: The flaming ruin left by a strike, one of thousands near the eastern front.
abstract: Ukrainian soldiers at a military depot after it was hit by at least one projectile on Monday night, in the eastern town of Druzhkivka. At least two Ukrainian soldiers were wounded in the strike on Druzhkivka, about 20 miles from the front lines.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian soldiers at a military depot after it was hit by at least one projectile on Monday night, in the eastern town of Druzhkivka. At least two Ukrainian soldiers were wounded in the strike on Druzhkivka, about 20 miles from the front lines.

headline: Ruinous Flooding in India and Bangladesh Kills at Least 116
abstract: In regions of the two countries still reeling from flooding in May, monsoon rains brought more misery, with hundreds of thousands of people evacuated and communications cut.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Heavy monsoon rains in India and Bangladesh have flooded an airport and knocked down cellphone towers, bridges and power lines, cutting off communications for millions of people and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of thousands.

headline: A Russian official says Ukraine hit drilling rigs in the Black Sea.
abstract: Ukraine has struck three Russian drilling rigs in the northwestern Black Sea, a Russian official said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has struck three Russian drilling rigs in the northwestern Black Sea, a Russian official said on Monday.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Israel’s Governing Coalition Collapses
abstract: Also, forced labor is found in China’s battery supply and Colombia elects a new president.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s governing coalition will vote to dissolve Parliament before the end of the month, the prime minister’s office said, sending the country into its fifth election in three years.

headline: Pence Navigates a Possible White House Run, and a Fraught Political Moment
abstract: In a speech on Monday, former Vice President Mike Pence sounded like a future presidential candidate, but not like someone interested in discussing the specifics of Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence has emerged from the Jan. 6 hearings in a peculiar position.

headline: Lennie Rosenbluth, Who Led North Carolina to a Title, Dies at 89
abstract: With a starting lineup of New Yorkers, the undefeated Tarheels beat a Kansas team led by Wilt Chamberlain in triple overtime to win the 1957 N.C.A.A. championship.
lead_paragraph: Lennie Rosenbluth, the All-America forward who led a North Carolina team with a starting lineup of New Yorkers to an unbeaten season and a thrilling victory over Wilt Chamberlain’s Kansas squad in the 1957 N.C.A.A. basketball tournament championship game, died on Saturday. He was 89.

headline: The Kremlin says two captured American fighters are ‘soldiers of fortune’ not protected by the rules of war.
abstract: Moscow says the Americans who fought for Ukraine are not regular soldiers who would be covered by the Geneva Conventions, calling their conduct criminal.
lead_paragraph: The Kremlin’s chief spokesman told NBC News on Monday that two American fighters who went missing in Ukraine, Alex Drueke, 39, and Andy Tai Ngoc Huynh, 27, were “soldiers of fortune,” and had been taken into custody. The spokesman also claimed that the two men were not protected by the Geneva Conventions as prisoners of war.

headline: ‘We Are Not Safe’: Ethiopians Flee Massacre That Killed Hundreds
abstract: The massacre in Oromia, the nation’s largest region, came as the country grappled with a grueling civil war and the worst drought in decades.
lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — For decades, the village had been a sanctuary for the families, who tilled the land and cared for their herds in Ethiopia’s largest region.

headline: Biden Says He Is Considering Seeking a Gas Tax Holiday
abstract: With regular gasoline around $5 per gallon, suspending the federal gas tax would provide a measure of relief for consumers, but Congress would need to take action.
lead_paragraph: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del. — President Biden said on Monday that he was considering seeking a gas tax holiday to ease high fuel prices, a major political dilemma for the White House as it struggles to address record inflation.

headline: Clela Rorex, Clerk Who Broke a Gay-Marriage Barrier, Dies at 78
abstract: In 1975 she issued a gay couple a license to marry in Colorado, becoming a hero to some and an object of hate for others.
lead_paragraph: Clela Rorex, who made headlines in 1975 when, as the Boulder County clerk in Colorado, she issued a marriage license to a gay couple, one of the first to do so in the nation, died on Sunday at a hospice center in Longmont, Colo. She was 78.

headline: In a Return to the Land, Tribes Will Jointly Manage a National Monument
abstract: Five Native American tribes will work with the Bureau of Land Management to plan and conserve Bears Ears National Monument in Utah, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Bears Ears National Monument, whose red-rock landscape sprawls across more than 1.3 million acres in southeastern Utah, will be managed jointly by the federal government and Native American tribes in what administration officials said represents a “one-of-a-kind” model of cooperation.

headline: Jan. 6 Hearing Will Highlight Trump’s Pressure Campaign on State Officials
abstract: The House committee investigating the Capitol attack will also underscore the vitriol and suffering that election workers endured because of President Donald J. Trump’s lies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol on Tuesday plans to detail President Donald J. Trump’s personal involvement in a pressure campaign on state officials to subvert the will of the voters as well as an audacious scheme to put forward false slates of electors in seven states to keep him in power.

headline: Jury in Bill Cosby’s Sex Assault Case Ends Third Day of Deliberation
abstract: No verdict has been reached in the civil case brought by a woman who says Mr. Cosby molested her at the Playboy Mansion in 1975, when she was 16.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on the verdict in Bill Cosby’s civil trial.

headline: Russia’s Blockade of Ukraine Is ‘War Crime,’ Top E.U. Official Says
abstract: The remarks by the official, Josep Borrell Fontelles, were among the strongest language from a Western leader in describing the Kremlin’s tactics to subjugate Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Russian blockade that has stopped Ukraine from exporting its vast storehouses of grain and other goods, threatening starvation in distant corners of the globe, is a “war crime,” the European Union’s top foreign policy official declared Monday.

headline: He Promised to Transform Colombia as President. Can He Fulfill That Vow?
abstract: During his campaign, Gustavo Petro proposed major reforms if he was elected. After winning Sunday’s presidential election, he’ll now have to prove he can carry out those changes.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — In a packed arena in Bogotá on Sunday, amid a burst of confetti and below a sign that read “Colombia won,” Gustavo Petro celebrated his victory as the first leftist ever elected president of Colombia.

headline: Many an Expert Hobbyist
abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners’s puzzle is an instant success.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — It’s a welcome return for the constructor Alex Eaton-Salners, who is making his 45th appearance in the daily New York Times Crossword today. His puzzles tend to be on the harder side, with 44 percent of them publishing on a Thursday, so solvers familiar with his work may be surprised or apprehensive about seeing his byline on a Tuesday. Never fear, dear solvers: Today’s theme, discussed below, is absolutely approachable enough for a Tuesday.

headline: 132 Civilians Killed by Rebel Attacks in Central Mali, Government Says
abstract: Several villages near the town of Bankass were attacked over the weekend by jihadists, officials said.
lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — Attacks by jihadist rebels over the weekend in the West African nation of Mali killed 132 civilians, the government said Monday.

headline: Russian Journalist’s Nobel Medal Sells for $103.5 Million
abstract: Dmitri A. Muratov, the editor of the independent newspaper Novaya Gazeta, will donate proceeds to UNICEF to help Ukrainian child refugees.
lead_paragraph: The Nobel Peace Prize put up for auction by the Russian journalist Dmitri A. Muratov to help Ukrainian refugees sold Monday night for $103.5 million to an anonymous buyer, obliterating the record for a Nobel medal.

headline: After a Pivotal Period in Ukraine, U.S. Officials Predict the War’s Path
abstract: As Russia makes slow but steady progress, the arrival of new weapons systems will help Ukraine hang on to territory, U.S. officials and analysts say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Russia shifted its military campaign to focus on eastern Ukraine this spring, senior officials in the Biden administration said the next four to six weeks of fighting would determine the war’s eventual path.

headline: Nordic Combined, One of the Oldest Winter Olympic Sports, Faces Elimination
abstract: Leaders of Nordic combined, a mix of cross-country skiing and ski jumping, thought they had secured the future of the sport. But the International Olympic Committee is skeptical.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a decade of nurturing the participation of girls and women, the leaders of Nordic combined, one of the original Winter Olympic competitions, were fairly certain they had secured the future of their sport for years to come.

headline: A Shopping Trip for Apples, Over the Last Bridge in Lysychansk
abstract: Bridges are critical in the battle for Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, separated by a river. Shelling has mostly destroyed them, but that didn’t stop one woman from walking across to buy some basics.
lead_paragraph: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — The woman’s mission was simple: she was going shopping, and she would not be deterred. Svitlana Zhyvaga just needed to cross a bridge.

headline: ‘Jersey Is Taking Over’: N.J. Hoopers Outshine the Shadow of New York
abstract: Far more N.B.A. players have come from New York than its neighbor state. But a wave of rising stars in boys’ basketball can shift the trend.
lead_paragraph: Elliot Cadeau was born in Brooklyn, but he doesn’t have any memories of living in the borough. When he was 3 months old, his parents packed up their possessions, strapped him into his car seat and decamped to New Jersey.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: A small town has become a turning point in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: As Russia has seized control of much of the Donbas region, a small town has become a focus point where Ukraine’s leaders say the fate of the country’s Donbas region could be decided.

headline: Corrections: June 21, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 21, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about a project documenting Black family heirlooms referred incorrectly to a book written by the historian Tiya Miles. Her book “All That She Carried” traces the story of one cotton sack, not a cotton dress.

headline: These 11 Moderate Voters See an America That Others Don’t
abstract: For its latest focus group, Times Opinion spoke with 11 middle-of-the-road voters about culture war issues: abortion, gun control and trans rights.
lead_paragraph: For its latest focus group, Times Opinion spoke with 11 middle-of-the-road voters about culture war issues: abortion, gun control and trans rights.

headline: Stephen Colbert Explains How His ‘Late Show’ Staff Was Detained in Washington
abstract: “The Capitol Police are much more cautious than they were, say, 18 months ago, and for a very good reason,” Colbert said. “If you don’t know what that reason is, I know what news network you watch.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: U.S. officials predict more gains for Russia, but stronger pushback from Ukraine in the east.
abstract: When Russia shifted its military campaign to focus on eastern Ukraine this spring, senior officials in the Biden administration said the next four to six weeks of fighting would determine the war’s eventual path.
lead_paragraph: When Russia shifted its military campaign to focus on eastern Ukraine this spring, senior officials in the Biden administration said the next four to six weeks of fighting would determine the war’s eventual path.

headline: U.K. Train Strike Brings Transit Chaos
abstract: Travel was disrupted for tens of millions of people during the country’s biggest walkout in decades as union leaders warned of a summer of labor unrest.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain was hobbled on Tuesday by its largest railway strike in three decades, halting trains across the country, throwing travel plans for tens of millions of Britons and visitors into chaos, and setting off what union and government leaders warned could be a long summer of labor unrest.

headline: When Antlers Tangle, Sometimes Both Animals Lose
abstract: Antlers, the headgear of deer, moose and elk, are more useful for display than combat. But that does not stop deadly lockups from occurring.
lead_paragraph: As the days of summer pass, the antlers get longer on moose, elk and other animals in the cervid, or deer, family. The animals spend most of the summer grazing, their head weaponry sheathed in fuzzy velvet. But by the start of autumn, the antlers will be ready for action as male suitors gather to posture, preen and butt heads — a behavior that some people may have in mind when they use the phrase “locking horns.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: China’s Surveillance State Is Growing. These Documents Reveal How.
abstract: A New York Times analysis of over 100,000 government bidding documents found that China’s ambition to collect digital and biological data from its citizens is more expansive and invasive than previously known.
lead_paragraph: A New York Times analysis of over 100,000 government bidding documents found that China’s ambition to collect digital and biological data from its citizens is more expansive and invasive than previously known.

headline: Four Takeaways From a Times Investigation Into China’s Expanding Surveillance State
abstract: Times reporters spent over a year combing through government bidding documents that reveal the country’s technological road map to ensure the longevity of its authoritarian rule.
lead_paragraph: China’s ambition to collect a staggering amount of personal data from everyday citizens is more expansive than previously known, a Times investigation has found. Phone-tracking devices are now everywhere. The police are creating some of the largest DNA databases in the world. And the authorities are building upon facial recognition technology to collect voice prints from the general public.

headline: With Kalashnikov Burgers and Black Comedy, Libyans Try to Move On From Conflict
abstract: After more than a decade of chaos and war, fed-up Libyans are clamoring for peace — and making clear they’ve had enough violence: “We want to taste life, not death.”
lead_paragraph: MISURATA, Libya — When Taha al-Baskini won a part in a new play about soldiers who reunite after dying in combat, his costume was already in his closet. His onstage camouflage pants were the same ones he had worn as a militia fighter during Libya’s most recent civil war a few years ago, when an airstrike injured Mr. al-Baskini and killed several of his comrades as they defended their city.

headline: A Russian journalist’s Nobel medal sells for $103.5 million.
abstract: The Nobel Peace Prize put up for auction by the Russian journalist Dmitri A. Muratov to help Ukrainian refugees sold Monday night for $103.5 million to an anonymous buyer, obliterating the record for a Nobel medal.
lead_paragraph: The Nobel Peace Prize put up for auction by the Russian journalist Dmitri A. Muratov to help Ukrainian refugees sold Monday night for $103.5 million to an anonymous buyer, obliterating the record for a Nobel medal.

headline: 1972: A 36-Day Hunger Strike Ends in Northern Ireland
abstract: Irish Republican Army members imprisoned in a Belfast jail called an end to a protest that lasted more than a month.
lead_paragraph: BELFAST, June 20 (UPI).— Irish Republican Army men in Belfast’s Crumlin Road jail today ended a 36-day hunger strike in return for Britain’s virtual concession of political-prisoner status.

headline: John Grisham Is Still Battling His Southern Demons
abstract: “It was such a hard-right-wing, racist society that I grew up in. I’ve come a long way.”
lead_paragraph: “It was such a hard-right-wing, racist society that I grew up in. I’ve come a long way.”

headline: Building Back Better — One Community at a Time
abstract: Michelle Wilde Anderson’s “The Fight to Save the Town” highlights four places where citizens have come together to combat urban decline.
lead_paragraph: THE FIGHT TO SAVE THE TOWNReimagining Discarded AmericaBy Michelle Wilde Anderson

headline: How Bad Are the Germs in Public Restrooms, Really?
abstract: Communal bathrooms can harbor plenty of pathogens, but simple precautions will help keep them at bay.
lead_paragraph: Q: What is the real risk of public toilet seats?

headline: A Medieval Dramedy Sheathed in Magic, and the Absurd
abstract: Ottessa Moshfegh’s fifth novel, “Lapvona,” is set in a corrupt fiefdom plagued by drought, famine and, well, plague.
lead_paragraph: Lapvona is a minor fiefdom somewhere in medieval Europe. Its ruler, Lord Villiam, is a spoiled and petulant schemer, so feeble that when he walks down from his castle to the church in the village, he has to be carried back uphill. Lapvona was once a good place, with fertile soil and low taxes. Now, in the aftermath of a plague, it is grim, parched and poor. Its plight is worsened because Villiam has at his disposal a gang of bandits who periodically ransack the village, stealing crops for Villiam to secretly sell to his business contacts in another fiefdom up north. Lapvona is also squalid in all the familiar medieval ways: a place of pestilence, deformities and skin diseases, lurid crime and extreme punishment.

headline: Two Years Later, We Still Don’t Understand Long Covid. Why?
abstract: Dr. Lekshmi Santhosh parses what research has illuminated about long Covid, and what questions remain.
lead_paragraph: Depending on the data you look at, between 10 and 40 percent of people who get Covid will still have symptoms months later. For some, those symptoms will be modest. A cough, some fatigue. For others, they’ll be life-altering: Debilitating brain fog. Exhaustion. Cardiovascular problems. Blood clotting.

headline: If I Get Canceled, Let Them Eat Me Alive
abstract: I want friends whose minds are not tethered to mine in bonds of allegiance but spin freely of their own accord.
lead_paragraph: What should my friends do if I am being canceled?

headline: In the Scramble for a Campsite, Everyone Deserves an Equal Chance
abstract: A booking system used by the National Park Service may be disadvantaging  marginalized communities the service has worked hard to attract.
lead_paragraph: In the summer darkness of a July night in 2016, I was stumbling bleary-eyed toward the kiosk at the entrance to Camp 4, the campground in Yosemite National Park favored by climbers worldwide, when I tripped on something.

headline: When It Comes to Timber Theft, There Are No Clear-Cut Villains
abstract: Lyndsie Bourgon’s “Tree Thieves” casts the American environmental movement in all its complexity.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, I’d thought of trees as tall, attractive sources of shade and occasional power outages. Then I read “The Overstory,” the novel by Richard Powers, and I began to see them as wondrously complex organisms that protect the planet and even communicate with one another. Trees, it turns out, are amazing!

headline: In This Y.A. Novel, the Grief Comes Before the Tragedy
abstract: Robin Benway’s new book, “A Year to the Day,” explores death and loss, but in reverse.
lead_paragraph: I’m used to a certain kind of grief story. It begins with a shattering loss; the rest of the novel explores the question of how to go on. We follow a grieving character through the depths of the pain and the self-sabotage, the emptiness and the lashing out, the vivid or fading memories, the euphoria of being alive and seeing everything anew, until — if it’s a story that turns toward healing — the character has reached a place where we can bear to turn away.

headline: Why You Might Buy Your Next Car Online
abstract: Tesla shifted to selling cars entirely online in 2019. Now, some established automakers, like Ford, are talking about taking a similar approach.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, many auto experts said Tesla was making a big mistake by deciding to sell cars only online, arguing that whatever bad feelings people had about dealerships they were essential to the car business.

headline: There’s Never Been a Better Time for an Outdoor Dinner Party
abstract: Here’s how to make your dinner — and your summer — a memorable one.
lead_paragraph: As warm weather arrives, so does the opportunity to entertain outdoors — an especially appealing prospect this year, as the pandemic drags on but it feels like we’ve been isolated for long enough.

headline: Will Kathy Hochul’s Low-Key Primary Come at a Cost? Allies Fear Yes.
abstract: Gov. Hochul is expected to handily win next week’s primary. But some allies worry her campaign is failing to energize key voters for November’s election.
lead_paragraph: Charles B. Rangel, the longtime dean of Harlem politics, had a blunt question for two of Gov. Kathy Hochul’s top political aides at a private meeting last month: Where’s the campaign?

headline: The Government Set a Colossal Wildfire. What Are Victims Owed?
abstract: Two prescribed burns got out of control, becoming New Mexico’s largest recorded wildfire. But despite the backlash, experts say it’s necessary to thin forests in a region primed for destruction.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Can Natural Gas Be Used to Create Power With Fewer Emissions?
abstract: One company says it has the technology. And though investors looking for cleaner power generation are lining up, some environmentalists are skeptical.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Upstart, a series about young companies harnessing new science and technology.

headline: Finding Traces of Harriet Tubman on Maryland’s Eastern Shore
