abstract: Across the city, landlords and brokers have been testing the upper limits as rental rates soar and available inventory declines.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn has put another sky-high rental in its books, with the leasing, starting in July, of a sprawling duplex for $40,000 a month.

headline: Why Conspiracy Theories Flourish in Trump’s America
abstract: “It is too soon to say whether this delegitimization is permanent,” one scholar says.
lead_paragraph: Whether he is out of power or in office, Donald Trump deploys conspiracy theory as a political mobilizing tool designed to capture anger at the liberal establishment, to legitimize racial resentment and to unite voters who feel oppressed by what they see as a dominant socially progressive culture.

headline: Ocasio-Cortez Endorses Insurgent in New York Lt. Governor’s Race
abstract: Ana María Archila, who would be the first Latina elected statewide, gained national attention after she confronted a senator over the Supreme Court confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh.
lead_paragraph: For much of her first term, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez raised her profile by fighting for nationwide initiatives favored by the far left, like Medicare for All and the Green New Deal.

headline: What Should You Do When Your Partner Lies About His Earnings?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on a financial betrayal — and more.
lead_paragraph: My significant other and I have committed to being life partners. After living together for a year, we bought a house. We split the purchase cost and the cost of extensive renovations 50-50. We own the house in joint tenancy. We do not share any expenses other than household expenses and split those costs based on income. I have been very open about my finances and willingly give my partner access to all my accounts as he is retired from a career as a successful financial adviser.

headline: Risking Their Lives to Defy Hitler
abstract: Halik Kochanski’s “Resistance” traces the underground opposition to the Nazis across the continent of Europe.
lead_paragraph: For continental Europeans World War II was a vastly different experience than it was for the people of the British Commonwealth or the United States. In the English-speaking world the war was largely a long narrative of military operations happening somewhere else — sometimes going very badly, but always going, and ending in a comfortably self-affirming victory. They were spared the hardships, horrors, moral dilemmas and later recriminations of foreign occupation.

headline: The Historian George Chauncey Wins the Kluge Humanities Prize
abstract: Chauncey, a professor of American history at Columbia, becomes the first scholar in L.G.B.T.Q. studies to receive the $500,000 award.
lead_paragraph: The Library of Congress has named the historian George Chauncey this year’s winner of the John W. Kluge Prize for Achievement in the Study of Humanity, making him the first scholar in L.G.B.T.Q. studies to be honored with the award.

headline: On a Divided Mount Everest, Climate Cooperation Is Being Tested
abstract: China and Nepal have both established unmanned weather stations high on the world’s tallest mountain.
lead_paragraph: A new landmark greeted mountaineers nearing the summit of Mount Everest this spring: a seven-foot-tall mast of scientific instruments bolted into the coarse shale of an outcropping known as Bishop Rock. It’s only about 130 vertical feet from the 29,032-foot summit, where one can look down the opposite side of the mountain, into China, and see another weather station about an equal distance from the top.

headline: Could New York City Lose Its Last Remaining Jewish Congressman?
abstract: Three decades ago, Jewish lawmakers made up roughly half of New York City’s House delegation. Now there is one: Jerrold Nadler, who faces a tough primary battle.
lead_paragraph: The clock was nearing midnight on Shavuot, the Jewish Feast of Weeks, when Ruth W. Messinger offered a prophetic political warning to a crowd munching on holiday cheesecake at the Jewish community center on Manhattan’s Upper West Side.

headline: The Real Enforcers of Gender Equity in Sports: Angry Parents
abstract: Girls are supposed to have equal access in schools. In practice, districts aren’t forced to change unless someone speaks up.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Ginger Folger’s son, John, played high school football in Gainesville, Ga., their hometown, about 50 miles northeast of Atlanta.

headline: Biden Pushes Congress for Three-Month Gas Tax Holiday
abstract: Vulnerable Democrats have championed the move ahead of the midterm elections, but experts remain skeptical that suspending the federal tax would benefit consumers much.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With fuel prices near record highs, President Biden on Wednesday urged Congress to temporarily suspend the federal gas tax and give Americans “just a little bit of breathing room,” even as the proposal faced dim prospects on Capitol Hill.

headline: The Netrebko Question
abstract: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko is opera’s biggest star. But her career is in disarray because of her ties to Putin, and arts companies around the world are divided on whether to welcome her back.
lead_paragraph: MONTE CARLO — Anna Netrebko, the superstar Russian soprano, stood on the steps of the ornate Casino de Monte-Carlo, taking photos with friends and watching Aston Martins and Ferraris zoom through the night.

headline: Living In ... East Williamsburg, Brooklyn
abstract: Those nostalgic for 1980s New York will find much to love in this area, where buildings are slathered in graffiti and stylish people fill the streets.
lead_paragraph: Those nostalgic for 1980s New York will find much to love in this area, where buildings are slathered in graffiti and stylish people fill the streets.

headline: A Big Step Toward Fusion Energy Is Hailed by a Seattle Start-Up
abstract: Zap Energy said its experimental reactor core was ready for a milestone test. Skeptics routinely question whether the technology is currently possible.
lead_paragraph: Zap Energy, a fusion energy start-up working on a low-cost path to producing electricity commercially, said last week that it had taken an important step toward testing a system its researchers believe will eventually produce more electricity than it consumes.

headline: First Pineapples, Now Fish: To Pressure Taiwan, China Flexes Economic Muscle
abstract: Taiwan’s lucrative grouper industry is bracing for heavy losses after China’s recent ban on imports of the fish from the island.
lead_paragraph: FANGLIAO, Taiwan — Lin Chun-lai bought his grouper farm in southern Taiwan about a decade ago with an eye on mainland China’s growing appetite for live fish. In just a few years, the former electrician made enough money to comfortably support his family of four and even open a small inn.

headline: East Williamsburg, Brooklyn: A ‘Gritty, Industrial Vibe,’ With Pliable Borders
abstract: Those nostalgic for 1980s New York will find much to love in this neighborhood, where buildings are slathered in graffiti and stylish young people fill the streets.
lead_paragraph: In the East Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, residential blocks feel like an afterthought. Townhouses fill the spaces between industrial corridors. Parks are steps from scrapyards, where musclebound men with sledgehammers pulverize appliances. You can easily find a place to get your freight truck washed.

headline: In Two Elections, North and South, Boris Johnson Risks a Sharp Rebuke
abstract: Scandals, economic pain and an uproar over lockdown parties have left Britain’s Conservatives at risk of losing both recent advances and old strongholds.
lead_paragraph: WAKEFIELD, England — Prime Minister Boris Johnson has yet to campaign in the stately but faded city of Wakefield in West Yorkshire, even though his Conservative Party is at risk of losing a highly symbolic seat in a parliamentary election there on Thursday. But that doesn’t mean he’s not on people’s minds — or tongues.

headline: Inside the Push to Diversify the Book Business
abstract: For generations, America’s major publishers focused almost entirely on white readers. Now a new cadre of executives like Lisa Lucas is trying to open up the industry.
lead_paragraph: At the end of one of her first days on the job at Pantheon books in January 2021, Lisa Lucas picked up her iPad, settled into a couch and began swiping through the manuscript of an unpublished novel called “Sweet, Soft, Plenty Rhythm.” Written by Laura Warrell, the story follows a jazz musician and his entanglements with a dozen or so women. As Lucas devoured its pages, she slipped into a kind of trance. Hours ticked by. The sun set outside her windows, and still she could not stop reading.

headline: The Man Who Made the Sari Haute
abstract: As his country’s most famous designer, Sabyasachi has persuaded Indians to see the luxury in their fashion heritage. Can he persuade Americans too?
lead_paragraph: In New York, Sabyasachi Mukherjee can almost be anonymous. He takes morning runs in Central Park; walks through Times Square, looking up at the billboards like a little kid; dines at family-run Chinese restaurants, the kinds of places where he’s unlikely to be photographed with a mouthful of food. Whenever he sees anyone from South Asia, he veers in the opposite direction, hoping to avoid an awkward encounter. But run-ins are inevitable, as when a fan stopped him recently coming out of the Plaza Hotel — a doctor from India, eager to exchange a word with India’s most famous fashion designer.

headline: Dressing Simply, but Well. It’s Not So Simple.
abstract: Upselling the suit was on the agenda during this Milan Fashion Week, when Italian men’s wear returned in glory.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Conjuring the pleasures of being “well, but simply, dressed” is how Brunello Cucinelli describes a design brief that has turned him, the son of an Umbrian farmer, into a self-made billionaire.

headline: The Addictive Appeal of Aroids
abstract: If you’re hooked on houseplants like Monstera, Philodendron and pothos, wait until you meet the other members of the aroid family.
lead_paragraph: If you’re hooked on houseplants like Monstera, Philodendron and pothos, wait until you meet the other members of the aroid family.

headline: These Curious-Looking Plants Have an Addictive Appeal
abstract: If you’re hooked on houseplants like Monstera, Philodendron and pothos, wait until you meet the other members of the aroid family.
lead_paragraph: Warning: Aroids may be habit-forming.

headline: The 25 Most Significant New York City Novels From the Last 100 Years
abstract: Four writers and one bookseller gathered over Zoom to make a list devoted to fiction in which the city is more than mere setting.
lead_paragraph: What to say about New York? As both a place and an idea, it’s too big to be summed up or even fully known. But that hasn’t stopped countless writers from trying, often via fiction — which, like the city, lends itself to wandering. If anything, New York’s scale and complexity — the diversity of neighborhoods and industries and lives that coexist here — are what make it an inexhaustible and consistently compelling setting. There’s also the fact that it’s so closely associated with ambition, which, as any storyteller will confirm, tends to be a useful thing for a protagonist to have. And so, despite myriad differences in aims and style, the New York City novel has become its own literary category, one that T explored for this project, which compiles what we’ve deemed to be the 25 most influential New York novels published between 1921 and 2021.

headline: Vaccinations for children under 5 start in New York City, including in Times Square.
abstract: In a city that was once the epicenter of the pandemic, many parents have been eager to vaccinate the last age group still awaiting shots.
lead_paragraph: Families in New York City began vaccinating children younger than 5 against Covid-19 on Wednesday after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention endorsed the vaccines over the weekend and many parts of the United States started giving shots this week.

headline: Britain’s inflation rate climbs to 9.1 percent, a fresh 40-year high.
abstract: The latest data comes during crippling train strikes as workers demand pay in line with the rising cost of living.
lead_paragraph: Prices in Britain climbed 9.1 percent in May from a year earlier, a slight acceleration in the inflation rate that was released during  a week of transit disruption as transport workers strike for, among other things, pay increases in line with the cost of living.

headline: Saudi Leader Visits Turkey, Moving to Mend Rift Over Journalist’s Murder
abstract: The 2018 killing and dismemberment of the Saudi dissident and journalist Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents in Istanbul drove a deep wedge between the two countries.
lead_paragraph: The crown prince of Saudi Arabia visited Turkey on Wednesday for the first time since Saudi agents murdered the prominent dissident and journalist Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul in 2018, driving a deep rift between the two regional powers.

headline: Big Returns for Investing in Fine Wine and Whiskey? It Was Fraud, U.S. Says.
abstract: The scheme, which the authorities say used “aggressive and deceptive tactics,” defrauded more than 150 people of about $13 million, according to court documents.
lead_paragraph: One company claims on its website that purchasing its whiskey can “help you acquire a piece of history.” Another says it specializes in the acquisition and sale of “the world’s most illustrious exciting and pleasurable Investment Grade” wines.

headline: How Biden’s Approval Rating Got So Low
abstract: Heading into the midterms, Democratic candidates are contending with the unpopularity of their party’s leader.
lead_paragraph: During his campaign for president and in his first year in office, Joe Biden tried to be all things to all people. But trying to govern on behalf of such a broad political coalition has left his administration with something of an identity crisis.

headline: Allyson Felix’s Retirement Plan Has Already Started
abstract: The 11-time Olympic medalist is running her final competitive season. Up next? Full-time advocacy and mentorship.
lead_paragraph: Allyson Felix isn’t done yet.

headline: Finding Alternative Route for Ukraine’s Grain Exports Isn’t So Simple, Experts Say
abstract: Proposed alternatives include exporting into Poland or transporting it into Romania and out through the Black Sea port of Constanta.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s blockade of the Black Sea has inflated global grain prices, raised fears of hunger in some countries and drawn widespread condemnation. It has also provoked a vexing problem: how to find a new route out for Ukraine’s agricultural exports.

headline: A Pro-Religion Court
abstract: What the 6-3 conservative Supreme Court majority’s latest ruling means.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has become the most pro-religion it’s been since at least the 1950s, and it appears to include the six most pro-religion justices since at least World War II.

headline: A pivotal showdown approaches in eastern Ukraine as more villages fall to Russia.
abstract: Approaching a pivotal moment in their invasion of Ukraine, Russian forces have tightened their vise around two key eastern cities, raising the risk their slow, brutal advance will capture the cities and trap the Ukrainian troops defending them.
lead_paragraph: Approaching a pivotal moment in their invasion of Ukraine, Russian forces have tightened their vise around two key eastern cities, raising the risk their slow, brutal advance will capture the cities and trap the Ukrainian troops defending them.

headline: Sriracha Shortage Is Taking Some Spice Out of Life
abstract: An abysmal spring harvest of Mexican chiles caused an “unprecedented shortage” of Asian hot sauces, a California-based producer said.
lead_paragraph: A fixture at Vietnamese restaurants, sriracha sauce can lace aromatic pho with a jolt of heat. It’s the star ingredient in spicy mayonnaise zigzagging countless sushi rolls, and it has even inspired a legion of fans to dress up for Halloween each year like a red plastic squeeze bottle with green cap.

headline: $625,000 Homes in Oregon, Louisiana and Georgia
abstract: A Tudor Revival house in Portland, a Craftsman bungalow in Baton Rouge and a two-family home in Savannah.
lead_paragraph: A Tudor Revival house in Portland, a Craftsman bungalow in Baton Rouge and a two-family home in Savannah.

headline: $625,000 Homes in Oregon, Louisiana and Georgia
abstract: A Tudor Revival house in Portland, a Craftsman bungalow in Baton Rouge and a two-family home in Savannah.
lead_paragraph: This house is in the Woodstock neighborhood, on a quiet street a few blocks from a handful of coffee shops, a German deli and a grocery store specializing in local products. Reed College, a liberal arts school with about 1,500 undergraduate students and a number of early 20th-century Gothic Revival buildings, is less than five minutes away by car.

headline: When Outrage Isn’t Enough to Bring Change
abstract: An examination of crises in the Americas — including school shootings in the U.S. — yields a sobering theory about why even a national outpouring of pain cannot always overcome political divides.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Taking in the View(s)
abstract: No matter how long you’ve been in New York, there’s always a new spot to discover where the city can take your breath away.
lead_paragraph: I recently spent the night on Governors Island for the first time, and as I watched the sunset from one of the island’s highest hills, I was stunned by how beautiful the city looked from a slightly different angle from what I was used to.

headline: Why Summer Fires in California Are So Dangerous
abstract: Though fires increasingly erupt year-round in the Golden State, those in the summer and fall tend to be far more destructive.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost July, which is typically the beginning of California’s fire season.

headline: Clean energy investment lags as oil and gas prices soar.
abstract: The head of the International Energy Agency said high prices for fossil fuels would probably persist for years.
lead_paragraph: Oil and gas prices are likely to remain inflated for years given the uneven transition to cleaner energy sources, the head of the International Energy Agency said Wednesday.

headline: A Six-Bedroom Beachfront Perch for $3.5 Million
abstract: A contemporary six-bedroom villa on the southern coast of Anguilla, an island in the eastern Caribbean Sea, is on the market for $3.5 million.
lead_paragraph: A contemporary six-bedroom villa on the southern coast of Anguilla, an island in the eastern Caribbean Sea, is on the market for $3.5 million.

headline: House Hunting on Anguilla: Modern Elegance, Steps From the Caribbean
abstract: This January saw some of the island’s highest tourism numbers in recent years, lending some momentum to a rebounding sales market.
lead_paragraph: This contemporary six-bedroom villa on the southern coast of Anguilla overlooks a small beach with a cove in the Caribbean Sea. Built in 2006 on 0.65 acres in the LockRum Bay area, the three-story home sits about 25 feet above sea level and has 6,000 square feet of interior space, with hurricane-proof windows and doors, said Elaine Hearn, a co-founder of Properties in Paradise, which has the listing. Numerous balconies and patios surrounding a pool and artificial turf lawn offer views of the nearby Caribbean islands of St. Martin and St. Barthélemy, she said.

headline: Will Biden’s Gas Tax Holiday Make a Difference?
abstract: Many economists say suspending federal taxes on gas will not significantly cut prices for consumers.
lead_paragraph: This afternoon, President Biden will ask Congress to lift federal taxes on gas through the end of September, just before the midterm elections, The Times’s Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Lydia DePillis report. Oil prices have risen to their highest levels in 14 years, squeezing consumers, and the president is hoping to alleviate some of the economic pain that has been a drag on his popularity.

headline: Kaliningrad, Russia’s Westernmost Outpost, Is Again a Flash Point in East-West Relations
abstract: Wedged between Poland and Lithuania and bristling with missiles capable of flinging conventional or nuclear warheads into Europe, Kaliningrad has become emblematic of the Cold War era.
lead_paragraph: A former American national security adviser once called Kaliningrad, a Russian enclave sandwiched between the NATO members Poland and Lithuania, “a dagger in the heart of Europe.”

headline: Analysis: What Turkey Wants to Let Finland and Sweden Into NATO
abstract: Finnish and Swedish hopes of being accepted as applicants by next week’s NATO summit meeting have been dashed by a Turkish government that says it is in no hurry.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Spurred by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Finland and Sweden applied last month to join NATO, anticipating swift and smooth entry into the alliance. Instead they are in a bind, their path blocked by the unpredictable Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

headline: Powell says the Fed is ‘not trying to provoke’ a recession, but it is ‘certainly a possibility.’
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, testified before a Senate committee at a moment of rapid inflation and rising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, said that the central bank might be able to lower rapid inflation without tipping America into a painful downturn, though he cautioned that pulling it off would be “very challenging” to achieve and that a recession is “certainly a possibility.”

headline: M.T.A. Vows to Make Subways 95% Accessible. It Will Take 33 Years.
abstract: The M.T.A. will spend billions to add elevators and ramps to stations over the next several decades, settling lawsuits accusing it of violating the rights of people with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: New York has lagged for years behind other major American cities in making its subway system accessible to people with disabilities: Just 126 of its 472 stations, or 27 percent, have elevators or ramps that make them fully accessible.

headline: A Source of Comfort in Our Search for Quantum Meaning
abstract: Effective theories in physics can help us measure and examine reality, despite the many things we do not yet know.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: The Rookie Some Didn’t Want Now Has a Fan Base Feeling Optimistic
abstract: When Detroit drafted Moritz Seider, a contingent of fans had “pure shock and disappointment.” But after a strong rookie season, those fans hope he can help end a six-year playoff drought.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Red Wings have completed their sixth consecutive losing season, but still there’s a buzz in the Motor City that one of the N.H.L.’s most storied franchises may finally be on the road back to prominence.

headline: Onstage, Paradise for Black Characters Often Comes With a Price
abstract: A tricky challenge for Black playwrights: offering deliverance, even hope, while staying truthful about real-life tragedy.
lead_paragraph: In “Soft,” Donja R. Love’s affecting new play at MCC Theater, a teenager wonders where Black boys go when they die. By the end the audience gets the answer: a haven overgrown with flowers where Black boys can truly be themselves.

headline: ‘Not in This for the Money’: Why Some Families Sue North Korea
abstract: Families whose relatives have been abducted or imprisoned by North Korea are seeking to hold the country financially accountable despite the long odds of collecting money from the isolated nation.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — A grieving couple in Ohio, a retired preschool teacher in South Korea and a woman who left Japan 62 years ago have one thing in common: They are among a small number of people who have sued North Korea.

headline: Chinese Businessman Tied to Alibaba Rape Case Is Sentenced to Prison
abstract: A court found Zhang Guo guilty of “forcible indecency.” The tech giant fired his accuser last year after she claimed that he had molested her and that her boss had raped her.
lead_paragraph: When a young female employee at Alibaba, one of China’s biggest technology firms, accused her manager and a company client of sexually assaulting her after an alcohol-fueled work dinner last summer, it seemed like a turning point for the country’s fledgling #MeToo movement.

headline: Panel Finds Daniel Snyder Interfered With Sexual Harassment Investigation
abstract: In a memo, a Congressional panel said it found evidence that the Washington Commanders owner conducted a “shadow investigation” of accusers.
lead_paragraph: As the N.F.L. was investigating his team for widespread workplace misconduct, the Washington Commanders owner Daniel Snyder directed a “shadow investigation” to interfere with and undermine its findings, a Congressional committee found.

headline: James Rado, Co-Creator of the Musical ‘Hair,’ Is Dead at 90
abstract: Working with his fellow writer and actor Gerome Ragni and the composer Galt MacDermot, he jolted Broadway into the Age of Aquarius.
lead_paragraph: James Rado, who jolted Broadway into the Age of Aquarius as a co-creator of “Hair,” the show, billed as an “American tribal love-rock musical,” that transfigured musical theater tradition with radical ’60s iconoclasm and rock ’n’ roll, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: A Quiet Word With Italy’s Master of Horror
abstract: A 20-film retrospective in New York of the filmmaker Dario Argento’s work shows why he’s had audiences jumping out of their seats for nearly five decades.
lead_paragraph: ROME — For a man who has spent nearly 50 years scaring the pants off movie audiences, the Italian director Dario Argento does not come across as frightening at all.

headline: The I.R.S. backlog of unprocessed tax returns has grown to 21 million.
abstract: The national taxpayer advocate criticized the Biden administration for being slow to make changes at the Internal Revenue Service.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The backlog of tax returns at the Internal Revenue Service has grown to more than 20 million in the last year despite efforts by the Biden administration to process filings and send out refunds more quickly, the national taxpayer advocate said in a report published on Wednesday.

headline: Semafor Readies Entry Into Tricky Digital News Market
abstract: The news start-up Semafor has raised $25 million from wealthy individuals, with a goal of cultivating direct relationships between its journalists and its audience.
lead_paragraph: News articles will be broken into sections distinguishing facts from opinion. Reporters’ bylines will be as prominent as headlines. And journalists will be permitted to offer their analysis on social media.

headline: ‘Disappearance at Clifton Hill,’ ‘Damsel’ and More Streaming Gems
abstract: Inventive riffs on murder mysteries, westerns and gangster movies are among the highlights of this month’s under-the-radar streaming recommendations.
lead_paragraph: The director Albert Shin lays on the dread from the opening frames of this atmospheric Canadian thriller; something’s wrong here, even if we don’t yet know what. Abby (Tuppence Middleton) doesn’t know either, but she has spent most of her life haunted by the childhood incident that begins the film: a half-understood encounter at a lake during which she might have witnessed a kidnapping. Now, as an adult whose life is falling apart, she does what so many of us do: She ignores her own problems and becomes fixated on the increasingly peculiar details of a barely remembered incident. Shin has a way of unsettlingly creeping his camera and peering inquisitively into darkness (literal and figurative); the result is a solid, moody mystery about buried secrets and oddball history. Bonus: an appropriately odd appearance by the Canadian treasure David Cronenberg as a grizzled podcaster.

headline: Nancy Pelosi’s Napa: Wealthy Friends and a Husband’s Porsche Crash
abstract: An accident shines a light on the House speaker’s California life among the vineyards.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi had just urged Brown University graduates to stay resilient and summon their “better angels” on Memorial Day weekend when she was forced to turn her attention to a less uplifting situation: her husband’s arrest in California.

headline: Penélope Cruz, Antonio Banderas and Their ‘Official Competition’
abstract: The two Spanish actors discuss working together on a satire about the film industry, how they feel about awards and how they get into character.
lead_paragraph: That the international stars Penélope Cruz and Antonio Banderas had never spent more than two minutes together on the big screen is a surprising truth.

headline: Recipes Beginner Cooks Really Need
abstract: We have 10 new recipes packed with smart tips and nuggets of kitchen wisdom.
lead_paragraph: Hi there, it’s Melissa Clark, holding down the fort for Sam while he’s on the road. This means I get the happy privilege of introducing a brand-new package of 10 brilliant recipes for beginner cooks.

headline: How Fast Fashion Became Faster — and Worse for the Earth
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Evelyn Wang, age 17.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Evelyn Wang, age 17, from Naperville North High School in Naperville, Ill., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s Ninth Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 16,664 entries.

headline: Endangered Languages Are Worth Saving
abstract: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Zoe Yu, age 17.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Zoe Yu, age 17, from The Woodlands College Park High School in The Woodlands, Texas, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s Ninth Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 16,664 entries.

headline: What’s Worse: Climate Denial or Climate Hypocrisy?
abstract: Today the rhetorical war has largely been won, but the outlook grows a lot more confusing when everyone agrees to agree.
lead_paragraph: In early 2020, Larry Fink — the chief executive of BlackRock, a financial firm whose $10 trillion in assets under management are roughly equivalent to the aggregate wealth of Latin America, and about twice that of Africa — did his best to stake his claim as the face of an environmentally responsible business future. “Climate change has become a defining factor in companies’ long-term prospects,” Fink wrote in his annual letter to C.E.O.s that year. He called global warming the most serious threat to the financial system in his 40 years of experience and promised a drastic response from his firm: making sustainability “integral to portfolio construction and risk management”; ditching investments that contribute to the problem; and pursuing not just sustainability but transparency, too, so we all could see what impacts the company was having.

headline: 3 N.Y.C. Detainees Die in Less Than a Week, Bringing Year’s Total to 9
abstract: The deaths came just a week after a judge gave New York City until the fall to come up with a plan for fixing Rikers to avoid a federal takeover.
lead_paragraph: In the week since a federal judge granted New York City at least another six months to reform its troubled jail system, three people who had recently been held at the troubled Rikers Island jail complex have died.

headline: Should You Buy Now, Pay Later? Tread Carefully.
abstract: Afterpay, Apple and other financial tech companies are popularizing installment plans for paying off shopping splurges. These programs can also cause confusion and a loss of control.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Britain Declares National Incident After Poliovirus Found in London
abstract: No cases of polio have been identified so far, but health officials urged those who were not fully immunized to seek vaccines immediately.
lead_paragraph: Health authorities in Britain have declared a national incident after finding evidence suggesting local spread of poliovirus in London.

headline: ‘Patriotic and Honest Republicans’ Telling the Truth
abstract: Readers praise the testimony of election officials and are appalled at attacks on them. Also: Election hypocrisy; a ruling on religion; Tolstoy in Ukraine; book browsing.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: Flamenco Within and Beyond a Boundary
abstract: Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana’s show “Fronteras” at the Joyce Theater has a group of very good and remarkably equal dancers sharing a bounded space.
lead_paragraph: Whether showing off or baring their souls, flamenco dancers tend to be soloists. Confining eight of them within a border — an area outlined with tape on the floor — has the flavor of a social experiment. How will they share the stage?

headline: Muna’s Fresh Start
abstract: The indie-pop band was dropped by its major label early in the pandemic, then scored a TikTok hit with “Silk Chiffon,” featuring a verse from its new label boss: Phoebe Bridgers.
lead_paragraph: The members of Muna kept calling themselves “impenetrable.” They were sorry about this, they insisted, as each lurched into the frame of a video call from a backyard in Los Angeles, ping-ponging inside jokes and rearranging themselves into different configurations.

headline: Labor Agency Seeks Broad Order Against Starbucks in Federal Court
abstract: The National Labor Relations Board is aiming to stop what it says is extensive illegal activity by the coffee chain amid a national union campaign.
lead_paragraph: Federal labor regulators have asked a court to force Starbucks to stop what they say is extensive illegal activity in response to a nationwide campaign in which workers at more than 150 corporate-owned stores have voted to unionize.

headline: The Lessons of Nothingness From Maverick Zen Monks
abstract: Art today is often a parade of the self. The Freer Gallery of Art presents objects by medieval artists who plunge you into the world by removing you from it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the country heaves, when the stress levels spike, a little nothingness goes a long way.

headline: Why the Fed Is Risking a Recession
abstract: Home sales are flagging and the rest of the economy is expected to slow, maybe sharply, as rates increase. Why is the Federal Reserve doing this?
lead_paragraph: Recession fears are ramping up as the Federal Reserve embarks upon an aggressive campaign to raise interest rates, and politicians and members of the public are increasingly questioning why central bankers are planning to cause the economy pain.

headline: Black Maternal Mortality Is Still a Crisis
abstract: Linda Villarosa’s new book, ‘Under the Skin,’ shows just how urgent the problem is.
lead_paragraph: As I was preparing to interview Linda Villarosa, the author of a new book, “Under the Skin: The Hidden Toll of Racism on American Lives and on the Health of Our Nation,” I saw a headline that reinforced how urgent her book’s message is: “CDC: Maternal mortality disparities have worsened.” The story, from Axios, showed in stark graphics how the maternal mortality gap between Black mothers and mothers of other races has only become larger since 2018. In 2020, the most recent year for which we have data, the maternal mortality rate per 100,000 births was 55.3 for Black women, 19.1 for white women and 18.2 for Hispanic women.

headline: Andrew Gillum, DeSantis’s 2018 Rival, Is Charged With Conspiracy and Fraud
abstract: The former Democratic nominee for Florida governor was indicted in a criminal case stemming from his time as Tallahassee mayor and statewide candidate.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Andrew Gillum, the Democrat who lost the 2018 Florida governor’s race to Ron DeSantis, surrendered to federal authorities in Tallahassee on Wednesday after he and a close associate were charged with conspiracy and 19 counts of fraud over how they raised and used funds when he was mayor of Tallahassee and a candidate for governor.

headline: Gadgets Were Hot. Now They’re Not.
abstract: Not long ago, it seemed impossible to find a laptop. The pandemic has upended that, too.
lead_paragraph: A lot of companies have been caught off guard by changes in our spending choices this year. Americans eager to travel and party after two years of staying largely at home are gorging on plane tickets and fancier clothes — and ignoring the patio furniture and soft pants that we splurged on in 2020.

headline: $3.2 Million Settlement in Police Killing of Daunte Wright
abstract: The settlement was reached months after a former Brooklyn Center, Minn., police officer was sentenced to two years in prison for the fatal shooting of Mr. Wright during a traffic stop.
lead_paragraph: The city of Brooklyn Center, Minn., has agreed to pay a $3.2 million settlement to the family of Daunte Wright, a 20-year-old Black man who was fatally shot by a police officer during a traffic stop in April 2021 near Minneapolis. The officer said she meant to fire her Taser instead.

headline: Driver in Fatal Times Square Attack Found Not Responsible Because of Mental Illness
abstract: Richard Rojas, a Navy veteran, spiraled after he was discharged. Prosecutors said he was culpable, but failed to sway jurors in the 2017 attack that left one dead and injured nearly two dozen.
lead_paragraph: The maroon Honda seemed to appear in Times Square out of nowhere one day in the spring of 2017, swerving onto a curb on 42nd Street, then speeding north along the sidewalk on Seventh Avenue, striking more than 20 people and scattering dozens of others before ramming a bollard at 45th Street.

headline: Rupert Murdoch and Jerry Hall Are Said to Be Divorcing
abstract: The media mogul’s fourth divorce is unlikely to change the ownership structure of Mr. Murdoch’s empire, but it could reverberate through companies such as Fox News and The Wall Street Journal.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch, the media titan, and Jerry Hall, the model and actress, are getting divorced, according to two people with knowledge of the decision. The people would speak only anonymously to discuss a personal matter.

headline: What’s the Plan for the Tampon Shortage?
abstract: As some consider switching to reusable menstrual products, factors like cost, accessibility and long-held personal preferences could be barriers.
lead_paragraph: Menstrual care products are personal, practically by definition. Various methods are passed down by family and trusted friends, carefully explained or hastily taught in bathroom stalls. Once people find a product that works for them, they tend to stick with it.

headline: Sport Is Again Divided Over Inclusiveness and a Level Playing Field
abstract: A ruling by swimming’s world governing body effectively bars transgender women from high levels of competition in the name of fairness. Critics say the decision was itself unfair.
lead_paragraph: Should the primary aim of elite sports be competitive fairness? Or does maintaining integrity mean that inclusiveness is just as important as a level playing field?

headline: Biden’s top trade negotiator defended China tariffs as an important source of leverage.
abstract: The Biden administration has come under pressure to ease tariffs as a way to help deal with inflation.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers on Wednesday pressed President Biden’s top trade negotiator over the administration’s trade strategy toward China, including what, if anything, Mr. Biden planned to do about tariffs on Chinese goods that were imposed by his predecessor.

headline: A ‘Sad Kinship’ as Towns Build Memorials to Victims of Mass Shootings
abstract: From San Bernardino, Calif., and Aurora, Colo., to Orlando, Fla., and Newtown, Conn., sites of memory honor those killed in gun violence, and survivors.
lead_paragraph: Sandra Mendoza picked a forest green panel to recall the S.U.V. her husband, Juan Espinoza, a car aficionado and restorer, proudly purchased before his life was taken.

headline: Brittney Griner’s Supporters Call on Biden to Strike a Deal to Free Her
abstract: The campaign by dozens of organizations representing people of color, women and L.G.B.T.Q. voters comes amid growing frustrations over the pace of the U.S. effort to bring her home.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of organizations representing people of color, women and L.G.B.T.Q. voters called on President Biden on Wednesday to strike a deal for the release of Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. star who has been detained in Russia since February.

headline: Title IX Gave Women Greater Access to Education. Here’s What It Says and Does.
abstract: The law has grown participation for women and girls in sports and has had other significant ramifications, too.
lead_paragraph: On June 23, 1972, President Richard M. Nixon signed an omnibus education bill that would change the paths of millions of women and girls in the United States. At first glance, the sweep conveyed by the words themselves can be hard to recognize.

headline: How a Cyborg Challenges Reality
abstract: In a letter to a fellow poet, the author details a shared truth among disabled people.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Jaylon Ferguson, Baltimore Ravens Linebacker, Dies at 26
abstract: Mr. Ferguson was unresponsive when he was found in a house in North Baltimore, the authorities said. The Baltimore police said investigators “are not ruling out the possibility of an overdose.”
lead_paragraph: Jaylon Ferguson, an outside linebacker who was entering his fourth season with the Baltimore Ravens, died after the authorities found him unresponsive in a North Baltimore home late Tuesday, the police said. He was 26.

headline: Judge Allows Fox News Defamation Suit to Include Fox Corporation
abstract: The decision broadens the possible legal exposure to the highest ranks of the Fox media empire.
lead_paragraph: A judge presiding in the defamation lawsuit against Fox News by Dominion Voting Systems ruled this week that the cable channel’s parent company, Fox Corporation, can be included in the suit, broadening the possible legal exposure to the highest ranks of the Fox media empire.

headline: Kayaking: An Outdoor Adventure and a Full-Body Workout
abstract: Watercraft sales exploded during the pandemic, and many more garages now have kayaks in them. But do you know how to get the best workout in one?
lead_paragraph: Last year, my wife and I took a kayaking day trip to the tip of Point Reyes, a peninsula just north of San Francisco formed by the San Andreas Fault shoving a slice of California out to sea.

headline: Are Large Corporate Profit Margins Causing Inflation?
abstract: New research suggests the answer is yes, in part.
lead_paragraph: Markups and profits of businesses in the United States last year were the highest since at least the 1950s, according to an analysis published on Tuesday by the Roosevelt Institute, a progressive think tank. This has raised questions about a possible relationship between corporate greed and inflation.

headline: At 52, Mabou Mines Is Still Testing Boundaries
abstract: A three-day retrospective will shine a spotlight on the group’s most daring projects.
lead_paragraph: The word “crazy” comes up fairly regularly when talking to people about the Mabou Mines theater company.

headline: Vivian Hewitt, Who Amassed a Major Collection of Black Art, Dies at 102
abstract: Ms. Hewitt, a librarian, and her husband used their keen eyes and connections in New York to buy works by Romare Bearden, Jacob Lawrence and others.
lead_paragraph: Vivian Hewitt was easy to shop for. Not for her the old standards — flowers, perfume, perhaps a new television. No clothing or jewelry.

headline: Proud Boys Case Shows Tensions Between Parallel Inquiries Into Jan. 6
abstract: Federal prosecutors and defense lawyers in the sedition case against the far-right group joined forces to request a delay in the trial, citing the hearing by the House select committee.
lead_paragraph: For the past year or so, the Justice Department and the House select committee on Jan. 6 have largely managed to avoid interfering with each other, even though both have been driving hard and fast over the same terrain in pursuit of the facts about the mob attack on the Capitol last year and what led to it.

headline: Only With Distance
abstract: After a horrible divorce, they managed to develop a fragile friendship in their 80s.
lead_paragraph: Nora Johnson had been making weekly visits to an older man after he suffered a mild stroke. But he wasn’t just any older man. “We had the worst marriage in the history of human relations,” Nora wrote in her 2014 Modern Love essay. “Dysfunctional doesn’t even begin to describe it.

headline: Drake Hits the Nightclub
abstract: How did the rapper arrive on the dance floor? And what subcultures and expectations might he experiment with next?
lead_paragraph: In the past, Drake has been focused on rewiring hip-hop with melody. But his seventh solo studio album, “Honestly, Nevermind” — which arrived as a surprise, with an elaborate nine-and-a-half-minute video for the track “Falling Back” — is an unanticipated pivot toward the dance floor. Drake has long included moments like this on his albums, but they rarely shaped the narrative. But now, for the first time, production that is hard-knocking and up-tempo is reshaping his sound.

headline: Shooting on San Francisco Train Leaves 1 Dead and 1 Injured, Police Say
abstract: The authorities said that no arrests had been made and that the shooting appeared to be an isolated event. They were still looking for the attacker, who opened fire during an argument.
lead_paragraph: An attacker opened fire on a light rail train in San Francisco on Wednesday morning, killing one person during an argument and injuring a bystander before running out of the train, the authorities said.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: A Deadly Earthquake in Afghanistan
abstract: Also, a pivotal showdown looms in Eastern Ukraine and China squeezes Taiwan’s economy.
lead_paragraph: An earthquake struck a remote and mountainous part of Afghanistan yesterday, killing more than 1,000 people and injuring at least 1,600 others.

headline: Murder Conviction Overturned for Father Whose Son Died in Hot Car
abstract: The Georgia Supreme Court ruled that extensive evidence of Justin Ross Harris’s sexual activities was “extremely and unfairly prejudicial” and could have affected the jury during his trial in 2016.
lead_paragraph: The Georgia Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned a father’s conviction on murder and other charges, nearly six years after he was found guilty of having deliberately left his toddler son to die in a hot car.

headline: Devastating Afghanistan Earthquake Leaves More Than 1,000 Dead
abstract: The quake — the deadliest in the country in two decades — was the latest in a string of tragedies to affect the country since the Taliban seized power from the U.S.-backed government last summer.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For much of the past two decades, the southeastern part of Afghanistan near the Pakistani border was plagued by insurgent activity, as police and military posts were frequently overwhelmed by Taliban fighters, and received few benefits from the American military presence.

headline: Understanding Rent Regulation in N.Y.C.
abstract: Rent-stabilized apartments in the city are due to have their largest rent increase in almost a decade.
lead_paragraph: The rent-regulation system has been in place for decades to help insulate rents from market forces, and rent-stabilized homes remain a crucial component of New York City’s dwindling affordable housing stock. The panel that regulates the rents of roughly one million homes across New York City has approved some of the largest increases in years. Here’s what you should know about how this system works.

headline: Runners-Up From Our 9th Annual Student Editorial Contest
abstract: Dress codes, book bans, bike racks and social media activism. Teenagers tackle these issues and more in these 18 runners-up essays.
lead_paragraph: Here are the 18 runners-up in our Ninth Annual Student Editorial Contest. They join 11 winners and 53 honorable mentions as our favorite essays of the 16,664 we received this year.

headline: Remember Pizza Rat? Meet Pollinator Rat.
abstract: In a city in Colombia, researchers say, common rodents help a plant produce fruit when they snack on its flower petals.
lead_paragraph: Birds do it. So do bees. Especially bees.

headline: Mykolaiv, Defiant
abstract: The Ukrainian port has become a linchpin of resistance on the southern front.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: In Boebert’s District, as Elsewhere, Democrats Surge Into G.O.P. Primary
abstract: Thousands of Democrats in Western Colorado are voting in the primary on Tuesday against Representative Lauren Boebert, part of a broader effort to defeat far-right Republicans.
lead_paragraph: BASALT, Colo. — Claudia Cunningham had never voted for a Republican in her life. She swore she couldn’t or her father would roll over in his grave. But ahead of the Colorado primary on Tuesday, she did the once-unthinkable: registered as unaffiliated so that she could vote in the G.O.P. primary against her congresswoman, Lauren Boebert.

headline: Biden Urges Congress to Suspend Gas Tax for 3 Months
abstract: As fuel prices soar in the U.S., President Biden called on Congress to temporarily lift the federal gas tax — about 18 cents per gallon of gasoline and 24 cents per gallon of diesel — through the end of September.
lead_paragraph: As fuel prices soar in the U.S., President Biden called on Congress to temporarily lift the federal gas tax — about 18 cents per gallon of gasoline and 24 cents per gallon of diesel — through the end of September.

headline: Mike Pence is expected to wade into the New York governor’s race by backing Lee Zeldin.
abstract: Mr. Pence’s endorsement comes in the final days of a contentious Republican primary for governor.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence on Wednesday was expected to announce his endorsement of Representative Lee Zeldin for governor of New York, days before the Long Island congressman faces Rudolph W. Giuliani’s son and two other candidates in a Republican primary on Tuesday.

headline: The Picaresque Life of the Man Who Modernized Neuroscience
abstract: Benjamin Ehrlich’s “The Brain in Search of Itself” is a lovingly crafted biography of the Spanish scientist (and artist, and hypnotist) who showed us what our brains are made of.
lead_paragraph: “The devil child,” his family called him.

headline: Russia Gains in the East, Threatening to Overrun Luhansk
abstract: The seizure of three strategic villages confronts Ukrainian commanders with a grim choice: fight on and risk encirclement or retreat and lose the last major centers in the region.
lead_paragraph: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — Ukrainian forces dug in for a last-ditch defense against Russian advances Wednesday in Luhansk Province, where the invaders now threaten to overrun two major cities that had resisted their halting progress.

headline: Is Inflation About to Cause a Recession?
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s extraordinary interest rate increase may rein in rising prices, but at a heavy cost.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.

headline: Does Eric Adams Own This Brooklyn Apartment? It’s Complicated.
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams has said that he no longer owns a Brooklyn co-op, despite public records to the contrary. But in public filings, he acknowledged ownership.
lead_paragraph: During his successful campaign for mayor last year, Eric Adams was dogged by a gnawing ethical question concerning his failure to disclose ownership of a Brooklyn apartment.

headline: Under Pressure From LIV Golf, the PGA Tour Defends Its Perch
abstract: Jay Monahan, the tour’s commissioner, announced prize money increases for next year to try to appease players and called the rival circuit an “irrational threat” that was trying to “buy the sport.”
lead_paragraph: CROMWELL, Conn. — For the last month, as the upstart, Saudi-backed LIV Golf circuit has poached some of the most widely known players from the established PGA Tour, there has been speculation that eventually the rival organizations might have to learn to coexist.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Meghan Stabile, Who Linked Jazz and Hip-Hop, Dies at 39
abstract: Shows that she produced on a shoestring sought to energize the jazz scene by connecting with younger audiences accustomed to D.J.s and turntables.
lead_paragraph: Meghan Stabile, who saw jazz and hip-hop as genres that could cross-pollinate and who, hoping to bring jazz to younger audiences, started a shoestring business producing concerts that explored the intersection of the two, died on June 12 in Valrico, Fla. She was 39.

headline: Tony Siragusa, a Defensive Lineman Known as Goose, Dies at 55
abstract: Siragusa won a Super Bowl with the Baltimore Ravens in the 2000 season and worked as a broadcaster after his playing career.
lead_paragraph: Tony Siragusa, the Super Bowl-winning defensive tackle and football television analyst for Fox Sports, died on Wednesday, owners of the Indianapolis Colts and the Baltimore Ravens said. He was 55 years old.

headline: Justice Dept. Issues More Subpoenas in Trump Electors Investigation
abstract: Federal prosecutors sought information from two men who had worked on behalf of the Trump campaign and a third who signed up as a Trump elector in Georgia, a state won by President Biden.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department stepped up its criminal investigation of a plan by President Donald J. Trump and his allies to create slates of so-called fake electors in a bid to keep Mr. Trump in power during the 2020 election, as federal agents delivered grand jury subpoenas on Wednesday to at least four people connected to the plan.

headline: Pentagon Pressed to Review How It Judges an Ally’s Will to Fight
abstract: Lawmakers say the U.S. government failed to provide accurate assessments amid the conflicts in Ukraine and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress is poised to force the Pentagon to study how it assesses allies’ will to fight, amid criticism from lawmakers that the U.S. government has regularly failed to make such assessments accurately.

headline: ‘Torso Killer’ Charged in Strangulation of Long Island Woman in 1968
abstract: DNA evidence linked Richard Cottingham to the killing of Diane Cusick, prompting Nassau County prosecutors to review 13 years of unsolved murders of women.
lead_paragraph: When Diane Cusick’s last class for the evening ended on Feb. 15, 1968, the 23-year-old children’s dance instructor went to a Long Island mall to buy a pair of shoes.

headline: Roger Goodell Defends Commanders Investigation, but Not Team’s Owner
abstract: The N.F.L.’s commissioner defended the league’s investigation into harassment claims against the Washington Commanders, but offered no support of the team’s owner, Daniel Snyder, who did not appear.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell stood by the league’s investigation into allegations of workplace misconduct at the Washington Commanders organization at a congressional hearing on Wednesday, despite being challenged by House members about the N.F.L.’s decision not to compel a written report of the findings or to come down more harshly on the Commanders’ owner, Daniel Snyder.

headline: Biden Just Proposed a Gas Tax Holiday. Will It Work?
abstract: The president’s idea isn’t a new one. Republicans like Glenn Youngkin and Ron DeSantis got there first.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden on Wednesday proposed a three-month suspension of federal taxes on gasoline and diesel, many Republicans rolled their eyes. And many Democrats wondered what had taken him so long.

headline: The G.O.P. Tries to Build a Gay Ghetto
abstract: Conservatives are launching a broad attack on gay rights and gay culture.
lead_paragraph: This past weekend, the Republican Party in Texas voted on an outrageous platform that not only denies the results of the 2020 presidential election, but also rejects gay marriage and seeks to “protect” minors until they turn 17 against “predatory sexual behaviors,” such as drag queens reading stories aloud to children.

headline: Uvalde School District Puts Police Chief on Leave After Mass Shooting
abstract: The state’s top police official faulted Chief Pete Arredondo for delaying the confrontation with a gunman who killed 21 people in an elementary school last month.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The chief of the school district police force in Uvalde, Texas, was placed on administrative leave after the state’s top police official faulted him for delaying the confrontation with a gunman at Robb Elementary School last month, the school district said on Wednesday.

headline: Your Summer Politics Quiz
abstract: Let’s see how much you remember.
lead_paragraph: Let’s see how much you remember.

headline: Inflation Complicates Biden’s Deliberations on Student Loan Forgiveness
abstract: The president is trying to balance his campaign promise to cancel thousands of dollars in student debt for tens of millions of borrowers with concerns such a move would be seen as a handout.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The soaring cost of food, gasoline and other staples is further complicating a fraught debate among President Biden and his closest advisers over whether to follow through on his campaign pledge to cancel thousands of dollars of student loan debt for tens of millions of people.

headline: Many Russian Cyberattacks Failed in First Months of Ukraine War, Study Says
abstract: A report published by Microsoft also found that Moscow’s disinformation campaign to establish a narrative of the war favorable to Russia was doing better than expected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new examination of how Russia used its cybercapabilities in the first months of the war in Ukraine contains a number of surprises: Moscow conducted more cyberattacks than was realized at the time to bolster its invasion, but more than two-thirds of them failed, echoing its poor performance on the physical battlefield.

headline: We Can Do Better Than Title IX
abstract: We must dismantle the grandfathered-in systemic advantages that male athletes and male-dominated sports infrastructures continue to enjoy.
lead_paragraph: When it was enacted on June 23, 1972, Title IX was the greatest thing ever to happen to girls’ and women’s sports in America.

headline: As the war grinds on, U.S. lawmakers press for better military assessments of allies’ will to fight.
abstract: WASHINGTON — Congress is poised to force the Pentagon to study how it assesses allies’ will to fight, amid criticism from lawmakers that the U.S. government has regularly failed to make such assessments accurately.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress is poised to force the Pentagon to study how it assesses allies’ will to fight, amid criticism from lawmakers that the U.S. government has regularly failed to make such assessments accurately.

headline: An Outbreak of Meningococcal Disease in Florida Is Growing, the C.D.C. Says
abstract: So far, 26 cases, including seven deaths, have been identified, primarily in men who have sex with men.
lead_paragraph: An outbreak of meningococcal disease in Florida has caused at least 26 cases of the serious illness, an official from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Wednesday. Seven of the cases have been fatal, said Sam Crowe, a C.D.C. epidemiologist.

headline: Gun Bill’s Progress Reflects Political Shift, but G.O.P. Support Is Fragile
abstract: Only two of the 14 Republicans who broke ranks to support taking up gun legislation are facing voters this year, showing how difficult such deals could be in the future.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the Senate vote on the bipartisan gun control bill.

headline: A Year Later, Some Republicans Second-Guess Boycotting the Jan. 6 Panel
abstract: The decision by Representative Kevin McCarthy not to appoint Republicans to the committee has given Democrats the chance to set out an uninterrupted narrative.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the House committee hearing on the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.

headline: ‘Chernobyl: The Lost Tapes’ Review: Excavating Images From the Fallout
abstract: This archival documentary uses footage from the former Soviet Union to reconstruct the nuclear disaster from the perspectives of people who were present.
lead_paragraph: Drawing on archival visual material from the former Soviet Union and a mix of old and contemporary interviews, the tense documentary “Chernobyl: The Lost Tapes” reconstructs the 1986 nuclear disaster from the perspectives of people present during its devastation.

headline: 6 People Killed in Helicopter Crash in West Virginia Mountains
abstract: The helicopter that crashed in Logan County was used during the Vietnam War and was being flown this week by enthusiasts.
lead_paragraph: Six people were killed when a helicopter being flown during a reunion for enthusiasts of historical aircraft crashed on Wednesday evening in Logan County, W.Va., the authorities said.

headline: ‘Corsicana’ Review: Four Lost Hearts in the Heart of Texas
abstract: In a strange and beautiful new play by Will Arbery, finding happiness is a process of failing upward.
lead_paragraph: The difference between comedy and tragedy is often just a matter of timing. Bring the curtain down early enough and even “Macbeth” can have a happy ending; in the back story of a play full of laughs, you’ll often find a bucket of tears.

headline: They Searched Online for Abortion Clinics. They Found Anti-Abortion Centers.
abstract: Using Google ads and the promise of free services, Human Coalition, a Texas nonprofit, intercepts women across the country who want to end their pregnancies and tries to stop them.
lead_paragraph: Using Google ads and the promise of free services, Human Coalition, a Texas nonprofit, intercepts women across the country who want to end their pregnancies and tries to stop them.

headline: Louisiana Nursing Home Owner Faces Cruelty Charges in Deadly Hurricane Evacuation
abstract: Bob Glynn Dean Jr. faces Medicaid fraud and other criminal charges after sending more than 800 residents to a squalid warehouse in August 2021, when Hurricane Ida pummeled the state, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The owner of seven nursing homes in Louisiana who sent more than 800 residents to a squalid warehouse lacking restrooms and proper medicine last year when Hurricane Ida battered the region was arrested on Wednesday on state fraud and cruelty charges, the authorities said.

headline: Photosynthetic Process
abstract: Jeff Chen’s puzzle gives us twice the bang for our buck.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Jeff Chen is back, and his puzzle is something to get excited about.

headline: A study of the war details Russia’s many failed cyberattacks, but also its power in disinformation.
abstract: WASHINGTON — A new examination of how Russia used its cybercapabilities in the first months of the war in Ukraine contains a number of surprises: Moscow conducted more cyberattacks than was realized at the time to bolster its invasion, but more than two-thirds of them failed, echoing its poor performance on the physical battlefield.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new examination of how Russia used its cybercapabilities in the first months of the war in Ukraine contains a number of surprises: Moscow conducted more cyberattacks than was realized at the time to bolster its invasion, but more than two-thirds of them failed, echoing its poor performance on the physical battlefield.

headline: ‘Love & Gelato’ Review: A Young Girl, Transfigured by Italy
abstract: A mother’s final wish leads her daughter to retrace her Roman holiday in this lighthearted coming-of-age story.
lead_paragraph: For many American teenagers, college is the great undiscovered country. But in the romantic comedy, “Love & Gelato,” Lina (Susanna Skaggs) has just lost her beloved mother to cancer. Before she matriculates to her first year of university at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, she is obligated to live out her mother’s final wish for her. Her mother had a transformative trip to Italy in her youth, and her request is that Lina should follow in her footsteps. Cautious Lina can find a way to worry about anything, but magnanimously, she agrees to spend her summer in Rome.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Jewish Political Clout at Risk In a Changing New York City
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 23, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “When I was in Congress, you could have a minyan in the New York delegation. We went from a minyan to a minority to hardly anybody.”

headline: Corrections: June 23, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, June 23, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about a rent increase of at least 3.25 percent for rent-stabilized homes in New York City misstated how Christina Smyth, a representative of landlords on the Rent Guidelines Board, voted. She voted in favor of the proposal that passed, not against it.

headline: Russia Crimps Gas Flows Just as Europe Races to Stock Up for Winter
abstract: The routine summer practice of filling Europe’s natural gas tanks has become a battle after Russia cut deliveries by more than half.
lead_paragraph: Germany’s largest storage chamber for natural gas stretches underneath a swath of farmland the size of nine soccer fields in the western part of the country. The bucolic area has become a kind of battlefield in Europe’s effort to defend itself against a looming gas crisis driven by Russia.

headline: The Dream’s Clean-Slate Strategy Made Space for a Star: Rhyne Howard
abstract: Howard is a top candidate for the Rookie of the Year Award. Atlanta is rebuilding after a few rocky years, on and off the court.
lead_paragraph: The Atlanta Dream were looking to start over.

headline: From Russian Elites, No Sign of Broad Challenge to Putin
abstract: Many business owners and intellectuals fled Russia after the invasion of Ukraine, but others stayed behind, struggling to redefine their lives. Their diverging choices do not add up to a broad challenge to Vladimir Putin’s war.
lead_paragraph: Aleksandr Y. Lebedev looks like a prime target for sanctions meant to prompt Russia’s elites to turn against the Kremlin. He is a onetime billionaire and a former K.G.B. agent with deep connections both in Russia’s ruling class and in the West; his son owns British newspapers and is a member of the House of Lords.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Ukraine’s president addresses African leaders.
lead_paragraph: Volodymyr Zelensky, the president of Ukraine, lobbied the African Union for support this week. He faced an uphill battle, addressing leaders who have close ties to Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin.

headline: In a first for bloodhounds, Trumpet wins Westminster.
abstract: Trumpet, 4, fended off a tough field of fellow champions, earning Best in Show out of the hound group.
lead_paragraph: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — Trumpet, a magnificently be-wrinkled and be-jowled bloodhound from Illinois, won Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Wednesday night, nosing out a tough crowd of competitors that included a fluffy Samoyed, a silky Maltese and an all-business German shepherd.

headline: Prosecutors Ask That Ghislaine Maxwell Spend at Least 30 Years in Prison
abstract: Ms. Maxwell, who will be sentenced next week, showed an “utter lack of remorse” for helping Jeffrey Epstein recruit and abuse girls, federal prosecutors told a judge.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Ghislaine Maxwell’s sentencing.

headline: The Tangled Tale of Eric Adams’s Apartment in Brooklyn
abstract: The mayor acknowledged that he does, in fact, still co-own the apartment, which he’d previously said was fully owned by a former partner.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at the status of Mayor Eric Adams’s ownership of an apartment in Brooklyn. And, if you’ve ever wanted to own your very own subway car, one is about to be auctioned off.

headline: As Russian forces fortify a Ukrainian nuclear power plant, employees are fleeing repression, local officials say.
abstract: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, Europe’s largest, lies in southern Ukraine in a strategically important spot.
lead_paragraph: Russian soldiers who control a giant nuclear power plant in Ukraine are detaining workers and subjecting them to brutal interrogations in a search for possible saboteurs, prompting many employees to leave and raising concerns about safety, Ukrainian officials say.

headline: Stephen Colbert Taunts Ron Johnson for Faking It
abstract: Colbert said that the Wisconsin senator tried to avoid talking to reporters after Tuesday’s Jan. 6 hearing, “but like most things, he’s not very good at that.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: The Stranded Sons of Shakhtar Donetsk
abstract: One of Ukraine’s top soccer teams rushed its youth academy players out of the path of war in February. Months later, many of the boys are stuck in a lonely limbo.
lead_paragraph: SPLIT, Croatia — It was in their moment of triumph, when they had beaten their opponents and come together to collect their medals, when some of the boys were overcome with sadness, when the tears welled in their eyes.

headline: Extreme Weather Hits China With Massive Floods and Scorching Heat
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people have been displaced by the historic flooding. Elsewhere, record-high temperatures are rupturing roads and driving energy consumption.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China is grappling with extreme weather emergencies across the country, with the worst flooding in decades submerging houses and cars in the south and record-high heat waves in the northern and central provinces causing roads to buckle.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: When Did Perfume Stop Being About Sex?
abstract: Its decades-long grip on the global fragrance industry is slipping. You can thank changing views on sexual orientation and gender.
lead_paragraph: When a new Yves Saint Laurent perfume came out in 2001, Tom Ford, the creative director of the house at the time, threw a sensational party at the Paris Stock Exchange, where he put a gaggle of practically nude models on display in a giant plexiglass container. The fragrance was called Nu, French for “nude.”

headline: G.O.P. Testimony at Jan. 6 Panel Exposes a Party Torn Between Truth and Trump
abstract: A Democratic-run committee relies on Republican witnesses to build the case against the former president — in searing detail.
lead_paragraph: As the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol has built its public case that Donald J. Trump was at the center of an attempted coup, the panel has relied heavily on a seemingly unlikely stream of witnesses: Mr. Trump’s own advisers, his fellow Republicans and even his own family.

headline: Reporting on the Future, Now
abstract: Cade Metz, a technology correspondent for The Times, shares how he approaches his reporting and what excites him most about the beat.
lead_paragraph: In labs across the world, scientists are developing the power of quantum mechanics, a field of physics that behaves unlike anything we experience in our everyday lives. In 2019, Google announced that its quantum computer had achieved “quantum supremacy,” which could allow new kinds of computers to perform calculations at what were once unimaginable speeds. Other companies and research labs are exploring techniques like quantum teleportation, which sends data between locations without moving the matter that holds it — a concept that Albert Einstein had deemed impossible.

headline: Elvis Broke Fashion Boundaries, Too
abstract: He was many things, as a new biopic illustrates, but one of the least appreciated was his role as a gender pioneer.
lead_paragraph: Everybody has a personal Elvis. He is there for us all, lodged in the collective unconscious, one of few humans who can legitimately be termed an icon, although it is not always certain of what.

headline: Molière, Turning 400, Can Still Surprise
abstract: In an anniversary year for the playwright, new productions in the Paris region show why his work still appeals to myriad audiences.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “I’m in shock,” a teenage boy sitting near me declared when the lights went up on a recent performance of Molière’s “The Forced Marriage” at the Comédie-Française, France’s oldest theater company. “It was really sexual,” one of his schoolmates told her friends on the way out. “It’s not the kind of stuff you should show.”

headline: European leaders are meeting today to decide on granting Ukraine E.U. candidate status.
abstract: Their approval would allow Ukraine to be a candidate to join the bloc, starting what could be a long road.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders will meet on Thursday to put Ukraine on a path toward joining the bloc, signaling to the embattled nation — and to Russia — that they expect Ukraine to win the benefits of being in the club, even if it takes a decade or longer to fully join.

headline: What Fed Chair Powell has said about inflation, interest rates and the risk of a recession.
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, is appearing before the House financial services committee on Thursday, after testifying in the Senate on Wednesday about the central bank’s efforts to bring inflation under control. Notably, Mr. Powell said that while the Fed was trying to avoid it, a recession was “certainly a possibility.”
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, is appearing before the House financial services committee on Thursday, after testifying in the Senate on Wednesday about the central bank’s efforts to bring inflation under control. Notably, Mr. Powell said that while the Fed was trying to avoid it, a recession was “certainly a possibility.”

headline: Korean currency falls to 13-year low amid global recession fears.
abstract: South Korea’s export-driven economy makes it particularly sensitive to conditions in the global economy.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — The South Korean won hit its lowest point against the U.S. dollar in nearly 13 years on Thursday, opening at 1,299 won and weakening to more than 1,300 in intraday trading.

headline: Mink!
abstract: Throughout her life, Representative Patsy Mink challenged the status quo. As a leading advocate of Title IX, she defended the bill against those who sought to weaken it.
lead_paragraph: Throughout her life, Representative Patsy Mink challenged the status quo. As a leading advocate of Title IX, she defended the bill against those who sought to weaken it.

headline: Seeking a West Village Rental for Less Than $3,000. Which Option Did She Choose?
abstract: When a pandemic price hike forced her out of her one-bedroom apartment, a downtown renter searched for something comparable that she could afford. Here’s what she found.
lead_paragraph: When a pandemic price hike forced her out of her one-bedroom apartment, a downtown renter searched for something comparable that she could afford. Here’s what she found.

headline: The Ancient Art of Falconry at the Jersey Shore
abstract: How Ocean City cleared the gulls from its boardwalk — with falcons and hawks.
lead_paragraph: The war between humans and gulls in Ocean City, N.J., reached a turning point in 2019. In the years leading up to then, the town’s populations of great black-backed, ring-billed, laughing and herring gulls had become increasingly comfortable snatching beachgoers’ French fries, potato chips and other finger foods. One day that spring, Ocean City’s mayor, Jay Gillian, watched as a gull swooped into a stroller on the boardwalk and stole a slice of pizza from a toddler’s hands. The mayor swears he saw blood on the little girl’s face, though he admits it may have been sauce. The town’s brand — its slogan is “America’s Greatest Family Resort” — was being sullied.

headline: Poem: love & the memory of it
abstract: Jay Hopler died last week. Illness streaks across this poem from his final collection — but also love.
lead_paragraph: I always remember these lines in Jay Hopler’s debut book of poems, “Green Squall”: “Being born is a shame–/But it’s not so bad, as journeys go. … ” Sixteen years later comes Hopler’s third book of poems, one that documents his journey on the other end of a life, as he grapples with a terminal illness. Illness streaks across these new poems, toppling them with sonic devastation. The ending of this poem speaks for itself, but its sadness intermingles with the speaker’s love for the “atomic girl” and the way her laughter “echoed off the rocks.” Hopler died on June 15, 2022 at the age of 51. Selected by Victoria Chang

headline: What Is American Music? Three Classical Albums Offer Answers.
abstract: Recordings by the violinists Daniel Hope and Johnny Gandelsman, as well as by PUBLIQuartet, wrestle with the country’s past and present.
lead_paragraph: What is American classical music, exactly? When crafting their answers, programmers have historically chosen one of two approaches: cautious, piecemeal efforts or risky, all-in-one fusion.

headline: When the Backlash Came for Title IX, She Fought Back
abstract: Throughout her life, Representative Patsy Mink challenged the status quo. As a leading advocate of Title IX, she defended the bill against those who sought to weaken it.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, on June 23, President Richard Nixon signed Title IX, the 37-word snippet within the Educational Amendments of 1972 that prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex “under any education program or activity receiving federal financial assistance.”

headline: Never Mind Your Wallet. Armed Robbers Want Your French Bulldog.
