abstract: The House Jan. 6 committee painted a picture of how President Donald J. Trump schemed to pressure the Justice Department into overturning the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: The House Jan. 6 committee painted a picture of how President Donald J. Trump schemed to pressure the Justice Department into overturning the 2020 election.

headline: On Loving Day, a Celebration of Their Own Indefatigable Love
abstract: Ashley Burks and Anthony Misiak, an interracial couple, knew they were meant to be together after meeting in college, even if others didn’t.
lead_paragraph: From the moment they accidentally bumped into each other on campus at the University of Illinois, Chicago, in August 2016, Kia Ashley Burks and Anthony Joseph Misiak have believed they were perfectly suited for each other.

headline: After Many High School Reunions, Classmates Become Newlyweds
abstract: As members of Indianola High School’s class of 1992, Brenda Langstraat and Ve Bui saw each other every five years. Eventually, those reunions led to love.
lead_paragraph: Ve Bui loved high school so much, he thought it would go on forever.

headline: Winning Her Heart Through His Way With Words
abstract: Alejandro Rojas and Jaclyn Belson met a year ago on the dating app Bumble. She was immediately drawn to his sense of humor. He was taken with her blue eyes.
lead_paragraph: While the photos Alejandro José Rojas had uploaded to the dating app Bumble caught Jaclyn Ariel Belson’s eye when she saw his profile in June 2021, it was the captions Mr. Rojas had written for the images that really stood out to her.

headline: This Is How We Talk About Ending Things
abstract: First we agree to stop seeing each other. Then we pretend we never had that conversation.
lead_paragraph: We decided to go to 7-11 to restock our caffeine supplies. He wanted his favorite brand of iced coffee; I wanted some of those Yerba Mate energy drinks. These caffeine treks had become a new sort of love language for us, my growing feelings manifesting through the memorization of his coffee order.

headline: What’s Two ‘Yentas’ Plus One Senator? A Lifetime Together.
abstract: Adam Topper and Jordan Manekin were set up in 2019 by two women they call “the yentas,” and later married by Senator Cory Booker.
lead_paragraph: Soon after Adam Michael Topper met Jordan Cole Manekin in the spring of 2019, he started to compare him to another man in his life: Senator Cory Booker, Democrat from New Jersey, who was then Mr. Topper’s boss.

headline: Party Animals?
abstract: What happens when some of our favorite creatures are left to their own devices.
lead_paragraph: TWO DOGSWritten and illustrated by Ian Falconer

headline: In Warsaw Park, Ukraine’s Teen Refugees Hang Out and Hang On
abstract: Some fled to Poland’s capital alone. All feel deeply uneasy about the future. For the young Ukrainians packing into Poland’s capital, a park offers a place where they can try to cope, together.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Every afternoon at a park outside a distinctively Stalinesque skyscraper in central Warsaw, scores of Ukrainian teenagers come together. They are young refugees, trying to cope.

headline: Conservatives Lose 2 Races in U.K., Adding to Pressure on Boris Johnson
abstract: The double defeat exposed the party’s vulnerabilities and was likely to revive talk of another no-confidence vote against the prime minister.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s governing Conservative Party lost two strategically important parliamentary seats on Friday, prompting the resignation of a party chairman and raising fresh doubts about the future of the country’s scandal-scarred leader, Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

headline: Corrections: June 24, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, June 24, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about subpoenas issued by the Justice Department in investigation of the Trump fraudulent electors plan misspelled the name of a Trump campaign aide who received a subpoena. The aide is Shawn Flynn, not Sean.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Title IX Promised Gender Equity. But Who Enforced It? Parents.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 24, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I was never a bra-burning feminist. But I was able to show my daughter that she can stand up for herself and not be treated as someone lesser or not equal.”

headline: Trevor Noah Has Gun Law Ideas for New York
abstract: Noah says the state should propose new restrictions where “anyone can buy a gun if they want, but the gun stores are only open on the nights that the Knicks win.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Ukraine’s foreign minister sees E.U. candidacy as a crucial step toward joining a ‘liberal empire.’
abstract: “History has been made,” he said of Ukraine’s being accepted as a candidate for E.U. membership.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — As the European Union summit began in Brussels on Thursday evening, an aide to Ukraine’s foreign minister tuned into the proceedings on a laptop.

headline: Court Ruling on Guns: The Legislature’s Options
abstract: It’s now up to Albany to pass restrictions on gun ownership that would be allowed under the Supreme Court decision invalidating New York’s law.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at what the Legislature can do now that the Supreme Court has invalidated New York’s concealed-carry gun law. We’ll also look at how changing demographics are reflected in a House race in Manhattan.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘Rise’ Review: To Be Giannis
abstract: The story of the real-life N.B.A. superstar Giannis Antetokounmpo is told with heartfelt charm in this endearing Disney+ biopic.
lead_paragraph: “Giannis: The Improbable Rise of an NBA MVP,” Mirin Fader’s biography of Giannis Antetokounmpo, portrays the Greek-born basketball superstar as a young man of sweet-natured innocence and irrepressible enthusiasm. Immigrating to the United States to play pro ball for the Milwaukee Bucks, where he was the 15th overall pick in the 2013 N.B.A. draft, he sees everything through eyes of guileless wonder: He’s dazzled by chocolate custard and hot dogs, by peanut butter bars and mixed-berry smoothies.

headline: Fed Confronts a ‘New World’ of Inflation
abstract: Central banks had a longstanding playbook for how inflation worked. In the postpandemic era, all bets are off.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are questioning whether their longstanding assumptions about inflation still apply as price gains remain stubbornly and surprisingly rapid — a bout of economic soul-searching that could have big implications for the American economy.

headline: After Years of Acrimony, China and Australia Cautiously Reach Out
abstract: The arrival of a new government in Canberra has set the stage for ministerial talks and overtures for easing tensions. Plenty still divides the two nations.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Four years after Australia’s ties with China entered a downward spiral, with Australia emerging as an energetic counterweight to Beijing’s growing might, the two countries have begun to explore whether they can patch things up.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Let the Record Show’ and ‘Hell of a Book’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: LET THE RECORD SHOW: A Political History of ACT UP New York, 1987-1993, by Sarah Schulman. (Picador, 752 pp., $22.) Schulman’s book, based on 17 years of interviews with nearly 200 members of the influential direct-action group committed to ending AIDS, “doesn’t seek to memorialize history but to ransack it,” the former Times critic Parul Sehgal wrote. “This is not reverent, definitive history. This is a tactician’s bible.”

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Baz Luhrmann's latest film, "Elvis."
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Baz Luhrmann's latest film, "Elvis."

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, June 24, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: ‘Rent, Forever’: The Price of Living in New York City
abstract: Most New Yorkers will never own their homes, and yet people keep coming. Why?
lead_paragraph: New York City is a renter’s town.

headline: Jan. 6 Has Surfaced America’s Disdain for Democracy
abstract: Jamelle Bouie explores what the Jan. 6 hearings reveal about America’s political project.
lead_paragraph: The Jan. 6 hearings have made it clear that Donald Trump led a concerted, monthslong effort to overturn a democratic election. The extensive interviews — over 1,000 — that the House select committee conducted prove that Trump was told there was no evidence of election fraud, but he pressed his anti-democratic case regardless. And it appears that the hearings may be making an impact on public opinion: An ABC News/Ipsos survey released Sunday found that 58 percent of respondents believe Trump should be charged with a crime for his role in the Jan. 6 attack, up from 52 percent in April.

headline: For the Most Complex Heroines in Animation, Look to Japan
abstract: The girls and women of anime tend to experience the conflicting emotions of real life. That’s because the auteurs try to create “an everyday, real person.”
lead_paragraph: At a time of widespread debate over the depiction of women in film, the top Japanese animators have long been creating heroines who are more layered and complex than many of their American counterparts. They have faults and weaknesses and tempers as well as strengths and talents. They’re not properties or franchises; they’re characters the filmmakers believe in.

headline: New York City Rent Increase: What You Need to Know
abstract: The increase will be the highest in nearly a decade.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers who live in rent-stabilized apartments will soon pay higher rents — 3.25 percent more on one-year leases and 5 percent more on two-year leases — the sharpest increase in nearly a decade.

headline: The Sleep Debt Collector Is Here
abstract: Recent studies in humans and mice have shown that late nights and early mornings may cause long lasting damage to your brain.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: How Droll: Story Collections Poke Fun at Human Contradiction
abstract: From Acapulco to Red Lobster, mushrooms to Middle Eastern Studies, new short fiction puts the tensions of modern life on full display.
lead_paragraph: Dream sequences. References to Heidegger and Red Lobster. Special appearances by a dog named Freud and a metaphysics-spouting dragon. A woman posing as a Surrealist painting of a woman looking in the mirror.

headline: To Understand Alsace Whites, Look to the Past
abstract: The wines may be easy to enjoy, but they are hard to find in the United States. The reasons can be found in the recent history of the region.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been accused of reaching the age where I regularly refer to the past.

headline: Meet the New Man Behind the National Park Service
abstract: The park service’s first Native American director, Charles F. Sams III, has plans to address overcrowding, improve accessibility and share the country’s untold stories.
lead_paragraph: Last December, Charles F. Sams III made history when he became the first Native American to be appointed director of the National Park Service. He had his work cut out for him.

headline: How to Start Investing, Even in a Bear Market
abstract: The immediate outlook is grim, but low-cost funds that track the entire market can help you prosper over the long term, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: The party in the financial markets is long over. Chatter about hot stocks and fabulous opportunities in cryptocurrencies and NFTs has died down to a whisper. Recession and bear market are the big buzz words these days.

headline: What They Wanted
abstract: My grandparents died as they lived: on their own terms and holding hands.
lead_paragraph: There was nothing traditional about my grandparents, other than, perhaps, my grandmother’s rabid interest in my love life.

headline: You Don’t Want to Wear a Mask? Do It for Hugh Jackman.
abstract: Beginning in July, Broadway will no longer require audiences to mask up. Actors and theater workers aren’t loving the idea.
lead_paragraph: Last month, in a much-celebrated moment of public disciplining during a talk back with the cast of “Company,” a woman in the audience who was told to please put her mask back on refused and then, mocking the directive, waved it in the air and placed it over her eyes. Up onstage, Patti LuPone was not having it and told her to get out. As if incubated in a lab manufacturing legend-resistant organisms — and unlike almost anyone else on the west side of Manhattan — this was a person immune to the ire of Patti LuPone. Yelling back defiantly, she proclaimed, “I pay your salary.” A member of the theater’s Covid safety staff proceeded to escort her out of the building.

headline: A Psychedelic Renaissance at the V.A.
abstract: Four Veterans Affairs clinicians, frustrated with existing treatments for addiction and PTSD, have turned to drugs the government still deems illegal.
lead_paragraph: The last known experiment at a Department of Veterans Affairs clinic with psychedelic-assisted therapy started in 1963. That was the year President John F. Kennedy was assassinated. “Surfin’ U.S.A.” topped the music charts, and American troops had not yet deployed to Vietnam.

headline: From Florida to Poland, We Must March for the Right to Exist
abstract: The boundary between freedom and oppression is thin.
lead_paragraph: Last Saturday, toward the end of the Riga-Kyiv Pride March for Freedom in Latvia, I saw a burly man in a unicorn head lean out of a second-floor window and wave grandly at the parade below. His yellow and blue shirt had “Kyiv” emblazoned across it. March participants had been leading the 5,000-strong crowd in the chant “Make love, not war,” artfully linking the right to love, everywhere, with the right to self-determination and peace in Ukraine. In response to the queer Minotaur in Ukraine’s colors, the marchers erupted into cries of “Slava Ukraini,” or “Glory to Ukraine.”

headline: The Jan. 6 Hearings Have Been So Much Better Than I Expected
abstract: They might even change a few minds.
lead_paragraph: I felt a nauseating dread as the Jan. 6 hearings approached, fearing that all they would do is demonstrate Donald Trump’s impunity. That the former president attempted a coup has been obvious since his mob descended on the Capitol, if not before. With Trump, however, the question has never been whether he’s committed outrageous misdeeds, but whether those misdeeds can be made to matter. Over and over again, the answer to that question has been no.

headline: No One Is Above the Law, and That Starts With Donald Trump
abstract: The prosecution of the former president is not only permissible but required for the sake of American democracy.
lead_paragraph: In a 2019 ruling requiring the former White House counsel Don McGahn to testify at a congressional hearing about former President Donald Trump’s alleged abuses of power, Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson declared that “presidents are not kings.” If we take that admonition from our next Supreme Court justice seriously and look at the evidence amassed so far by the House select committee on the Jan. 6 attack, we can — and in fact must — conclude that the prosecution of Mr. Trump is not only permissible but required for the sake of American democracy.

headline: These Homeowners Decided to Rent Again
abstract: Some homeowners looked at rising home prices and decided to get out while the going was still good. Now they’re renters again.
lead_paragraph: As a general rule, it’s a bad idea to try to time a market, and housing is no exception. But some homeowners who’ve been sitting on the sidelines watching their home values soar have decided that now is the time to cash out before a downward slide takes hold.

headline: How the Artistic Director of the Moth Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Catherine Burns, unsurprisingly, likes to read and remember people’s stories, while running through Brooklyn, gardening and playing games with her family.
lead_paragraph: “We invite people from all walks of life to come tell a 10-minute story,” said Catherine Burns, the artistic director of the Moth, renowned for its storytelling series. After getting its start in a New York City living room 25 years ago, the Moth has expanded into stage and touring performances, television, educational programs, radio and podcasts. A typical storytelling event, Ms. Burns said, can feature an astronaut, a former K.G.B. prisoner and a dental hygienist. “I get to meet the wildest, most wonderful variety of people in this job.”

headline: Crime, Taxes, Abortion: Where the 7 Candidates for N.Y. Governor Stand
abstract: Ahead of the state primary elections, Republican and Democratic candidates expound on the issues — and exactly where upstate New York begins.
lead_paragraph: In the primary races for governor of New York, the candidates in each party naturally have some common alliances but also some surprising differences.

headline: How Alton Mason Went from ‘Male Model of the Year’ to ‘Elvis’
abstract: Once known for doing back flips on the runway, the 24-year-old makes his acting debut playing Little Richard.
lead_paragraph: Name: Alton Mason

headline: In Flint, a Pull to Clearer Waters Down South
abstract: The photographer LaToya Ruby Frazier traveled to Michigan in 2016 to document the ongoing crisis that sent one family back to the fresh springs of Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: Amid a financial crisis in 2014, Michigan’s then-governor Rick Snyder cut costs by switching the city of Flint’s water supply from Lake Huron (treated with corrosion controls at the Detroit Water and Sewerage Department) to the Flint River. Contaminated with fecal matter and other toxic waste, the river water was pumped through pipes that were leaching lead and sickened this predominantly Black city of about 100,000, nearly half of whom live in poverty.

headline: Recruiting Trail Puts Basketball’s Changes on Display
abstract: Young prospects in men’s basketball have numerous ways to impress college coaches (and options to bypass them). But the way coaches are looking for new talent has changed, too.
lead_paragraph: BLAIRSTOWN, N.J. — Three days after traveling from his family’s vacation home in Porto Heli, Greece, Symeon Efstathiou found himself in a basketball gym at a remote boarding school tucked away in the northwest corner of New Jersey.

headline: What to Know About N.Y.’s Primary Election on June 28
abstract: How to vote as Gov. Kathy Hochul seeks to fend off Democratic rivals and as Republicans pick a challenger.
lead_paragraph: The race for New York’s next governor is in full swing, and Primary Day is set for Tuesday, June 28.

headline: In Russia’s War, China and India Emerge as Financiers
abstract: Their purchases of Russian crude are undermining the West’s efforts to isolate the Kremlin and upending the global oil markets.
lead_paragraph: As Russia tries to break the stranglehold of sanctions, China and India are emerging as Moscow’s pivotal financiers by purchasing large amounts of Russian crude, putting themselves in the middle of the messy war with Ukraine and a geopolitical standoff with the West.

headline: With Swag and Swagger, State Democrats Vie for Front of Presidential Primary Line
abstract: After Iowa’s disastrous 2020 caucuses, Democratic officials are weighing drastic changes to the 2024 calendar. States, angling for early attention, are waxing poetic. Behold, the New Jersey Turnpike!
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — High-ranking Democrats distributed gift bags and glossy pamphlets, waxing poetic about New Hampshire’s Manchester Airport and the New Jersey Turnpike.

headline: When the Rent Rushes Relationships
abstract: Soaring rents across the country have motivated some young couples to move in together earlier than they planned.
lead_paragraph: Xin-rui Lee didn’t initially want to live with her partner.

headline: After Six-Decade Hiatus, Experimental Psychedelic Therapy Returns to the V.A.
abstract: A series of clinical trials using MDMA and psilocybin mushrooms represent a resurrection of promising research abandoned in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Veterans Affairs recently began offering psychedelic substances to patients as a part of clinical trials, a major step in the quest to determine the therapeutic potential of illegal drugs the federal government has long deemed dangerous.

headline: Experts Say We Have the Tools to Fight Addiction. So Why Are More Americans Overdosing Than Ever?
abstract: Why haven’t we solved the addiction crisis?
lead_paragraph: For most of his life, Harris Marquesano struggled to live inside his own skin. He was a sweet boy — affectionate with his parents, protective of his little sister and devoted to his friends. But he had more energy than he knew what to do with, and he worried almost constantly. In preschool, when his teacher had to have surgery, he was so distressed by her absence that he tried to take over his classroom, presiding over each playgroup like a tiny, anxious general. By junior high, he was acting out in earnest. Some of Harris’s teachers suggested to his mother, Stephanie Marquesano, that he was just testing limits. But she knew it was more than that. “He was crawling out of his own skin half the time,” she said. “Running around and acting out was the only way for him to manage that feeling.”

headline: States Rush to Revamp Laws After Supreme Court’s Gun Ruling
abstract: After some restrictions on gun permits were deemed unconstitutional, legislators announced plans to craft new laws that honor the ruling while still creating limits.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: ‘At Their Breaking Point’: Tenants Fight to Stay in Their Homes
abstract: Since New York’s eviction moratorium ended in January, tenants and their landlords are returning to housing court.
lead_paragraph: Rocio Quero Yescas is 56 and walks with a cane, and she fears she will trip and fall because the floor tiles in her apartment keep peeling up.

headline: Her Father Fled the Nazis. She’s the New U.S. Ambassador to Germany.
abstract: For Amy Gutmann, a respected democracy scholar, her role as President Biden’s envoy to Germany is not a job, “it’s a mission,” one both professional and personal.
lead_paragraph: FEUCHTWANGEN, Germany — After Amy Gutmann’s father fled the Nazis in 1934, he swore never to set foot in Germany again. For the rest of his life, he boycotted German goods and only spoke English to his daughter. Germany, he impressed on her when she was growing up, was “very bad.”

headline: Truck Beach Was For Locals. Then the Oceanfront Homes Arrived.
abstract: In the Hamptons, a longstanding battle over a sliver of beach returns to court.
lead_paragraph: For as long as Nathaniel Miller can remember, he has spent every summer at a beach in Napeague, a once-remote strip of marsh, pine forest and dunes sandwiched between Amagansett and Montauk in the Hamptons.

headline: What is a recession, and when is the next one going to begin?
abstract: Recessions since World War II have lasted just over 10 months each, on average. The last one, which began in 2020, lasted just two months.
lead_paragraph: Chaotic stock markets, sky-high interest rates and the pain of inflation have left one question at the top of Americans’ minds: Are we in a recession?

headline: How Does Temperature Affect Wine?
abstract: In hot weather, it’s important to think about the weight and serving temperature of a wine, rather than its color.
lead_paragraph: Some people imagine the best wines in hot weather are exclusively whites and rosés. But I have never subscribed to this thinking. I still want to drink reds with plenty of the foods that might end up on a grill at any sort of summer gathering.

headline: Does Keeping Jurors Unbiased Mean Keeping Everyone Else Quiet?
abstract: A journalist’s comments prompt the delay of a high-profile criminal trial, and everyone gets a reminder in how careful they need to be in discussing ongoing cases.
lead_paragraph: When Brittany Higgins, a former government staff member, came forward with her allegations of rape, which she said took place inside Australia’s Parliament building, the entire country was transfixed. Her claim that she had been assaulted by a colleague in the defense minister’s office while she was sleeping after a night of drinking prompted protests across Australia by women demanding changes in a male-dominated political culture.

headline: ‘I’ve Never Seen a Flood Like This’: Bangladesh Reels From Heavy Rains
abstract: South Asia is used to downpours, and occasional floods, during monsoon season. But this year’s flooding has been extreme, especially in Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: PEKERKHAL, Bangladesh — Rohima Begum was cooking breakfast last week when the floodwaters flowed into her tin-and-bamboo home and began racing across the floor.

headline: Analysis: What the battle for Sievierodonetsk shows about the war.
abstract: Wars are not won by retreats. But it is also possible to win the battle and lose the war.
lead_paragraph: Wars are not won by retreats. But it is also possible to win the battle and lose the war.

headline: One Elite High School’s Struggle Over Admissions
abstract: A fierce debate about the criteria for enrolling students at Lowell, in California, has echoes of the soul-searching happening across the U.S. education system.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, meaningful questions have been asked about the tests that often sit at the heart of admissions to the top schools in the United States.

headline: U.S. Repatriates Afghan Whose Guantánamo Detention Was Unlawful
abstract: Qatar played a pivotal role in the transfer of the man, who was held for 15 years, into the custody of the Taliban government of Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: The United States on Friday complied with a federal court order and released a former Afghan militiaman from detention in Guantánamo Bay, in a case that reflects the changing political realities of Afghanistan.

headline: A New Status Quo
abstract: The Supreme Court declared that Americans have a broad right to arm themselves in public.
lead_paragraph: Two major developments in Washington yesterday upended the terrain of the American gun debate. The first was a Supreme Court ruling striking down a New York State law that restricted people’s ability to carry guns in public. The second was the Senate passage of a bipartisan bill that would become the most significant change to federal gun safety laws in nearly three decades.

headline: Myanmar Junta Sends Aung San Suu Kyi to Solitary Confinement
abstract: The United Nations and human rights advocates criticized the transfer from house arrest, and urged the regime to free her and all other political prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar’s ousted civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, has been transferred from house arrest to prison and is being held in solitary confinement, according to a spokesman for the military junta that seized power last year.

headline: For the Mets, Deep Breaths, a Little Chatter and a Lot of Wins
abstract: The top team in the National League has improved in numerous ways. Part of that process was slowing down and finding a way to maintain focus.
lead_paragraph: Last season, the Mets were in first place in their division for four months before collapsing. They finished with a 77-85 record, their 10th losing season in the past 15. One of the biggest culprits: an offense that was one of the worst in Major League Baseball. Only three teams scored fewer runs, and those teams averaged nearly 100 losses.

headline: An Ace Finds Success by Visualizing Failure
abstract: In building himself up, and challenging his own limits, Joe Musgrove of the San Diego Padres has found it valuable to imagine what might go wrong. It could get him a Cy Young Award.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Joe Musgrove was in the pool, following the instructions of his teachers, but he and his fellow neophytes were struggling. His stomach convulsed, and his lungs pleaded with his brain to surface for air. Musgrove, the emerging ace of the San Diego Padres, held out until the last desperate instant, almost to the breaking point, before he finally came up for air.

headline: Commonwealth Meeting in Rwanda Has a Long Agenda. Human Rights Isn’t on It.
abstract: A summit of the organization that was born out of the embers of the British Empire is being held for the first time in the African country, but discussion of the host’s alleged abuses is conspicuously missing.
lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — Presidents, princes and prime ministers from across the world gathered on Friday in Kigali, the hilly capital of Rwanda, to examine some of the pressing issues facing their nations and the association that unites them: the Commonwealth.

headline: In Russia’s war over Ukraine, China and India emerge as financiers.
abstract: As Russia tries to break the stranglehold of sanctions, China and India are emerging as Moscow’s pivotal financiers by purchasing large amounts of Russian crude, putting themselves in the middle of the messy war with Ukraine and a geopolitical standoff with the West.
lead_paragraph: As Russia tries to break the stranglehold of sanctions, China and India are emerging as Moscow’s pivotal financiers by purchasing large amounts of Russian crude, putting themselves in the middle of the messy war with Ukraine and a geopolitical standoff with the West.

headline: The Last Resident of Monowi
abstract: Elsie Eiler operates the only remaining business in her tiny Nebraska town. What will happen once she’s gone?
lead_paragraph: Elsie Eiler operates the only remaining business in her tiny Nebraska town. What will happen once she’s gone?

headline: Looking for Affordable Housing in New York? Here’s Where to Find It.
abstract: Enter your household income and size, and we’ll tell you what housing programs you may be eligible for and how to apply.
lead_paragraph: Enter your household income and size, and we’ll tell you what housing programs you may be eligible for and how to apply.

headline: Following Recall, San Francisco School Board Reverses Course
abstract: The board voted this week to switch elite Lowell High School back to a merit-based admissions system.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco voters in February ousted three school board members in a landslide election that proponents hoped would reshape the city’s education policy and politics.

headline: Relief Efforts Intensify in Afghanistan After Devastating Earthquake
abstract: Aid has been streaming into the rugged regions hit by the quake on Wednesday. Hundreds were killed and many more are missing, with officials saying that they do not expect to find more survivors.
lead_paragraph: Relief efforts ramped up on Friday to aid victims of the deadly earthquake that struck an impoverished region of southeastern Afghanistan this week in a disaster that killed hundreds and devastated a country already teetering on economic collapse nearly a year after the Taliban seized power.

headline: After the Gun Ruling
abstract: Plus, Intel pressures Congress to provide funding for U.S. chip production.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday’s sweeping Supreme Court decision striking down a New York State law that restricted concealed weapons is likely to set off another round of soul searching among law firms, banks and others about whether to work with the gun industry and its allies.

headline: Watching ‘Queer as Folk’ but Craving ‘Heartstopper’
abstract: Major reboots and revivals are falling short in the writing as they try to diversify and expand their L.G.B.T.Q. worlds. It doesn’t have to be that way.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been watching gay television since Steven Carrington was a ’mo on “Dynasty.” I cried when a gay son died of AIDS in “An Early Frost,” rejoiced when Jack slipped Ethan the tongue on “Dawson’s Creek” and melted as Patrick married David on that other “Creek” — Schitt’s.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 3: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by July 1 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 12.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Week Three of our 13th Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: Ukrainian insurgents kill a Kremlin-backed politician in occupied Kherson, part of a wave of attacks.
abstract: A growing guerrilla movement appears to have been fueled by public anger over worsening economic, security and humanitarian conditions.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian guerrilla fighters claimed on Friday to have killed a Kremlin-backed politician in the Russian-controlled southern region of Kherson, the latest in a series of attacks aimed at destabilizing the occupation authorities.

headline: ‘Ghost Flights’? The Facts Behind Transporting Migrant Children
abstract: Government flights carrying undocumented children from the border to federally licensed shelters around the country are being criticized by conservative politicians in an election year.
lead_paragraph: For months, Republican politicians and commentators have been accusing the Biden administration of flying thousands of undocumented migrants on secret nighttime “ghost flights” from the border to cities all over the country.

headline: ‘My Aching Heart Is Shattered Into Little Pieces’
abstract: A year ago, Champlain Towers South collapsed in Surfside, Fla. The lives of those who lost loved ones and homes have never been the same.
lead_paragraph: SURFSIDE, Fla. — A year later, the shock of the collapse of Champlain Towers South has not worn off. Not for the people whose loved ones died crushed in the rubble. Not for their neighbors who made it out alive but dispossessed.

headline: The ‘Most Real Richard III There’s Ever Been’
abstract: The Royal Shakespeare Company has cast a disabled actor to play the “deformed, unfinish’d” king for the first time. The choice has been hailed as a landmark moment.
lead_paragraph: STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, England — A raucous party was underway in one of the Royal Shakespeare Company’s rehearsal rooms this month as the cast of “Richard III” ran through the play’s opening, dancing in a conga line while music blared and balloons bounced off the floor.

headline: Heat Waves Around the World Push People and Nations ‘to the Edge’
abstract: Large, simultaneous heat waves are growing more common. China, America, Europe and India have all been stricken recently, and scientists are starting to understand why certain far-flung places get hit at once.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans are once again in the grips of dangerous heat. Hot air blanketed Europe last weekend, causing parts of France and Spain to feel the way it usually does in July or August. High temperatures scorched northern and central China even as heavy rains caused flooding in the country’s south. Some places in India began experiencing extraordinary heat in March, though the start of the monsoon rains has brought some relief.

headline: Buck Ellison’s Great White Society
abstract: From the driving range to the dude ranch, an artist stages intimate, alluring portraits of U.S. hegemony from within its walls.
lead_paragraph: Their beery, blueblood inhibition hangs in the periwinkle dusk. The photograph shows the two DeVos brothers, scions of the Amway multilevel marketing empire, finishing a game of golf with their dad. Two men crouch over a short putt. One nurses a can of low-cal Michelob Ultra. The third stands behind them, his stance strong, his back turned to the camera and to us, draining his bladder in a stream as straight as a titanium shaft. They seem firm and composed, in the flower of youth. And the fourth figure, the caddy saddled with the golf bag in the Everglades heat — who is he? He’s everyone else. He wants to be them, and maybe, if he tugs hard enough on his bootstraps, he will be.

headline: A Rhodes Scholar’s Starbucks Ambition and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: In 6-to-3 Ruling, Supreme Court Ends Nearly 50 Years of Abortion Rights
abstract: The decision will lead to all but total bans on the procedure in about half of the states.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest abortion news and the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

headline: How State Abortion Laws Are Changing
abstract: About half the states are expected to ban or further restrict access to abortion.
lead_paragraph: About half of states are expected to ban or further restrict access to abortion following the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, which for 50 years guaranteed the constitutional right to abortion.

headline: Stocks have a rare positive week.
abstract: The S&P 500 had a weekly gain of about 6.5 percent, only its second positive week in the past twelve.
lead_paragraph: Stocks jumped on Friday in their best day in two years and posted a large gain for the week, a relatively rare development during a tumultuous time for Wall Street.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: Learn to cook in 10 easy dishes. Also in this edition: a commoner fixes up a 60-room English castle, and an interview with John Grisham.
lead_paragraph: Learn to cook in 10 easy dishes. Also in this edition: a commoner fixes up a 60-room English castle, and an interview with John Grisham.

headline: The decision to overturn Roe clashes with the views of a majority of Americans.
abstract: Few issues are more politically fraught than abortion. So, it is notable that the decision by Republican-appointed justices to end a constitutional right to abortion conflicted with the views of a majority of Americans.
lead_paragraph: Few issues are more politically fraught than abortion. So, it is notable that the decision by Republican-appointed justices to end a constitutional right to abortion conflicted with the views of a majority of Americans.

headline: What did Planned Parenthood v. Casey say?
abstract: In Planned Parenthood v. Casey in 1992, the Supreme Court affirmed what it called the central holding of Roe v. Wade: that states may not prohibit abortions before fetal viability, the point when a fetus could survive outside the womb, which is now about 23 weeks.
lead_paragraph: In Planned Parenthood v. Casey in 1992, the Supreme Court affirmed what it called the central holding of Roe v. Wade: that states may not prohibit abortions before fetal viability, the point when a fetus could survive outside the womb, which is now about 23 weeks.

headline: As Russia Chokes Ukraine’s Grain Exports, Romania Tries to Fill In
abstract: With famine threatening millions, Europe is intent on finding alternatives to one of world’s biggest food exporters, whose landlocked crop is stranded by war.
lead_paragraph: Stopping at the edge of a vast field of barley on his farm in Prundu, 30 miles outside Romania’s capital city of Bucharest, Catalin Corbea pinched off a spiky flowered head from a stalk, rolled it between his hands, and then popped a seed in his mouth and bit down.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Easy vegan peanut-butter maple ice cream, roasted mushroom larb and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: I remember receiving the first edition of this newsletter about seven years ago, when I was working as a customer service representative at a food magazine. And now, for one day only, I’m the writer. Life comes at you fast! This is Priya Krishna, by the way.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks are scary, but not too scary. (Except the one about the demon on a rampage. That’s very scary.)
lead_paragraph: Because last month’s picks took a deep dive into depravity, this time I’m (mostly) sticking to low-gore, less-scary horror movies that won’t keep you up at night.

headline: Serena Williams’s Wimbledon Draw Could Have Been Worse
abstract: After a year away from singles, she risked drawing the world’s No. 1, Iga Swiatek, in the first round. Instead, she will face a player ranked 113th.
lead_paragraph: In her first singles match in a year, Serena Williams could have faced one of the new leaders of the game that she once dominated.

headline: Here are past cases that have upheld or chipped away at Roe v. Wade.
abstract: The legal case over a law that makes most abortions illegal after 15 weeks of pregnancy is by no means the first to challenge or chip away at Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, the case before the nation’s highest court on a restrictive Mississippi law, is the most consequential on women’s access to abortion since the court’s 1973 decision in Roe v. Wade.

headline: Paulo Dybala and the Problem With Italy
abstract: The travails of Dybala, whose contract with Juventus runs out this month, are emblematic of a soccer ecosystem that is often a world apart.
lead_paragraph: Paulo Dybala did not, particularly, look as if he were ready to say goodbye. As the lights at the Allianz Stadium in Turin, his home for the last seven years, flashed and flickered, and Tina Turner’s “The Best” began its crescendo, he started to cry. Not in the sense of a single, elegant tear rolling down the cheek. He sobbed. He racked. His chest heaved as he gulped for air.

headline: ‘Shock and Dismay’ Over the Abortion Ruling
abstract: Most readers decry the Supreme Court’s decision to force many women to unwillingly endure “the risks and consequences of pregnancy.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Dobbs v. Jackson Decision, Annotated
abstract: New York Times reporters are providing analysis of the landmark Supreme Court decision that overturned Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters are providing analysis of the landmark Supreme Court decision that overturned Roe v. Wade.

headline: Saudi Arabia, a Growing Force in Golf, Seeks to Host Women’s Tennis
abstract: The kingdom shook up the PGA Tour with the creation of the LIV Golf series. Now it is pushing to secure a WTA Tour event.
lead_paragraph: With the golf world already divided over Saudi Arabia’s emergence as a powerful force in the game, another major sport is contending with whether to do business with the kingdom.

headline: Daily Harvest Recalls Lentil and Leek Crumbles After Consumers Fall Ill
abstract: With nearly 500 reports of sickness, and viral posts from influencers, the company and experts are now trying to figure out what happened.
lead_paragraph: The vegan food delivery service Daily Harvest recalled a lentil-based product after customers claimed on social media that they’d become severely sick after eating it. The company said that it had received approximately 470 reports of illness or adverse reactions, including gastrointestinal issues and potential liver damage, according to a press release issued Thursday.

headline: ‘The Biggest Uncertainty Is Us’
abstract: Katharine Hayhoe, a climate scientist, says sustainable choices must become the easiest, most affordable ones.
lead_paragraph: I wanted to speak with Katharine Hayhoe about us.

headline: Germany Ends Ban on Abortion Advertisement
abstract: The vote to scrap the law came on the same day that Roe v. Wade was overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German lawmakers voted on Friday to end a Nazi-era ban on the advertisement of abortion services, a measure that had effectively criminalized doctors who provided information about the procedure.

headline: What are abortion trigger laws and which states have them?
abstract: Trigger laws will move to quickly outlaw abortions in 13 states. Some laws are expected to take effect almost immediately, while others are written to take effect about a month after the ruling.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade and give individual states the choice of banning or allowing abortions will most immediately affect the 13 states that have trigger laws.

headline: Is Birth Control Still Legal in the U.S.?
abstract: The Supreme Court decision that overruled Roe v. Wade does not indicate that the justices would revisit past decisions about birth control.
lead_paragraph: Birth control remains legal everywhere in the United States, though several states allow doctors and pharmacists to refuse to prescribe or dispense contraceptives, according to the Guttmacher Institute.  The Supreme Court decision that overruled Roe v. Wade does not indicate that the Court would revisit past decisions about birth control.

headline: Politico’s Roe v. Wade scoop becomes law.
abstract: In May, Politico’s reporters published a draft opinion outlining the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. Today, the high court made it official.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court made huge headlines on Friday with its decision to end the constitutional right to abortion. But the decision was also unusual because it was already known.

headline: A Creamy, Vegan Potato Salad You Can Linger Over
abstract: Tahini steps in for mayonnaise in this vegan take on the classic, finished with fresh and charred scallions.
lead_paragraph: Creamy, tangy, sweet and savory, a mayo-dressed potato salad is the crowd-pleasing heart of countless American cookouts and picnics — just as long as you make sure to keep it out of the sun.

headline: Roe’s Death Will Change American Democracy
abstract: The anti-abortion movement has won its decades-long effort to undo Roe. Now what?
lead_paragraph: The anti-abortion movement has long argued that reversing Roe v. Wade would strengthen American democracy. Roe, the argument goes, short-circuited a process of state-by-state debate and compromise, freezing the democratic process and imposing a single abortion solution on the nation. Undoing the constitutional right to abortion, then, is seen as a win for democracy — a first step in allowing each state to set its own policy.

headline: How Abortion Bans Will Ripple Across America
abstract: With Roe overturned, the distances many women will need to travel for an abortion will increase drastically. See the range of scenarios.
lead_paragraph: With Roe overturned, the distances many women will need to travel for an abortion will increase drastically. See the range of scenarios.

headline: 6 Cool Ice Pops to Make With Your Kids
abstract: It’s summer. Go wild.
lead_paragraph: On the hottest days of summer, there’s nothing better than a nice, cold ice pop — in theory, anyway. In reality, they can be a little meh, more like a stick of barely-flavored ice that immediately melts into a watery mess all over your hands.

headline: A Sleepy Baltic Rail Line Gets a Geopolitical Wakeup Call
abstract: Russia has accused Lithuania, a NATO member, of choking off the flow of goods to Kaliningrad, its enclave on the Baltic, as part of sanctions over the war in Ukraine. Lithuania says Russia is lying.
lead_paragraph: KYBARTAI, Lithuania — As war rages in Ukraine, fueling ever-growing tensions between NATO and Russia, a sleepy Baltic railway station with no passengers and few trains this week found itself at the center of a perilous new confrontation between East and West.

headline: Vatican Releases Letters From Jews Pleading for Help During the Holocaust
abstract: Pope Francis has ordered files containing requests for assistance from people throughout Europe, many of them converts to Roman Catholicism, to be made available online.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Written between 1938 and 1944, and previously unreleased to the general public, the letters reveal desperation and fear. They reflect the humiliation, discrimination and confinement Jews were subjected to during a dark moment in European history.

headline: Furor Over the Supreme Court Ruling on Guns
abstract: Readers express dismay over the justices’ rejection of a New York gun law.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Here are the companies that will cover travel expenses for employee abortions.
abstract: A handful of companies have committed to helping their employees access abortion services.
lead_paragraph: Here’s an updating list of companies that will cover travel expenses for employee abortions.

headline: Review: Before Riccardo Muti Leaves Chicago, a Verdi Farewell
abstract: “Un Ballo in Maschera” is the last in a series of Verdi operas led in concert by the Chicago Symphony’s music director, who departs after next season.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Mortality, the fragility of life, permeates Verdi’s “Un Ballo in Maschera” from its lonely first measures.

headline: Gov. Hochul Calls Decision Overturning Roe ‘Repulsive at Every Level’
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul declared New York a “safe harbor” for those seeking abortions as advocates and lawmakers in the state moved to respond to the Supreme Court ruling.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York responded on Friday morning to the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade by declaring her state a “safe harbor” for those seeking abortions and reaffirming her commitment to abortion rights.

headline: 3 Theaters, 3 Plays, One Cast, All at Once
abstract: The Crucible Theater in Sheffield, England, is celebrating its 50th anniversary with a mind-boggling logistical challenge that also honors a declining industry in the city.
lead_paragraph: SHEFFIELD, England — Visitors to Tudor Square in the center of this northern English city might spot some unusual figures there this week: a woman sprinting through in a neon boilersuit, or a tutu, or a man running with a box of scissors. And if they look like they’re in a hurry to get somewhere, that’s because they are. These are actors, and they have an entrance to make — on a different stage from the one they just left.

headline: Thomas’s concurring opinion raises questions about what rights might be next.
abstract: The same rationale could also be used to overturn cases establishing rights to contraception, same-sex consensual relations and same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Justice Clarence Thomas, in his concurring opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, laid out a vision that prompted concerns about what other rights could disappear: The same rationale that the Supreme Court used to declare there was no right to abortion, he said, should also be used to overturn cases establishing rights to contraception, same-sex consensual relations and same-sex marriage.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: The late-night hosts had plenty of news to discuss this week, including the Jan. 6 hearings in Washington and the F.D.A. ban on Juul e-cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: The late-night hosts had plenty of news to discuss this week, including the Jan. 6 hearings in Washington and the F.D.A. ban on Juul e-cigarettes.

headline: Beyoncé’s Dance-Floor Salvation, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Taylor Swift, the Mars Volta, Gorillaz featuring Thundercat and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Americans Celebrate and Mourn Abortion Decision as New Fights Loom
abstract: The Supreme Court sent the issue of abortion back to the states in an even more polarized era than when Roe v. Wade was introduced.
lead_paragraph: Within minutes of the Supreme Court’s overturning of Roe v. Wade on Friday, the attorney general in Missouri issued an opinion banning abortion in his state. Abortion clinics in several cities, including Montgomery, Ala., and Sioux Falls, S.D., shut down. But others in Illinois and Ohio kept seeing patients.

headline: E.U. leaders plan for a painful scenario: Russia turning off the gas.
abstract: The tapering of gas has forced Germany, Europe’s economic engine, to escalate its energy emergency protocol and urge residents to conserve power. The next step is rationing.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European leaders meeting in Brussels this week were eager to focus on granting Ukraine E.U. candidate status, but have also had to address a pressing problem linked to the war: Russia has slowly been turning off the gas tap.

headline: The Woman Who Vanished From Her Family’s Lush California Estate
abstract: In “Vera Kelly Lost and Found,” the final volume of Rosalie Knecht’s 1960s-era private detective trilogy, Vera searches for her missing girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: I’ve anticipated few novels this year with as much excitement as VERA KELLY LOST AND FOUND (Tin House, 222 pp., paperback, $15.95), the final volume in Rosalie Knecht’s nearly note-perfect 1960s-era private detective trilogy. Any trepidation I had about it not measuring up vanished with the opening sentences: “Max liked to throw parties. The call would go out to the girls from the bar, the Harlem students who never went to Brooklyn except for her, and the confab of ladies we called les grandes dames, who lived in several apartments in a single building in Little Italy and spent their days making jam for each other and sending harassing letters to the editors of The Village Voice.”

headline: The Simplest Salmon and Other Easy Recipes
abstract: A vegetable tofu curry, a tuna mayo rice bowl, a crispy-edged quesadilla: You don’t have to be great in the kitchen to get delicious results.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, one of our editors, Nikita Richardson, suggested that we do a package of recipes for true beginner cooks, a step-by-step program for people who can barely boil water. The recipes needed to be great, because not only do we want you to learn to cook, we also want you to love it.

headline: Pennsylvania’s race for governor takes on huge stakes for abortion rights.
abstract: If Doug Mastriano, the Republican nominee, beats his Democratic opponent, Josh Shapiro, he and the state’s G.O.P.-led legislature are all but certain to move to outlaw abortion.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Supreme Court has struck down Roe v. Wade, the most important election this year in America when it comes to abortion will be the contest for governor of Pennsylvania.

headline: Documenta Was a Whole Vibe. Then a Scandal Killed the Buzz.
abstract: Accusations that an image was antisemitic broke the mood at a daring festival of experiments. This year’s Documenta deserves a closer look, our critic says.
lead_paragraph: KASSEL, Germany — No one knows just how big Documenta 15 is. The latest edition of the prestigious international art exhibition, which takes place every five years here, opened last Saturday and runs through mid-September. It resists all the usual metrics.

headline: ‘Buy Now, Pay Later’ Becomes a New Way to Pay for Guns
abstract: Credova, a little-known fintech company, is leading the way in offering installment plans to buyers of guns and hunting supplies.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, as American consumers were being wooed with “buy now, pay later” loans that let them pay for online purchases — from makeup to Peloton bikes — in small increments, one start-up had an idea: Why not adapt the model to sell outdoor recreation gear, including guns?

headline: Garland says Justice Department will protect access to an abortion.
abstract: He also called on Congress to pass a federal law that protects the right to an abortion.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland called the Supreme Court decision to strike down the right to an abortion “a devastating blow to reproductive freedom,” and he vowed to use the Justice Department’s authority to protect the right to the procedure.

headline: Congress Passes Bipartisan Gun Legislation, Clearing It for Biden
abstract: The House gave final approval to the Senate-passed compromise, ending nearly three decades of congressional inaction.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress gave final approval on Friday to a bipartisan compromise intended to stop dangerous people from accessing firearms, ending nearly three decades of congressional inaction over how to counter gun violence and toughen the nation’s gun laws.

headline: ‘A Grievous Wrong Was Righted’: Anti-Abortion Activists Celebrate the End of Roe
abstract: This was the moment they had imagined for half a century, a dream many refused to believe was impossible.
lead_paragraph: The staff of Susan B. Anthony Pro-Life America waited in anticipation at its headquarters in northern Virginia on Friday morning, trying to refresh the Supreme Court website that would not load.

headline: Murder of 2 Priests Hands Mexican Leaders a New Critic: the Catholic Church
abstract: The government has failed for years to quell rising violence and the resulting public outcry, but the church’s voice cannot easily be dismissed.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The murder of two Jesuit priests inside a church in Mexico this week stunned a country where frustration had been building for years over the government’s failure to stem a deluge of killing.

headline: Love Letter: A Never-Ending Non-Conversation
abstract: Is a breakup a breakup if it’s barely acknowledged?
lead_paragraph: Kyleigh McPeek, the final finalist in our latest Modern Love college essay contest, has been dumped many times.

headline: ‘This Is Not Over’: Biden Tries to Galvanize Voters After Abortion Ruling
abstract: “This decision must not be the final word,” President Biden said after the Supreme Court eliminated the constitutional right to abortion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Calling the Supreme Court’s reversal of Roe v. Wade a “tragic error,” President Biden on Friday tried to galvanize voters ahead of the midterm elections and called on Americans to “make their voices heard.”

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jamelle Bouie
abstract: A conversation with New York Times Opinion columnist Jamelle Bouie.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jamelle Bouie. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Does Your Nose Help Pick Your Friends?
abstract: In a small study, researchers in an olfaction lab found that people who had an instant personal connection also had similarities in their body odors.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: I Prayed and Protested to End Roe. What Comes Next?
abstract: What the overturning of Roe v. Wade means to abortion opponents like me.
lead_paragraph: Roe v. Wade’s reversal has elicited cries of anger and despair from those who feel a sense of dread for the future of women and the future of America.

headline: Wonking Out: Hot Economies and High Prices
abstract: An overview of the changes in inflation analysis.
lead_paragraph: It is a truth universally acknowledged — well, anyway, a truth acknowledged by everyone I know who thinks about the subject — that a hot economy leads to higher wages and prices. When demand for labor is strong, workers can and do demand wage hikes; when demand for goods and services is strong, businesses have “pricing power,” or the ability to raise prices without losing customers.

headline: Most U.S. abortions are already performed using pills. That share is likely to climb.
abstract: Taking pills to end a pregnancy accounts for a majority of abortions in the United States, both legal and not. Now that the Supreme Court has overturned Roe v. Wade, medication abortion will play a larger role, especially among women who lose access to abortion clinics.
lead_paragraph: Taking pills to end a pregnancy accounts for a majority of abortions in the United States, both legal and not. Now that the Supreme Court has overturned Roe v. Wade, medication abortion will play a larger role, especially among women who lose access to abortion clinics.

headline: Is it legal for women to travel out of state for an abortion?
abstract: There are no abortion bans that attempt to prosecute women who cross state lines to seek an abortion.
lead_paragraph: There are currently no abortion bans that attempt to prosecute women who cross state lines to seek an abortion.

headline: Baxter Black, Who Elevated Cowboy Poetry to Folk Art, Dies at 77
abstract: His wide-ranging work, including books, speeches and regular appearances on NPR, celebrated cowpokes, feed lots and life on the range.
lead_paragraph: Baxter Black, the country’s best-known cowboy poet, whose witty, big-hearted verse about cowpokes, feed lots and wide-open vistas elevated the tradition of Western doggerel to something of a folk art, died on June 10 at his home, a ranch outside Benson, Ariz. He was 77.

headline: Congress Clears Bill to Extend Free Meals for Children Through the Summer
abstract: The bipartisan bill passed as pandemic-era waivers, including a provision that offers free meals to all children, were about to lapse.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House passed legislation on Friday to extend free meals and other food assistance for children, clearing it for President Biden’s signature one week before a series of pandemic-era waivers was set to expire.

headline: How candidates competing in Tuesday’s primary elections are reacting to the Supreme Court’s decision.
abstract: Anti-abortion Republican candidates basked in the moment and Democrats anguished over the uncertain future of reproductive rights.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on primary elections and results in Illinois, Colorado and New York.

headline: Juul Gets Temporary Reprieve to Keep Selling Its E-Cigarettes
abstract: The company is appealing the F.D.A.’s decision to ban sales of its vaping products.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Friday granted a temporary reprieve to Juul Labs that will allow it to keep its e-cigarettes on the market, pending further court review of a decision just a day earlier by the Food and Drug Administration to ban sales of the company’s products.

headline: DeSantis has already moved to restrict abortions in Florida.
abstract: The state was once a refuge for the procedure in the Southeast.
lead_paragraph: Florida, the nation’s third-most populous state, also has the third-highest abortion rate, after New York and Illinois. Friday’s Supreme Court ruling and recent actions by Republican state leaders are expected to soon change that.

headline: Biden Slams Supreme Court for Its Ruling on Abortion
abstract: President Biden warned that the decision could jeopardize the health of millions of women in the United States and urged people to vote.
lead_paragraph: President Biden warned that the decision could jeopardize the health of millions of women in the United States and urged people to vote.

headline: Fresh Fed financial disclosures omit the officials who ignited ethics scandal.
abstract: The Dallas and Boston regional Fed presidents whose 2020 trades caused an uproar resigned late in 2021. Their transactions from last year were excluded from a new wave of disclosures.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve did not disclose updated financial information for two former regional bank presidents whose trading ignited a scandal at the central bank, even though they held important monetary policy roles for most of 2021 — the year covered by a fresh set of disclosures released on Friday.

headline: Dobbs, Named in Abortion Case Ending Roe, Had Little to Do With It
abstract: His name was affixed to the historic lawsuit after he became Mississippi’s chief health officer in 2018.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Thomas E. Dobbs III, the man whose name on Friday became synonymous with the Supreme Court decision to let states ban abortions, had almost nothing to do with the landmark case.

headline: Immersed in ‘Stranger Things,’ Then Strolling to Beckett
abstract: Our writer checked out two very different experiences in New York. In Netflix’s TV re-creation, you fight Demogorgons. In “Cascando,” you walk off your existential angst.
lead_paragraph: Before the pizza parlor, before the arcade games, before the ice cream shop and the merch kiosks (so many merch kiosks!) and the photo op with a fiberglass-and-silicone Demogorgon, “Stranger Things: The Experience,” at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, puts on a show.

headline: U.S. Outlines Compensation Rules for Some Havana Syndrome Victims
abstract: The cause of the ailments first observed in American diplomats and C.I.A. officers serving in Cuba remains a mystery.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department on Friday released its rules and guidelines for providing financial support to victims of Havana syndrome, the mysterious ailments that have affected American diplomats, C.I.A. officers and others since 2016.

headline: World leaders react to Roe ruling.
abstract: Several European leaders criticized the Supreme Court’s decision, which goes against a global trend, while the Vatican welcomed it.
lead_paragraph: It applies to a single country, but the U.S. Supreme Court ruling scrapping the constitutional right to abortion reverberated globally, drawing a wave of responses from world leaders, some of them heated — “horrific,” “a huge setback” — as denunciation outweighed praise.

headline: Olympics Snub Women’s Nordic Combined and Put the Sport on Notice
abstract: The International Olympic Committee said not enough countries are participating in the women’s competitions to include them. The men’s event may be the next to go.
lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee decided Friday not to add a women’s Nordic combined event to the 2026 Winter Games in Milan and Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy, a devastating setback for dozens of women who have dedicated their lives to the event in recent years and a potentially fatal blow to one of the original Winter Olympic competitions.

headline: West Coast governors commit to abortion rights firewall.
abstract: The commitment memo changed no laws in their states, which have been legislating for months to protect abortion rights in anticipation of the ruling.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Vowing to make the West Coast a firewall for reproductive rights, the governors of California, Oregon and Washington on Friday announced a joint commitment to maintain access to abortion and contraception and to protect providers and patients from the legal reach of other states.

headline: Biden’s Gas Tax Holiday Wouldn’t Make Much Difference
abstract: The president’s proposal is mainly symbolic, to show he cares.
lead_paragraph: President Biden says he’s still committed to reducing U.S. carbon emissions to net zero in the near future. At the moment, though, his overriding priority is to ensure an ample supply of gasoline at reasonable prices.

headline: Review: Pacific Northwest Ballet Finally Makes It Back to New York
abstract: On Thursday’s mixed bill, Ulysses Dove’s “Dancing on the Front Porch of Heaven” was the most arresting and emotionally resonant work.
lead_paragraph: A cross-country visit from a major American ballet company is almost always of interest; after so much pandemic upheaval, it merits appreciation just as a logistical feat. For the first time in six years, Pacific Northwest Ballet, from Seattle, has made its way to New York with a full-fledged season, which originally was scheduled for June 2020. The company even brought its orchestra.

headline: Three Women, ‘Hollowed Out and Ready to Burst’
abstract: Debut novels of women seeking solace in sex, in sitcoms, in the innocence they are denied.
lead_paragraph: The unnamed narrator of Alyssa Songsiridej’s debut, LITTLE RABBIT (242 pp., Bloomsbury, $26), is a 30-year-old novelist living in Somerville, Mass. She meets a choreographer two decades her senior at a residency in Maine, where she is focused diligently on finishing her own first book and where she finds the unnamed choreographer — the director of his own company — irritating, “dominating dinner with stories about his dance career.” But months later, when “Little Rabbit” begins, the choreographer comes to town from New York, and he emails her. They start having sex, which soon turns into consensual violence, the choreographer dominating and the protagonist submitting. That dynamic, in turn, morphs into a kind of love.

headline: F.B.I. Raids Orlando Museum and Removes Basquiat Paintings
abstract: All 25 works in the museum’s Jean-Michel Basquiat exhibition were seized by the F.B.I. An affidavit called into question their origin and their authenticity.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation raided the Orlando Museum of Art on Friday, taking all 25 works that had been part of an exhibition on the life and work of Jean-Michel Basquiat, the museum said.

headline: On Broadway, One Show Decides to Keep Masks. No, It’s Not ‘Phantom.’
abstract: “American Buffalo,” at Circle in the Square, is sticking with masking till it closes, July 10, citing the “proximity of the audience to the actors” and “the staging in the round.”
lead_paragraph: Three days after the Broadway League announced that all 41 theaters would make masks optional starting July 1, one of those theaters has decided to stick with mandatory face coverings.

headline: How women who support abortion rights are reacting to the news.
abstract: Women across the nation react with anger and fear. One says she feels the “nation is on fire.”
lead_paragraph: Our reporters are speaking with women across the United States as they react to Friday’s Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade. Here is a selection of what they have heard from women who support maintaining access to abortion.

headline: Hochul Calls Supreme Court’s Abortion Ruling ‘Repulsive’
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York condemned the decision, saying extremism had “infiltrated the Supreme Court of the United States of America.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York condemned the decision, saying extremism had “infiltrated the Supreme Court of the United States of America.”

headline: Ask Wirecutter: Internet While Camping?
abstract: A reader asks how to find reliable internet while vacationing somewhere remote.
lead_paragraph: A reader asks how to find reliable internet while vacationing somewhere remote.

headline: Democrats turn to donors after the abortion decision, and Republicans follow suit — but with a different message.
abstract: Democrats’ fund-raising blasts filled email boxes and social media feeds as they aimed to capitalize on the fear and alarm that many left-leaning voters felt.
lead_paragraph: Democrats in some of the most competitive races for Senate and governor this year instantly appealed to donors on Friday after the Supreme Court overturned 50 years of precedent on abortion rights.

headline: Monkeypox and the Gay Community
abstract: Many monkeypox cases have been found in men who have sex with men.
lead_paragraph: This weekend marks the end of Pride month, as cities across the country host events to celebrate the L.G.B.T.Q. community.

headline: Here are key passages from the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe.
abstract: Central to the decision is Justice Alito’s belief that the Constitution does not include a right to abortion.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court decision that overturned Roe v. Wade and ruled that states should be allowed to ban abortions was written by Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. and joined by five other justices.

headline: You Deserve Better, No Matter What Your Boss Says (or Doesn’t)
abstract: From not working when you shouldn’t to needing your manager to show some common decency, it’s OK to stick up for yourself.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Beer and Body Slams, as Craft Brewers and Wrestlers Get in the Ring
abstract: Small beer companies and independent wrestling leagues find that pairing their offerings attracts big crowds and big fun.
lead_paragraph: On a broiling Friday night in Brooklyn, beer fans gathered to try cold I.P.A.s from scores of breweries and blow off steam by screaming. In most contexts, raucous shouting is discouraged. But at Other Half Brewing’s Green City Championship beer festival, held this month at ZeroSpace, a sprawling events venue in Gowanus, crushing beer while cutting loose was precisely the point of the event’s entertainment: professional wrestling.

headline: Members of Congress voice mixed opinions on the Roe ruling.
abstract: Lawmakers trickled into the Capitol on Friday to tightened security and the news of Roe v. Wade being overturned.
lead_paragraph: As members of Congress flooded into the Capitol on Friday morning for a packed legislative day before a recess, news of the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade reverberated through the building.

headline: With New Threats Looming, Canada Commits Billions to Air Defense
abstract: But it is unclear that giving new capabilities to Norad will be effective against new, superfast missiles.
lead_paragraph: Spending on military programs often leads to years of heated political debate and little action in Canada. But the announcement this week that Canada will spend nearly 5 billion Canadian dollars over the next six years on upgrading Norad’s defense systems passed with barely a ripple of controversy.

headline: How women who oppose abortion are reacting to the court’s decision.
abstract: Abortion opponents said they were shedding happy tears and remembering those who regretted past abortions.
lead_paragraph: Our reporters are speaking with women across the United States as they react to Friday’s Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade. Here is a selection of what they have heard from women who oppose abortion.

headline: The Fall of Sievierodonetsk
abstract: Ukraine will withdraw its forces from the largely ruined eastern city.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Anti-Abortion Supporters Celebrate Supreme Court’s Ruling
abstract: Anti-abortion activists celebrated the court’s decision to reverse Roe v. Wade outside the Supreme Court and across the country.
lead_paragraph: Anti-abortion activists celebrated the court’s decision to reverse Roe v. Wade outside the Supreme Court and across the country.

headline: The Ruling Overturning Roe Is an Insult to Women and the Judicial System
abstract: This is the start of a new era of conflict over abortion.
lead_paragraph: Even if we knew it was coming, the shock reverberates.

headline: Russian forces move to encircle Lysychansk, starting with southern villages.
abstract: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — Ukraine’s decision to retreat from Sievierodonetsk, a strategic city in the country’s east, hands Russia another victory in its grinding campaign to seize the Donbas region.
lead_paragraph: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — Ukraine’s decision to retreat from Sievierodonetsk, a strategic city in the country’s east, hands Russia another victory in its grinding campaign to seize the Donbas region.

headline: Ukraine Retreats From Embattled City, as Russia Grinds On
abstract: With the withdrawal from Sievierodonetsk, the fighting shifts to neighboring Lysychansk, the last city in the Luhansk region still under Ukrainian control.
lead_paragraph: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — After weeks of bloody street fighting and months of withering artillery fire, Ukrainian forces will withdraw from Sievierodonetsk, a city that President Volodymyr Zelensky once said would determine the “fate” of the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine.

headline: Gloria Allen, Transgender Activist Who Ran a Charm School, Dies at 76
abstract: She overcame a life of intolerance and abuse to teach style, etiquette and life lessons to young transgender people who were at risk.
lead_paragraph: Gloria Allen, a transgender activist whose experiences running a charm school in Chicago for at-risk transgender youth inspired an acclaimed documentary film, “Mama Gloria,” and play, “Charm,” died on June 13 at her home in Chicago. She was 76.

headline: Juul Users Prepare to Say Goodbye to Their Vape of Choice
abstract: After a Food and Drug Administration ruling against the company, fans of the brand said they appreciated its simple design. “I definitely will miss the Juuls,” a leather worker in Detroit said.
lead_paragraph: After roughly 25 years of cigarette smoking, Tim Marchman wanted to quit. And yet he didn’t want to become what he calls “a vape guy,” the kind of person who spends hours in specialty shops choosing from dozens of electronic nicotine delivery devices, many of them quite elaborate. So he settled on what struck him as the simplest option, Juul, a brand that for a time was practically synonymous with vaping.

headline: What Are Men Wearing Now?
abstract: A reader looking to update their wardrobe wonders where to begin.
lead_paragraph: Since there is nothing like going straight to the source for an answer, and since Guy Trebay, our men’s wear critic, is currently on the front lines (or front row) of this issue at the men’s wear shows, I asked him how he would translate the latest designer developments for the everyday male wardrobe. Here’s the intel he sent back from the theater of operations:

headline: The Man Most Responsible for Ending Roe Worries That It Could Hurt His Party
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump has privately told friends and advisers that a ruling overturning Roe v. Wade will be “bad for Republicans.”
lead_paragraph: The end of the landmark Roe v. Wade ruling was the culmination of decades of work by Republicans and social conservatives — one that came to pass only after a former Democrat from New York who had once supported abortion rights helped muscle through three Supreme Court justices.

headline: Scene Outside Mississippi Abortion Clinic After Roe Is Overturned
abstract: Clinic escorts directed traffic outside the Jackson Women’s Health Organization as a small group of anti-abortion demonstrators gathered outside after the Supreme Court’s reversal of Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Clinic escorts directed traffic outside the Jackson Women’s Health Organization as a small group of anti-abortion demonstrators gathered outside after the Supreme Court’s reversal of Roe v. Wade.

headline: Athletes, Players Unions and Leagues Criticize Abortion Ruling
