abstract: The commissioners of the N.B.A. and W.N.B.A. said in a joint statement that “women should be able to make their own decisions concerning their health and future.”
lead_paragraph: Megan Rapinoe, the outspoken star of the U.S. women’s soccer team, was among several professional athletes on Friday to criticize the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. She had not originally been scheduled to appear at a news conference ahead of the team’s friendly against Colombia but spent nearly 30 minutes addressing the ruling, which ends the constitutional right to an abortion.

headline: ‘You Cannot Stop Abortions’: Four Writers On the End of Roe v. Wade
abstract: Michelle Goldberg, Lauren Kelley and Leah Libresco Sargeant join Lulu Garcia-Navarro to discuss what comes next after Dobbs.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Goldberg, Lauren Kelley and Leah Libresco Sargeant join Lulu Garcia-Navarro to discuss what comes next after Dobbs.

headline: Ken Knowlton, a Father of Computer Art and Animation, Dies at 91
abstract: His work at Bell Labs in the 1960s laid the groundwork for today’s computer-generated imagery in film and on TV.
lead_paragraph: Ken Knowlton, an engineer, computer scientist and artist who helped pioneer the science and art of computer graphics and made many of the first computer-generated pictures, portraits and movies, died on June 16 in Sarasota, Florida. He was 91.

headline: The youngest U.S. children may not be able to get vaccinated at the local pharmacy. Here’s why.
abstract: Age requirements vary among the larger pharmacy chains, and some won’t give the shots to children younger than 5.
lead_paragraph: U.S. children as young as 6 months are now eligible for coronavirus vaccines, and many parents are breathing a sigh of relief. But the pharmacy that offered easy access to immunization to you or an older child might not accommodate the under-5 group.

headline: NASA Pauses Psyche, a Mission to a Metal-Rich Asteroid
abstract: Delays in setting up the spacecraft’s navigation software mean the mission may not reach the asteroid until 2029 or 2030, rather than 2026.
lead_paragraph: Computer software delays pushed back the launch of a NASA spacecraft to explore what appears to be a metal asteroid that may be the core of a protoplanet that was blown apart in the early days of the solar system by a giant collision.

headline: Mad About Roe? Here’s What to Do Now.
abstract: I wrote the “Handbook for a Post-Roe America.” It’s time to put it into practice.
lead_paragraph: In February 2021, I uprooted my husband, three children and two cats from our longtime home to move across the country to a house we had only seen on FaceTime, in a city we only knew from college football. I did this because I believe that everyone who supports abortion rights must do what they’re able to to keep abortion accessible for those who have the least resources to get one.

headline: Politicians React to Supreme Court’s Ruling on Abortion
abstract: Democratic leaders condemned the court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, while some Republican lawmakers celebrated the ruling.
lead_paragraph: Democratic leaders condemned the court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, while some Republican lawmakers celebrated the ruling.

headline: Jim Obergefell and L.G.B.T.Q. groups warn that abortion ruling could impact other rights.
abstract: Advocates for L.G.B.T.Q. rights expressed dismay over Justice Clarence Thomas’s opinion concurring with the decision.
lead_paragraph: Advocates for L.G.B.T.Q. rights on Friday sounded the alarm over Justice Clarence Thomas’s concurring opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, calling it a potential assault on the legal doctrine protecting a wide array of Americans’ civil rights.

headline: Meta clamps down on internal discussion of Roe v. Wade’s overturning.
abstract: Meta told its workers on Friday not to openly discuss the Supreme Court’s ruling eliminating the constitutional right to an abortion on wide-reaching communication channels inside the company, people with knowledge of the situation said.
lead_paragraph: Meta told its workers on Friday not to openly discuss the Supreme Court’s ruling eliminating the constitutional right to an abortion on wide-reaching communication channels inside the company, people with knowledge of the situation said.

headline: Haleh Afshar, Who Fought for Rights of Muslim Women, Dies at 77
abstract: An Iranian-born British scholar and self-described “Muslim feminist,” she joined the House of Lords and advised the British government on women’s issues.
lead_paragraph: Haleh Afshar, a prominent Iranian-British professor who dedicated her career in government and scholarship to promoting the rights of Muslim women, died on May 12 at her home in Heslington, England. She was 77.

headline: Abortion funds raise millions in donations to help people seeking the procedure.
abstract: As of Friday afternoon, the National Network of Abortion Funds had received more than $3 million from about 33,000 new donations.
lead_paragraph: Abortion funds, the local organizations that provide financial and logistical support for people seeking abortions, have received millions of dollars in new funding after the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade on Friday.

headline: Are abortion medications delivered by mail illegal?
abstract: The end of Roe v. Wade will make little immediate difference on access to medications, though legal experts say that could change as more trigger laws are certified.
lead_paragraph: It is still legal in most states to receive abortion medication by mail, which has been allowed since December 2021, when the Food and Drug Administration lifted a restriction that required patients to obtain the pills from a certified provider.

headline: U.S.-Led Alliance Faces Frustration, and Pain of its Own, Over Russia Sanctions
abstract: Vladimir V. Putin is making gains in his war on Ukraine while the United States and its allies struggle with soaring energy prices and inflation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four months into the war in Ukraine, the countries aligned against Russia face growing economic pain even as sanctions and energy embargoes are showing little impact on Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s military campaign or his political standing at home.

headline: Special Edition: Roe v. Wade Is Overturned
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Overturn Is Official
abstract: “It’s kind of embarrassing as an American,” Xavier Becerra, President Biden’s health secretary, said.
lead_paragraph: Roe v. Wade didn’t live to see 50.

headline: June 24, 2022: The Day Chief Justice Roberts Lost His Court
abstract: Outflanked by five impatient and ambitious justices to his right, the chief justice has become powerless to pursue his incremental approach.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the most important case of his 17-year tenure, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. found himself entirely alone.

headline: Companies Are More Vocal Than Ever on Social Issues. Not on Abortion.
abstract: The corporate response to the Supreme Court’s Friday decision was more muted, and the companies that did speak out mostly talked about their health care policies.
lead_paragraph: Companies had more than a month to formulate a response to the end of federal abortion rights in the United States, if they didn’t weigh in immediately after a draft opinion was leaked in May.

headline: How G.O.P. Support for Decriminalizing Abortion Faded Over Decades
abstract: Before the 1973 Roe v. Wade ruling, more Republicans than Democrats backed decriminalizing the procedure. But a political and religious coalition rose and took the party in a new direction.
lead_paragraph: Few can imagine it today, but on the eve of the Roe v. Wade ruling in 1973, more Republicans than Democrats supported decriminalizing abortion.

headline: Hochul Has Raised $34 Million So Far. Her Goal May Be Double That.
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s fund-raising pace could make her run for a full term the most expensive campaign ever for governor of New York.
lead_paragraph: It was the night after the first debate among the Democrats running to be New York’s governor, and the favored incumbent, Gov. Kathy Hochul, was in a fund-raising mood.

headline: Friday’s ruling prompts confusion and closures at abortion clinics.
abstract: Doctors and clinic owners were calling lawyers and looking for guidance from state attorneys general.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision overturning the constitutional right to abortion unleashed waves of confusion, panic and resignation for doctors and women across the country as they tried to understand a legal landscape that was changing by the hour.

headline: ‘It’s Become Real’: Abortion Decision Roils Midterms, Sending Fight to States
abstract: Democrats hope the fall of Roe v. Wade will jolt abortion rights supporters into action in midterm elections. But is it enough to turn voters’ attention away from inflation?
lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — The Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade on Friday catapulted the explosive battle over abortion rights into the center of several marquee midterm races, turning the fight over key governor’s contests and coveted Senate seats into heated debates about personal freedom and public health.

headline: Countries aligned against Russia face growing economic pain, even as Putin proves resilient to sanctions.
abstract: WASHINGTON — Four months into the war in Ukraine, the countries aligned against Russia face growing economic pain even as sanctions and energy embargoes are showing little impact on Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s military campaign or his political standing at home.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four months into the war in Ukraine, the countries aligned against Russia face growing economic pain even as sanctions and energy embargoes are showing little impact on Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s military campaign or his political standing at home.

headline: Thousands Protest in New York After Supreme Court Overturns Roe v. Wade
abstract: Demonstrators in Union Square and Washington Square Park voiced their frustrations and fears about the Supreme Court decision.
lead_paragraph: Hours after the U.S. Supreme Court ruled to overturn Roe v. Wade on Friday, thousands gathered in New York City to voice their fears and anger over the historic decision to eliminate the constitutional right to an abortion.

headline: ‘Abortion Is Just the Beginning’: Six Experts on the Decision Overturning Roe
abstract: These passages are key to understanding the Dobbs decision.
lead_paragraph: These passages are key to understanding the Dobbs decision.

headline: Abortion Ruling Poses New Questions About How Far Supreme Court Will Go
abstract: The decision overruling Roe v. Wade exposed internal divisions among conservative justices about reconsidering other rights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s decision on Friday to end the constitutional right to abortion concluded one battle for now but immediately posed another far-reaching question: whether the judicial ground under rights in other personal matters, including contraception and same-sex marriage, is now also shaky.

headline: Leaving Wish Lists at the Door, Senators Found Consensus on Guns
abstract: The bipartisan gun safety legislation that cleared Congress on Friday was the product of weeks of fraught negotiations that started with both sides acknowledging what had to stay off the table.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Inside a pink-hued hideaway office in the basement of the Capitol last month, Senator Christopher S. Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut, did something unusual for the start of a high-stakes legislative negotiation: Instead of a wish list, he came with a blacklist.

headline: Kavanaugh Gave Private Assurances. Collins Says He ‘Misled’ Her.
abstract: “I am a don’t-rock-the-boat kind of judge,” the justice told the senator in a discussion on Roe, according to notes from a meeting before his confirmation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During a two-hour meeting in her Senate office with the Supreme Court nominee Brett M. Kavanaugh on Aug. 21, 2018, Senator Susan Collins of Maine pressed him hard on why she should trust him not to overturn Roe v. Wade if she backed his confirmation.

headline: Turns Out These Anti-Roe Justices Don’t Believe in Precedent After All
abstract: Before they were confirmed, this is what these five justices had to say about Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Before they were confirmed, this is what these five justices had to say about Roe v. Wade.

headline: Requiem for the Supreme Court
abstract: The decision overturning Roe v. Wade is a stunning moment for America and for its high court.
lead_paragraph: They did it because they could.

headline: Sensing the World Anew Through Other Species
abstract: Ed Yong talks about “An Immense World,” and Terry Alford discusses “In the Houses of Their Dead.”
lead_paragraph: Ed Yong’s new book, “An Immense World,” urges readers to break outside their “sensory bubble” to consider the unique ways that dogs, dolphins, mice and other animals experience their surroundings.

headline: 2 Killed and at Least 19 Wounded in Shooting in Norway’s Capital
abstract: The shooting happened near a popular gay club in downtown Oslo, on the weekend when the city is set to host its Pride parade.
lead_paragraph: OSLO, Norway — Two people were killed and at least 19 injured early Saturday morning in downtown Oslo when a gunman opened fire outside two nightclubs and a diner, the police and Norway’s state broadcaster said.

headline: Cause of an Uprising?
abstract: Adam Aaronson drops in with a slick Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Adam Aaronson is still in college, and he’s one of a coterie of young constructors who have come on strong in the last few years. This is his seventh Saturday puzzle since his New York Times Crossword debut at the beginning of 2020 — and all have been crowd-pleasers, with fresh and vibrant fill. Today’s grid has nine debuts, all in the Across entries; some are showstoppers, but there are also some great clues for ordinary objects that make this solve a delight.

headline: Occupied Mariupol is suffering deeply, its mayor says.
abstract: Mariupol, a Ukrainian port city that became emblematic of the savagery of Russia’s military campaign, is now suffering deeply under Russian rule, according to the city’s mayor.
lead_paragraph: Mariupol, a Ukrainian port city that became emblematic of the savagery of Russia’s military campaign, is now suffering deeply under Russian rule, according to the city’s mayor.

headline: At Pikes Peak Hill Climb, a Drive to Win and to Put the Race on the Map
abstract: The 12.4-mile sprint up to an altitude exceeding 14,000 feet is renowned internationally but more obscure in the United States, where hill climbs and rally racing are less popular.
lead_paragraph: Across the world, the Pikes Peak International Hill Climb is known as one of the most prestigious car races, a treacherous 12.4-mile sprint up one of the highest summits of the Rockies. But for many people in the United States, and even some in its host city, Colorado Springs, the race is hardly known at all.

headline: Coal Dust and Methane Below, Russian Bombs Above
abstract: The war has added a new threat to the dangerous lives of miners in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: DOBROPILLIA, Ukraine — When Aleksander Maryinych enters a metal cage and descends into darkness with dozens of other miners for his six-hour shifts, the concussive thumps of an artillery war are replaced by the clatter of rail carts and the grind of machinery carving deep into the earth.

headline: The Day the Supreme Court Crashed the Title IX Party
abstract: Celebration of the 50th anniversary of Title IX was dampened as female athletes were saddened — and angered — by the Supreme Court’s reversal of Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Billie Jean King and A’ja Wilson danced together at an awards dinner.

headline: Will the Specter of Monkeypox Affect Pride Weekend in New York?
abstract: Some say they have changed their plans in response to the city’s 39 positive cases, while others plan to carry on as safely as they can.
lead_paragraph: For L.G.B.T.Q. people in New York City, the last Friday in June is usually a joyful day. The streets come alive with the telltale signs of a celebratory weekend: music, dancing, kissing, the occasional trail of glitter confetti.

headline: Corrections: June 25, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 25, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a risk of bias in death examinations misstated the amount of time Jocelyn McLean wrongly spent in jail after the death of her daughter. It was almost a year, not more than a year. The error was repeated in a picture caption.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Nonbinary Air Travelers Continue to Face a Male-or-Female World
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 25, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “It’s always extremely anxious for me as I have to take a false version of myself.”

headline: Special Episode: Roe v. Wade Is Overturned
abstract: In a decision with sweeping implications, the Supreme Court eliminated the constitutional right to abortion. What comes next?
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, a ruling that eliminates women’s constitutional right to abortion after almost 50 years. “Roe was egregiously wrong from the start,” Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. wrote on behalf of the majority, while President Biden has denounced the court’s action as the “realization of extreme ideology.”

headline: Belarus’s Leader, ‘Europe’s Last Dictator,’ Burnishes Links to Russia
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia  met with President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus on Saturday amid questions over how far Minsk will allow itself to be drawn into the war.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks before Russia invaded Ukraine, it held joint military drills with its neighbor and ally Belarus, massing tens of thousands of soldiers along the Ukrainian border even as the two countries’ leaders denied reports that the Kremlin was planning to go to war.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: John Legend and Chrissy Teigen Sell a Pair of Penthouses in NoLIta
abstract: The couple got nearly $16.8 million, making it one of the largest closings in New York City in June. The biggest, a Midtown penthouse, sold for around $56 million.
lead_paragraph: The musician John Legend and his wife, the model Chrissy Teigen, have bid farewell to their Manhattan home, and, it seems, to New York for now.

headline: Norway Mass Shooting Is Being Investigated as Terrorism, Police Say
abstract: The attack, which killed two people and seriously wounded 10 others near a gay club in Oslo, came hours before the city’s Pride parade, which has now been canceled.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — A 10-day Pride festival in Norway was cut short on Saturday after an early-morning shooting left two people dead and at least 10 others seriously wounded outside a popular gay club in downtown Oslo.

headline: How to Survive a Rental Bidding War
abstract: As the rental market convulses with a dearth of listings and intense demand, list prices can be deceptive. Here’s how to handle a bidding war.
lead_paragraph: Q: I recently attended an open house for a rental in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where the broker let applicants know in advance, via email and in person, that he would be accepting best and final offers on rent and commission. This was no luxury apartment; the building wasn’t new, nor did it have any amenities. I offered the listed price: $6,000 a month, with a 15 percent commission. He responded that he had already received offers for $6,800 and that I would have to offer more to be considered. How should renters respond to these tactics?

headline: Jess Walter’s End-of-the-World Fun
abstract: The author’s ninth work of fiction, “The Angel of Rome,” collects stories of lonely characters caught in their own versions of Sisyphean hell.
lead_paragraph: John Cheever, in his essay “Why I Write Short Stories,” said, “I like to think that they are read by men and women in the dentist’s office, waiting to be called to the chair.” Several of the stories in “The Angel of Rome” fit that temporal harmony, that confluence of waiting time and story length, while also offering readers/dental patients the pleasures of intensely affecting fiction.

headline: The Quest to Beat High Gas Prices
abstract: From changing their work hours to driving farther in search of cheaper deals, people have been making crafty calculations to grapple with expensive gasoline.
lead_paragraph: “I SOLD MY GIRLFRIENDS CAR CAUSE GAS PRICES ARE HIGH 😳” reads the caption on the video Justice Alexander posted online this spring. In the clip, Mr. Alexander, a content creator in Los Angeles, sits atop a horse and declares that he will now travel on horseback.

headline: Giuliani’s Loyalty to Trump Was Born in His Darkest Moment
abstract: How America’s mayor got to this low point.
lead_paragraph: Shaye Moss, a Georgia election worker, described on national television on Tuesday the smear campaign that Rudy Giuliani waged against her and her mother. Mr. Giuliani, speaking to Georgia legislators weeks after the 2020 presidential vote, had accused the two women of engaging in “surreptitious, illegal behavior” while working the polls on election night and conjured a racist image of them “passing around USB ports as if they are vials of heroin or cocaine.” The fabricated allegations, based on a cynical misrepresentation of a video, were designed to persuade Georgia officials to overturn the election results in their state, and they triggered an avalanche of harassment and death threats against the women.

headline: The End of Roe Is Just the Beginning
abstract: An improbable anti-abortion triumph yields an uncertain political future.
lead_paragraph: By any reasonable political science theory, any normal supposition about how power works in our republic, this day should not have come.

headline: The Radical Reign of Clarence Thomas
abstract: An out-of-control court sends women back to the Dark Ages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “What is happening here?” a distraught Nancy Pelosi said on Friday.

headline: Elizabeth Warren and Tina Smith: We’ve Seen What Will Happen Next to America’s Women
abstract: Roe is gone, but the fight has just begun.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has spoken: Roe is gone. But the Supreme Court doesn’t get the final say on abortion. The American people will have the last word through their representatives in Congress and the White House.

headline: In Southeast Asia, Luxury Hotel Bargains Aren’t Hard to Find
abstract: The region is emerging from Covid isolation only to find a dearth of the Chinese visitors who once flocked there. Some hotels are responding with deals for travelers from the U.S. and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: When newly married Marissa, 28, and Sean Cavenagh, 31, of Chicago decided to spend their honeymoon in Southeast Asia this summer, they planned to stay in Airbnbs and modest hotels while wending their way through Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam and Indonesia. But when they discovered the astounding bargains to be had at some of the most luxurious properties in these destinations, they radically upgraded.

headline: N.Y. Republican Quandary: How to Veer Right and Still Win in November
abstract: Most of the Republican candidates for governor are embracing conservative stances as the primary nears, but that may turn off moderate voters in November.
lead_paragraph: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. — For most of his early political career, Lee M. Zeldin was a classic Long Island moderate Republican: As an Army officer elected to the State Senate, he worked with Democrats to champion causes like tax cuts, veterans’ benefits and even beer, protecting breweries in his district and elsewhere.

headline: Century-Old State Laws Could Determine Where Abortion Is Legal
abstract: In Wisconsin, Michigan and other states, abortion bans that were long considered dormant could determine if access to the procedure survives the overturning of Roe.
lead_paragraph: Abortion has become or will soon become illegal in more than a dozen states whose legislatures had passed so-called trigger laws, allowing for bans shortly after the Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade on Friday.

headline: Christina Ricci’s Search for Authenticity
abstract: The actress, who grew up in the public eye, finally finds the role she’s been looking for.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Christina Ricci knew there were great roles out there for her. She just had to wait until she was older. Not old — just older. Old enough to no longer be judged for how sexy she was (or wasn’t). Old enough that the men in the room didn’t think about her in that way.

headline: How Elon Musk Helped Lift the Ceiling on C.E.O. Pay
abstract: The gap with workers widened even further as public companies granted top executives rich pay packages partly inspired by Tesla.
lead_paragraph: When Tesla awarded Elon Musk a multibillion-dollar pay package in 2018, the landmark deal helped to vastly increase the potential compensation of the chief executives at many of America’s biggest public companies.

headline: In New York, Anti-Abortion Centers Outnumber Abortion Clinics
abstract: Crisis pregnancy centers, which encourage women to give birth, prepare for a post-Roe world in a state that is considered a bastion of abortion rights.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Clinton was walking up East 149th Street in the South Bronx one afternoon last fall, ruminating over her decision to end an unexpected pregnancy. She was five weeks along, already a single parent to two children, and her finances were unstable. She wasn’t sure if the father of her unborn child would remain in the picture and didn’t think she could handle feeding a third mouth on her own.

headline: The Voices of Men Affected by Abortion
abstract: In light of the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, advocates from all sides of the issue have called for men to be part of the conversation. The Times heard from hundreds who wanted to share their stories.

headline: The Joy in Finding Your Chosen Family
abstract: For L.G.B.T.Q. people, the bonds between friends can be liberating and transformative. Five of these close-knit communities tell their stories.
lead_paragraph: When Lenny Lasater moved to Georgia in her early 20s, it didn’t take long to find her family. She quickly met the Bickersons, a group of queer women scattered across the South who met through mutual friends and banded together. Each Bickerson had given herself a name that started with the letter B — Ms. Lasater eventually became known as “Big Star,” because she was active in the local theater scene and played in a band.

headline: A Detroit Designer Works From Home
abstract: Tracy Reese, whose clients include Michelle Obama, returned to her hometown to reimagine her approach to making clothes, from top to bottom.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion, and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.

headline: Russia hits Ukraine with over 40 missiles, including in areas that were recently spared.
abstract: UZHGOROD, Ukraine — As intense battles raged in eastern Ukraine and Russian forces pressed to cut off the supply lines for thousands of Ukrainian soldiers, Moscow unleashed more than 40 missiles on targets across the country on Saturday morning, including in areas in the north and west that have been largely spared in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: UZHGOROD, Ukraine — As intense battles raged in eastern Ukraine and Russian forces pressed to cut off the supply lines for thousands of Ukrainian soldiers, Moscow unleashed more than 40 missiles on targets across the country on Saturday morning, including in areas in the north and west that have been largely spared in recent weeks.

headline: An N.F.L. Rookie’s Back-up Plan: A Track World Championship
abstract: Devon Allen is one of the best hurdlers in the world. He’ll soon shift his focus to N.F.L. training camp.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Devon Allen ran the third-fastest time in the history of the 110-meter hurdles.

headline: The End of Roe
abstract: The Supreme Court’s abortion ruling will transform American life and politics.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has overturned the constitutional right to an abortion in America.

headline: Businesses Are Bracing for the Political and Social Fight Post-Roe
abstract: Reeling from competing demands from stakeholders — including activists, clients, consumers, shareholders and elected officials — businesses are increasingly caught in the middle of the country’s bruising culture wars.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: For a Kyiv techno collective, ‘now everything is about politics.’
abstract: “This war has destroyed the statement that art could be outside politics,” the group’s booking and communications manager said.
lead_paragraph: Before the Russian invasion and the pandemic, Ukraine had become an increasingly popular destination for club tourists over the past decade. Among the highlights were the biannual Cxema raves — parties in factories, skate parks and even an abandoned Soviet restaurant that united thousands on the dance floor to a soundtrack of experimental electronic music.

headline: How to Discipline a Rogue Supreme Court
abstract: Make use of the constitutional system.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court does not exist above the constitutional system.

headline: Abortion access is shifting rapidly one day after the overturning of Roe.
abstract: The consequences of the Supreme Court’s decision overturning the right to abortion cascaded across the country on Saturday, as millions of Americans began to grapple with one of the swiftest, most expansive transformations to reproductive rights in 50 years.
lead_paragraph: The consequences of the Supreme Court’s decision overturning the right to abortion cascaded across the country on Saturday, as millions of Americans began to grapple with one of the swiftest, most expansive transformations to reproductive rights in 50 years.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of June 20, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: Biden Signs Gun Bill Into Law, Ending Years of Stalemate
abstract: The bill is the most significant gun measure to clear Congress in nearly three decades, though it falls short of more restrictive gun control proposals that Democrats favor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Saturday signed into law a bipartisan gun bill intended to prevent dangerous people from accessing firearms and increase investments in the nation’s mental health system, ending nearly three decades of gridlock in Washington over how to address gun violence in the United States.

headline: The Burger That Instagram Built
abstract: At Monty’s Good Burger, a chain in Los Angeles, there’s no meat but lots of selfies.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Even if you’ve never eaten food from Monty’s Good Burger, there’s a good chance it’s crossed your path on the internet. It could have been the photo of Joaquin Phoenix celebrating his 2020 Oscar win by biting into a Monty’s burger with Rooney Mara, or Travis Barker and Kourtney Kardashian sharing a Monty’s Oat Matcha Latte shake, “Lady and the Tramp” style.

headline: Mayor of Embattled Southern Ukrainian City Urges All Residents to Leave
abstract: The request by the Mykolaiv official was somewhat surprising, given that the city’s combative, never-say-die spirit has become a symbol of Ukrainian resistance.
lead_paragraph: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — The mayor of this embattled southern port city, under attack from Russian forces since the start of the war, has called for “everyone who wants to survive” to leave, because “it’s not clear when all this will be over.”

headline: ‘Wild Swimming’ in Restricted Beijing Offers Refreshing Break From Rules
abstract: China’s congested and highly regulated capital is not known for either its natural refuges or its rule-bending. But swimming in the city’s lakes and waterways is a cherished, if contested, tradition.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Beneath a curving concrete overpass, behind a wall of green fencing, surrounded by the roar of traffic, a swimming hole beckons in the heart of Beijing.

headline: Russia Unleashes a Missile Barrage, While Inching Ahead in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: Some of the missiles were launched from Belarus, whose leader is meeting Saturday with the Russian president.
lead_paragraph: From the skies above Belarus to the north and the waters of the Black Sea to the south, Russian forces unleashed a fusillade of cruise missiles across Ukraine on Saturday, Ukrainian officials said, in one of the most widespread and coordinated aerial assaults in weeks.

headline: The Wait for Little Kid Vaccines Is Over. Parental Exhaustion Isn’t.
abstract: The payoff feels somewhat anticlimactic.
lead_paragraph: Covid vaccines are available for children under 5.

headline: Feminism’s Journey Over the Decades
abstract: Readers react to articles about a feminist backlash and the 50th anniversary of Ms. magazine.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Supreme Court Puts Gun Rights Above the Human Life
abstract: The same week, President Biden signed into law a bipartisan bill on guns.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court this week embraced a vision of the Second Amendment that is profoundly at odds with precedent and the dangers that American communities face today, upending the longstanding practice of letting states decide for themselves how to regulate gun possession in public.

headline: ‘We Have Nothing’: Afghan Quake Survivors Despair Over Recovery
abstract: With the economy in ruins and aid in short supply, survivors of the earthquake in this remote stretch of eastern Afghanistan wonder what their next move could be.
lead_paragraph: GEYAN, Afghanistan — As dawn broke over his village on Friday morning, Abdul Qadir dug through the rubble of his family home desperate to find a small sack of flour buried somewhere beneath the piles of wood and dust.

headline: For Conservative Christians, the End of Roe Was a Spiritual Victory
abstract: Many religious people who are opposed to abortion worked for decades to overturn Roe v. Wade. “It seems like an answer to prayer,” one said after the Supreme Court’s decision.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 50 years, conservative Christians marched, strategized and prayed. And then, on an ordinary Friday morning in June, the day they had dreamed of finally came.

headline: Lightning Shock Avalanche to Keep Dream of 3-Peat Alive
abstract: The Tampa Bay Lightning stymied the Colorado Avalanche in Game 5 of the Stanley Cup Finals to send the series back to Florida.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — After the Tampa Bay Lightning lost a heartbreaker in overtime on Wednesday to fall behind three games to one in the Stanley Cup Finals, the easy money was on the Colorado Avalanche to close out the series at home on Friday.

headline: Commando Network Coordinates Flow of Weapons in Ukraine, Officials Say
abstract: A secretive operation involving U.S. Special Operations forces hints at the scale of the effort to assist Ukraine’s still outgunned military.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Russian troops press ahead with a grinding campaign to seize eastern Ukraine, the nation’s ability to resist the onslaught depends more than ever on help from the United States and its allies — including a stealthy network of commandos and spies rushing to provide weapons, intelligence and training, according to U.S. and European officials.

headline: A New Task for Biden: Readying Allies for a Long Conflict in Ukraine
abstract: In March, talk of victory was in the air. Now, maintaining unity against President Vladimir V. Putin is looking harder, with President Biden heading to Germany and Spain to rally Europe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Biden met his Western allies in Europe three months ago, the world was rallying behind Ukraine, and NATO suddenly had a new sense of purpose — its old purpose, containing Russia. There was talk of “crippling sanctions.” President Vladimir V. Putin was in retreat, and talk of victory was in the air.

headline: The Leader of the QAnon Conspiracy Theory Returns
abstract: Three posts on Friday night signaled the resurfacing of a figure who used a variety of conspiracy theories to marshal support for Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: After more than a year of silence, the mysterious figure behind the QAnon conspiracy theory has reappeared.

headline: How the House Jan. 6 Panel Has Redefined the Congressional Hearing
abstract: No bloviating speeches or partisan rancor. Lots of video and a tight script. The story of Donald J. Trump’s efforts to hold on to power is being unspooled in a way totally new to Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: The typical congressional hearing features a pileup of long-winded statements — what some might consider bloviating. There are harsh partisan exchanges that can obscure the substance at hand. Visual presentations tend to involve an easel. The television audience is largely on C-SPAN.

headline: Americans Face New Abortion Landscape in Wake of Roe Decision
abstract: Around the country, a patchwork of laws was taking hold amid protest and celebration.
lead_paragraph: A new and rapidly shifting reality took hold across America on Saturday as abortion, a basic legal right for nearly a half century, was outlawed in some states, and the initial bursts of elation and shock from the overturning of Roe v. Wade gave way to action.

headline: Commonwealth’s Fissures Exposed at Week of Meetings
abstract: This year’s summit for the group of nations came as they grappled with the place of the monarchy, and as many were forging connections with powers like China and Russia.
lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — As the leaders of the Commonwealth wrapped up a week of closed-door meetings, panel discussions and formal dinners on Saturday in Rwanda, this “family of nations” still stood at a crossroads, with questions remaining about its usefulness and whether it can reinvent itself for the 21st century.

headline: Supreme Court Throws Abortion to an Unlevel State Playing Field
abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade shifted the abortion fight to state legislatures, where gerrymandering has given Republicans an advantage.
lead_paragraph: In his concurring opinion to the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh struck a note of optimism that democracy and the will of the people would prevail, even on the agonizing issue of a woman’s right to end a pregnancy.

headline: More than 20 Migrants Die in Effort to Enter Spanish Enclave in Africa
abstract: The deaths occurred during an attempted mass crossing by 2,000 people over border fences into Melilla. Several human rights groups have called for an investigation.
lead_paragraph: Moroccan officials said on Saturday that at least 23 migrants had died and scores more had been injured after what the authorities described as a stampede during an attempted mass crossing into the Spanish enclave of Melilla, in North Africa. But human rights organizations accused the security forces of using indiscriminate force at the crossing, and have called for an investigation into the deaths.

headline: Court Widens Scope of Deportations
abstract: The Biden administration had instructed ICE agents to focus on immigrants who were considered a threat. But a judge’s order means millions more could now be targeted for deportation.
lead_paragraph: A Biden administration policy that prioritized the arrest of undocumented immigrants who are considered a threat to public safety and national security has been suspended as of Saturday, rendering millions of people vulnerable to deportation.

headline: Gareth Bale Will Join Los Angeles F.C. in Major League Soccer
abstract: Bale, who helped Wales qualify for the World Cup, will prepare for the tournament in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Gareth Bale helped ensure that Wales would play in the World Cup for the first time since 1958, there has been only one question on the minds of his countrymen: For which club would he sign, and play, to prepare for the tournament?

headline: Michel David-Weill, Influential Lazard Banker, Dies at 89
abstract: A member of his firm’s family dynasty, he built Lazard into an elite player on Wall Street while keeping it a smaller operation than most of its competitors.
lead_paragraph: Michel David-Weill, an investment banker and scion of the Lazard banking dynasty who helped shape Lazard into a powerful global banking institution before he was bought out in 2005, died on June 16 at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

headline: A Year Away, a New Coach and the Same Goal: Winning Wimbledon
abstract: Ahead of her 21st Wimbledon appearance, Serena Williams discussed coming back from a tough injury, but steered away from political discussions.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — At first glance, it certainly looked like business as usual at Wimbledon on Saturday.

headline: For Some N.B.A. Draftees, Making It to the Pros Runs in the Family
abstract: Three of the top five picks in this year’s N.B.A. draft have parents who played professionally, including in the W.N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: When the Houston Rockets selected Auburn’s Jabari Smith Jr. with the third pick of the N.B.A. draft on Thursday, it continued a tradition of basketball as a family inheritance.

headline: Shareholder Advisory Firm Backs Spirit-Frontier Merger
abstract: After Frontier raised its offer for Spirit on Friday, the firm ISS reversed its recommendation that shareholders consider a rival bid from JetBlue.
lead_paragraph: The influential shareholder advisory service Institutional Shareholder Services is now advising Spirit Airlines’ investors to vote in favor of a proposed merger with Frontier Airlines over a rival offer from JetBlue Airways, after Frontier increased its offer.

headline: Dead Roaches That Ate Moon Dust Went Up for Auction. Then NASA Objected.
abstract: The sale was halted after the space agency claimed it owned everything associated with a 1969 experiment that explored whether lunar soil was dangerous to terrestrial life.
lead_paragraph: Unanswered questions fill the cosmos: Are there infinite universes? Why does anything exist? How much would one pay for moon dust digested by a cockroach?

headline: Three Astros Pitchers Combine to No-Hit the Yankees
abstract: Cristian Javier dominated for seven innings, and two relievers finished the job, handing the Yankees their seventh no-hit loss in franchise history.
lead_paragraph: It took three pitchers, 150 pitches and 15 strikeouts, but the Houston Astros combined for a no-hitter against the Yankees on Saturday at Yankee Stadium, beating the best team in baseball, 3-0.

headline: How Did Roe Fall? Before a Decisive Ruling, a Powerful Red Wave.
abstract: The downfall of the constitutional right to abortion began 12 years ago, after Republicans swept state house elections and passed hundreds of restrictions.
lead_paragraph: The downfall of the constitutional right to abortion began 12 years ago, after Republicans swept state house elections and passed hundreds of restrictions.

headline: Decades Ago, Alito Laid Out Methodical Strategy to Eventually Overrule Roe
abstract: A slow-burning hostility to constitutional abortion rights runs through the career of the author of the Supreme Court opinion overturning them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the spring of 1985, a 35-year-old lawyer in the Justice Department, Samuel A. Alito Jr., cautioned the Reagan administration against mounting a frontal assault on Roe v. Wade, the landmark ruling that declared a constitutional right to abortion. The Supreme Court was not ready to overturn it, he said, so urging it to do so could backfire.

headline: Jeffrey Escoffier, Health Official and Scholar of Gay Theory, Dies at 79
abstract: He wrote extensively on gay identity and history, but New Yorkers knew a different side of his work: his campaigns on H.I.V. and other health issues.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Escoffier, whose remarkably varied career included helping to shape public health campaigns in New York City and writing extensively on gay identity and how it has been influenced by gay pornography and other factors, died on May 20 in Brooklyn. He was 79.

headline: Bonus Features
abstract: Matthew Stock and Finn Vigeland put on a cinematic spectacle, with a little something extra.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is the first collaboration between two makers of memorable Sunday puzzles, although they’ve been in touch since meeting at a crossword competition in 2018. Finn Vigeland is a transportation planner in Washington, D.C.; Matthew Stock works for a math education nonprofit in East St. Louis, Ill., and is moving to Florida next month to teach eighth-grade math.

headline: Mr. Happy Face, a Chihuahua Mix With a Mohawk, Crowned World’s Ugliest Dog
abstract: He was the winner of a competition that promotes the adoption of dogs, even ones with perpetually protruding tongues and missing fur.
lead_paragraph: Out of a field that included a “hairless mutant” with no teeth and a crooked face, a creature that resembled “a hyena or mandrill baboon,” and a canine with a “gorilla-looking head,” a Chihuahua mix named Mr. Happy Face emerged on Friday as the foulest of them all, winner of the 2022 World’s Ugliest Dog contest.

headline: Planned Parenthood of Utah has sued to block the state’s abortion ban.
abstract: The lawsuit argues that the state’s ban violates several provisions in the State Constitution, including the right to determine family composition and the right to equality between the sexes.
lead_paragraph: Planned Parenthood Association of Utah filed a lawsuit on Saturday seeking to block the state’s ban on abortion, which came into effect after the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

headline: 34 Senate Democrats urge Biden to take action on abortion.
abstract: With little hope of legislative action following the Supreme Court’s ruling, lawmakers urged the president to take “bold action” to defend Americans’ reproductive rights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A group of Senate Democrats sent a letter to President Biden on Saturday urging him to take “bold action” on abortion rights, a day after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, the landmark case that legalized abortion nationwide.

headline: ‘An Invisible Cage’: How China Is Policing the Future
abstract: Vast surveillance data allows the state to target people whose behavior or characteristics are deemed suspicious by an algorithm, even if they’ve done nothing wrong.
lead_paragraph: The more than 1.4 billion people living in China are constantly watched. They are recorded by police cameras that are everywhere, on street corners and subway ceilings, in hotel lobbies and apartment buildings. Their phones are tracked, their purchases are monitored, and their online chats are censored.

headline: The Ultimate Tennis Disrupter Faces the Wimbledon Crucible
abstract: Emma Raducanu came out of nowhere to win the U.S. Open at 18 years old. Things have been a little rocky ever since.
lead_paragraph: The British tennis-sphere gasped earlier this month.

headline: Here is what foreign-policy experts are discussing ahead of the G7 meeting.
abstract: Before Russia invaded Ukraine, this year’s Group of 7 summit was supposed to provide an opportunity to change gears from typical geopolitics and finance, and focus on the future. The top themes were meant to be climate, public health amid the coronavirus pandemic and equity around the globe.
lead_paragraph: Before Russia invaded Ukraine, this year’s Group of 7 summit was supposed to provide an opportunity to change gears from typical geopolitics and finance, and focus on the future. The top themes were meant to be climate, public health amid the coronavirus pandemic and equity around the globe.

headline: Biden’s new task is to ready allies for a long conflict in Ukraine.
abstract: President Biden will be trying to unite his allies on new ways to isolate Moscow.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden met his Western allies in Europe three months ago, the world was rallying behind Ukraine, and NATO suddenly had a new sense of purpose — its old purpose, containing Russia. There was talk of “crippling sanctions.” President Vladimir V. Putin was in retreat, and talk of victory was in the air.

headline: Corrections: June 26, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 26, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 1 about crisis pregnancy centers in New York City includes an outdated reference to Roe v. Wade. After the section went to press, the Supreme Court handed down a decision that overturned Roe.

headline: Rising food and fuel prices loom over the summit.
abstract: Hovering over the Group of 7 meeting and the NATO summit that follows it is a perilous moment for the global economy, probably the most tenuous since the 2008-09 financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Hovering over the Group of 7 meeting and the NATO summit that follows it is a perilous moment for the global economy, probably the most tenuous since the 2008-09 financial crisis.

headline: NASA’s Return to the Moon Starts With Launching a 55-Pound CubeSat
abstract: NASA has grandiose plans for sending astronauts back to the moon. Those start with a microwave-size private spacecraft about to lift off.
lead_paragraph: In the coming years, NASA will be busy at the moon.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘The First Time I Met My Neighbor, He Was Sitting Outside With a Friend’
abstract: Learning little things about someone, a tourist’s sleepy retreat and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A One-Woman Town, Documented for Over 17 Years
abstract: In 2005, the journalist Alyssa Schukar began photographing the life of Elsie Eiler, the sole resident of Monowi, Neb.
lead_paragraph: The party had already started by the time I arrived in Monowi, Nebraska’s one-woman town, last summer.

headline: Abortion Pills Take the Spotlight as States Impose Abortion Bans
abstract: Demand for medication abortion is surging, setting the stage for new legal battles.
lead_paragraph: In the hours after the Supreme Court released its decision overturning the legal right to abortion in the United States, nearly 100 requests for appointments flowed into Just the Pill, a nonprofit organization that arranges for patients to obtain abortion pills in several states.

headline: MAGA Voters Send a $50 Million G.O.P. Plan Off the Rails in Illinois
abstract: Republican leaders think a moderate nominee for governor could beat Gov. J.B. Pritzker. But the party’s base seems to prefer a far-right state senator — and he is getting help from Mr. Pritzker.
lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Ill. — Darren Bailey, the front-runner in the Republican primary for governor of Illinois, was finishing his stump speech last week at a senior center in this Central Illinois town when a voice called out: “Can we pray for you?”

headline: The U.S. and Britain will ban imports of gold from Russia.
abstract: President Biden announced the decision before the start of a G7 summit meeting in Germany.
lead_paragraph: The United States and other Group of 7 countries will ban imports of gold from Russia, seeking to undercut a key source of revenue for Moscow as it wages war in Ukraine, President Biden said on Sunday as G7 leaders gathered in the Bavarian Alps.

headline: The Dobbs Decision Isn’t Just About Abortion. It’s About Power.
abstract: The legal journalist Dahlia Lithwick breaks down the Dobbs decision and considers the “raw power” of the Supreme Court’s conservative supermajority.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, a Supreme Court majority voted to overturn Roe v. Wade. Nearly all abortions are already banned in at least nine states, home to 7.2 million women of reproductive age. And it is likely that other bans and restrictions will follow. As the court’s three liberal justices put it in their dissenting opinion, “One result of today’s decision is certain: the curtailment of women’s rights, and of their status as free and equal citizens.”

headline: In This Novel of Female Friendship, Birds of a Feather Drift Apart
abstract: The stylish, reckless heroines of Carlene Bauer’s “Girls They Write Songs About” bond over their similarities, until one decides to settle down.
lead_paragraph: The evolutionary psychologist and anthropologist Robin Dunbar is fond of the term homophily — “love of the same” — to describe why certain people strike up friendships. We’re all aware of the phenomenon in which longtime pals grow alike, but homophily suggests that a fair number of them are actually alike from the start. The relevant proverb: “Birds of a feather flock together.”

headline: Necromancers, Killers and Presidents, Summoned From the Pages of History
abstract: Did Abraham Lincoln, like John Wilkes Booth, ever find solace in spiritualism?
lead_paragraph: Is there anything more unknowable than a politician’s soul? Even a figure as exhaustively documented as Abraham Lincoln — whole tomes have been devoted to his marriage, his melancholy, his hats — remains in some essential way a mystery, the private man subsumed by two-plus centuries of folklore and iconography. But he was of course a person who lived and loved and grieved like any other — and like his assassin, John Wilkes Booth, found perhaps some solace in the prospect of an afterworld still reachable from this one.

headline: Happy Marriages, Petty Temptations and Angel Sex
abstract: Our romance novel columnist, Olivia Waite, has some summer reading recommendations.
lead_paragraph: Romance has been understandably reluctant to put the pandemic on the page. A handful of authors have tried, but audience reaction has been decidedly negative. It seems that acknowledging Covid torpedoes the sense of escapism people are hungry for.

headline: Blitz Bazawule Is Building Bridges Between Worlds
abstract: The artist and filmmaker, who is directing a new version of “The Color Purple,” publishes his first novel, “The Scent of Burnt Flowers.”
lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ga. — Blitz Bazawule did not look like someone with the weight of a multimillion-dollar movie on his shoulders.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: France’s Far Right Surges Into Parliament, and Further Into the Mainstream
abstract: Marine Le Pen’s National Rally now has a place of power in the political establishment and a chance to prove itself in the eyes of voters.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In 2017, after the far-right leader Marine Le Pen and her allies won only a handful of seats in parliamentary elections, she blamed France’s two-round voting system for shutting her party out of Parliament despite getting over one million ballots cast in its favor.

headline: Schools Are Spending Billions on High-Tech Defense for Mass Shootings
abstract: The market for weapon detectors and crisis alert badges in schools is booming. But there are questions about whether the new technology is effective.
lead_paragraph: Reid Bauer was finishing lunch period last year at his middle school in the Atlanta area when an alarm began blaring through the halls, warning of an emergency. Reid, then in sixth grade, had never heard the school’s “code red” alert before.

headline: Tick Hunting: The Prey Are Tiny, and the Bait Is Human
abstract: Climate change and other factors have brought several new species of ticks, and frightening new diseases, to New York in recent years.
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, N.Y. — Before he goes out to hunt, Brian Leydet pulls on his hiking boots and his all-white jumpsuit, fetches a homemade flannel flag out of his car and then, most importantly, duct-tapes his socks to his pant legs.

headline: Strutting Their Looks
abstract: The best outfits from LadyLand, the Ailey Spirit Gala and the Songwriters Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: LadyLand, the queer music festival started by the nightlife impresario Ladyfag, took place on June 17 at the Brooklyn Mirage. The massive space throbbed with health goths sporting torn mesh, Day-Glo ravers clacking plastic beaded jewelry, shirtless circuit boys clenching their square jaws and the occasional fetishists shaking their exposed buttocks.

headline: 21 Teenagers Found Dead in South African Tavern, Officials Say
abstract: Initial reports suggested that there had been a stampede inside the club, in the coastal city of East London.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Twenty-one teenagers were found dead early Sunday morning in a tavern in the coastal city of East London, South Africa, the police said, in a tragedy that remains something of a mystery and that has left much of the country, including top officials, reeling emotionally.

headline: Vacationing 101 for Those Who Have Forgotten How
abstract: Have you forgotten how to take time off? You’re not alone.
lead_paragraph: I used to fancy myself a pretty good vacationer. I’m a lifestyle reporter; excelling at leisure was sort of my thing. But on my family’s recent weeklong trip to Mexico — our first real getaway since the pandemic began and our first family vacation since our baby was born — I floundered.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘How Houston Moved 25,000 People From the Streets Into Homes of Their Own’
abstract: The nation’s fourth-largest city hasn’t solved homelessness, but its remarkable progress can suggest a way forward.
lead_paragraph: Michael Kimmelman, the architecture critic of The New York Times, traveled to Houston to observe an approach to chronic homelessness that has won widespread praise.

headline: America the Merciless
abstract: I can’t help but see our nation’s particular bent toward cruelty.
lead_paragraph: As the Fourth of July looms with its flags and its barbecues and its full-throated patriotism, I find myself mulling over the idea of American exceptionalism. What, if anything, makes this country different from other countries, or from the rest of the developed world, in terms of morals or ideals? In what ways do our distinct values inform how America treats its own citizens?

headline: Growing Up in the Shadow of DACA
abstract: A generation of young people, still without a pathway to citizenship, tentatively plans for a future that remains uncertain.
lead_paragraph: Think back on the big triumphs of being a teenager: the possibilities presented by a first paycheck; the blend of fear and freedom the first time you drove alone after getting your driver’s license. Upon graduating from high school, scholarship or financial aid made the dream of education possible, opening the door to a far more expansive world along the way.

headline: An Innovator Sold Jordan’s National Dish in a To-Go Cup. Controversy Ensued.
abstract: Is “mansaf in a cup” a novel way to enjoy the country’s most treasured delicacy, or an affront to its most hallowed traditions?
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — The idea struck the restaurateur like a bolt of lightning after he spilled food on his suit while eating in his car.

headline: As G7 leaders meet, Russia sends a message with missile attacks.
abstract: Russia unleashed a new round of missiles at Kyiv on Sunday, the first attack on the Ukrainian capital in weeks, an apparent show of defiance as a summit of the world’s biggest democracies opened on Sunday with new steps to isolate Moscow.
lead_paragraph: Russia unleashed a new round of missiles at Kyiv on Sunday, the first attack on the Ukrainian capital in weeks, an apparent show of defiance as a summit of the world’s biggest democracies opened on Sunday with new steps to isolate Moscow.

headline: No, Justice Alito, Reproductive Justice Is in the Constitution
abstract: The repeal of Roe v. Wade brings a return of sexual servitude for women.
lead_paragraph: Black women’s sexual subordination and forced pregnancies were foundational to slavery. If cotton was euphemistically king, Black women’s wealth-maximizing forced reproduction was queen.

headline: Will LIV Golf Diminish PGA Tour Events Like the Travelers Championship?
abstract: A prized mainstay of Connecticut’s sporting calendar for 70 years, the Travelers has become more than just a golf tournament.
lead_paragraph: CROMWELL, Conn. — The Travelers Championship in central Connecticut, contested on a golf course beside cornfields, is celebrating its 70th anniversary this week, which makes it one of the oldest continuously operated PGA Tour events. Through the decades, the tournament has changed names and venues, but in a small state lacking a professional franchise in one of the four leading North American sports (the N.H.L.’s Hartford Whalers left 25 years ago), the Travelers has been a prized mainstay of Connecticut’s sporting calendar.

headline: When Nature Calls, Phillies Relievers Have a Place to Go
abstract: With the Relief Room, a Phillies fan has created an over-the-top shrine to baseball’s most unsung players. It is in his downstairs bathroom.
lead_paragraph: HATBORO, Pa. — It’s the top of the ninth inning at Citizens Bank Park, and the Philadelphia Phillies’ relievers are at it again. They have already blown one lead, with Jeurys Familia and Seranthony Domínguez giving up homers in the seventh. Now after a comeback, the game has unraveled with closer Corey Knebel on the mound.

headline: Reliving Painful History
abstract: For many people on Capitol Hill, the Jan. 6 hearings are personal.
lead_paragraph: The House Jan. 6 committee’s hearings have revealed unseen footage, unheard testimony and new details about Donald Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election. They’ve also stirred painful memories for those who experienced the attack firsthand. I asked my colleague Emily Cochrane, who’s covered Congress since 2018 and was inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, about how the hearings have landed.

headline: Woman Is Charged in Death of Newborn Abandoned in 1985
abstract: The cold case, from Maine, was among the latest to be closed using genetic genealogy. As a tool for identifying the remains of infants, and determining who their mothers are, the method is not without controversy.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, she looked like a rag doll.

headline: Ukraine War’s Latest Victim? The Fight Against Climate Change.
abstract: As leaders of the Group of 7 gather in Germany, the scramble to replace Russian fossil fuels is raising concerns that hard-won climate targets will be missed.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Russia’s invasion of Ukraine seemed like an unexpected opportunity for environmentalists, who had struggled to focus the world’s attention on the kind of energy independence that renewable resources can offer. With the West trying to wean itself from Russian oil and gas, the argument for solar and wind power seemed stronger than ever.

headline: As states ban abortion, demand for birth control and abortion pills is rising.
abstract: Some women are stockpiling birth control, emergency contraception and abortion pills in case legislation prevents them from accessing it in their home state.
lead_paragraph: Less than 48 hours after the Supreme Court said states could ban abortion, health care providers have noticed an increase in interest in birth control, emergency contraception and abortion pills.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Patients and StatesTurn Focus to Pills
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 26, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “When people say we’re going back to the days before Roe, there’s no such thing as a time machine — we have a very different pharmaceutical landscape.”

headline: For Gun Violence Researchers, Bipartisan Bill Is a ‘Glass Half Full’
abstract: About two dozen American researchers focus exclusively on how to prevent gun violence. They have waged an often-frustrating battle to translate their findings into public policy.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — Jeffrey W. Swanson, a sociologist at Duke University, is no stranger to Washington’s gun laws debate. He has been studying violence and mental illness for more than 30 years, building a scientific case for policies that might reduce gun deaths.

headline: Past G7 summits have produced some memorable photos.
abstract: International summits are usually highly scripted, and not meant to produce candid moments. But Group of 7 conferences have occasionally offered telling snapshots of the relationships among global leaders.
lead_paragraph: International summits are usually highly scripted, and not meant to produce candid moments. But Group of 7 conferences have occasionally offered telling snapshots of the relationships among global leaders.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Make Eric Kim’s new recipe for a crispy wonton salad, then plan for the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Genevieve Ko here filling in for Sam and channeling his energy: Today’s a good day to think about the food for parties you’re throwing next weekend.

headline: Mass Shootings: Where the True Evil Lies
abstract: Readers discuss the notion of evil in the context of mass killings in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Dobbs, Roe and the Myth of ‘Bodily Autonomy’
abstract: The end of Roe v. Wade is a reminder that we have human rights and human obligations.
lead_paragraph: “We hold that Roe and Casey must be overruled,” the Supreme Court declared on Friday in its majority opinion in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization. It boggles the mind, really. The fight over abortion that has raged as long as I can remember has taken a decisive turn. The broad spectrum of emotions in reaction to this decision — from outrage to jubilation and everything in between — will be on full display for weeks and months to come. Our feelings about this decision matter. But it is also critical that we continue to examine and clarify the merits of the arguments about abortion.

headline: Patrick Adams, Master of New York’s Underground Disco Scene, Dies at 72
abstract: He produced, arranged or engineered many of the era’s biggest nightclub hits, even if his records rarely got much play on the radio.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Adams, a producer, arranger and engineer who brought experimentation, sophistication and infectious grooves to countless soul and disco singles — his fellow producer Nile Rodgers called him “a master at keeping butts on the dance floor” — died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Dahlia Lithwick
abstract: A conversation with legal journalist Dahlia Lithwick.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Dahlia Lithwick. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: California looks to enshrine abortion rights in state constitution.
abstract: The state constitutional amendment is the latest in a wave of abortion rights legislation that has swept states led by Democrats.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — California state lawmakers are expected as soon as Monday to put a state constitutional amendment on the ballot that would explicitly protect reproductive rights.

headline: Proud Boys Ignored Orders Given at Pre-Jan. 6 Meeting
abstract: The directives, given during a video conference, included obeying police lines and keeping away from ordinary protesters. But members of the far-right group played aggressive roles in several breaches at the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: One week before scores of Proud Boys helped lead a pro-Trump mob in a violent assault on the Capitol last year, Enrique Tarrio, the chairman of the group, and some of his top lieutenants held a foul-mouthed video conference with a handpicked crew of members.

headline: Wagner’s Early Operas Shouldn’t Be Mere Curiosities
abstract: A survey at Oper Leipzig provides an opportunity to reassess the youthful efforts that have been excluded from the composer’s canon.
lead_paragraph: LEIPZIG, Germany — How quickly Richard Wagner changed his mind about “Rienzi,” his first successful opera.

headline: Prominent Activist in India Arrested Over Crusade Against Modi in Deadly Riots
abstract: Teesta Setalvad was detained by an antiterrorism squad to face charges of fabricating evidence against Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
lead_paragraph: A prominent Indian human rights activist who spearheaded a campaign to hold officials responsible for deadly 2002 riots in the western state of Gujarat has been arrested and faces charges of fabricating evidence against the prime minister, Narendra Modi.

headline: ‘Bodies They Ritual’ Review: Plush Robes and Cults
abstract: Angela Hanks’s new comedy is set in Santa Fe, N.M., where five women of color have traveled for some fancy R&R laced with New Age spirituality.
lead_paragraph: The tapas party had not gone over well: “The food was so tiny,” the guest of honor, Faye, recalled. “And I was so hungry.”

headline: More Than 400,000 Solar-Powered Umbrellas Recalled Over Fire Risk
abstract: The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission recalled the umbrellas, which were sold at Costco, because of the risk of lithium-ion batteries overheating.
lead_paragraph: The authorities have recalled more than 400,000 solar-powered umbrellas sold at Costco because of overheating and fire risks.

headline: The Ruling Was Just the Beginning: Both Sides Mobilize Over Abortion
abstract: Lawyers, politicians and advocacy groups responded to Friday’s Supreme Court ruling with fresh plans for the fight over abortion rights.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage on abortion news and the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

headline: Pride March in New York Infused With New Sense of Urgency
abstract: The annual parade included joyous celebration, but the Supreme Court’s abortion ruling and the threat to gay rights cast an undeniable shadow.
lead_paragraph: The festivities began on Sunday with a familiar feel: Revelers adorned in a palette of bright colors, waving rainbow flags and handmade signs, tossed confetti into the air as the roar of screams and bikers revving their motorcycle engines signaled the start of the annual New York City Pride March in Manhattan.

headline: Missile Strike in Kyiv Rattles Residents After Weeks of Quiet
abstract: The strike on Sunday morning shook many out of the relative sense of security that has prevailed in Ukraine’s capital since the Russians were pushed out of its periphery in early April.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Olha and her husband, Roman, stood on a concrete platform, carefully avoiding debris and shards of glass, staring at the smoldering building that contained the apartment they moved into one year ago.

headline: How Democrats and Republicans explained the Roe fallout on Sunday talk shows.
abstract: Democrats used the ruling to criticize Republicans as threats to women and their health care providers, while G.O.P. leaders stressed that states will continue to determine policy on the issue.
lead_paragraph: On the first weekend after the Supreme Court overturned nearly five decades of constitutional abortion rights, Democrats seized on the ruling to portray their Republican opponents as threats to women and their health care providers, while two sitting G.O.P. governors welcomed the decision, as they tried to emphasize that the matter is a local issue with more “debate” to be had.

headline: Russian Strike on Kyiv Looms Over G7 Summit
abstract: On the first day of their gathering, Group of 7 leaders moved to increase the economic pressure on Russia, but a missile attack on the Ukrainian capital made clear that Moscow is not backing down.
lead_paragraph: TELFS, Austria — Leaders of the Group of 7 nations said Sunday they would stop buying gold from Moscow and discussed a new American proposal to undercut its oil revenues, even as Russian forces rained missiles on Kyiv for the first time in weeks. The dueling escalation underscored how the war in Ukraine has consumed global politics and the world economy.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: The End of Roe
abstract: Plus Russia strikes Kyiv as G7 leaders meet and a Times investigation into China’s surveillance state.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade on Friday, ending the constitutional right to an abortion after almost 50 years. The decision, expected after a draft opinion leaked in May, sent a seismic social and political shock through American life.

headline: Novak Djokovic Has Prepared His Way. So Has Rafael Nadal.
abstract: By design, Djokovic usually does not play grass-court events before Wimbledon, and he has won five times with that tactic. Nadal, necessitated by injury, is on the same track this year.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — While the French Open has long been Rafael Nadal time, Wimbledon has become Novak Djokovic time.

headline: Scrumptious Bits
abstract: Drew Schmenner returns with a crossword that may intrigue newer solvers.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Some newer solvers, I’ve been told, feel a bit apprehensive when they face a blank grid. They fear that the puzzle will somehow best them and make them feel “stupid.”

headline: Rudy Giuliani Smacked on Back While Campaigning on Staten Island
abstract: Mr. Giuliani, who was campaigning for his son, Andrew, a Republican candidate for governor, said a man who hit him in the back said, “You’re going to kill women.”
lead_paragraph: A grocery store worker on Staten Island was arrested on Sunday after smacking Rudolph W. Giuliani on the back while the former mayor campaigned on behalf of his son, a Republican candidate for governor, according to the police and Mr. Giuliani.

headline: The Final Days of Mississippi’s Last Abortion Clinic
abstract: The Jackson Women’s Health Organization was at the center of the case that overturned Roe v. Wade. Already, supporters are planning new ways to help women in one of the poorest spots in the nation get access to abortions.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on abortion news and the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

headline: N.Y.C. Pride Marchers ‘Nervous’ After Court’s Abortion Ruling
abstract: Revelers at the annual New York City Pride March expressed concern about the future of gay rights after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Revelers at the annual New York City Pride March expressed concern about the future of gay rights after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.

headline: In Gee Chun Wins Women’s P.G.A. Championship
abstract: Despite shooting three over par in the third and fourth rounds, Chun handled a charge from Lexi Thompson to win her third career major tournament.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — In Gee Chun of South Korea rallied after losing the rest of her once-sizeable lead, overcoming a bogey-filled front nine to win the Women’s P.G.A. Championship on Sunday when Lexi Thompson faltered with her putter.

headline: The Strange Tale of Tina Peters
abstract: The county clerk has been consumed by election conspiracy theories, lionized by a movement and indicted in a bizarre scheme. Will Republicans nominate her to run elections in Colorado?
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on primary elections and results in Colorado.

headline: Under Court’s Shadow, N.Y. Governor Candidates Lob Final Pitches
abstract: Rulings on abortion and guns shape the final weekend of campaigning before Tuesday’s primary.
lead_paragraph: A pair of seismic rulings by the Supreme Court jolted the race for governor of New York on Sunday, as Democrats and Republicans made final pitches to an electorate that found itself at the center of renewed national debates over guns and abortion rights.

headline: Schauffele Holds Off Theegala to Win Travelers Championship
abstract: Xander Schauffele nearly let a three-shot lead slip away, but a birdie on No. 18 gave him a two-stroke victory over Sahith Theegala and J.T. Poston.
lead_paragraph: CROMWELL, Conn. — Before the first round of the Travelers Championship on Thursday, Sahith Theegala, a PGA Tour rookie, was asked if young players in the field were worried about the cluster of veterans spurning the tour to join the rival, Saudi-backed LIV Golf circuit.

headline: Astros Give Yankees a Tough Series, and a Measuring Stick
abstract: Aaron Judge carried his team to victory on Sunday, but in a four-game draw, Houston proved the Yankees can’t just coast to the pennant.
lead_paragraph: The best two teams in the American League played a ballgame in the sunshine, bookended by home runs. Jose Altuve drove the first pitch over the left-field wall, and Aaron Judge did the same to the last pitch. More than 44,000 fans packed into Yankee Stadium for the fourth day in a row. Some even stayed for a postgame promotion, playing catch on their field of dreams.

headline: Colombian Bullfight Stand Collapse Kills at Least 6
abstract: One child was reported dead when a spectator section collapsed at a bullfighting festival, and more than a hundred were reported injured.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — At least six people were killed and more than a hundred injured Sunday when wooden spectator stands at a bullfighting festival collapsed, sending people running for safety.

headline: Alligator Fatally Attacks Man at the Edge of a South Carolina Pond
abstract: Such attacks are rare in the United States, typically occurring about once a year, but the latest one on Friday was the second in less than a month.
lead_paragraph: A man was killed on Friday after being dragged into a retention pond by an alligator near Myrtle Beach, S.C., the first such deadly attack in the state since 2020, the authorities said.

headline: Colorado Avalanche Unseat Tampa Bay to Win the Stanley Cup
